﻿title: the iliad

﻿title: the iliad

author: homer

author: homer

translator: samuel butler

book i.

book i.
argument.
[40]

the quarrel between agamemnon and achilles—achilles withdraws

the contention of achilles and agamemnon.

from the war, and sends his mother thetis to ask jove to help the

in the war of troy, the greeks having sacked some of the neighbouring
towns, and taken from thence two beautiful captives, chryseïs and
briseïs, allotted the first to agamemnon, and the last to achilles.
chryses, the father of chryseïs, and priest of apollo, comes to the
grecian camp to ransom her; with which the action of the poem opens, in
the tenth year of the siege.
the priest being refused, and insolently
dismissed by agamemnon, entreats for vengeance from his god; who
inflicts a pestilence on the greeks.
achilles calls a council, and
encourages chalcas to declare the cause of it; who attributes it to the
refusal of chryseïs.
the king, being obliged to send back his captive,
enters into a furious contest with achilles, which nestor pacifies;
however, as he had the absolute command of the army, he seizes on
briseïs in revenge.
achilles in discontent withdraws himself and his
forces from the rest of the greeks; and complaining to thetis, she
supplicates jupiter to render them sensible of the wrong done to her
son, by giving victory to the trojans.
jupiter, granting her suit,
incenses juno: between whom the debate runs high, till they are
reconciled by the address of vulcan.
the time of two-and-twenty days is taken up in this book: nine
during the plague, one in the council and quarrel of the princes,
and twelve for jupiter’s stay with the æthiopians, at whose return
thetis prefers her petition.

trojans—scene between jove and juno on olympus.

the scene lies in the grecian camp,
then changes to chrysa, and lastly to olympus.

sing, o goddess, the anger of achilles son of peleus, that

achilles’ wrath, to greece the direful spring
of woes unnumber’d, heavenly goddess, sing!

brought countless ills upon the achaeans.

that wrath which hurl’d to pluto’s gloomy reign

many a brave soul did

the souls of mighty chiefs untimely slain;

it send hurrying down to hades, and many a hero did it yield a

whose limbs unburied on the naked shore,

prey to dogs and vultures, for so were the counsels of jove

devouring dogs and hungry vultures tore.

fulfilled from the day on which the son of atreus, king of men,

[41]

and great achilles, first fell out with one another.

since great achilles and atrides strove,

and which of the gods was it that set them on to quarrel?

such was the sovereign doom, and such the will of jove!

it was

[42]
declare, o muse!

the son of jove and leto; for he was angry with the king and sent

in what ill-fated hour[43]

a pestilence upon the host to plague the people, because the son

sprung the fierce strife, from what offended power
latona’s son a dire contagion spread,[44]
and heap’d the camp with mountains of the dead;

of atreus had dishonoured chryses his priest.

the king of men his reverent priest defied,[45]
and for the king’s offence the people died.

now chryses had

for chryses sought with costly gifts to gain

come to the ships of the achaeans to free his daughter, and had

his captive daughter from the victor’s chain.
suppliant the venerable father stands;

brought with him a great ransom: moreover he bore in his hand the

apollo’s awful ensigns grace his hands:

sceptre of apollo wreathed with a suppliant’s wreath, and he

by these he begs; and lowly bending down,
extends the sceptre and the laurel crown.

besought the achaeans, but most of all the two sons of atreus,

he sued to all, but chief implored for grace
the brother-kings, of atreus’ royal race[46]

who were their chiefs.

“ye kings and warriors!

“sons of atreus,” he cried, “and all other achaeans, may the gods

may your vows be crown’d,

who dwell in olympus grant you to sack the city of priam, and to

and troy’s proud walls lie level with the ground.
may jove restore you when your toils are o’er

reach your homes in safety; but free my daughter, and accept a

safe to the pleasures of your native shore.
but, oh!
relieve a wretched parent’s pain,
and give chryseïs to these arms again;
if mercy fail, yet let my presents move,

ransom for her, in reverence to apollo, son of jove.

and dread avenging phœbus, son of jove.

”

”

on this the rest of the achaeans with one voice were for

the greeks in shouts their joint assent declare,

respecting the priest and taking the ransom that he offered; but

the priest to reverence, and release the fair.

not so agamemnon, who spoke fiercely to him and sent him roughly

not so atrides; he, with kingly pride,

away.

repulsed the sacred sire, and thus replied:

“old man,” said he, “let me not find you tarrying about our

“hence on thy life, and fly these hostile plains,

ships, nor yet coming hereafter.

nor ask, presumptuous, what the king detains:

your sceptre of the god and your

hence, with thy laurel crown, and golden rod,

wreath shall profit you nothing.

nor trust too far those ensigns of thy god.

i will not free her.

mine is thy daughter, priest, and shall remain;

she shall

and prayers, and tears, and bribes, shall plead in vain;

grow old in my house at argos far from her own home, busying

till time shall rifle every youthful grace,
and age dismiss her from my cold embrace,
in daily labours of the loom employ’d,

herself with her loom and visiting my couch; so go, and do not

or doom’d to deck the bed she once enjoy’d.
hence then; to argos shall the maid retire,

provoke me or it shall be the worse for you.

far from her native soil and weeping sire.

”

”
[illustration: ] homer invoking the muse

the old man feared him and obeyed.

the trembling priest along the shore return’d,
and in the anguish of a father mourn’d.

not a word he spoke, but went

disconsolate, not daring to complain,
silent he wander’d by the sounding main;

by the shore of the sounding sea and prayed apart to king apollo

till, safe at distance, to his god he prays,

whom lovely leto had borne.

the god who darts around the world his rays.

“hear me,” he cried, “o god of the

“o smintheus!

silver bow, that protectest chryse and holy cilla and rulest

sprung from fair latona’s line,[47]

tenedos with thy might, hear me oh thou of sminthe.

thou guardian power of cilla the divine,[48]
thou source of light!

if i have

whom tenedos adores,

ever decked your temple with garlands, or burned your thigh-bones

and whose bright presence gilds thy chrysa’s shores.
if e’er with wreaths i hung thy sacred fane,[49]
or fed the flames with fat of oxen slain;

in fat of bulls or goats, grant my prayer, and let your arrows

god of the silver bow!
thy shafts employ,

avenge these my tears upon the danaans.

avenge thy servant, and the greeks destroy.

”

”

thus did he pray, and apollo heard his prayer.

thus chryses pray’d:—the favouring power attends,

he came down
furious from the summits of olympus, with his bow and his quiver

and from olympus’ lofty tops descends.

upon his shoulder, and the arrows rattled on his back with the

bent was his bow, the grecian hearts to wound;[50]

rage that trembled within him.

fierce as he moved, his silver shafts resound.

he sat himself down away from the

breathing revenge, a sudden night he spread,

ships with a face as dark as night, and his silver bow rang death

and gloomy darkness roll’d about his head.
the fleet in view, he twang’d his deadly bow,

as he shot his arrow in the midst of them.

and hissing fly the feather’d fates below.

first he smote their

on mules and dogs the infection first began;[51]

mules and their hounds, but presently he aimed his shafts at the

and last, the vengeful arrows fix’d in man.

people themselves, and all day long the pyres of the dead were

for nine long nights, through all the dusky air,

burning.

the pyres, thick-flaming, shot a dismal glare.

for nine whole days he shot his arrows among the people, but upon
the tenth day achilles called them in assembly—moved thereto by

but ere the tenth revolving day was run,

juno, who saw the achaeans in their death-throes and had

inspired by juno, thetis’ godlike son

compassion upon them.

convened to council all the grecian train;
for much the goddess mourn’d her heroes slain.
[52]

then, when they were got together, he rose

the assembly seated, rising o’er the rest,

and spoke among them.

achilles thus the king of men address’d:

“son of atreus,” said he, “i deem that we should now turn roving

“why leave we not the fatal trojan shore,

home if we would escape destruction, for we are being cut down by

and measure back the seas we cross’d before?
the plague destroying whom the sword would spare,

war and pestilence at once.

’tis time to save the few remains of war.

let us ask some priest or prophet, or
some reader of dreams (for dreams, too, are of jove) who can tell

but let some prophet, or some sacred sage,

us why phoebus apollo is so angry, and say whether it is for some

explore the cause of great apollo’s rage;

vow that we have broken, or hecatomb that we have not offered,
and whether he will accept the savour of lambs and goats without

or learn the wasteful vengeance to remove

blemish, so as to take away the plague from us.

by mystic dreams, for dreams descend from jove.

”

[53]

with these words he sat down, and calchas son of thestor, wisest

if broken vows this heavy curse have laid,
let altars smoke, and hecatombs be paid.
so heaven, atoned, shall dying greece restore,

of augurs, who knew things past present and to come, rose to

and phœbus dart his burning shafts no more.

speak.

”

he it was who had guided the achaeans with their fleet to

he said, and sat: when chalcas thus replied;

ilius, through the prophesyings with which phoebus apollo had

chalcas the wise, the grecian priest and guide,
that sacred seer, whose comprehensive view,

inspired him.

the past, the present, and the future knew:

with all sincerity and goodwill he addressed them

uprising slow, the venerable sage

thus:—

thus spoke the prudence and the fears of age:

“achilles, loved of heaven, you bid me tell you about the anger

“beloved of jove, achilles!
would’st thou know
why angry phœbus bends his fatal bow?

of king apollo, i will therefore do so; but consider first and

first give thy faith, and plight a prince’s word

swear that you will stand by me heartily in word and deed, for i

of sure protection, by thy power and sword:

know that i shall offend one who rules the argives with might, to

for i must speak what wisdom would conceal,

whom all the achaeans are in subjection.

and truths, invidious to the great, reveal,

a plain man cannot stand

bold is the task, when subjects, grown too wise,

against the anger of a king, who if he swallow his displeasure

instruct a monarch where his error lies;

now, will yet nurse revenge till he has wreaked it.
consider,

for though we deem the short-lived fury past,

therefore, whether or no you will protect me.

’tis sure the mighty will revenge at last.

”

”

and achilles answered, “fear not, but speak as it is borne in

to whom pelides:—“from thy inmost soul
speak what thou know’st, and speak without control.

upon you from heaven, for by apollo, calchas, to whom you pray,

e’en by that god i swear who rules the day,
to whom thy hands the vows of greece convey.
and whose bless’d oracles thy lips declare;
long as achilles breathes this vital air,

and whose oracles you reveal to us, not a danaan at our ships

no daring greek, of all the numerous band,

shall lay his hand upon you, while i yet live to look upon the

against his priest shall lift an impious hand;

face of the earth—no, not though you name agamemnon himself, who

not e’en the chief by whom our hosts are led,

is by far the foremost of the achaeans.

the king of kings, shall touch that sacred head.

”

”

thereon the seer spoke boldly.
“the god,” he said, “is angry

encouraged thus, the blameless man replies:

neither about vow nor hecatomb, but for his priest’s sake, whom

“nor vows unpaid, nor slighted sacrifice,
but he, our chief, provoked the raging pest,

agamemnon has dishonoured, in that he would not free his daughter

apollo’s vengeance for his injured priest.

nor take a ransom for her; therefore has he sent these evils upon

nor will the god’s awaken’d fury cease,

us, and will yet send others.

but plagues shall spread, and funeral fires increase,

he will not deliver the danaans

till the great king, without a ransom paid,

from this pestilence till agamemnon has restored the girl without
fee or ransom to her father, and has sent a holy hecatomb to

to her own chrysa send the black-eyed maid.

chryse.

[54]

thus we may perhaps appease him.

perhaps, with added sacrifice and prayer,
the priest may pardon, and the god may spare.

”

”

with these words he sat down, and agamemnon rose in anger.

the prophet spoke: when with a gloomy frown

his

the monarch started from his shining throne;

heart was black with rage, and his eyes flashed fire as he

black choler fill’d his breast that boil’d with ire,
and from his eye-balls flash’d the living fire:

scowled on calchas and said, “seer of evil, you never yet

“augur accursed!

prophesied smooth things concerning me, but have ever loved to

denouncing mischief still,

foretell that which was evil.

prophet of plagues, for ever boding ill!

you have brought me neither comfort

still must that tongue some wounding message bring,

nor performance; and now you come seeing among danaans, and

and still thy priestly pride provoke thy king?

saying that apollo has plagued us because i would not take a

for this are phœbus’ oracles explored,
to teach the greeks to murmur at their lord?
for this with falsehood is my honour stain’d,

ransom for this girl, the daughter of chryses.

is heaven offended, and a priest profaned;

i have set my

because my prize, my beauteous maid, i hold,

heart on keeping her in my own house, for i love her better even

and heavenly charms prefer to proffer’d gold?

than my own wife clytemnestra, whose peer she is alike in form

a maid, unmatch’d in manners as in face,

and feature, in understanding and accomplishments.

skill’d in each art, and crown’d with every grace;

still i will

not half so dear were clytæmnestra’s charms,

give her up if i must, for i would have the people live, not die;

when first her blooming beauties bless’d my arms.
yet, if the gods demand her, let her sail;
our cares are only for the public weal:
let me be deem’d the hateful cause of all,
and suffer, rather than my people fall.

but you must find me a prize instead, or i alone among the

the prize, the beauteous prize, i will resign,
so dearly valued, and so justly mine.
but since for common good i yield the fair,

argives shall be without one.

my private loss let grateful greece repair;

this is not well; for you behold,

nor unrewarded let your prince complain,

all of you, that my prize is to go elsewhither.

that he alone has fought and bled in vain.

”

”

and achilles answered, “most noble son of atreus, covetous beyond

“insatiate king (achilles thus replies),

all mankind, how shall the achaeans find you another prize?

fond of the power, but fonder of the prize!

we

would’st thou the greeks their lawful prey should yield,

have no common store from which to take one.

the due reward of many a well-fought field?

those we took from

the spoils of cities razed and warriors slain,

the cities have been awarded; we cannot disallow the awards that

we share with justice, as with toil we gain;

have been made already.

but to resume whate’er thy avarice craves

give this girl, therefore, to the god,

(that trick of tyrants) may be borne by slaves.

and if ever jove grants us to sack the city of troy we will

yet if our chief for plunder only fight,
the spoils of ilion shall thy loss requite,
whene’er, by jove’s decree, our conquering powers

requite you three and fourfold.

shall humble to the dust her lofty towers.

”

”

then agamemnon said, “achilles, valiant though you be, you shall
not thus outwit me.

then thus the king: “shall i my prize resign

you shall not overreach and you shall not

with tame content, and thou possess’d of thine?
great as thou art, and like a god in fight,

persuade me.

think not to rob me of a soldier’s right.

are you to keep your own prize, while i sit tamely
under my loss and give up the girl at your bidding?

at thy demand shall i restore the maid?

let the

first let the just equivalent be paid;
such as a king might ask; and let it be

achaeans find me a prize in fair exchange to my liking, or i will

a treasure worthy her, and worthy me.
or grant me this, or with a monarch’s claim

come and take your own, or that of ajax or of ulysses; and he to

this hand shall seize some other captive dame.
the mighty ajax shall his prize resign;[55]
ulysses’ spoils, or even thy own, be mine.

whomsoever i may come shall rue my coming.

the man who suffers, loudly may complain;

but of this we will

and rage he may, but he shall rage in vain.
but this when time requires.
—it now remains

take thought hereafter; for the present, let us draw a ship into

we launch a bark to plough the watery plains,

the sea, and find a crew for her expressly; let us put a hecatomb

and waft the sacrifice to chrysa’s shores,
with chosen pilots, and with labouring oars.
soon shall the fair the sable ship ascend,

on board, and let us send chryseis also; further, let some chief

and some deputed prince the charge attend:

man among us be in command, either ajax, or idomeneus, or

this creta’s king, or ajax shall fulfil,
or wise ulysses see perform’d our will;
or, if our royal pleasure shall ordain,

yourself, son of peleus, mighty warrior that you are, that we may

achilles’ self conduct her o’er the main;
let fierce achilles, dreadful in his rage,

offer sacrifice and appease the anger of the god.

the god propitiate, and the pest assuage.

”

”
[illustration: ] mars

achilles scowled at him and answered, “you are steeped in

at this, pelides, frowning stern, replied:

insolence and lust of gain.

“o tyrant, arm’d with insolence and pride!
inglorious slave to interest, ever join’d
with fraud, unworthy of a royal mind!

with what heart can any of the

what generous greek, obedient to thy word,

achaeans do your bidding, either on foray or in open fighting?

shall form an ambush, or shall lift the sword?

i

what cause have i to war at thy decree?

came not warring here for any ill the trojans had done me.
i have

the distant trojans never injured me;

no quarrel with them.

to phthia’s realms no hostile troops they led:

they have not raided my cattle nor my

safe in her vales my warlike coursers fed;

horses, nor cut down my harvests on the rich plains of phthia;

far hence removed, the hoarse-resounding main,
and walls of rocks, secure my native reign,
whose fruitful soil luxuriant harvests grace,

for between me and them there is a great space, both mountain and

rich in her fruits, and in her martial race.

sounding sea.
we have followed you, sir insolence!

hither we sail’d, a voluntary throng,

for your

to avenge a private, not a public wrong:

pleasure, not ours—to gain satisfaction from the trojans for your

what else to troy the assembled nations draws,

shameless self and for menelaus.

but thine, ungrateful, and thy brother’s cause?
is this the pay our blood and toils deserve;
disgraced and injured by the man we serve?

you forget this, and threaten to
rob me of the prize for which i have toiled, and which the sons
of the achaeans have given me.

and darest thou threat to snatch my prize away,

never when the achaeans sack any

due to the deeds of many a dreadful day?

rich city of the trojans do i receive so good a prize as you do,

a prize as small, o tyrant!
match’d with thine,

though it is my hands that do the better part of the fighting.

as thy own actions if compared to mine.

when the sharing comes, your share is far the largest, and i,

thine in each conquest is the wealthy prey,

forsooth, must go back to my ships, take what i can get and be

though mine the sweat and danger of the day.
some trivial present to my ships i bear:

thankful, when my labour of fighting is done.

or barren praises pay the wounds of war.

now, therefore, i

but know, proud monarch, i’m thy slave no more;

shall go back to phthia; it will be much better for me to return

my fleet shall waft me to thessalia’s shore:

home with my ships, for i will not stay here dishonoured to

left by achilles on the trojan plain,

gather gold and substance for you.

what spoils, what conquests, shall atrides gain?

”

”

and agamemnon answered, “fly if you will, i shall make you no

to this the king: “fly, mighty warrior!
fly;

prayers to stay you.

thy aid we need not, and thy threats defy.

i have others here who will do me honour,

there want not chiefs in such a cause to fight,

and above all jove, the lord of counsel.

and jove himself shall guard a monarch’s right.

there is no king here so

of all the kings (the god’s distinguish’d care)

hateful to me as you are, for you are ever quarrelsome and

to power superior none such hatred bear:

ill-affected.

strife and debate thy restless soul employ,

what though you be brave?

and wars and horrors are thy savage joy,

was it not heaven that

if thou hast strength, ’twas heaven that strength bestow’d;

made you so?

for know, vain man!
thy valour is from god.

go home, then, with your ships and comrades to lord

haste, launch thy vessels, fly with speed away;

it over the myrmidons.

rule thy own realms with arbitrary sway;

i care neither for you nor for your anger;

i heed thee not, but prize at equal rate
thy short-lived friendship, and thy groundless hate.
go, threat thy earth-born myrmidons:—but here[56]
’tis mine to threaten, prince, and thine to fear.

and thus will i do: since phoebus apollo is taking chryseis from

know, if the god the beauteous dame demand,

me, i shall send her with my ship and my followers, but i shall

my bark shall waft her to her native land;
but then prepare, imperious prince!

come to your tent and take your own prize briseis, that you may

prepare,
fierce as thou art, to yield thy captive fair:
even in thy tent i’ll seize the blooming prize,
thy loved briseïs with the radiant eyes.

learn how much stronger i am than you are, and that another may

hence shalt thou prove my might, and curse the hour
thou stood’st a rival of imperial power;
and hence, to all our hosts it shall be known,

fear to set himself up as equal or comparable with me.

that kings are subject to the gods alone.

”

”

the son of peleus was furious, and his heart within his shaggy

achilles heard, with grief and rage oppress’d,
his heart swell’d high, and labour’d in his breast;
distracting thoughts by turns his bosom ruled;
now fired by wrath, and now by reason cool’d:

breast was divided whether to draw his sword, push the others

that prompts his hand to draw the deadly sword,

aside, and kill the son of atreus, or to restrain himself and

force through the greeks, and pierce their haughty lord;

check his anger.

this whispers soft his vengeance to control,
and calm the rising tempest of his soul.

while he was thus in two minds, and was drawing

just as in anguish of suspense he stay’d,

his mighty sword from its scabbard, minerva came down from heaven

while half unsheathed appear’d the glittering blade,[57]
minerva swift descended from above,

(for juno had sent her in the love she bore to them both), and

sent by the sister and the wife of jove
(for both the princes claim’d her equal care);

seized the son of peleus by his yellow hair, visible to him

behind she stood, and by the golden hair
achilles seized; to him alone confess’d;

alone, for of the others no man could see her.

a sable cloud conceal’d her from the rest.

achilles turned in

he sees, and sudden to the goddess cries,

amaze, and by the fire that flashed from her eyes at once knew

known by the flames that sparkle from her eyes:

that she was minerva.

[illustration: ] minerva repressing the fury of achilles

“why are you here,” said he, “daughter of

“descends minerva, in her guardian care,

aegis-bearing jove?

a heavenly witness of the wrongs i bear

to see the pride of agamemnon, son of atreus?

from atreus’ son?

let me tell you—and it shall surely be—he shall pay for this

—then let those eyes that view

insolence with his life.

the daring crime, behold the vengeance too.

”

”

and minerva said, “i come from heaven, if you will hear me, to

“forbear (the progeny of jove replies)
to calm thy fury i forsake the skies:
let great achilles, to the gods resign’d,

bid you stay your anger.

to reason yield the empire o’er his mind.

juno has sent me, who cares for both of

by awful juno this command is given;

you alike.

the king and you are both the care of heaven.

cease, then, this brawling, and do not draw your

the force of keen reproaches let him feel;

sword; rail at him if you will, and your railing will not be

but sheathe, obedient, thy revenging steel.

vain, for i tell you—and it shall surely be—that you shall

for i pronounce (and trust a heavenly power)
thy injured honour has its fated hour,
when the proud monarch shall thy arms implore,

hereafter receive gifts three times as splendid by reason of this

and bribe thy friendship with a boundless store.

present insult.

then let revenge no longer bear the sway;

hold, therefore, and obey.

command thy passions, and the gods obey.

”

”

“goddess,” answered achilles, “however angry a man may be, he

to her pelides:—“with regardful ear,
’tis just, o goddess!

must do as you two command him.

i thy dictates hear.

this will be best, for the gods

hard as it is, my vengeance i suppress:

ever hear the prayers of him who has obeyed them.

those who revere the gods the gods will bless.

”

”

he stayed his hand on the silver hilt of his sword, and thrust it

he said, observant of the blue-eyed maid;

back into the scabbard as minerva bade him.
then she went back to

then in the sheath return’d the shining blade.

olympus among the other gods, and to the house of aegis-bearing

the goddess swift to high olympus flies,

jove.

and joins the sacred senate of the skies.

but the son of peleus again began railing at the son of atreus,

nor yet the rage his boiling breast forsook,

for he was still in a rage.

which thus redoubling on atrides broke:

“wine-bibber,” he cried, “with the

“o monster!

face of a dog and the heart of a hind, you never dare to go out

mix’d of insolence and fear,
thou dog in forehead, but in heart a deer!

with the host in fight, nor yet with our chosen men in ambuscade.

when wert thou known in ambush’d fights to dare,
or nobly face the horrid front of war?
’tis ours, the chance of fighting fields to try;

you shun this as you do death itself.

thine to look on, and bid the valiant die:

you had rather go round and

so much ’tis safer through the camp to go,

rob his prizes from any man who contradicts you.

and rob a subject, than despoil a foe.

you devour your

scourge of thy people, violent and base!

people, for you are king over a feeble folk; otherwise, son of

sent in jove’s anger on a slavish race;

atreus, henceforward you would insult no man.

who, lost to sense of generous freedom past,
are tamed to wrongs;—or this had been thy last.

therefore i say,
and swear it with a great oath—nay, by this my sceptre which

now by this sacred sceptre hear me swear,

shalt sprout neither leaf nor shoot, nor bud anew from the day on

which never more shall leaves or blossoms bear,

which it left its parent stem upon the mountains—for the axe

which sever’d from the trunk (as i from thee)
on the bare mountains left its parent tree;
this sceptre, form’d by temper’d steel to prove

stripped it of leaf and bark, and now the sons of the achaeans

an ensign of the delegates of jove,

bear it as judges and guardians of the decrees of heaven—so

from whom the power of laws and justice springs
(tremendous oath!
inviolate to kings);

surely and solemnly do i swear that hereafter they shall look

by this i swear:—when bleeding greece again

fondly for achilles and shall not find him.

shall call achilles, she shall call in vain.

in the day of your

when, flush’d with slaughter, hector comes to spread

distress, when your men fall dying by the murderous hand of

the purpled shore with mountains of the dead,

hector, you shall not know how to help them, and shall rend your

then shalt thou mourn the affront thy madness gave,

heart with rage for the hour when you offered insult to the

forced to deplore when impotent to save:
then rage in bitterness of soul to know

bravest of the achaeans.

this act has made the bravest greek thy foe.

”

”

with this the son of peleus dashed his gold-bestudded sceptre on

he spoke; and furious hurl’d against the ground
his sceptre starr’d with golden studs around:

the ground and took his seat, while the son of atreus was
beginning fiercely from his place upon the other side.

then sternly silent sat.

then

with like disdain

uprose smooth-tongued nestor, the facile speaker of the pylians,

the raging king return’d his frowns again.
to calm their passion with the words of age,
slow from his seat arose the pylian sage,
experienced nestor, in persuasion skill’d;

and the words fell from his lips sweeter than honey.

words, sweet as honey, from his lips distill’d:[58]

two
generations of men born and bred in pylos had passed away under

two generations now had pass’d away,

his rule, and he was now reigning over the third.

wise by his rules, and happy by his sway;
two ages o’er his native realm he reign’d,
and now the example of the third remain’d.

with all

all view’d with awe the venerable man;

sincerity and goodwill, therefore, he addressed them thus:—

who thus with mild benevolence began:—

“of a truth,” he said, “a great sorrow has befallen the achaean

“what shame, what woe is this to greece!

land.

what joy

surely priam with his sons would rejoice, and the trojans

to troy’s proud monarch, and the friends of troy!

be glad at heart if they could hear this quarrel between you two,

that adverse gods commit to stern debate

who are so excellent in fight and counsel.

the best, the bravest, of the grecian state.

i am older than either

young as ye are, this youthful heat restrain,

of you; therefore be guided by me.

nor think your nestor’s years and wisdom vain.

moreover i have been the
familiar friend of men even greater than you are, and they did

a godlike race of heroes once i knew,

not disregard my counsels.
never again can i behold such men as

such as no more these aged eyes shall view!

pirithous and dryas shepherd of his people, or as caeneus,

lives there a chief to match pirithous’ fame,
dryas the bold, or ceneus’ deathless name;

exadius, godlike polyphemus, and theseus son of aegeus, peer of

theseus, endued with more than mortal might,
or polyphemus, like the gods in fight?

the immortals.

with these of old, to toils of battle bred,

these were the mightiest men ever born upon this

in early youth my hardy days i led;

earth: mightiest were they, and when they fought the fiercest

fired with the thirst which virtuous envy breeds,
and smit with love of honourable deeds,

tribes of mountain savages they utterly overthrew them.

strongest of men, they pierced the mountain boar,
ranged the wild deserts red with monsters’ gore,
and from their hills the shaggy centaurs tore:

i came

yet these with soft persuasive arts i sway’d;

from distant pylos, and went about among them, for they would

when nestor spoke, they listen’d and obey’d.

have me come, and i fought as it was in me to do.

if in my youth, even these esteem’d me wise;

not a man now

do you, young warriors, hear my age advise.

living could withstand them, but they heard my words, and were

atrides, seize not on the beauteous slave;

persuaded by them.

that prize the greeks by common suffrage gave:

so be it also with yourselves, for this is the

nor thou, achilles, treat our prince with pride;

more excellent way.

let kings be just, and sovereign power preside.

therefore, agamemnon, though you be strong,

thee, the first honours of the war adorn,
like gods in strength, and of a goddess born;

take not this girl away, for the sons of the achaeans have
already given her to achilles; and you, achilles, strive not

him, awful majesty exalts above

further with the king, for no man who by the grace of jove wields

the powers of earth, and sceptred sons of jove.

a sceptre has like honour with agamemnon.

let both unite with well-consenting mind,

you are strong, and

so shall authority with strength be join’d.
leave me, o king!

have a goddess for your mother; but agamemnon is stronger than

to calm achilles’ rage;

you, for he has more people under him.

rule thou thyself, as more advanced in age.

son of atreus, check your

forbid it, gods!

anger, i implore you; end this quarrel with achilles, who in the

achilles should be lost,

day of battle is a tower of strength to the achaeans.

the pride of greece, and bulwark of our host.

”

”

and agamemnon answered, “sir, all that you have said is true, but

this said, he ceased.
the king of men replies:
“thy years are awful, and thy words are wise.
but that imperious, that unconquer’d soul,

this fellow must needs become our lord and master: he must be

no laws can limit, no respect control.
before his pride must his superiors fall;

lord of all, king of all, and captain of all, and this shall

his word the law, and he the lord of all?
him must our hosts, our chiefs, ourself obey?

hardly be.

what king can bear a rival in his sway?

granted that the gods have made him a great warrior,

grant that the gods his matchless force have given;

have they also given him the right to speak with railing?

has foul reproach a privilege from heaven?

”

”

achilles interrupted him.

here on the monarch’s speech achilles broke,

“i should be a mean coward,” he cried,

and furious, thus, and interrupting spoke:

“were i to give in to you in all things.

“tyrant, i well deserved thy galling chain,

order other people
about, not me, for i shall obey no longer.

to live thy slave, and still to serve in vain,

furthermore i say—and

should i submit to each unjust decree:—

lay my saying to your heart—i shall fight neither you nor any man

command thy vassals, but command not me.

about this girl, for those that take were those also that gave.

seize on briseïs, whom the grecians doom’d

but of all else that is at my ship you shall carry away nothing

my prize of war, yet tamely see resumed;
and seize secure; no more achilles draws

by force.

his conquering sword in any woman’s cause.

try, that others may see; if you do, my spear shall be

the gods command me to forgive the past:
but let this first invasion be the last:

reddened with your blood.

for know, thy blood, when next thou darest invade,
shall stream in vengeance on my reeking blade.

”

”

when they had quarrelled thus angrily, they rose, and broke up

at this they ceased: the stern debate expired:

the assembly at the ships of the achaeans.

the chiefs in sullen majesty retired.

the son of peleus went

company, while agamemnon drew a vessel into the water and chose a

meantime atrides launch’d with numerous oars

crew of twenty oarsmen.

he escorted chryseis on board and sent

high on the deck was fair chryseïs placed,

moreover a hecatomb for the god.

and sage ulysses with the conduct graced:

and ulysses went as captain.

safe in her sides the hecatomb they stow’d,

these, then, went on board and sailed their ways over the sea.

then swiftly sailing, cut the liquid road.

but the son of atreus bade the people purify themselves; so they

the host to expiate next the king prepares,

purified themselves and cast their filth into the sea.

with pure lustrations, and with solemn prayers.
wash’d by the briny wave, the pious train[59]
are cleansed; and cast the ablutions in the main.

then they

sea-shore, and the smoke with the savour of their sacrifice rose

the sable fumes in curling spires arise,

curling up towards heaven.

and waft their grateful odours to the skies.

thus did they busy themselves throughout the host.

the army thus in sacred rites engaged,

but agamemnon

atrides still with deep resentment raged.

did not forget the threat that he had made achilles, and called

to wait his will two sacred heralds stood,

his trusty messengers and squires talthybius and eurybates.

talthybius and eurybates the good.

“go,”

“haste to the fierce achilles’ tent (he cries),

said he, “to the tent of achilles, son of peleus; take briseis by

thence bear briseïs as our royal prize:

the hand and bring her hither; if he will not give her i shall

submit he must; or if they will not part,

come with others and take her—which will press him harder.

ourself in arms shall tear her from his heart.

”

”

he charged them straightly further and dismissed them, whereon

the unwilling heralds act their lord’s commands;

they went their way sorrowfully by the seaside, till they came to

pensive they walk along the barren sands:

the tents and ships of the myrmidons.
they found achilles sitting
by his tent and his ships, and ill-pleased he was when he beheld

arrived, the hero in his tent they find,

them.

with gloomy aspect on his arm reclined.

they stood fearfully and reverently before him, and never a

at awful distance long they silent stand,

word did they speak, but he knew them and said, “welcome,

loth to advance, and speak their hard command;

heralds, messengers of gods and men; draw near; my quarrel is not

decent confusion!
this the godlike man
perceived, and thus with accent mild began:
“with leave and honour enter our abodes,
ye sacred ministers of men and gods!
[60]

with you but with agamemnon who has sent you for the girl

i know your message; by constraint you came;
not you, but your imperious lord i blame.

briseis.

patroclus, haste, the fair briseïs bring;

therefore, patroclus, bring her and give her to them,

conduct my captive to the haughty king.

but let them be witnesses by the blessed gods, by mortal men, and

but witness, heralds, and proclaim my vow,
witness to gods above, and men below!
but first, and loudest, to your prince declare

by the fierceness of agamemnon’s anger, that if ever again there

(that lawless tyrant whose commands you bear),
unmoved as death achilles shall remain,
though prostrate greece shall bleed at every vein:
the raging chief in frantic passion lost,

be need of me to save the people from ruin, they shall seek and
they shall not find.
agamemnon is mad with rage and knows not how

blind to himself, and useless to his host,

to look before and after that the achaeans may fight by their

unskill’d to judge the future by the past,

ships in safety.

in blood and slaughter shall repent at last.

”

”

patroclus did as his dear comrade had bidden him.

[illustration: ] the departure of briseis from the tent of achilles

he brought

patroclus now the unwilling beauty brought;

briseis from the tent and gave her over to the heralds, who took

she, in soft sorrows, and in pensive thought,

her with them to the ships of the achaeans—and the woman was loth

pass’d silent, as the heralds held her hand,

to go.

and oft look’d back, slow-moving o’er the strand.

then achilles went all alone by the side of the hoar sea,

not so his loss the fierce achilles bore;

weeping and looking out upon the boundless waste of waters.

but sad, retiring to the sounding shore,

he

o’er the wild margin of the deep he hung,

raised his hands in prayer to his immortal mother, “mother,” he

that kindred deep from whence his mother sprung:[61]

cried, “you bore me doomed to live but for a little season;

there bathed in tears of anger and disdain,

surely jove, who thunders from olympus, might have made that

thus loud lamented to the stormy main:

little glorious.

“o parent goddess!

it is not so.

since in early bloom

agamemnon, son of atreus, has done

thy son must fall, by too severe a doom;
sure to so short a race of glory born,
great jove in justice should this span adorn:
honour and fame at least the thunderer owed;
and ill he pays the promise of a god,
if yon proud monarch thus thy son defies,

me dishonour, and has robbed me of my prize by force.

obscures my glories, and resumes my prize.

”

”

as he spoke he wept aloud, and his mother heard him where she was

far from the deep recesses of the main,

sitting in the depths of the sea hard by the old man her father.

where aged ocean holds his watery reign,
the goddess-mother heard.

forthwith she rose as it were a grey mist out of the waves, sat

the waves divide;
and like a mist she rose above the tide;

down before him as he stood weeping, caressed him with her hand,

beheld him mourning on the naked shores,

and said, “my son, why are you weeping?

and thus the sorrows of his soul explores.

what is it that grieves

“why grieves my son?

you?

thy anguish let me share;

keep it not from me, but tell me, that we may know it

reveal the cause, and trust a parent’s care.

together.
”

”

achilles drew a deep sigh and said, “you know it; why tell you

what you know well already?

is but to mention what too well you know.

the sire insulted, and his gifts denied:

away.
so he went back in anger, and apollo, who loved him dearly,

the insulted sire (his god’s peculiar care)

heard his prayer.

to phœbus pray’d, and phœbus heard the prayer:

then the god sent a deadly dart upon the
argives, and the people died thick on one another, for the arrows

a dreadful plague ensues: the avenging darts

went everywhither among the wide host of the achaeans.

incessant fly, and pierce the grecian hearts.

at last a

a prophet then, inspired by heaven, arose,

seer in the fulness of his knowledge declared to us the oracles

of apollo, and i was myself first to say that we should appease

him.

to avert the vengeance of the power divine;

which he has since done.

incensed he threaten’d, and his threats perform’d:

the achaeans are now taking the girl in

a ship to chryse, and sending gifts of sacrifice to the god; but

with offer’d gifts to make the god relent;

the heralds have just taken from my tent the daughter of briseus,

but now he seized briseïs’ heavenly charms,

whom the achaeans had awarded to myself.

and of my valour’s prize defrauds my arms,
defrauds the votes of all the grecian train;[63]
and service, faith, and justice, plead in vain.

“help your brave son, therefore, if you are able.

but, goddess!
thou thy suppliant son attend.

go to olympus,

to high olympus’ shining court ascend,

and if you have ever done him service in word or deed, implore

urge all the ties to former service owed,

the aid of jove.

and sue for vengeance to the thundering god.

ofttimes in my father’s house have i heard you

oft hast thou triumph’d in the glorious boast,

glory in that you alone of the immortals saved the son of saturn

that thou stood’st forth of all the ethereal host,

from ruin, when the others, with juno, neptune, and pallas

when bold rebellion shook the realms above,
the undaunted guard of cloud-compelling jove:
when the bright partner of his awful reign,
the warlike maid, and monarch of the main,
the traitor-gods, by mad ambition driven,

minerva would have put him in bonds.

durst threat with chains the omnipotence of heaven.

it was you, goddess, who

then, call’d by thee, the monster titan came
(whom gods briareus, men ægeon name),

delivered him by calling to olympus the hundred-handed monster

through wondering skies enormous stalk’d along;

whom gods call briareus, but men aegaeon, for he is stronger even

not he that shakes the solid earth so strong:

than his father; when therefore he took his seat all-glorious

with giant-pride at jove’s high throne he stands,
and brandish’d round him all his hundred hands:

beside the son of saturn, the other gods were afraid, and did not

the affrighted gods confess’d their awful lord,
they dropp’d the fetters, trembled, and adored.

bind him.

[64]

go, then, to him, remind him of all this, clasp his

this, goddess, this to his remembrance call,

knees, and bid him give succour to the trojans.

embrace his knees, at his tribunal fall;

let the achaeans

conjure him far to drive the grecian train,

be hemmed in at the sterns of their ships, and perish on the

to hurl them headlong to their fleet and main,
to heap the shores with copious death, and bring

sea-shore, that they may reap what joy they may of their king,

the greeks to know the curse of such a king.

and that agamemnon may rue his blindness in offering insult to

let agamemnon lift his haughty head
o’er all his wide dominion of the dead,
and mourn in blood that e’er he durst disgrace

the foremost of the achaeans.

the boldest warrior of the grecian race.

”

”
[illustration: ] thetis calling briareus to the assistance of jupiter
“unhappy son!

thetis wept and answered, “my son, woe is me that i should have

(fair thetis thus replies,

borne or suckled you.

while tears celestial trickle from her eyes)

would indeed that you had lived your span

why have i borne thee with a mother’s throes,
to fates averse, and nursed for future woes?

free from all sorrow at your ships, for it is all too brief;

[65]
so short a space the light of heaven to view!
so short a space!

alas, that you should be at once short of life and long of sorrow

and fill’d with sorrow too!
o might a parent’s careful wish prevail,
far, far from ilion should thy vessels sail,

above your peers: woe, therefore, was the hour in which i bore

and thou, from camps remote, the danger shun
which now, alas!

you; nevertheless i will go to the snowy heights of olympus, and

too nearly threats my son.
yet (what i can) to move thy suit i’ll go
to great olympus crown’d with fleecy snow.

tell this tale to jove, if he will hear our prayer: meanwhile
stay where you are with your ships, nurse your anger against the

meantime, secure within thy ships, from far

achaeans, and hold aloof from fight.

behold the field, not mingle in the war.
the sire of gods and all the ethereal train,

for jove went yesterday to

now mix with mortals, nor disdain to grace

with him.

he will return to olympus twelve days hence; i will

twelve days the powers indulge the genial rite,
returning with the twelfth revolving light.

then go to his mansion paved with bronze and will beseech him;

then will i mount the brazen dome, and move

nor do i doubt that i shall be able to persuade him.

the high tribunal of immortal jove.

hecatomb.

beneath the deck the destined victims stow’d:

when they had come inside the harbour they furled the

forestays, lowered the mast into its place, and rowed the ship to
the place where they would have her lie; there they cast out

the sails they furl’d, they lash the mast aside,

their mooring-stones and made fast the hawsers.

and dropp’d their anchors, and the pinnace tied.

they then got out

her, thus returning from the furrow’d main,
ulysses led to phœbus’ sacred fane;

he gave to chryses, thus the hero said:
“hail, reverend priest!
to phœbus’ awful dome

agamemnon has sent me to bring you back your child, and to offer

a suppliant i from great atrides come:

sacrifice to apollo on behalf of the danaans, that we may

unransom’d, here receive the spotless fair;
accept the hecatomb the greeks prepare;

propitiate the god, who has now brought sorrow upon the argives.

and may thy god who scatters darts around,
atoned by sacrifice, desist to wound.

”

”[67]

so saying he gave the girl over to her father, who received her

at this, the sire embraced the maid again,

gladly, and they ranged the holy hecatomb all orderly round the

so sadly lost, so lately sought in vain.

altar of the god.

then near the altar of the darting king,

they washed their hands and took up the

disposed in rank their hecatomb they bring;
with water purify their hands, and take

barley-meal to sprinkle over the victims, while chryses lifted up

the sacred offering of the salted cake;

his hands and prayed aloud on their behalf.

while thus with arms devoutly raised in air,

“hear me,” he cried,

and solemn voice, the priest directs his prayer:

“o god of the silver bow, that protectest chryse and holy cilla,

“god of the silver bow, thy ear incline,
whose power incircles cilla the divine;

and rulest tenedos with thy might.

whose sacred eye thy tenedos surveys,

even as thou didst hear me

and gilds fair chrysa with distinguish’d rays!

aforetime when i prayed, and didst press hardly upon the

if, fired to vengeance at thy priest’s request,

achaeans, so hear me yet again, and stay this fearful pestilence

thy direful darts inflict the raging pest:
once more attend!
avert the wasteful woe,

from the danaans.

and smile propitious, and unbend thy bow.

”

”

thus did he pray, and apollo heard his prayer.

so chryses pray’d.
apollo heard his prayer:

when they had done

and now the greeks their hecatomb prepare;

praying and sprinkling the barley-meal, they drew back the heads

between their horns the salted barley threw,

of the victims and killed and flayed them.

and, with their heads to heaven, the victims slew:[68]

they cut out the

the limbs they sever from the inclosing hide;

thigh-bones, wrapped them round in two layers of fat, set some

the thighs, selected to the gods, divide:
on these, in double cauls involved with art,

pieces of raw meat on the top of them, and then chryses laid them

the choicest morsels lay from every part.

on the wood fire and poured wine over them, while the young men

the priest himself before his altar stands,

stood near him with five-pronged spits in their hands.

and burns the offering with his holy hands.

when the

pours the black wine, and sees the flames aspire;

thigh-bones were burned and they had tasted the inward meats,

the youth with instruments surround the fire:
the thighs thus sacrificed, and entrails dress’d,

they cut the rest up small, put the pieces upon the spits,

the assistants part, transfix, and roast the rest:

roasted them till they were done, and drew them off: then, when
they had finished their work and the feast was ready, they ate

then spread the tables, the repast prepare;

it, and every man had his full share, so that all were satisfied.

each takes his seat, and each receives his share.

as soon as they had had enough to eat and drink, pages filled the

when now the rage of hunger was repress’d,
with pure libations they conclude the feast;

mixing-bowl with wine and water and handed it round, after giving

the youths with wine the copious goblets crown’d,[69]

every man his drink-offering.

and, pleased, dispense the flowing bowls around

thus all day long the young men worshipped the god with song,
hymning him and chaunting the joyous paean, and the god took

with hymns divine the joyous banquet ends,

pleasure in their voices; but when the sun went down, and it came

the pæans lengthen’d till the sun descends:
the greeks, restored, the grateful notes prolong;
apollo listens, and approves the song.

on dark, they laid themselves down to sleep by the stern cables
of the ship, and when the child of morning, rosy-fingered dawn,

’twas night; the chiefs beside their vessel lie,

appeared they again set sail for the host of the achaeans.

till rosy morn had purpled o’er the sky:

apollo

then launch, and hoist the mast: indulgent gales,

sent them a fair wind, so they raised their mast and hoisted

supplied by phœbus, fill the swelling sails;

their white sails aloft.
as the sail bellied with the wind the

the milk-white canvas bellying as they blow,

ship flew through the deep blue water, and the foam hissed

the parted ocean foams and roars below:

against her bows as she sped onward.

above the bounding billows swift they flew,

when they reached the

till now the grecian camp appear’d in view.

wide-stretching host of the achaeans, they drew the vessel

far on the beach they haul their bark to land,

ashore, high and dry upon the sands, set her strong props beneath

(the crooked keel divides the yellow sand,)
then part, where stretch’d along the winding bay,

her, and went their ways to their own tents and ships.

the ships and tents in mingled prospect lay.

but achilles abode at his ships and nursed his anger.

but raging still, amidst his navy sat
the stern achilles, stedfast in his hate;

he went not

nor mix’d in combat, nor in council join’d;

to the honourable assembly, and sallied not forth to fight, but

but wasting cares lay heavy on his mind:

gnawed at his own heart, pining for battle and the war-cry.

in his black thoughts revenge and slaughter roll,
and scenes of blood rise dreadful in his soul.

now after twelve days the immortal gods came back in a body to

twelve days were past, and now the dawning light
the gods had summon’d to the olympian height:

olympus, and jove led the way.

jove, first ascending from the watery bowers,
leads the long order of ethereal powers.

thetis was not unmindful of the

when, like the morning-mist in early day,

and went through great heaven with early morning to olympus,

and to the seats divine her flight address’d.
there, far apart, and high above the rest,

where she found the mighty son of saturn sitting all alone upon

the thunderer sat; where old olympus shrouds

its topmost ridges.

his hundred heads in heaven, and props the clouds.

she sat herself down before him, and with her

beneath his beard, and one his knees embraced.

“father jove, if i ever did you service in word or deed among the

the sacred counsels of his breast conceal’d.
not so repulsed, the goddess closer press’d,

kept firm hold of his knees, and besought him a second time.

still grasp’d his knees, and urged the dear request.

“incline your head,” said she, “and promise me surely, or else

“o sire of gods and men!
thy suppliant hear;

you disdain me.

i will consider

with jealous eyes thy close access survey;

the matter, and will bring it about as you wish.

but part in peace, secure thy prayer is sped:

see, i incline
my head that you may believe me.

witness the sacred honours of our head,

this is the most solemn promise
that i can give to any god.

the nod that ratifies the will divine,

i never recall my word, or deceive,
or fail to do what i say, when i have nodded my head.

the faithful, fix’d, irrevocable sign;

”

this seals thy suit, and this fulfils thy vows—”

to hurl us all from our seats, he can do so, for he is far the

good humour with us.

the gracious power is willing to be pleased.

[illustration: ] jupiter
[illustration: ] the apotheosis of homer

book ii.

book ii.
argument.
the trial of the army, and catalogue of the forces.

jove sends a lying dream to agamemnon, who thereon calls the

jupiter, in pursuance of the request of thetis, sends a deceitful

chiefs in assembly, and proposes to sound the mind of his army—in

vision to agamemnon, persuading him to lead the army to battle, in
order to make the greeks sensible of their want of achilles.
the
general, who is deluded with the hopes of taking troy without his
assistance, but fears the army was discouraged by his absence, and the
late plague, as well as by the length of time, contrives to make trial
of their disposition by a stratagem.
he first communicates his design
to the princes in council, that he would propose a return to the
soldiers, and that they should put a stop to them if the proposal was
embraced.
then he assembles the whole host, and upon moving for a
return to greece, they unanimously agree to it, and run to prepare the
ships.
they are detained by the management of ulysses, who chastises
the insolence of thersites.
the assembly is recalled, several speeches
made on the occasion, and at length the advice of nestor followed,
which was to make a general muster of the troops, and to divide them

the end they march to fight—catalogue of the achaean and trojan

into their several nations, before they proceeded to battle.
this gives
occasion to the poet to enumerate all the forces of the greeks and
trojans, and in a large catalogue.
the time employed in this book consists not entirely of one day.
the scene lies in the grecian camp, and upon the sea-shore; towards

forces.

the end it removes to troy.

now the other gods and the armed warriors on the plain slept

it hovered

the dream then left him, and he thought of things that were

the phantom said; then vanish’d from his sight,
resolves to air, and mixes with the night.

surely not to be accomplished.

a thousand schemes the monarch’s mind employ;

he thought that on that same day

elate in thought he sacks untaken troy:

he was to take the city of priam, but he little knew what was in

vain as he was, and to the future blind,

the mind of jove, who had many another hard-fought fight in store

what mighty toils to either host remain,

alike for danaans and trojans.

then presently he woke, with the

agamemnon; but the people pressed forward to hear.

the sceptred rulers lead; the following host,

they swarmed

pour’d forth by thousands, darkens all the coast.

like bees that sally from some hollow cave and flit in countless

as from some rocky cleft the shepherd sees
clustering in heaps on heaps the driving bees,

throng among the spring flowers, bunched in knots and clusters;

rolling and blackening, swarms succeeding swarms,

even so did the mighty multitude pour from ships and tents to the

with deeper murmurs and more hoarse alarms;

assembly, and range themselves upon the wide-watered shore, while
among them ran wildfire rumour, messenger of jove, urging them

dusky they spread, a close embodied crowd,

ever to the fore.

and o’er the vale descends the living cloud.
[81]

thus they gathered in a pell-mell of mad

so, from the tents and ships, a lengthen’d train

confusion, and the earth groaned under the tramp of men as the

spreads all the beach, and wide o’ershades the plain:
along the region runs a deafening sound;
beneath their footsteps groans the trembling ground.
fame flies before the messenger of jove,

people sought their places.

and shining soars, and claps her wings above.

nine heralds went crying about among

nine sacred heralds now, proclaiming loud[82]

them to stay their tumult and bid them listen to the kings, till

the monarch’s will, suspend the listening crowd.

at last they were got into their several places and ceased their

soon as the throngs in order ranged appear,

clamour.

and fainter murmurs died upon the ear,

then king agamemnon rose, holding his sceptre.

the king of kings his awful figure raised:
high in his hand the golden sceptre blazed;

this was

the golden sceptre, of celestial flame,

the work of vulcan, who gave it to jove the son of saturn.
jove

by vulcan form’d, from jove to hermes came.

gave it to mercury, slayer of argus, guide and guardian.
king

to pelops he the immortal gift resign’d;

mercury gave it to pelops, the mighty charioteer, and pelops to
atreus, shepherd of his people.

the immortal gift great pelops left behind,

atreus, when he died, left it to

in atreus’ hand, which not with atreus ends,

thyestes, rich in flocks, and thyestes in his turn left it to be

to rich thyestes next the prize descends;

borne by agamemnon, that he might be lord of all argos and of the

and now the mark of agamemnon’s reign,
subjects all argos, and controls the main.

isles.

[83]

leaning, then, on his sceptre, he addressed the argives.

on this bright sceptre now the king reclined,
and artful thus pronounced the speech design’d:

“my friends,” he said, “heroes, servants of mars, the hand of

“ye sons of mars, partake your leader’s care,

heaven has been laid heavily upon me.

heroes of greece, and brothers of the war!

cruel jove gave me his

of partial jove with justice i complain,

solemn promise that i should sack the city of priam before

and heavenly oracles believed in vain

returning, but he has played me false, and is now bidding me go

a safe return was promised to our toils,

ingloriously back to argos with the loss of much people.

renown’d, triumphant, and enrich’d with spoils.

such is

now shameful flight alone can save the host,

the will of jove, who has laid many a proud city in the dust, as

our blood, our treasure, and our glory lost.
so jove decrees, resistless lord of all!
at whose command whole empires rise or fall:
he shakes the feeble props of human trust,
and towns and armies humbles to the dust.
what shame to greece a fruitful war to wage,

he will yet lay others, for his power is above all.

oh, lasting shame in every future age!

it will be a

once great in arms, the common scorn we grow,

sorry tale hereafter that an achaean host, at once so great and

repulsed and baffled by a feeble foe.

valiant, battled in vain against men fewer in number than
themselves; but as yet the end is not in sight.
think that the

so small their number, that if wars were ceased,

achaeans and trojans have sworn to a solemn covenant, and that

and greece triumphant held a general feast,

they have each been numbered—the trojans by the roll of their
householders, and we by companies of ten; think further that each

all rank’d by tens, whole decades when they dine

of our companies desired to have a trojan householder to pour out
their wine; we are so greatly more in number that full many a
company would have to go without its cup-bearer.

must want a trojan slave to pour the wine.

but they have in

[84]

the town allies from other places, and it is these that hinder me

but other forces have our hopes o’erthrown,

from being able to sack the rich city of ilius.

and troy prevails by armies not her own.

nine of jove’s

now nine long years of mighty jove are run,

years are gone; the timbers of our ships have rotted; their

since first the labours of this war begun:
our cordage torn, decay’d our vessels lie,

tackling is sound no longer.

and scarce insure the wretched power to fly.
haste, then, for ever leave the trojan wall!

our wives and little ones at home

our weeping wives, our tender children call:

look anxiously for our coming, but the work that we came hither

love, duty, safety, summon us away,

to do has not been done.

’tis nature’s voice, and nature we obey.

now, therefore, let us all do as i say:

our shatter’d barks may yet transport us o’er,

let us sail back to our own land, for we shall not take troy.

safe and inglorious, to our native shore.
fly, grecians, fly, your sails and oars employ,
and dream no more of heaven-defended troy.

”

”

with these words he moved the hearts of the multitude, so many of
them as knew not the cunning counsel of agamemnon.

his deep design unknown, the hosts approve

they surged to

atrides’ speech.
the mighty numbers move.

and fro like the waves of the icarian sea, when the east and

so roll the billows to the icarian shore,

south winds break from heaven’s clouds to lash them; or as when

from east and south when winds begin to roar,
burst their dark mansions in the clouds, and sweep

the west wind sweeps over a field of corn and the ears bow

the whitening surface of the ruffled deep.
and as on corn when western gusts descend,[85]

beneath the blast, even so were they swayed as they flew with

before the blast the lofty harvests bend:
thus o’er the field the moving host appears,

loud cries towards the ships, and the dust from under their feet

with nodding plumes and groves of waving spears.
the gathering murmur spreads, their trampling feet
beat the loose sands, and thicken to the fleet;
with long-resounding cries they urge the train
to fit the ships, and launch into the main.
they toil, they sweat, thick clouds of dust arise,

rose heavenward.
they cheered each other on to draw the ships

the doubling clamours echo to the skies.

into the sea; they cleared the channels in front of them; they

e’en then the greeks had left the hostile plain,

began taking away the stays from underneath them, and the welkin

and fate decreed the fall of troy in vain;

rang with their glad cries, so eager were they to return.

but jove’s imperial queen their flight survey’d,

“shall then the grecians fly!

no: let my greeks, unmoved by vain alarms,
once more refulgent shine in brazen arms.

go about

haste, goddess, haste!

at once among the host, and speak fairly to them, man by man,

the flying host detain,

that they draw not their ships into the sea.

nor let one sail be hoisted on the main.

for dreadful is the wrath of kings.

”

but when he came across any common man who was making a noise, he

coward and no soldier; you are nobody either in fight or council;

ye gods, what dastards would our host command!
swept to the war, the lumber of a land.

all.

his are the laws, and him let all obey.

”[86]

thus masterfully did he go about among the host, and the people

the loudest silenced, and the fiercest cool’d.

and heaves huge surges to the trembling shores;

and a still silence lulls the camp to peace.
thersites only clamour’d in the throng,

tongue—a man of many words, and those unseemly; a monger of

loquacious, loud, and turbulent of tongue:

sedition, a railer against all who were in authority, who cared

awed by no shame, by no respect controll’d,
in scandal busy, in reproaches bold:
with witty malice studious to defame,
scorn all his joy, and laughter all his aim:—
but chief he gloried with licentious style
to lash the great, and monarchs to revile.

not what he said, so that he might set the achaeans in a laugh.

his figure such as might his soul proclaim;

he was the ugliest man of all those that came before

one eye was blinking, and one leg was lame:

troy—bandy-legged, lame of one foot, with his two shoulders
rounded and hunched over his chest.

his mountain shoulders half his breast o’erspread,

his head ran up to a point,
but there was little hair on the top of it.

thin hairs bestrew’d his long misshapen head.

achilles and ulysses

spleen to mankind his envious heart possess’d,

hated him worst of all, for it was with them that he was most

and much he hated all, but most the best:

wont to wrangle; now, however, with a shrill squeaky voice he

ulysses or achilles still his theme;

began heaping his abuse on agamemnon.

but royal scandal his delight supreme,

the achaeans were angry and

the son of atreus.

“agamemnon,” he cried, “what ails you now, and what more do you

“amidst the glories of so bright a reign,

want?

what moves the great atrides to complain?

your tents are filled with bronze and with fair women, for

’tis thine whate’er the warrior’s breast inflames,
the golden spoil, and thine the lovely dames.
with all the wealth our wars and blood bestow,
thy tents are crowded and thy chests o’erflow.

whenever we take a town we give you the pick of them.

thus at full ease in heaps of riches roll’d,

would you

what grieves the monarch?

have yet more gold, which some trojan is to give you as a ransom

say, shall we march with our unconquer’d powers

and bring the race of royal bastards here,
for troy to ransom at a price too dear?
but safer plunder thy own host supplies;

for his son, when i or another achaean has taken him prisoner?

say, wouldst thou seize some valiant leader’s prize?

or

no.

this mighty tyrant were no tyrant long.

”

thus railed thersites, but ulysses at once went up to him and

fierce from his seat at this ulysses springs,[87]

rebuked him sternly.

in generous vengeance of the king of kings.
with indignation sparkling in his eyes,
he views the wretch, and sternly thus replies:

“check your glib tongue, thersites,” said

“peace, factious monster, born to vex the state,
with wrangling talents form’d for foul debate:
curb that impetuous tongue, nor rashly vain,

he, “and babble not a word further.

and singly mad, asperse the sovereign reign.

chide not with princes when

have we not known thee, slave!

you have none to back you.

of all our host,

there is no viler creature come before

the man who acts the least, upbraids the most?

troy with the sons of atreus.

think not the greeks to shameful flight to bring,

drop this chatter about kings, and
neither revile them nor keep harping about going home.

nor let those lips profane the name of king.

we do not

for our return we trust the heavenly powers;

yet know how things are going to be, nor whether the achaeans are

be that their care; to fight like men be ours.

to return with good success or evil.

but grant the host with wealth the general load,

how dare you gibe at

except detraction, what hast thou bestow’d?

agamemnon because the danaans have awarded him so many prizes?

suppose some hero should his spoils resign,
art thou that hero, could those spoils be thine?

i

gods!

tell you, therefore—and it shall surely be—that if i again catch
you talking such nonsense, i will either forfeit my own head and

let me perish on this hateful shore,

be no more called father of telemachus, or i will take you, strip

and let these eyes behold my son no more;
if, on thy next offence, this hand forbear

you stark naked, and whip you out of the assembly till you go

to strip those arms thou ill deserv’st to wear,
expel the council where our princes meet,

blubbering back to the ships.

and send thee scourged and howling through the fleet.

”

”

on this he beat him with his staff about the back and shoulders

he said, and cowering as the dastard bends,
the weighty sceptre on his back descends.

till he dropped and fell a-weeping.

the golden sceptre raised a

on the round bunch the bloody tumours rise:

the tears spring starting from his haggard eyes;
trembling he sat, and shrunk in abject fears,

looking foolish as he wiped the tears from his eyes.

from his vile visage wiped the scalding tears;
while to his neighbour each express’d his thought:

the people

“ye gods!

was a fine plane-tree from beneath which there welled a stream of

a mighty dragon shot, of dire portent;

then we saw a prodigy; for jove sent a fearful

serpent out of the ground, with blood-red stains upon its back,
and it darted from under the altar on to the plane-tree.

straight to the tree his sanguine spires he roll’d,

now

and curl’d around in many a winding fold;

there was a brood of young sparrows, quite small, upon the

the topmost branch a mother-bird possess’d;

topmost bough, peeping out from under the leaves, eight in all,
and their mother that hatched them made nine.

eight callow infants fill’d the mossy nest;

the serpent ate the

herself the ninth; the serpent, as he hung,

poor cheeping things, while the old bird flew about lamenting her

while hovering near, with miserable moan,

her by the wing as she was screaming.

the mother last, as round the nest she flew,

then, when he had eaten

nor long survived: to marble turn’d, he stands

a lasting prodigy on aulis’ sands.

stone, and we stood there wondering at that which had come to
