pass.

trust in his omen, and support the war.

seeing, then, that such a fearful portent had broken in

for while around we gazed with wondering eyes,
and trembling sought the powers with sacrifice,

upon our hecatombs, calchas forthwith declared to us the oracles

full of his god, the reverend chalcas cried,[90]

of heaven.

‘ye grecian warriors!

‘why, achaeans,’ said he, ‘are you thus speechless?

lay your fears aside.

jove has sent us this sign, long in coming, and long ere it be

this wondrous signal jove himself displays,

fulfilled, though its fame shall last for ever.

of long, long labours, but eternal praise.

as the serpent
ate the eight fledglings and the sparrow that hatched them, which

as many birds as by the snake were slain,

makes nine, so shall we fight nine years at troy, but in the

so many years the toils of greece remain;

tenth shall take the town.

but wait the tenth, for ilion’s fall decreed:’

’ this was what he said, and now it is

thus spoke the prophet, thus the fates succeed.

all coming true.

obey, ye grecians!

stay here, therefore, all of you, till we take

with submission wait,

the city of priam.

nor let your flight avert the trojan fate.

”

”

on this the argives raised a shout, till the ships rang again

he said: the shores with loud applauses sound,

with the uproar.

the hollow ships each deafening shout rebound.

nestor, knight of gerene, then addressed them.

then nestor thus—“these vain debates forbear,

“shame on you,” he cried, “to stay talking here like children,
when you should fight like men.

ye talk like children, not like heroes dare.

where are our covenants now, and

where now are all your high resolves at last?

where the oaths that we have taken?

your leagues concluded, your engagements past?

shall our counsels be flung
into the fire, with our drink-offerings and the right hands of

vow’d with libations and with victims then,

fellowship wherein we have put our trust?

now vanish’d like their smoke: the faith of men!

we waste our time in

while useless words consume the unactive hours,

words, and for all our talking here shall be no further forward.

no wonder troy so long resists our powers.

stand, therefore, son of atreus, by your own steadfast purpose;

rise, great atrides!

lead the argives on to battle, and leave this handful of men to

and with courage sway;
we march to war, if thou direct the way.
but leave the few that dare resist thy laws,

rot, who scheme, and scheme in vain, to get back to argos ere

the mean deserters of the grecian cause,

they have learned whether jove be true or a liar.
for the mighty

to grudge the conquests mighty jove prepares,

son of saturn surely promised that we should succeed, when we

and view with envy our successful wars.
on that great day, when first the martial train,

argives set sail to bring death and destruction upon the trojans.

big with the fate of ilion, plough’d the main,

he showed us favourable signs by flashing his lightning on our

jove, on the right, a prosperous signal sent,
and thunder rolling shook the firmament.

right hands; therefore let none make haste to go till he has

encouraged hence, maintain the glorious strife,

first lain with the wife of some trojan, and avenged the toil and

till every soldier grasp a phrygian wife,

sorrow that he has suffered for the sake of helen.

till helen’s woes at full revenged appear,
and troy’s proud matrons render tear for tear.

nevertheless,

before that day, if any greek invite

if any man is in such haste to be at home again, let him lay his

his country’s troops to base, inglorious flight,
stand forth that greek!

hand to his ship that he may meet his doom in the sight of all.

and hoist his sail to fly,
and die the dastard first, who dreads to die.

but, o king, consider and give ear to my counsel, for the word

but now, o monarch!
all thy chiefs advise:[91]

that i say may not be neglected lightly.

nor what they offer, thou thyself despise.
among those counsels, let not mine be vain;

divide your men,

in tribes and nations to divide thy train:

agamemnon, into their several tribes and clans, that clans and

his separate troops let every leader call,

tribes may stand by and help one another.

each strengthen each, and all encourage all.

if you do this, and if

what chief, or soldier, of the numerous band,

the achaeans obey you, you will find out who, both chiefs and

or bravely fights, or ill obeys command,

peoples, are brave, and who are cowards; for they will vie

when thus distinct they war, shall soon be known

against the other.

and what the cause of ilion not o’erthrown;

thus you shall also learn whether it is

if fate resists, or if our arms are slow,

through the counsel of heaven or the cowardice of man that you
shall fail to take the town.

if gods above prevent, or men below.

”

”

and agamemnon answered, “nestor, you have again outdone the sons

to him the king: “how much thy years excel

of the achaeans in counsel.

in arts of counsel, and in speaking well!

would, by father jove, minerva, and

o would the gods, in love to greece, decree

apollo, that i had among them ten more such councillors, for the

but ten such sages as they grant in thee;

city of king priam would then soon fall beneath our hands, and we

such wisdom soon should priam’s force destroy,

should sack it.

and soon should fall the haughty towers of troy!

but the son of saturn afflicts me with bootless

but jove forbids, who plunges those he hates

wranglings and strife.

in fierce contention and in vain debates:

achilles and i are quarrelling about this

now great achilles from our aid withdraws,

girl, in which matter i was the first to offend; if we can be of

by me provoked; a captive maid the cause:

one mind again, the trojans will not stave off destruction for a

if e’er as friends we join, the trojan wall

day.

must shake, and heavy will the vengeance fall!

now, therefore, get your morning meal, that our hosts join

but now, ye warriors, take a short repast;

in fight.

and, well refresh’d, to bloody conflict haste.

whet well your spears; see well to the ordering of your

his sharpen’d spear let every grecian wield,

shields; give good feeds to your horses, and look your chariots

and every grecian fix his brazen shield,

carefully over, that we may do battle the livelong day; for we

let all excite the fiery steeds of war,
and all for combat fit the rattling car.
this day, this dreadful day, let each contend;

shall have no rest, not for a moment, till night falls to part

no rest, no respite, till the shades descend;
till darkness, or till death, shall cover all:

us.

let the war bleed, and let the mighty fall;

the bands that bear your shields shall be wet with the sweat

till bathed in sweat be every manly breast,

upon your shoulders, your hands shall weary upon your spears,

with the huge shield each brawny arm depress’d,
each aching nerve refuse the lance to throw,

your horses shall steam in front of your chariots, and if i see

and each spent courser at the chariot blow.

any man shirking the fight, or trying to keep out of it at the

who dares, inglorious, in his ships to stay,
who dares to tremble on this signal day;

ships, there shall be no help for him, but he shall be a prey to

that wretch, too mean to fall by martial power,

dogs and vultures.

the birds shall mangle, and the dogs devour.

”

”

thus he spoke, and the achaeans roared applause.

the monarch spoke; and straight a murmur rose,

as when the
waves run high before the blast of the south wind and break on

loud as the surges when the tempest blows,

some lofty headland, dashing against it and buffeting it without

that dash’d on broken rocks tumultuous roar,

ceasing, as the storms from every quarter drive them, even so did

and foam and thunder on the stony shore.

the achaeans rise and hurry in all directions to their ships.

straight to the tents the troops dispersing bend,

there they lighted their fires at their tents and got dinner,

the fires are kindled, and the smokes ascend;

offering sacrifice every man to one or other of the gods, and
praying each one of them that he might live to come out of the

with hasty feasts they sacrifice, and pray,

fight.

to avert the dangers of the doubtful day.

agamemnon, king of men, sacrificed a fat five-year-old

a steer of five years’ age, large limb’d, and fed,[92]

bull to the mighty son of saturn, and invited the princes and

to jove’s high altars agamemnon led:

elders of his host.

there bade the noblest of the grecian peers;

first he asked nestor and king idomeneus,

and nestor first, as most advanced in years.

then the two ajaxes and the son of tydeus, and sixthly ulysses,

next came idomeneus,[93] and tydeus’ son,[94]
ajax the less, and ajax telamon;[95]

peer of gods in counsel; but menelaus came of his own accord, for

then wise ulysses in his rank was placed;

he knew how busy his brother then was.

and menelaus came, unbid, the last.

they stood round the bull

[96]

with the barley-meal in their hands, and agamemnon prayed,

the chiefs surround the destined beast, and take
the sacred offering of the salted cake:
when thus the king prefers his solemn prayer;

saying, “jove, most glorious, supreme, that dwellest in heaven,

“o thou!
whose thunder rends the clouded air,
who in the heaven of heavens hast fixed thy throne,
supreme of gods!

and ridest upon the storm-cloud, grant that the sun may not go

unbounded, and alone!
hear!
and before the burning sun descends,

down, nor the night fall, till the palace of priam is laid low,

before the night her gloomy veil extends,
low in the dust be laid yon hostile spires,

and its gates are consumed with fire.

be priam’s palace sunk in grecian fires.

grant that my sword may
pierce the shirt of hector about his heart, and that full many of

in hector’s breast be plunged this shining sword,

his comrades may bite the dust as they fall dying round him.

and slaughter’d heroes groan around their lord!

”

”

thus he prayed, but the son of saturn would not fulfil his
prayer.

thus prayed the chief: his unavailing prayer

he accepted the sacrifice, yet none the less increased

great jove refused, and toss’d in empty air:
the god averse, while yet the fumes arose,

their toil continually.

prepared new toils, and doubled woes on woes.

when they had done praying and sprinkling

their prayers perform’d the chiefs the rite pursue,

the barley-meal upon the victim, they drew back its head, killed
it, and then flayed it.

the barley sprinkled, and the victim slew.

they cut out the thigh-bones, wrapped

the limbs they sever from the inclosing hide,
the thighs, selected to the gods, divide.

them round in two layers of fat, and set pieces of raw meat on

on these, in double cauls involved with art,

the top of them.

the choicest morsels lie from every part,

these they burned upon the split logs of
firewood, but they spitted the inward meats, and held them in the

from the cleft wood the crackling flames aspire

flames to cook.

while the fat victims feed the sacred fire.

when the thigh-bones were burned, and they had
tasted the inward meats, they cut the rest up small, put the

the thighs thus sacrificed, and entrails dress’d

pieces upon spits, roasted them till they were done, and drew

the assistants part, transfix, and roast the rest;

them off; then, when they had finished their work and the feast

then spread the tables, the repast prepare,

was ready, they ate it, and every man had his full share, so that
all were satisfied.

each takes his seat, and each receives his share.

as soon as they had had enough to eat and

soon as the rage of hunger was suppress’d,

drink, nestor, knight of gerene, began to speak.
“king

the generous nestor thus the prince address’d.

agamemnon,” said he, “let us not stay talking here, nor be slack

“now bid thy heralds sound the loud alarms,

in the work that heaven has put into our hands.
let the heralds

and call the squadrons sheathed in brazen arms;

summon the people to gather at their several ships; we will then

now seize the occasion, now the troops survey,

go about among the host, that we may begin fighting at once.

and lead to war when heaven directs the way.

”

”

thus did he speak, and agamemnon heeded his words.
he at once

he said; the monarch issued his commands;

sent the criers round to call the people in assembly.

straight the loud heralds call the gathering bands;

so they
called them, and the people gathered thereon.
the chiefs about

the chiefs inclose their king; the hosts divide,

the son of atreus chose their men and marshalled them, while

in tribes and nations rank’d on either side.

minerva went among them holding her priceless aegis that knows

high in the midst the blue-eyed virgin flies;
from rank to rank she darts her ardent eyes;

neither age nor death.

the dreadful ægis, jove’s immortal shield,

from it there waved a hundred tassels of

blazed on her arm, and lighten’d all the field:
round the vast orb a hundred serpents roll’d,

pure gold, all deftly woven, and each one of them worth a hundred
oxen.

form’d the bright fringe, and seem’d to burn in gold,

with this she darted furiously everywhere among the hosts

with this each grecian’s manly breast she warms,

of the achaeans, urging them forward, and putting courage into
the heart of each, so that he might fight and do battle without

swells their bold hearts, and strings their nervous arms,

ceasing.
thus war became sweeter in their eyes even than

no more they sigh, inglorious, to return,

returning home in their ships.

but breathe revenge, and for the combat burn.

as when some great forest fire is

as on some mountain, through the lofty grove,
the crackling flames ascend, and blaze above;
the fires expanding, as the winds arise,

raging upon a mountain top and its light is seen afar, even so as

shoot their long beams, and kindle half the skies:

they marched the gleam of their armour flashed up into the

so from the polish’d arms, and brazen shields,

firmament of heaven.

a gleamy splendour flash’d along the fields.

they were like great flocks of geese, or cranes, or swans on the

not less their number than the embodied cranes,
or milk-white swans in asius’ watery plains.

plain about the waters of cayster, that wing their way hither and

that, o’er the windings of cayster’s springs,[97]
stretch their long necks, and clap their rustling wings,

thither, glorying in the pride of flight, and crying as they

now tower aloft, and course in airy rounds,

settle till the fen is alive with their screaming.

now light with noise; with noise the field resounds.

even thus did

thus numerous and confused, extending wide,

their tribes pour from ships and tents on to the plain of the

the legions crowd scamander’s flowery side;[98]

scamander, and the ground rang as brass under the feet of men and

with rushing troops the plains are cover’d o’er,

horses.

and thundering footsteps shake the sounding shore.

they stood as thick upon the flower-bespangled field as

along the river’s level meads they stand,
thick as in spring the flowers adorn the land,

leaves that bloom in summer.

or leaves the trees; or thick as insects play,
the wandering nation of a summer’s day:

as countless swarms of flies buzz around a herdsman’s homestead

that, drawn by milky steams, at evening hours,
in gather’d swarms surround the rural bowers;
from pail to pail with busy murmur run

in the time of spring when the pails are drenched with milk, even

the gilded legions, glittering in the sun.

so did the achaeans swarm on to the plain to charge the trojans

so throng’d, so close, the grecian squadrons stood

and destroy them.

in radiant arms, and thirst for trojan blood.

the chiefs disposed their men this way and that before the fight

each leader now his scatter’d force conjoins

began, drafting them out as easily as goatherds draft their

in close array, and forms the deepening lines.
not with more ease the skilful shepherd-swain

flocks when they have got mixed while feeding; and among them

collects his flocks from thousands on the plain.

went king agamemnon, with a head and face like jove the lord of

the king of kings, majestically tall,
towers o’er his armies, and outshines them all;
like some proud bull, that round the pastures leads
his subject herds, the monarch of the meads,
great as the gods, the exalted chief was seen,
his strength like neptune, and like mars his mien;[99]
jove o’er his eyes celestial glories spread,
and dawning conquest played around his head.
say, virgins, seated round the throne divine,

thunder, a waist like mars, and a chest like that of neptune.

all-knowing goddesses!

as

immortal nine!
[100]

some great bull that lords it over the herds upon the plain, even

since earth’s wide regions, heaven’s umneasur’d height,

so did jove make the son of atreus stand peerless among the

and hell’s abyss, hide nothing from your sight,

multitude of heroes.

(we, wretched mortals!

and now, o muses, dwellers in the mansions of olympus, tell

lost in doubts below,

me—for you are goddesses and are in all places so that you see
all things, while we know nothing but by report—who were the

but guess by rumour, and but boast we know,)

chiefs and princes of the danaans?

o say what heroes, fired by thirst of fame,

as for the common soldiers,

or urged by wrongs, to troy’s destruction came.

they were so that i could not name every single one of them
though i had ten tongues, and though my voice failed not and my

to count them all, demands a thousand tongues,

heart were of bronze within me, unless you, o olympian muses,

a throat of brass, and adamantine lungs.

daughters of aegis-bearing jove, were to recount them to me.

daughters of jove, assist!
inspired by you
the mighty labour dauntless i pursue;
what crowded armies, from what climes they bring,

nevertheless, i will tell the captains of the ships and all the

their names, their numbers, and their chiefs i sing.

fleet together.

a little man, and his breastplate was made of linen, but in use

skill’d to direct the flying dart aright;

of the spear he excelled all the hellenes and the achaeans.

swift in pursuit, and active in the fight.

these

(athens the fair, where great erectheus sway’d,

high on the deck the king of men appears,

himself, all glorious in his armour of gleaming bronze—foremost

and his refulgent arms in triumph wears;

among the heroes, for he was the greatest king, and had most men

proud of his host, unrivall’d in his reign,

under him.

in silent pomp he moves along the main.

and those that dwelt in lacedaemon, lying low among the hills,

his brother follows, and to vengeance warms

from the others.

eager and loud from man to man he flies,

among them went menelaus himself, strong in

revenge and fury flaming in his eyes;

zeal, urging his men to fight; for he longed to avenge the toil

while vainly fond, in fancy oft he hears

and sorrow that he had suffered for the sake of helen.

the fair one’s grief, and sees her falling tears.

the men of pylos and arene, and thryum where is the ford of the

in ninety sail, from pylos’ sandy coast,
nestor the sage conducts his chosen host:
from amphigenia’s ever-fruitful land,
where æpy high, and little pteleon stand;
where beauteous arene her structures shows,

river alpheus; strong aipy, cyparisseis, and amphigenea; pteleum,

and thryon’s walls alpheus’ streams inclose:

helos, and dorium, where the muses met thamyris, and stilled his

and dorion, famed for thamyris’ disgrace,

minstrelsy for ever.

superior once of all the tuneful race,

he was returning from oechalia, where
eurytus lived and reigned, and boasted that he would surpass even
the muses, daughters of aegis-bearing jove, if they should sing

till, vain of mortals’ empty praise, he strove

against him; whereon they were angry, and maimed him.

to match the seed of cloud-compelling jove!

they robbed

too daring bard!
whose unsuccessful pride
the immortal muses in their art defied.
the avenging muses of the light of day

him of his divine power of song, and thenceforth he could strike

deprived his eyes, and snatch’d his voice away;
no more his heavenly voice was heard to sing,

the lyre no more.

his hand no more awaked the silver string.

these were commanded by nestor, knight of
gerene, and with him there came ninety ships.
and those that held arcadia, under the high mountain of cyllene,

where under high cyllenè, crown’d with wood,

near the tomb of aepytus, where the people fight hand to hand;

the shaded tomb of old æpytus stood;
from ripè, stratie, tegea’s bordering towns,

many arcadians, good

(ancæus’ son) the mighty squadron led.
their ships, supplied by agamemnon’s care,

ships in which to cross the sea, for they were not a people that

through roaring seas the wondering warriors bear;
the first to battle on the appointed plain,

occupied their business upon the waters.

but new to all the dangers of the main.

the men, moreover, of buprasium and of elis, so much of it as is

thus marched the host like a consuming fire, and the earth

now, like a deluge, covering all around,
the shining armies sweep along the ground;
swift as a flood of fire, when storms arise,
floats the wild field, and blazes to the skies.

groaned beneath them when the lord of thunder is angry and lashes

the unwelcome message to the phrygian king.
“cease to consult, the time for action calls;

of peace, while war is at hand.

war, horrid war, approaches to your walls!

i have been in many a battle, but

assembled armies oft have i beheld;

never yet saw such a host as is now advancing.

but ne’er till now such numbers charged a field:

they are crossing
the plain to attack the city as thick as leaves or as the sands

thick as autumnal leaves or driving sand,

of the sea.

the moving squadrons blacken all the strand.

hector, i charge you above all others, do as i say.

thou, godlike hector!

nastes led the carians, men of a strange speech.

miletus and the wooded mountain of phthires, with the water of

and proud miletus, came the carian throngs,

the river maeander and the lofty crests of mt.

with mingled clamours and with barbarous tongues.

mycale.
these were

[107]

commanded by nastes and amphimachus, the brave sons of nomion.

amphimachus and naustes guide the train,

he

naustes the bold, amphimachus the vain,

came into the fight with gold about him, like a girl; fool that

who, trick’d with gold, and glittering on his car,
rode like a woman to the field of war.

he was, his gold was of no avail to save him, for he fell in the

fool that he was!

river by the hand of the fleet descendant of aeacus, and achilles

by fierce achilles slain,
the river swept him to the briny main:
there whelm’d with waves the gaudy warrior lies

bore away his gold.

the valiant victor seized the golden prize.

sarpedon and glaucus led the lycians from their distant land, by

the forces last in fair array succeed,
which blameless glaucus and sarpedon lead
the warlike bands that distant lycia yields,

the eddying waters of the xanthus.

where gulfy xanthus foams along the fields.

book iii.

book iii.
argument.

alexandria, also called paris, challenges menelaus—helen and

the duel of menelaus and paris.

priam view the achaeans from the wall—the covenant—paris and

the armies being ready to engage, a single combat is agreed upon
between menelaus and paris (by the intervention of hector) for the
determination of the war.
iris is sent to call helen to behold the
fight.
she leads her to the walls of troy, where priam sat with his
counsellers observing the grecian leaders on the plain below, to whom
helen gives an account of the chief of them.
the kings on either part

menelaus fight, and paris is worsted—venus carries him off to

take the solemn oath for the conditions of the combat.
the duel ensues;
wherein paris being overcome, he is snatched away in a cloud by venus,

save him—scene between him and helen.

and transported to his apartment.
she then calls helen from the walls,
and brings the lovers together.
agamemnon, on the part of the grecians,
demands the restoration of helen, and the performance of the articles.
the three-and-twentieth day still continues throughout this book.
the scene is sometimes in the fields before troy, and sometimes in

when the companies were thus arrayed, each under its own captain,

troy itself.
thus by their leaders’ care each martial band

the trojans advanced as a flight of wild-fowl or cranes that

moves into ranks, and stretches o’er the land.
with shouts the trojans, rushing from afar,

scream overhead when rain and winter drive them over the flowing

proclaim their motions, and provoke the war.
so when inclement winters vex the plain
with piercing frosts, or thick-descending rain,

waters of oceanus to bring death and destruction on the pygmies,

to warmer seas the cranes embodied fly,[108]

and they wrangle in the air as they fly; but the achaeans marched

with noise, and order, through the midway sky;
to pigmy nations wounds and death they bring,
and all the war descends upon the wing,

silently, in high heart, and minded to stand by one another.

but silent, breathing rage, resolved and skill’d[109]

as when the south wind spreads a curtain of mist upon the

by mutual aids to fix a doubtful field,
swift march the greeks: the rapid dust around
darkening arises from the labour’d ground.
thus from his flaggy wings when notus sheds

mountain tops, bad for shepherds but better than night for

a night of vapours round the mountain heads,
swift-gliding mists the dusky fields invade,
to thieves more grateful than the midnight shade;
while scarce the swains their feeding flocks survey,

thieves, and a man can see no further than he can throw a stone,

lost and confused amidst the thicken’d day:

even so rose the dust from under their feet as they made all

so wrapp’d in gathering dust, the grecian train,

speed over the plain.

a moving cloud, swept on, and hid the plain.

when they were close up with one another, alexandrus came forward

now front to front the hostile armies stand,
eager of fight, and only wait command;
when, to the van, before the sons of fame
whom troy sent forth, the beauteous paris came:

as champion on the trojan side.

in form a god!

on his shoulders he bore the skin

the panther’s speckled hide
flow’d o’er his armour with an easy pride:
his bended bow across his shoulders flung,

of a panther, his bow, and his sword, and he brandished two

his sword beside him negligently hung;

spears shod with bronze as a challenge to the bravest of the

two pointed spears he shook with gallant grace,

achaeans to meet him in single fight.

and dared the bravest of the grecian race.

menelaus saw him thus

as thus, with glorious air and proud disdain,
he boldly stalk’d, the foremost on the plain,
him menelaus, loved of mars, espies,
with heart elated, and with joyful eyes:

stride out before the ranks, and was glad as a hungry lion that

so joys a lion, if the branching deer,

lights on the carcase of some goat or horned stag, and devours it

or mountain goat, his bulky prize, appear;
eager he seizes and devours the slain,

there and then, though dogs and youths set upon him.

press’d by bold youths and baying dogs in vain.

even thus
was menelaus glad when his eyes caught sight of alexandrus, for
he deemed that now he should be revenged.
he sprang, therefore,

thus fond of vengeance, with a furious bound,

from his chariot, clad in his suit of armour.

in clanging arms he leaps upon the ground
from his high chariot: him, approaching near,

alexandrus quailed as he saw menelaus come forward, and shrank in

the beauteous champion views with marks of fear,
smit with a conscious sense, retires behind,

fear of his life under cover of his men.

and shuns the fate he well deserved to find.

as one who starts back

as when some shepherd, from the rustling trees[110]

affrighted, trembling and pale, when he comes suddenly upon a

shot forth to view, a scaly serpent sees,
trembling and pale, he starts with wild affright

serpent in some mountain glade, even so did alexandrus plunge

and all confused precipitates his flight:

into the throng of trojan warriors, terror-stricken at the sight

so from the king the shining warrior flies,
and plunged amid the thickest trojans lies.

of the son of atreus.

as godlike hector sees the prince retreat,

then hector upbraided him.

he thus upbraids him with a generous heat:

“paris,” said he, “evil-hearted paris,

“unhappy paris!

fair to see, but woman-mad, and false of tongue, would that you

[111] but to women brave!
so fairly form’d, and only to deceive!

had never been born, or that you had died unwed.

oh, hadst thou died when first thou saw’st the light,
or died at least before thy nuptial rite!

better so, than

a better fate than vainly thus to boast,

live to be disgraced and looked askance at.

and fly, the scandal of thy trojan host.

will not the achaeans

gods!
how the scornful greeks exult to see
their fears of danger undeceived in thee!

mock at us and say that we have sent one to champion us who is

thy figure promised with a martial air,

fair to see but who has neither wit nor courage?

but ill thy soul supplies a form so fair.

did you not,

in former days, in all thy gallant pride,

such as you are, get your following together and sail beyond the

when thy tall ships triumphant stemm’d the tide,
when greece beheld thy painted canvas flow,

seas?

and crowds stood wondering at the passing show,

did you not from your a far country carry off a lovely

say, was it thus, with such a baffled mien,

woman wedded among a people of warriors—to bring sorrow upon your

you met the approaches of the spartan queen,

father, your city, and your whole country, but joy to your

thus from her realm convey’d the beauteous prize,

enemies, and hang-dog shamefacedness to yourself?

and both her warlike lords outshined in helen’s eyes?
this deed, thy foes’ delight, thy own disgrace,

and now can you

thy father’s grief, and ruin of thy race;

not dare face menelaus and learn what manner of man he is whose

this deed recalls thee to the proffer’d fight;

wife you have stolen?

or hast thou injured whom thou dar’st not right?

where indeed would be your lyre and your

soon to thy cost the field would make thee know
thou keep’st the consort of a braver foe.

love-tricks, your comely locks and your fair favour, when you

thy graceful form instilling soft desire,
thy curling tresses, and thy silver lyre,
beauty and youth; in vain to these you trust,

were lying in the dust before him?

when youth and beauty shall be laid in dust:

the trojans are a weak-kneed
people, or ere this you would have had a shirt of stones for the

troy yet may wake, and one avenging blow

wrongs you have done them.

crush the dire author of his country’s woe.

”

”

and alexandrus answered, “hector, your rebuke is just.

his silence here, with blushes, paris breaks:
“’tis just, my brother, what your anger speaks:

you are

but who like thee can boast a soul sedate,

hard as the axe which a shipwright wields at his work, and

so firmly proof to all the shocks of fate?
thy force, like steel, a temper’d hardness shows,
still edged to wound, and still untired with blows,
like steel, uplifted by some strenuous swain,

cleaves the timber to his liking.
as the axe in his hand, so keen

with falling woods to strew the wasted plain.

is the edge of your scorn.
still, taunt me not with the gifts

thy gifts i praise; nor thou despise the charms

that golden venus has given me; they are precious; let not a man

with which a lover golden venus arms;

disdain them, for the gods give them where they are minded, and

soft moving speech, and pleasing outward show,

none can have them for the asking.

no wish can gain them, but the gods bestow.

if you would have me do battle

yet, would’st thou have the proffer’d combat stand,

with menelaus, bid the trojans and achaeans take their seats,

the greeks and trojans seat on either hand;
then let a midway space our hosts divide,
and, on that stage of war, the cause be tried:
by paris there the spartan king be fought,

while he and i fight in their midst for helen and all her wealth.

for beauteous helen and the wealth she brought;

let him who shall be victorious and prove to be the better man

and who his rival can in arms subdue,

take the woman and all she has, to bear them to his home, but let

his be the fair, and his the treasure too.

the rest swear to a solemn covenant of peace whereby you trojans

thus with a lasting league your toils may cease,
and troy possess her fertile fields in peace;

shall stay here in troy, while the others go home to argos and

thus may the greeks review their native shore,

the land of the achaeans.

much famed for generous steeds, for beauty more.

”

”
he said.

when hector heard this he was glad, and went about among the

the challenge hector heard with joy,

trojan ranks holding his spear by the middle to keep them back,

then with his spear restrain’d the youth of troy,
held by the midst, athwart; and near the foe

and they all sat down at his bidding: but the achaeans still

advanced with steps majestically slow:

aimed at him with stones and arrows, till agamemnon shouted to

while round his dauntless head the grecians pour
their stones and arrows in a mingled shower.

them saying, “hold, argives, shoot not, sons of the achaeans;

then thus the monarch, great atrides, cried:
“forbear, ye warriors!
lay the darts aside:

hector desires to speak.

a parley hector asks, a message bears;
we know him by the various plume he wears.

”

”

they ceased taking aim and were still, whereon hector spoke.

awed by his high command the greeks attend,
the tumult silence, and the fight suspend.
while from the centre hector rolls his eyes

“hear from my mouth,” said he, “trojans and achaeans, the saying

on either host, and thus to both applies:
“hear, all ye trojan, all ye grecian bands,

of alexandrus, through whom this quarrel has come about.

what paris, author of the war, demands.

he bids

your shining swords within the sheath restrain,

the trojans and achaeans lay their armour upon the ground, while

and pitch your lances in the yielding plain.

he and menelaus fight in the midst of you for helen and all her

here in the midst, in either army’s sight,
he dares the spartan king to single fight;
and wills that helen and the ravish’d spoil,

wealth.

that caused the contest, shall reward the toil.

let him who shall be victorious and prove to be the
better man take the woman and all she has, to bear them to his

let these the brave triumphant victor grace,

own home, but let the rest swear to a solemn covenant of peace.

and different nations part in leagues of peace.

”

”

thus he spoke, and they all held their peace, till menelaus of

he spoke: in still suspense on either side

the loud battle-cry addressed them.

each army stood: the spartan chief replied:

“and now,” he said, “hear me

“me too, ye warriors, hear, whose fatal right

too, for it is i who am the most aggrieved.

a world engages in the toils of fight.

i deem that the
parting of achaeans and trojans is at hand, as well it may be,

to me the labour of the field resign;

seeing how much have suffered for my quarrel with alexandrus and
the wrong he did me.

me paris injured; all the war be mine.

let him who shall die, die, and let the

fall he that must, beneath his rival’s arms;

others fight no more.

and live the rest, secure of future harms.

bring, then, two lambs, a white ram and a

two lambs, devoted by your country’s rite,

black ewe, for earth and sun, and we will bring a third for jove.

to earth a sable, to the sun a white,
prepare, ye trojans!
while a third we bring
select to jove, the inviolable king.

moreover, you shall bid priam come, that he may swear to the

let reverend priam in the truce engage,
and add the sanction of considerate age;

covenant himself; for his sons are high-handed and ill to trust,

his sons are faithless, headlong in debate,

and the oaths of jove must not be transgressed or taken in vain.

and youth itself an empty wavering state;

young men’s minds are light as air, but when an old man comes he

cool age advances, venerably wise,

looks before and after, deeming that which shall be fairest upon

turns on all hands its deep-discerning eyes;
sees what befell, and what may yet befall,

both sides.
”

concludes from both, and best provides for all.

the trojans and achaeans were glad when they heard this, for they

the nations hear with rising hopes possess’d,

thought that they should now have rest.

and peaceful prospects dawn in every breast.

they backed their

within the lines they drew their steeds around,

and from their chariots issued on the ground;
next, all unbuckling the rich mail they wore,

armour, laying it down upon the ground; and the hosts were near

laid their bright arms along the sable shore.

to one another with a little space between them.

on either side the meeting hosts are seen
with lances fix’d, and close the space between.

hector sent two

ships, and he did as agamemnon had said.

the lamb for jove, the inviolable king.

meanwhile iris went to helen in the form of her sister-in-law,

wife of the son of antenor, for helicaon, son of antenor, had

the various goddess of the rainbow flies:

married laodice, the fairest of priam’s daughters.

(like fair laodice in form and face,
the loveliest nymph of priam’s royal race:)

she found her

her in the palace, at her loom she found;

in her own room, working at a great web of purple linen, on which

the golden web her own sad story crown’d,

she was embroidering the battles between trojans and achaeans,

the trojan wars she weaved (herself the prize)

that mars had made them fight for her sake.

and the dire triumphs of her fatal eyes.

iris then came close

to whom the goddess of the painted bow:

up to her and said, “come hither, child, and see the strange
doings of the trojans and achaeans.

“approach, and view the wondrous scene below!

till now they have been

[112]

warring upon the plain, mad with lust of battle, but now they

each hardy greek, and valiant trojan knight,
so dreadful late, and furious for the fight,

have left off fighting, and are leaning upon their shields,

now rest their spears, or lean upon their shields;

sitting still with their spears planted beside them.

ceased is the war, and silent all the fields.

alexandrus

paris alone and sparta’s king advance,

and menelaus are going to fight about yourself, and you are to be

in single fight to toss the beamy lance;
each met in arms, the fate of combat tries,

the wife of him who is the victor.

thy love the motive, and thy charms the prize.

”

”

thus spoke the goddess, and helen’s heart yearned after her

this said, the many-coloured maid inspires

former husband, her city, and her parents.

her husband’s love, and wakes her former fires;
her country, parents, all that once were dear,

she threw a white

rush to her thought, and force a tender tear,
o’er her fair face a snowy veil she threw,

mantle over her head, and hurried from her room, weeping as she

and, softly sighing, from the loom withdrew.

went, not alone, but attended by two of her handmaids, aethrae,
daughter of pittheus, and clymene.
and straightway they were at

her handmaids, clymene and æthra, wait

the scaean gates.

her silent footsteps to the scæan gate.

the two sages, ucalegon and antenor, elders of the people, were

there sat the seniors of the trojan race:
(old priam’s chiefs, and most in priam’s grace,)

seated by the scaean gates, with priam, panthous, thymoetes,

the king the first; thymœtes at his side;

lampus, clytius, and hiketaon of the race of mars.

lampus and clytius, long in council tried;
panthus, and hicetaon, once the strong;

these were too

and next, the wisest of the reverend throng,

old to fight, but they were fluent orators, and sat on the tower

antenor grave, and sage ucalegon,
lean’d on the walls and bask’d before the sun:
chiefs, who no more in bloody fights engage,
but wise through time, and narrative with age,

like cicales that chirrup delicately from the boughs of some high

in summer days, like grasshoppers rejoice,

tree in a wood.

a bloodless race, that send a feeble voice.

when they saw helen coming towards the tower,

these, when the spartan queen approach’d the tower,

they said softly to one another, “small wonder that trojans and

in secret own’d resistless beauty’s power:
they cried, “no wonder[113] such celestial charms

achaeans should endure so much and so long, for the sake of a

for nine long years have set the world in arms;

woman so marvellously and divinely lovely.

what winning graces!
what majestic mien!
she moves a goddess, and she looks a queen!

still, fair though she
be, let them take her and go, or she will breed sorrow for us and

yet hence, o heaven, convey that fatal face,

for our children after us.

and from destruction save the trojan race.

”

”

but priam bade her draw nigh.

the good old priam welcomed her, and cried,

“my child,” said he, “take your

“approach, my child, and grace thy father’s side.

seat in front of me that you may see your former husband, your

see on the plain thy grecian spouse appears,

kinsmen and your friends.

the friends and kindred of thy former years.

i lay no blame upon you, it is the

no crime of thine our present sufferings draws,

gods, not you who are to blame.

not thou, but heaven’s disposing will, the cause

it is they that have brought

the gods these armies and this force employ,

about this terrible war with the achaeans.

the hostile gods conspire the fate of troy.

tell me, then, who is

but lift thy eyes, and say, what greek is he
(far as from hence these aged orbs can see)
around whose brow such martial graces shine,

yonder huge hero so great and goodly?

so tall, so awful, and almost divine!

i have seen men taller by a

though some of larger stature tread the green,

head, but none so comely and so royal.

none match his grandeur and exalted mien:

surely he must be a king.

he seems a monarch, and his country’s pride.

”

”

“sir,” answered helen, “father of my husband, dear and reverend

thus ceased the king, and thus the fair replied:
“before thy presence, father, i appear,
with conscious shame and reverential fear.
ah!

in my eyes, would that i had chosen death rather than to have

had i died, ere to these walls i fled,
false to my country, and my nuptial bed;

come here with your son, far from my bridal chamber, my friends,
my darling daughter, and all the companions of my girlhood.

my brothers, friends, and daughter left behind,

but

false to them all, to paris only kind!

it was not to be, and my lot is one of tears and sorrow.
as for

for this i mourn, till grief or dire disease

your question, the hero of whom you ask is agamemnon, son of

shall waste the form whose fault it was to please!

atreus, a good king and a brave soldier, brother-in-law as surely

the king of kings, atrides, you survey,
great in the war, and great in arts of sway:

as that he lives, to my abhorred and miserable self.

my brother once, before my days of shame!

”

and oh!
that still he bore a brother’s name!
”

the old man marvelled at him and said, “happy son of atreus,

with wonder priam view’d the godlike man,
extoll’d the happy prince, and thus began:

child of good fortune.

“o bless’d atrides!
born to prosperous fate,
successful monarch of a mighty state!

i see that the achaeans are subject to you

how vast thy empire!
of your matchless train

in great multitudes.

what numbers lost, what numbers yet remain!

when i was in phrygia i saw much horsemen,

in phrygia once were gallant armies known,
in ancient time, when otreus fill’d the throne,
when godlike mygdon led their troops of horse,

the people of otreus and of mygdon, who were camping upon the

and i, to join them, raised the trojan force:
against the manlike amazons we stood,[114]

banks of the river sangarius; i was their ally, and with them

and sangar’s stream ran purple with their blood.

when the amazons, peers of men, came up against them, but even

but far inferior those, in martial grace,

they were not so many as the achaeans.

and strength of numbers, to this grecian race.

”

”

the old man next looked upon ulysses; “tell me,” he said, “who is

this said, once more he view’d the warrior train;
“what’s he, whose arms lie scatter’d on the plain?

that other, shorter by a head than agamemnon, but broader across

broad is his breast, his shoulders larger spread,
though great atrides overtops his head.

the chest and shoulders?

nor yet appear his care and conduct small;

his armour is laid upon the ground, and

from rank to rank he moves, and orders all.
the stately ram thus measures o’er the ground,

he stalks in front of the ranks as it were some great woolly ram
ordering his ewes.

and, master of the flock, surveys them round.

”

”

and helen answered, “he is ulysses, a man of great craft, son of

then helen thus: “whom your discerning eyes

laertes.

have singled out, is ithacus the wise;

he was born in rugged ithaca, and excels in all manner

a barren island boasts his glorious birth;

of stratagems and subtle cunning.

his fame for wisdom fills the spacious earth.

”

”

on this antenor said, “madam, you have spoken truly.

antenor took the word, and thus began:[115]
“myself, o king!

ulysses once

have seen that wondrous man
when, trusting jove and hospitable laws,

came here as envoy about yourself, and menelaus with him.

to troy he came, to plead the grecian cause;

i

(great menelaus urged the same request;)

received them in my own house, and therefore know both of them by

my house was honour’d with each royal guest:
i knew their persons, and admired their parts,

sight and conversation.

both brave in arms, and both approved in arts.

when they stood up in presence of the

erect, the spartan most engaged our view;

assembled trojans, menelaus was the broader shouldered, but when
both were seated ulysses had the more royal presence.

ulysses seated, greater reverence drew.

after a

when atreus’ son harangued the listening train,

time they delivered their message, and the speech of menelaus ran

just was his sense, and his expression plain,

trippingly on the tongue; he did not say much, for he was a man
of few words, but he spoke very clearly and to the point, though

his words succinct, yet full, without a fault;

he was the younger man of the two; ulysses, on the other hand,

he spoke no more than just the thing he ought.

when he rose to speak, was at first silent and kept his eyes

but when ulysses rose, in thought profound,[116]

fixed upon the ground.

his modest eyes he fix’d upon the ground;

there was no play nor graceful movement of
his sceptre; he kept it straight and stiff like a man unpractised
in oratory—one might have taken him for a mere churl or

as one unskill’d or dumb, he seem’d to stand,

simpleton; but when he raised his voice, and the words came

nor raised his head, nor stretch’d his sceptred hand;
but, when he speaks, what elocution flows!

driving from his deep chest like winter snow before the wind,

soft as the fleeces of descending snows,[117]
the copious accents fall, with easy art;
melting they fall, and sink into the heart!

then there was none to touch him, and no man thought further of

wondering we hear, and fix’d in deep surprise,

what he looked like.

our ears refute the censure of our eyes.

”

”

priam then caught sight of ajax and asked, “who is that great and

the king then ask’d (as yet the camp he view’d)
“what chief is that, with giant strength endued,

goodly warrior whose head and broad shoulders tower above the

whose brawny shoulders, and whose swelling chest,

rest of the argives?

and lofty stature, far exceed the rest?
“ajax the great, (the beauteous queen replied,)
himself a host: the grecian strength and pride.

”

see!

“that,” answered helen, “is huge ajax, bulwark of the achaeans,

bold idomeneus superior towers

and on the other side of him, among the cretans, stands idomeneus

amid yon circle of his cretan powers,

looking like a god, and with the captains of the cretans round

great as a god!

him.
often did menelaus receive him as a guest in our house when

i saw him once before,

he came visiting us from crete.

with menelaus on the spartan shore.

i see, moreover, many other

the rest i know, and could in order name;

achaeans whose names i could tell you, but there are two whom i

all valiant chiefs, and men of mighty fame.
yet two are wanting of the numerous train,
whom long my eyes have sought, but sought in vain:

can nowhere find, castor, breaker of horses, and pollux the

castor and pollux, first in martial force,
one bold on foot, and one renown’d for horse.

mighty boxer; they are children of my mother, and own brothers to

my brothers these; the same our native shore,

myself.

one house contain’d us, as one mother bore.

either they have not left lacedaemon, or else, though

perhaps the chiefs, from warlike toils at ease,

they have brought their ships, they will not show themselves in

for distant troy refused to sail the seas;

battle for the shame and disgrace that i have brought upon them.

perhaps their swords some nobler quarrel draws,
ashamed to combat in their sister’s cause.

”

”

with him who is the victor.

and who his rival shall in arms subdue,
his be the dame, and his the treasure too.

we are to swear to a solemn covenant

and troy possess her fertile fields in peace:

so shall the greeks review their native shore,
much famed for generous steeds, for beauty more.

”

”

“o first and greatest power!

“ye greeks and trojans, let the chiefs engage,

city of ilius: i dare not with my own eyes witness this fight

but spare the weakness of my feeble age:
in yonder walls that object let me shun,

between my son and menelaus, for jove and the other immortals

nor view the danger of so dear a son.
whose arms shall conquer and what prince shall fall,

alone know which shall fall.

heaven only knows; for heaven disposes all.

”

”

on this he laid the two lambs on his chariot and took his seat.

this said, the hoary king no longer stay’d,
but on his car the slaughter’d victims laid:

he gathered the reins in his hand, and antenor sat beside him;

then seized the reins his gentle steeds to guide,

the two then went back to ilius.

”

with these words she moved the heart of helen to anger.

she spoke, and helen’s secret soul was moved;
she scorn’d the champion, but the man she loved.
fair venus’ neck, her eyes that sparkled fire,
and breast, reveal’d the queen of soft desire.

when she

you thus beguile me?

“then is it still thy pleasure to deceive?

are you going to send me afield still

and woman’s frailty always to believe!
say, to new nations must i cross the main,

further to some man whom you have taken up in phrygia or fair

or carry wars to some soft asian plain?
for whom must helen break her second vow?

meonia?

what other paris is thy darling now?

menelaus has just vanquished alexandrus, and is to take

left to atrides, (victor in the strife,)

my hateful self back with him.

an odious conquest and a captive wife,

you are come here to betray me.

hence let me sail; and if thy paris bear

go

my absence ill, let venus ease his care.

sit with alexandrus yourself; henceforth be goddess no longer;

a handmaid goddess at his side to wait,
renounce the glories of thy heavenly state,

never let your feet carry you back to olympus; worry about him

be fix’d for ever to the trojan shore,

and look after him till he make you his wife, or, for the matter

his spouse, or slave; and mount the skies no more.

of that, his slave—but me?

for me, to lawless love no longer led,

i shall not go; i can garnish his bed

i scorn the coward, and detest his bed;

no longer; i should be a by-word among all the women of troy.

else should i merit everlasting shame,
and keen reproach, from every phrygian dame:
ill suits it now the joys of love to know,

besides, i have trouble on my mind.

too deep my anguish, and too wild my woe.

”

”

venus was very angry, and said, “bold hussy, do not provoke me;

with sparta’s king to meet in single fray:

”

”

and paris answered, “wife, do not vex me with your reproaches.

the prince replies: “ah cease, divinely fair,

this time, with the help of minerva, menelaus has vanquished me;

nor add reproaches to the wounds i bear;
this day the foe prevail’d by pallas’ power:

another time i may myself be victor, for i too have gods that

we yet may vanquish in a happier hour:

will stand by me.

there want not gods to favour us above;

come, let us lie down together and make

friends.

book iv.

book iv.
argument.

a quarrel in olympus—minerva goes down and persuades fandarus to

the breach of the truce, and the first battle.
the gods deliberate in council concerning the trojan war: they agree
upon the continuation of it, and jupiter sends down minerva to break

violate the oaths by wounding menelaus with an arrow—agamemnon

the truce.
she persuades pandarus to aim an arrow at menelaus, who is
wounded, but cured by machaon.
in the meantime some of the trojan
troops attack the greeks.

makes a speech and sends for machaon—he then goes about among his

agamemnon is distinguished in all the parts

captains and upbraids ulysses and sthenelus, who each of them

of a good general; he reviews the troops, and exhorts the leaders, some

retort fiercely—diomed checks sthenelus, and the two hosts then

by praises and others by reproof.
nestor is particularly celebrated for

engage, with great slaughter on either side.

his military discipline.
the battle joins, and great numbers are slain
on both sides.
the same day continues through this as through the last book (as it
does also through the two following, and almost to the end of the
seventh book).
the scene is wholly in the field before troy.

now the gods were sitting with jove in council upon the golden

and now olympus’ shining gates unfold;
the gods, with jove, assume their thrones of gold:
immortal hebe, fresh with bloom divine,
the golden goblet crowns with purple wine:

floor while hebe went round pouring out nectar for them to drink,

while the full bowls flow round, the powers employ

and as they pledged one another in their cups of gold they looked
down upon the town of troy.

their careful eyes on long-contended troy.

the son of saturn then began to tease

when jove, disposed to tempt saturnia’s spleen,

juno, talking at her so as to provoke her.

thus waked the fury of his partial queen,

“menelaus,” said he,

“two powers divine the son of atreus aid,

“has two good friends among the goddesses, juno of argos, and

imperial juno, and the martial maid;[125]

minerva of alalcomene, but they only sit still and look on, while

but high in heaven they sit, and gaze from far,

venus keeps ever by alexandrus’ side to defend him in any danger;

the tame spectators of his deeds of war.
not thus fair venus helps her favour’d knight,
the queen of pleasures shares the toils of fight,
each danger wards, and constant in her care,

indeed she has just rescued him when he made sure that it was all

saves in the moment of the last despair.
her act has rescued paris’ forfeit life,

over with him—for the victory really did lie with menelaus.

though great atrides gain’d the glorious strife.
then say, ye powers!

we

what signal issue waits

must consider what we shall do about all this; shall we set them

to crown this deed, and finish all the fates!

fighting anew or make peace between them?

shall heaven by peace the bleeding kingdoms spare,
or rouse the furies, and awake the war?

if you will agree to

yet, would the gods for human good provide,

this last menelaus can take back helen and the city of priam may

atrides soon might gain his beauteous bride,

remain still inhabited.

still priam’s walls in peaceful honours grow,
and through his gates the crowding nations flow.

”

”

minerva and juno muttered their discontent as they sat side by

thus while he spoke, the queen of heaven, enraged,
and queen of war, in close consult engaged:
apart they sit, their deep designs employ,

side hatching mischief for the trojans.

and meditate the future woes of troy.

minerva scowled at her

though secret anger swell’d minerva’s breast,
the prudent goddess yet her wrath suppress’d;

father, for she was in a furious passion with him, and said

but juno, impotent of passion, broke

nothing, but juno could not contain herself.

her sullen silence, and with fury spoke:

“dread son of

[illustration: ] the council of the gods

saturn,” said she, “what, pray, is the meaning of all this?

“shall then, o tyrant of the ethereal reign!

is my

my schemes, my labours, and my hopes be vain?

trouble, then, to go for nothing, and the sweat that i have

have i, for this, shook ilion with alarms,

sweated, to say nothing of my horses, while getting the people

assembled nations, set two worlds in arms?
to spread the war, i flew from shore to shore;
the immortal coursers scarce the labour bore.
at length ripe vengeance o’er their heads impends,

together against priam and his children?

but jove himself the faithless race defends.

do as you will, but we

loth as thou art to punish lawless lust,

other gods shall not all of us approve your counsel.

not all the gods are partial and unjust.

”

”

jove was angry and answered, “my dear, what harm have priam and

the sire whose thunder shakes the cloudy skies,
sighs from his inmost soul, and thus replies:
“oh lasting rancour!
oh insatiate hate
to phrygia’s monarch, and the phrygian state!
what high offence has fired the wife of jove?
can wretched mortals harm the powers above,

his sons done you that you are so hotly bent on sacking the city

that troy, and troy’s whole race thou wouldst confound,

of ilius?

and yon fair structures level with the ground!

will nothing do for you but you must go within their walls

haste, leave the skies, fulfil thy stern desire,

and eat priam raw, with his sons and all the other trojans to

burst all her gates, and wrap her walls in fire!

boot?

let priam bleed!

have it your own way then; for i would not have this matter

if yet you thirst for more,

become a bone of contention between us.

bleed all his sons, and ilion float with gore:
to boundless vengeance the wide realm be given,
till vast destruction glut the queen of heaven!

i say further, and lay my

so let it be, and jove his peace enjoy,[126]

saying to your heart, if ever i want to sack a city belonging to

when heaven no longer hears the name of troy.
but should this arm prepare to wreak our hate
on thy loved realms, whose guilt demands their fate;

friends of yours, you must not try to stop me; you will have to

presume not thou the lifted bolt to stay,

let me do it, for i am giving in to you sorely against my will.

remember troy, and give the vengeance way.

of all inhabited cities under the sun and stars of heaven, there

for know, of all the numerous towns that rise
beneath the rolling sun and starry skies,
which gods have raised, or earth-born men enjoy,

was none that i so much respected as ilius with priam and his

none stands so dear to jove as sacred troy.
no mortals merit more distinguish’d grace

whole people.

than godlike priam, or than priam’s race.

equitable feasts were never wanting about my altar,

still to our name their hecatombs expire,

nor the savour of burning fat, which is honour due to ourselves.

and altars blaze with unextinguish’d fire.

”

”

“my own three favourite cities,” answered juno, “are argos,

at this the goddess rolled her radiant eyes,
then on the thunderer fix’d them, and replies:
“three towns are juno’s on the grecian plains,
more dear than all the extended earth contains,

sparta, and mycenae.

mycenæ, argos, and the spartan wall;[127]

sack them whenever you may be displeased
with them.

these thou mayst raze, nor i forbid their fall:

i shall not defend them and i shall not care.

’tis not in me the vengeance to remove;

even if

the crime’s sufficient that they share my love.

i did, and tried to stay you, i should take nothing by it, for

of power superior why should i complain?

you are much stronger than i am, but i will not have my own work

resent i may, but must resent in vain.

wasted.

yet some distinction juno might require,

i too am a god and of the same race with yourself.

sprung with thyself from one celestial sire,

i am

a goddess born, to share the realms above,

saturn’s eldest daughter, and am honourable not on this ground

and styled the consort of the thundering jove;

only, but also because i am your wife, and you are king over the
gods.

nor thou a wife and sister’s right deny;[128]

let it be a case, then, of give-and-take between us, and

let both consent, and both by terms comply;

the rest of the gods will follow our lead.

so shall the gods our joint decrees obey,
and heaven shall act as we direct the way.

tell minerva to go and

see ready pallas waits thy high commands

take part in the fight at once, and let her contrive that the

to raise in arms the greek and phrygian bands;
their sudden friendship by her arts may cease,

trojans shall be the first to break their oaths and set upon the

and the proud trojans first infringe the peace.

achaeans.
”

”

the sire of gods and men heeded her words, and said to minerva,

the sire of men and monarch of the sky

“go at once into the trojan and achaean hosts, and contrive that

the advice approved, and bade minerva fly,

the trojans shall be the first to break their oaths and set upon

dissolve the league, and all her arts employ

the achaeans.
”

to make the breach the faithless act of troy.

this was what minerva was already eager to do, so down she darted

fired with the charge, she headlong urged her flight,

from the topmost summits of olympus.

and shot like lightning from olympus’ height.

she shot through the sky as
some brilliant meteor which the son of scheming saturn has sent

as the red comet, from saturnius sent

as a sign to mariners or to some great army, and a fiery train of

to fright the nations with a dire portent,
(a fatal sign to armies on the plain,
or trembling sailors on the wintry main,)
with sweeping glories glides along in air,

light follows in its wake.

and shakes the sparkles from its blazing hair:[129]
between both armies thus, in open sight
shot the bright goddess in a trail of light,

the trojans and achaeans were struck

with eyes erect the gazing hosts admire
the power descending, and the heavens on fire!

with awe as they beheld, and one would turn to his neighbour,

“the gods (they cried), the gods this signal sent,
and fate now labours with some vast event:

saying, “either we shall again have war and din of combat, or

jove seals the league, or bloodier scenes prepares;

jove the lord of battle will now make peace between us.

jove, the great arbiter of peace and wars.

”

”

thus did they converse.

they said, while pallas through the trojan throng,

then minerva took the form of laodocus,

(in shape a mortal,) pass’d disguised along.
like bold laodocus, her course she bent,

son of antenor, and went through the ranks of the trojans to find

who from antenor traced his high descent.

a mountain goat resign’d the shining spoil.

when

the folds it pierced, the plaited linen tore,

and razed the skin, and drew the purple gore.

as down thy snowy thigh distill’d the streaming flood.

when king agamemnon saw the blood flowing from the wound he was

with horror seized, the king of men descried

afraid, and so was brave menelaus himself till he saw that the

the shaft infix’d, and saw the gushing tide:
nor less the spartan fear’d, before he found

the shining barb appear above the wound,

then he took heart, but

then, with a sigh, that heaved his manly breast,

agamemnon heaved a deep sigh as he held menelaus’s hand in his

the royal brother thus his grief express’d,
and grasp’d his hand; while all the greeks around

own, and his comrades made moan in concert.

“dear brother,” he

“oh, dear as life!

cried, “i have been the death of you in pledging this covenant

did i for this agree
the solemn truce, a fatal truce to thee!
wert thou exposed to all the hostile train,

and letting you come forward as our champion.

to fight for greece, and conquer, to be slain!

the trojans have

the race of trojans in thy ruin join,

trampled on their oaths and have wounded you; nevertheless the

and faith is scorn’d by all the perjured line.

oath, the blood of lambs, the drink-offerings and the right hands

not thus our vows, confirm’d with wine and gore,
those hands we plighted, and those oaths we swore,

of fellowship in which we have put our trust shall not be vain.

shall all be vain: when heaven’s revenge is slow,

if he that rules olympus fulfil it not here and now, he will yet

jove but prepares to strike the fiercer blow.

fulfil it hereafter, and they shall pay dearly with their lives

the day shall come, that great avenging day,
when troy’s proud glories in the dust shall lay,
when priam’s powers and priam’s self shall fall,

and with their wives and children.

and one prodigious ruin swallow all.

the day will surely come when

i see the god, already, from the pole

mighty ilius shall be laid low, with priam and priam’s people,

bare his red arm, and bid the thunder roll;

when the son of saturn from his high throne shall overshadow them

i see the eternal all his fury shed,

with his awful aegis in punishment of their present treachery.

and shake his ægis o’er their guilty head.
such mighty woes on perjured princes wait;

this shall surely be; but how, menelaus, shall i mourn you, if it

but thou, alas!

be your lot now to die?

deserv’st a happier fate.
still must i mourn the period of thy days,
and only mourn, without my share of praise?

i should return to argos as a by-word,

deprived of thee, the heartless greeks no more

for the achaeans will at once go home.

shall dream of conquests on the hostile shore;

we shall leave priam and
the trojans the glory of still keeping helen, and the earth will

troy seized of helen, and our glory lost,

rot your bones as you lie here at troy with your purpose not

thy bones shall moulder on a foreign coast;

fulfilled.

while some proud trojan thus insulting cries,

then shall some braggart trojan leap upon your tomb

(and spurns the dust where menelaus lies,)

and say, ‘ever thus may agamemnon wreak his vengeance; he brought

his army in vain; he is gone home to his own land with empty

and such the conquest of her king of kings!

ships, and has left menelaus behind him.

oh!

say, and may the earth then swallow me.

ere that dire disgrace shall blast my fame,
o’erwhelm me, earth!
and hide a monarch’s shame.

”

the feeble dart is guiltless of my fate:

for my outer belt of burnished metal first stayed it, and under

stiff with the rich embroider’d work around,

me.

aesculapius out of the good will he bore him.

while round the prince the greeks employ their care,

the trojans rush tumultuous to the war;

forward against them, for they had put on their armour, and now

once more they glitter in refulgent arms,

renewed the fight.

once more the fields are fill’d with dire alarms.

you would not have then found agamemnon asleep nor cowardly and

nor had you seen the king of men appear

unwilling to fight, but eager rather for the fray.

confused, unactive, or surprised with fear;
but fond of glory, with severe delight,
his beating bosom claim’d the rising fight.

he left his

no longer with his warlike steeds he stay’d,

hold them in readiness against the time his limbs should weary of

the fiery coursers snorted at his side.

going about and giving orders to so many, for he went among the
ranks on foot.
when he saw men hasting to the front he stood by

on foot through all the martial ranks he moves

them and cheered them on.

and these encourages, and those reproves.

“argives,” said he, “slacken not one

“brave men!

whit in your onset; father jove will be no helper of liars; the

” he cries, (to such who boldly dare

trojans have been the first to break their oaths and to attack

urge their swift steeds to face the coming war),

us; therefore they shall be devoured of vultures; we shall take

“your ancient valour on the foes approve;
jove is with greece, and let us trust in jove.
’tis not for us, but guilty troy, to dread,
whose crimes sit heavy on her perjured head;

their city and carry off their wives and children in our ships.

her sons and matrons greece shall lead in chains,
and her dead warriors strew the mournful plains.

”

”

but he angrily rebuked those whom he saw shirking and disinclined

thus with new ardour he the brave inspires;

to fight.

or thus the fearful with reproaches fires:

“argives,” he cried, “cowardly miserable creatures,

“shame to your country, scandal of your kind;

have you no shame to stand here like frightened fawns who, when

born to the fate ye well deserve to find!

they can no longer scud over the plain, huddle together, but show

why stand ye gazing round the dreadful plain,

no fight?

prepared for flight, but doom’d to fly in vain?

you are as dazed and spiritless as deer.

confused and panting thus, the hunted deer
falls as he flies, a victim to his fear.

would you wait

still must ye wait the foes, and still retire,

till the trojans reach the sterns of our ships as they lie on the

till yon tall vessels blaze with trojan fire?

shore, to see whether the son of saturn will hold his hand over

or trust ye, jove a valiant foe shall chase,

you to protect you?

to save a trembling, heartless, dastard race?

”

”

thus did he go about giving his orders among the ranks.
passing

this said, he stalk’d with ample strides along,

through the crowd, he came presently on the cretans, arming round

to crete’s brave monarch and his martial throng;

idomeneus, who was at their head, fierce as a wild boar, while

high at their head he saw the chief appear,

meriones was bringing up the battalions that were in the rear.

and bold meriones excite the rear.

agamemnon was glad when he saw him, and spoke him fairly.

at this the king his generous joy express’d,
and clasp’d the warrior to his armed breast.

“idomeneus,” said he, “i treat you with greater distinction than

“divine idomeneus!

i do any others of the achaeans, whether in war or in other

what thanks we owe

things, or at table.

to worth like thine!
what praise shall we bestow?

when the princes are mixing my choicest

to thee the foremost honours are decreed,

wines in the mixing-bowls, they have each of them a fixed

first in the fight and every graceful deed.
for this, in banquets, when the generous bowls
restore our blood, and raise the warriors’ souls,

allowance, but your cup is kept always full like my own, that you

though all the rest with stated rules we bound,

may drink whenever you are minded.

unmix’d, unmeasured, are thy goblets crown’d.

go, therefore, into battle,

be still thyself, in arms a mighty name;

and show yourself the man you have been always proud to be.

maintain thy honours, and enlarge thy fame.

”

”

idomeneus answered, “i will be a trusty comrade, as i promised

to whom the cretan thus his speech address’d:

you from the first i would be.

“secure of me, o king!

urge on the other achaeans, that

exhort the rest.
fix’d to thy side, in every toil i share,

we may join battle at once, for the trojans have trampled upon

thy firm associate in the day of war.
but let the signal be this moment given;

their covenants.

to mix in fight is all i ask of heaven.

death and destruction shall be theirs, seeing

the field shall prove how perjuries succeed,

they have been the first to break their oaths and to attack us.

and chains or death avenge the impious deed.

”

”

the son of atreus went on, glad at heart, till he came upon the

charm’d with this heat, the king his course pursues,

two ajaxes arming themselves amid a host of foot soldiers.

and next the troops of either ajax views:
in one firm orb the bands were ranged around,
a cloud of heroes blacken’d all the ground.

as

thus from the lofty promontory’s brow

when a goat-herd from some high post watches a storm drive over

a swain surveys the gathering storm below;
slow from the main the heavy vapours rise,

the deep before the west wind—black as pitch is the offing and a

spread in dim streams, and sail along the skies,
till black as night the swelling tempest shows,
the cloud condensing as the west-wind blows:

mighty whirlwind draws towards him, so that he is afraid and

he dreads the impending storm, and drives his flock

drives his flock into a cave—even thus did the ranks of stalwart

to the close covert of an arching rock.

youths move in a dark mass to battle under the ajaxes, horrid

such, and so thick, the embattled squadrons stood,

with shield and spear.

with spears erect, a moving iron wood:
a shady light was shot from glimmering shields,

glad was king agamemnon when he saw them.

and their brown arms obscured the dusky fields.

“no need,” he cried, “to give orders to such leaders of the

“o heroes!

argives as you are, for of your own selves you spur your men on

worthy such a dauntless train,
whose godlike virtue we but urge in vain,
(exclaim’d the king), who raise your eager bands

to fight with might and main.

with great examples, more than loud commands.

would, by father jove, minerva, and

ah!
would the gods but breathe in all the rest

apollo that all were so minded as you are, for the city of priam

such souls as burn in your exalted breast,

would then soon fall beneath our hands, and we should sack it.

soon should our arms with just success be crown’d,
and troy’s proud walls lie smoking on the ground.

”

”

with this he left them and went onward to nestor, the facile

then to the next the general bends his course;

speaker of the pylians, who was marshalling his men and urging

(his heart exults, and glories in his force);
there reverend nestor ranks his pylian bands,
and with inspiring eloquence commands;
with strictest order sets his train in arms,
the chiefs advises, and the soldiers warms.

them on, in company with pelagon, alastor, chromius, haemon, and

alastor, chromius, haemon, round him wait,

bias shepherd of his people.

bias the good, and pelagon the great.

he placed his knights with their
chariots and horses in the front rank, while the foot soldiers,

the horse and chariots to the front assign’d,

brave men and many, whom he could trust, were in the rear.

the foot (the strength of war) he ranged behind;

the
cowards he drove into the middle, that they might fight whether

the middle space suspected troops supply,

they would or no.

inclosed by both, nor left the power to fly;

he gave his orders to the knights first,
bidding them hold their horses well in hand, so as to avoid

he gives command to “curb the fiery steed,

confusion.
“let no man,” he said, “relying on his strength or

nor cause confusion, nor the ranks exceed:
