before the rest let none too rashly ride;

trojans, nor yet let him lag behind or you will weaken your

no strength nor skill, but just in time, be tried:

attack; but let each when he meets an enemy’s chariot throw his

the charge once made, no warrior turn the rein,
but fight, or fall; a firm embodied train.
he whom the fortune of the field shall cast
from forth his chariot, mount the next in haste;
nor seek unpractised to direct the car,
content with javelins to provoke the war.

spear from his own; this be much the best; this is how the men of

our great forefathers held this prudent course,

old took towns and strongholds; in this wise were they minded.

thus ruled their ardour, thus preserved their force;
by laws like these immortal conquests made,
and earth’s proud tyrants low in ashes laid.

”

”

thus did the old man charge them, for he had been in many a

so spoke the master of the martial art,

fight, and king agamemnon was glad.

and touch’d with transport great atrides’ heart.

“i wish,” he said to him,

“oh!

“that your limbs were as supple and your strength as sure as your

hadst thou strength to match thy brave desires,
and nerves to second what thy soul inspires!

judgment is; but age, the common enemy of mankind, has laid his

but wasting years, that wither human race,

hand upon you; would that it had fallen upon some other, and that

exhaust thy spirits, and thy arms unbrace.
what once thou wert, oh ever mightst thou be!

you were still young.

and age the lot of any chief but thee.

”

”

and nestor, knight of gerene, answered, “son of atreus, i too

thus to the experienced prince atrides cried;
he shook his hoary locks, and thus replied:

would gladly be the man i was when i slew mighty ereuthalion; but

“well might i wish, could mortal wish renew[134]
that strength which once in boiling youth i knew;
such as i was, when ereuthalion, slain
beneath this arm, fell prostrate on the plain.

the gods will not give us everything at one and the same time.

but heaven its gifts not all at once bestows,

i

these years with wisdom crowns, with action those:

was then young, and now i am old; still i can go with my knights

the field of combat fits the young and bold,

and give them that counsel which old men have a right to give.

the solemn council best becomes the old:

the wielding of the spear i leave to those who are younger and

to you the glorious conflict i resign,

stronger than myself.

let sage advice, the palm of age, be mine.

”

”
he said.

agamemnon went his way rejoicing, and presently found menestheus,

with joy the monarch march’d before,

son of peteos, tarrying in his place, and with him were the

and found menestheus on the dusty shore,

athenians loud of tongue in battle.

with whom the firm athenian phalanx stands;

near him also tarried cunning

and next ulysses, with his subject bands.

ulysses, with his sturdy cephallenians round him; they had not

remote their forces lay, nor knew so far

yet heard the battle-cry, for the ranks of trojans and achaeans

the peace infringed, nor heard the sounds of war;

had only just begun to move, so they were standing still, waiting
for some other columns of the achaeans to attack the trojans and

the tumult late begun, they stood intent

begin the fighting.

to watch the motion, dubious of the event.

when he saw this agamemnon rebuked them and

the king, who saw their squadrons yet unmoved,
with hasty ardour thus the chiefs reproved:

said, “son of peteos, and you other, steeped in cunning, heart of

“can peleus’ son forget a warrior’s part.
and fears ulysses, skill’d in every art?

guile, why stand you here cowering and waiting on others?

why stand you distant, and the rest expect
to mix in combat which yourselves neglect?

you two

from you ’twas hoped among the first to dare

should be of all men foremost when there is hard fighting to be

the shock of armies, and commence the war;

done, for you are ever foremost to accept my invitation when we

for this your names are call’d before the rest,

councillors of the achaeans are holding feast.
you are glad

to share the pleasures of the genial feast:

enough then to take your fill of roast meats and to drink wine as

and can you, chiefs!

long as you please, whereas now you would not care though you saw

without a blush survey

ten columns of achaeans engage the enemy in front of you.

whole troops before you labouring in the fray?
say, is it thus those honours you requite?
the first in banquets, but the last in fight.

”

”

ulysses glared at him and answered, “son of atreus, what are you

ulysses heard: the hero’s warmth o’erspread
his cheek with blushes: and severe, he said:

talking about?

“take back the unjust reproach!

how can you say that we are slack?
when the

behold we stand

achaeans are in full fight with the trojans, you shall see, if

sheathed in bright arms, and but expect command.
if glorious deeds afford thy soul delight,
behold me plunging in the thickest fight.

you care to do so, that the father of telemachus will join battle

then give thy warrior-chief a warrior’s due,

with the foremost of them.

who dares to act whate’er thou dar’st to view.

you are talking idly.
”

”

when agamemnon saw that ulysses was angry, he smiled pleasantly

struck with his generous wrath, the king replies:

at him and withdrew his words.

“o great in action, and in council wise!

“ulysses,” said he, “noble son of

with ours, thy care and ardour are the same,

laertes, excellent in all good counsel, i have neither fault to

nor need i to commend, nor aught to blame.

find nor orders to give you, for i know your heart is right, and

sage as thou art, and learn’d in human kind,

that you and i are of a mind.

forgive the transport of a martial mind.

enough; i will make you amends for

haste to the fight, secure of just amends;

what i have said, and if any ill has now been spoken may the gods

the gods that make, shall keep the worthy, friends.

bring it to nothing.
”

”

he then left them and went on to others.

he said, and pass’d where great tydides lay,
his steeds and chariots wedged in firm array;

presently he saw the son

(the warlike sthenelus attends his side;)[135]

of tydeus, noble diomed, standing by his chariot and horses, with

sthenelus the son of capaneus beside him; whereon he began to

“o son of tydeus!

upbraid him.

(he, whose strength could tame

“son of tydeus,” he said, “why stand you cowering

the bounding steed, in arms a mighty name)
canst thou, remote, the mingling hosts descry,

here upon the brink of battle?

with hands unactive, and a careless eye?

tydeus did not shrink thus, but

not thus thy sire the fierce encounter fear’d;

was ever ahead of his men when leading them on against the

still first in front the matchless prince appear’d:

foe—so, at least, say they that saw him in battle, for i never

what glorious toils, what wonders they recite,

set eyes upon him myself.
they say that there was no man like

who view’d him labouring through the ranks of fight?

him.

i saw him once, when gathering martial powers,

he came once to mycenae, not as an enemy but as a guest, in

a peaceful guest, he sought mycenæ’s towers;

company with polynices to recruit his forces, for they were
levying war against the strong city of thebes, and prayed our
people for a body of picked men to help them.
the men of mycenae

armies he ask’d, and armies had been given,

were willing to let them have one, but jove dissuaded them by

not we denied, but jove forbade from heaven;

showing them unfavourable omens.

while dreadful comets glaring from afar,

tydeus, therefore, and polynices

forewarn’d the horrors of the theban war.

went their way.

[136]

when they had got as far the deep-meadowed and
rush-grown banks of the aesopus, the achaeans sent tydeus as

next, sent by greece from where asopus flows,

their envoy, and he found the cadmeans gathered in great numbers

a fearless envoy, he approach’d the foes;
thebes’ hostile walls unguarded and alone,

to a banquet in the house of eteocles.

dauntless he enters, and demands the throne.

stranger though he was, he
knew no fear on finding himself single-handed among so many, but

the tyrant feasting with his chiefs he found,

challenged them to contests of all kinds, and in each one of them

and dared to combat all those chiefs around:
dared, and subdued before their haughty lord;

was at once victorious, so mightily did minerva help him.

for pallas strung his arm and edged his sword.

the

stung with the shame, within the winding way,

cadmeans were incensed at his success, and set a force of fifty

to bar his passage fifty warriors lay;

youths with two captains—the godlike hero maeon, son of haemon,

two heroes led the secret squadron on,

and polyphontes, son of autophonus—at their head, to lie in wait

mason the fierce, and hardy lycophon;

for him on his return journey; but tydeus slew every man of them,

those fifty slaughter’d in the gloomy vale.

save only maeon, whom he let go in obedience to heaven’s omens.

he spared but one to bear the dreadful tale,

such was tydeus of aetolia.

such tydeus was, and such his martial fire;

his son can talk more glibly, but he

gods!

cannot fight as his father did.

how the son degenerates from the sire!

”

”

diomed made no answer, for he was shamed by the rebuke of

no words the godlike diomed return’d,

agamemnon; but the son of capaneus took up his words and said,

but heard respectful, and in secret burn’d:
not so fierce capaneus’ undaunted son;
stern as his sire, the boaster thus begun:

“son of atreus, tell no lies, for you can speak truth if you

“what needs, o monarch!
this invidious praise,
ourselves to lessen, while our sire you raise?
dare to be just, atrides!

will.

and confess

we boast ourselves as even better men than our fathers; we

our value equal, though our fury less.

took seven-gated thebes, though the wall was stronger and our men

with fewer troops we storm’d the theban wall,

were fewer in number, for we trusted in the omens of the gods and

and happier saw the sevenfold city fall,[137]

in the help of jove, whereas they perished through their own

in impious acts the guilty father died;
the sons subdued, for heaven was on their side.

sheer folly; hold not, then, our fathers in like honour with us.

far more than heirs of all our parents’ fame,
our glories darken their diminish’d name.

”

”

diomed looked sternly at him and said, “hold your peace, my
friend, as i bid you.

to him tydides thus: “my friend, forbear;

it is not amiss that agamemnon should urge

suppress thy passion, and the king revere:

the achaeans forward, for the glory will be his if we take the

his high concern may well excuse this rage,
whose cause we follow, and whose war we wage:
his the first praise, were ilion’s towers o’erthrown,

city, and his the shame if we are vanquished.

and, if we fail, the chief disgrace his own.

therefore let us

let him the greeks to hardy toils excite,

acquit ourselves with valour.

’tis ours to labour in the glorious fight.

”

”

as he spoke he sprang from his chariot, and his armour rang so

he spoke, and ardent, on the trembling ground
sprung from his car: his ringing arms resound.

fiercely about his body that even a brave man might well have

dire was the clang, and dreadful from afar,

been scared to hear it.

of arm’d tydides rushing to the war.

as when some mighty wave that thunders on the beach when the west
wind has lashed it into fury—it has reared its head afar and now

as when the winds, ascending by degrees,[138]

comes crashing down on the shore; it bows its arching crest high

first move the whitening surface of the seas,
the billows float in order to the shore,
the wave behind rolls on the wave before;
till, with the growing storm, the deeps arise,

over the jagged rocks and spews its salt foam in all

foam o’er the rocks, and thunder to the skies.

directions—even so did the serried phalanxes of the danaans march

so to the fight the thick battalions throng,
shields urged on shields, and men drove men along

steadfastly to battle.

sedate and silent move the numerous bands;

the chiefs gave orders each to his own

no sound, no whisper, but the chief’s commands,

people, but the men said never a word; no man would think it, for

those only heard; with awe the rest obey,

huge as the host was, it seemed as though there was not a tongue

as if some god had snatch’d their voice away.

among them, so silent were they in their obedience; and as they

not so the trojans; from their host ascends

marched the armour about their bodies glistened in the sun.

a general shout that all the region rends.

but
the clamour of the trojan ranks was as that of many thousand ewes

as when the fleecy flocks unnumber’d stand

that stand waiting to be milked in the yards of some rich

in wealthy folds, and wait the milker’s hand,

flock-master, and bleat incessantly in answer to the bleating of

the hollow vales incessant bleating fills,

their lambs; for they had not one speech nor language, but their

the lambs reply from all the neighbouring hills:

tongues were diverse, and they came from many different places.

such clamours rose from various nations round,
mix’d was the murmur, and confused the sound.

these were inspired of mars, but the others by minerva—and with

each host now joins, and each a god inspires,
these mars incites, and those minerva fires,

them came panic, rout, and strife whose fury never tires, sister

pale flight around, and dreadful terror reign;
and discord raging bathes the purple plain;
discord!

and friend of murderous mars, who, from being at first but low in

dire sister of the slaughtering power,

stature, grows till she uprears her head to heaven, though her

small at her birth, but rising every hour,
while scarce the skies her horrid head can bound,

feet are still on earth.

she stalks on earth, and shakes the world around;[139]

she it was that went about among them

the nations bleed, where’er her steps she turns,

and flung down discord to the waxing of sorrow with even hand

the groan still deepens, and the combat burns.

between them.

the bossed

the sounding darts in iron tempests flew,

great multitude—death-cry and shout of triumph of slain and

and shrilling shouts and dying groans arise;

slayers, and the earth ran red with blood.

with streaming blood the slippery fields are dyed,
and slaughter’d heroes swell the dreadful tide.

as torrents swollen

as torrents roll, increased by numerous rills,

with rage impetuous, down their echoing hills

hosts as they joined in battle.

shines forth reveal’d, and animates the fight.

“trojans, be bold, and force with force oppose;

be thus beaten by the argives.

your foaming steeds urge headlong on the foes!

their skins are not stone nor iron

nor are their bodies rocks, nor ribb’d with steel;

that when you hit them you do them no harm.

your weapons enter, and your strokes they feel.

he that hurled

had come from aenus; the bones and both the tendons were crushed

by the pitiless stone.

and spreads for aid his unavailing hands.

him, pulled the spear out of his chest, and then drawing his

the corpse now breathless on the bloody plain,

he did not strip him of his armour, for his thracian comrades,

to spoil his arms the victor strove in vain;

men who wear their hair in a tuft at the top of their heads,

the thracian bands against the victor press’d,

a grove of lances glitter’d at his breast.

all his great stature and valour; so he was driven back.

stern thoas, glaring with revengeful eyes,

thus the

two corpses lay stretched on earth near to one another, the one

thus fell two heroes; one the pride of thrace,

another fell round them.

death’s sable shade at once o’ercast their eyes,

and now no man would have made light of the fighting if he could

have gone about among it scatheless and unwounded, with minerva

with copious slaughter all the fields are red,
and heap’d with growing mountains of the dead.
had some brave chief this martial scene beheld,

might darts be bid to turn their points away,

[illustration: ] map of the plain of troy

book v.

book v.
argument.
the acts of diomed.

the exploits of diomed, who, though wounded by pandarus,

diomed, assisted by pallas, performs wonders in this day’s battle.
pandarus wounds him with an arrow, but the goddess cures him, enables
him to discern gods from mortals, and prohibits him from contending
with any of the former, excepting venus.

continues fighting—he kills pandarus and wounds aeneas—venus

æneas joins pandarus to oppose
him; pandarus is killed, and æneas in great danger but for the

rescues aeneas, but being wounded by diomed, commits him to the

assistance of venus; who, as she is removing her son from the fight, is
wounded on the hand by diomed.

care of apollo and goes to olympus, where she is tended by her

apollo seconds her in his rescue, and at
length carries off æneas to troy, where he is healed in the temple of

mother dione—mars encourages the trojans, and aeneas returns to

pergamus.
mars rallies the trojans, and assists hector to make a stand.
in the meantime æneas is restored to the field, and they overthrow

the fight cured of his wound—minerva and juno help the achaeans,

several of the greeks; among the rest tlepolemus is slain by sarpedon.
juno and minerva descend to resist mars; the latter incites diomed to
go against that god; he wounds him, and sends him groaning to heaven.
the first battle continues through this book.

and by the advice of the former diomed wounds mars, who returns

the scene is the same

to olympus to get cured.

as in the former.

then pallas minerva put valour into the heart of diomed, son of

but pallas now tydides’ soul inspires,[143]

tydeus, that he might excel all the other argives, and cover

fills with her force, and warms with all her fires,
above the greeks his deathless fame to raise,

himself with glory.

and crown her hero with distinguish’d praise.

she made a stream of fire flare from his

high on his helm celestial lightnings play,
his beamy shield emits a living ray;
the unwearied blaze incessant streams supplies,

shield and helmet like the star that shines most brilliantly in

like the red star that fires the autumnal skies,

summer after its bath in the waters of oceanus—even such a fire

when fresh he rears his radiant orb to sight,
and, bathed in ocean, shoots a keener light.

did she kindle upon his head and shoulders as she bade him speed

such glories pallas on the chief bestow’d,
such, from his arms, the fierce effulgence flow’d:
onward she drives him, furious to engage,

into the thickest hurly-burly of the fight.

where the fight burns, and where the thickest rage.

his armour rang rattling round him.

down sinks the warrior with a thundering sound,
his brazen armour rings against the ground.

deluge whole fields, and sweep the trees along,
through ruin’d moles the rushing wave resounds,

the yellow harvests of the ripen’d year,
and flatted vineyards, one sad waste appear!

rain from heaven, but in a moment it comes tearing onward, and

and all the labours of mankind are vain.

the rushing stream his brazen armour dyed,

”

whose arrow wounds the chief thou guard’st in fight;

and lay the boaster grovelling on the shore,

and now he is boasting that i shall not see the light of the sun

that vaunts these eyes shall view the light no more.

much longer.

”

thus he prayed, and pallas minerva heard him; she made his limbs

supple and quickened his hands and his feet.

his nerves confirm’d, his languid spirits cheer’d;

then she went up

war be thy province, thy protection mine;
rush to the fight, and every foe control;

trojans, for i have set in your heart the spirit of your knightly

wake each paternal virtue in thy soul:
strength swells thy boiling breast, infused by me,

father tydeus.

and all thy godlike father breathes in thee;

moreover, i have withdrawn the veil from your

yet more, from mortal mists i purge thy eyes,[145]

eyes, that you know gods and men apart.

and set to view the warring deities.
these see thou shun, through all the embattled plain;

if, then, any other god

nor rashly strive where human force is vain.

her.

”

when she had said this minerva went away, and the son of tydeus

with that, the blue-eyed virgin wing’d her flight;

again took his place among the foremost fighters, three times

the hero rush’d impetuous to the fight;
with tenfold ardour now invades the plain,

more fierce even than he had been before.

wild with delay, and more enraged by pain.

he was like a lion that
some mountain shepherd has wounded, but not killed, as he is

as on the fleecy flocks when hunger calls,

springing over the wall of a sheep-yard to attack the sheep.
the

amidst the field a brindled lion falls;

shepherd has roused the brute to fury but cannot defend his

if chance some shepherd with a distant dart

flock, so he takes shelter under cover of the buildings, while

the savage wound, he rouses at the smart,

the sheep, panic-stricken on being deserted, are smothered in

he foams, he roars; the shepherd dares not stay,
but trembling leaves the scattering flocks a prey;

heaps one on top of the other, and the angry lion leaps out over

heaps fall on heaps; he bathes with blood the ground,

the sheep-yard wall.

then leaps victorious o’er the lofty mound.

among the trojans.

but diomed took

vast was his wealth, and these the only heirs

both their lives and left their father sorrowing bitterly, for he

of all his labours and a life of cares.
cold death o’ertakes them in their blooming years,
and leaves the father unavailing tears:

nevermore saw them come home from battle alive, and his kinsmen

to strangers now descends his heapy store,

divided his wealth among themselves.

the race forgotten, and the name no more.

then he came upon two sons of priam, echemmon and chromius, as

they were both in one chariot.

trojans.

if we mortal call

he has killed many a brave man—unless indeed he is some

that wondrous force by which whole armies fall;

god who is angry with the trojans about their sacrifices, and

or god incensed, who quits the distant skies
to punish troy for slighted sacrifice;
(which, oh avert from our unhappy state!
for what so dreadful as celestial hate)?
whoe’er he be, propitiate jove with prayer;

has set his hand against them in his displeasure.

if man, destroy; if god, entreat to spare.

”

”

and the son of lycaon answered, “aeneas, i take him for none

to him the lycian: “whom your eyes behold,

other than the son of tydeus.

if right i judge, is diomed the bold:

i know him by his shield, the visor

such coursers whirl him o’er the dusty field,

of his helmet, and by his horses.

so towers his helmet, and so flames his shield.

it is possible that he may be a

havoc without heaven’s help, but has some god by his side who is

when it had hit him.

and turns unseen the frustrate dart away.

i have taken aim at him already and hit him

skill’d in the bow, on foot i sought the war,

chariot.
in my father’s stables there are eleven excellent
chariots, fresh from the builder, quite new, with cloths spread

ten polish’d chariots i possess’d at home,

over them; and by each of them there stand a pair of horses,

and still they grace lycaon’s princely dome:
there veil’d in spacious coverlets they stand;
and twice ten coursers wait their lord’s command.

champing barley and rye; my old father lycaon urged me again and

the good old warrior bade me trust to these,

again when i was at home and on the point of starting, to take

when first for troy i sail’d the sacred seas;

chariots and horses with me that i might lead the trojans in

in fields, aloft, the whirling car to guide,
and through the ranks of death triumphant ride.

battle, but i would not listen to him; it would have been much

but vain with youth, and yet to thrift inclined,
i heard his counsels with unheedful mind,

better if i had done so, but i was thinking about the horses,
which had been used to eat their fill, and i was afraid that in

and thought the steeds (your large supplies unknown)

such a great gathering of men they might be ill-fed, so i left

might fail of forage in the straiten’d town;

them at home and came on foot to ilius armed only with my bow and

so took my bow and pointed darts in hand
and left the chariots in my native land.

arrows.

“too late, o friend!
my rashness i deplore;

these it seems, are of no use, for i have already hit two

these shafts, once fatal, carry death no more.

chieftains, the sons of atreus and of tydeus, and though i drew

tydeus’ and atreus’ sons their points have found,

blood surely enough, i have only made them still more furious.

and undissembled gore pursued the wound.
in vain they bleed: this unavailing bow
serves, not to slaughter, but provoke the foe.
in evil hour these bended horns i strung,

i

and seized the quiver where it idly hung.

did ill to take my bow down from its peg on the day i led my band

cursed be the fate that sent me to the field

of trojans to ilius in hector’s service, and if ever i get home

without a warrior’s arms, the spear and shield!
if e’er with life i quit the trojan plain,

again to set eyes on my native place, my wife, and the greatness

if e’er i see my spouse and sire again,

of my house, may some one cut my head off then and there if i do

this bow, unfaithful to my glorious aims,

not break the bow and set it on a hot fire—such pranks as it

broke by my hand, shall feed the blazing flames.

plays me.

”

”

to whom the leader of the dardan race:

aeneas answered, “say no more.

“be calm, nor phœbus’ honour’d gift disgrace.

things will not mend till we two

the distant dart be praised, though here we need

go against this man with chariot and horses and bring him to a

the rushing chariot and the bounding steed.
against yon hero let us bend our course,

trial of arms.

and, hand to hand, encounter force with force.

mount my chariot, and note how cleverly the horses

now mount my seat, and from the chariot’s height
observe my father’s steeds, renown’d in fight;

of tros can speed hither and thither over the plain in pursuit or

practised alike to turn, to stop, to chase,
to dare the shock, or urge the rapid race;

flight.

secure with these, through fighting fields we go;

if jove again vouchsafes glory to the son of tydeus they
will carry us safely back to the city.

or safe to troy, if jove assist the foe.

take hold, then, of the

haste, seize the whip, and snatch the guiding rein;

whip and reins while i stand upon the car to fight, or else do

the warrior’s fury let this arm sustain;
or, if to combat thy bold heart incline,

you wait this man’s onset while i look after the horses.

take thou the spear, the chariot’s care be mine.

”

”
“o prince!

“aeneas,” replied the son of lycaon, “take the reins and drive;

(lycaon’s valiant son replied)

if we have to fly before the son of tydeus the horses will go

as thine the steeds, be thine the task to guide.

better for their own driver.

the horses, practised to their lord’s command,

if they miss the sound of your voice

shall bear the rein, and answer to thy hand;

when they expect it they may be frightened, and refuse to take us

but, if, unhappy, we desert the fight,

out of the fight.

thy voice alone can animate their flight;

the son of tydeus will then kill both of us and

else shall our fates be number’d with the dead,

take the horses.

and these, the victor’s prize, in triumph led.

therefore drive them yourself and i will be

thine be the guidance, then: with spear and shield

ready for him with my spear.

myself will charge this terror of the field.

”

”

they then mounted the chariot and drove full speed towards the

and now both heroes mount the glittering car;

son of tydeus.

the bounding coursers rush amidst the war;

sthenelus, son of capaneus, saw them coming and

their fierce approach bold sthenelus espied,

said to diomed, “diomed, son of tydeus, man after my own heart, i

who thus, alarm’d, to great tydides cried:
“o friend!

see two heroes speeding towards you, both of them men of might

two chiefs of force immense i see,
dreadful they come, and bend their rage on thee:

the one a skilful archer, pandarus son of lycaon, the other,

lo the brave heir of old lycaon’s line,

aeneas, whose sire is anchises, while his mother is venus.

and great æneas, sprung from race divine!

mount

enough is given to fame.

the chariot and let us retreat.
do not, i pray you, press so

ascend thy car!

furiously forward, or you may get killed.

and save a life, the bulwark of our war.

”

”

diomed looked angrily at him and answered: “talk not of flight,

at this the hero cast a gloomy look,
fix’d on the chief with scorn; and thus he spoke:

for i shall not listen to you: i am of a race that knows neither

“me dost thou bid to shun the coming fight?

flight nor fear, and my limbs are as yet unwearied.

me wouldst thou move to base, inglorious flight?
know, ’tis not honest in my soul to fear,
nor was tydides born to tremble here.

i am in no

i hate the cumbrous chariot’s slow advance,

mind to mount, but will go against them even as i am; pallas

and the long distance of the flying lance;
but while my nerves are strong, my force entire,
thus front the foe, and emulate my sire.

minerva bids me be afraid of no man, and even though one of them

nor shall yon steeds, that fierce to fight convey

escape, their steeds shall not take both back again.

those threatening heroes, bear them both away;
one chief at least beneath this arm shall die;

i say

so pallas tells me, and forbids to fly.

further, and lay my saying to your heart—if minerva sees fit to

but if she dooms, and if no god withstand,

vouchsafe me the glory of killing both, stay your horses here and

that both shall fall by one victorious hand,
then heed my words: my horses here detain,

make the reins fast to the rim of the chariot; then be sure you

fix’d to the chariot by the straiten’d rein;
swift to æneas’ empty seat proceed,

spring aeneas’ horses and drive them from the trojan to the

and seize the coursers of ethereal breed;

achaean ranks.

the race of those, which once the thundering god[146]

for ravish’d ganymede on tros bestow’d,

in payment for his son ganymede, and are the finest that live and

the best that e’er on earth’s broad surface run,

beneath the rising or the setting sun.

by mortal mares, from fierce laomedon:

to aeneas.

and two transport æneas o’er the plain.

we shall win great glory if we can take them.

these, were the rich immortal prize our own,
through the wide world should make our glory known.

”

thus did they converse, but the other two had now driven close up

to them, and the son of lycaon spoke first.

and stern lycaon’s warlike race begun:

“great and mighty

“prince, thou art met.

son,” said he, “of noble tydeus, my arrow failed to lay you low,

though late in vain assail’d,

so i will now try with my spear.

the spear may enter where the arrow fail’d.

”

”

he poised his spear as he spoke and hurled it from him.

he said, then shook the ponderous lance, and flung;

it struck

on his broad shield the sounding weapon rung,

the shield of the son of tydeus; the bronze point pierced it and

pierced the tough orb, and in his cuirass hung,

passed on till it reached the breastplate.

“he bleeds!

thereon the son of

the pride of greece!

(the boaster cries,)

belly; you will not stand out for long, and the glory of the

our triumph now, the mighty warrior lies!

”

”
“mistaken vaunter!

but diomed all undismayed made answer, “you have missed, not hit,

(diomed replied;)
thy dart has erred, and now my spear be tried;

and before you two see the end of this matter one or other of you

ye ’scape not both; one, headlong from his car,

shall glut tough-shielded mars with his blood.

with hostile blood shall glut the god of war.

”

”

with this he hurled his spear, and minerva guided it on to

he spoke, and rising hurl’d his forceful dart,
which, driven by pallas, pierced a vital part;
full in his face it enter’d, and betwixt

pandarus’s nose near the eye.

the nose and eye-ball the proud lycian fix’d;

it went crashing in among his white
teeth; the bronze point cut through the root of his tongue,

crash’d all his jaws, and cleft the tongue within,

coming out under his chin, and his glistening armour rang

till the bright point look’d out beneath the chin.

rattling round him as he fell heavily to the ground.

headlong he falls, his helmet knocks the ground:
earth groans beneath him, and his arms resound;

the horses

the starting coursers tremble with affright;

started aside for fear, and he was reft of life and strength.

the soul indignant seeks the realms of night.

aeneas sprang from his chariot armed with shield and spear,

to guard his slaughter’d friend, æneas flies,

fearing lest the achaeans should carry off the body.

his spear extending where the carcase lies;

he bestrode

watchful he wheels, protects it every way,

it as a lion in the pride of strength, with shield and spear

as the grim lion stalks around his prey.
o’er the fall’n trunk his ample shield display’d,

before him and a cry of battle on his lips resolute to kill the

he hides the hero with his mighty shade,

first that should dare face him.

and threats aloud!

but the son of tydeus caught up

then fierce tydides stoops; and from the fields

heaved with vast force, a rocky fragment wields.
not two strong men the enormous weight could raise,
such men as live in these degenerate days:[147]

ships.

(whom most he loved, as brave men love the brave,)

he then remounted his own chariot, seized the reins, and

then mounting on his car, resumed the rein,

drove with all speed in search of the son of tydeus.

and follow’d where tydides swept the plain.

now the son of tydeus was in pursuit of the cyprian goddess,

meanwhile (his conquest ravished from his eyes)
the raging chief in chase of venus flies:
no goddess she, commission’d to the field,

spear in hand, for he knew her to be feeble and not one of those

like pallas dreadful with her sable shield,
or fierce bellona thundering at the wall,

goddesses that can lord it among men in battle like minerva or

while flames ascend, and mighty ruins fall;
he knew soft combats suit the tender dame,

enyo the waster of cities, and when at last after a long chase he

new to the field, and still a foe to fame.
through breaking ranks his furious course he bends,

caught her up, he flew at her and thrust his spear into the flesh

and at the goddess his broad lance extends;

of her delicate hand.

through her bright veil the daring weapon drove,

the point tore through the ambrosial robe

the ambrosial veil which all the graces wove;

which the graces had woven for her, and pierced the skin between

her snowy hand the razing steel profaned,
and the transparent skin with crimson stain’d,

her wrist and the palm of her hand, so that the immortal blood,

from the clear vein a stream immortal flow’d,

or ichor, that flows in the veins of the blessed gods, came

such stream as issues from a wounded god;[148]
pure emanation!

pouring from the wound; for the gods do not eat bread nor drink

uncorrupted flood!
unlike our gross, diseased, terrestrial blood:
(for not the bread of man their life sustains,

wine, hence they have no blood such as ours, and are immortal.

nor wine’s inflaming juice supplies their veins:)

venus screamed aloud, and let her son fall, but phoebus apollo

with tender shrieks the goddess fill’d the place,
and dropp’d her offspring from her weak embrace.

caught him in his arms, and hid him in a cloud of darkness, lest

the fainting chief, and wards the mortal wound.

and diomed shouted out as he left her, “daughter of jove, leave

then with a voice that shook the vaulted skies,
the king insults the goddess as she flies:
“ill with jove’s daughter bloody fights agree,

war and battle alone, can you not be contented with beguiling

the field of combat is no scene for thee:

silly women?

go, let thy own soft sex employ thy care,

if you meddle with fighting you will get what will

go, lull the coward, or delude the fair.

make you shudder at the very name of war.

taught by this stroke renounce the war’s alarms,
and learn to tremble at the name of arms.

”

”
tydides thus.

the goddess, seized with dread,

she

i love best of all mankind, out of the fight.

the war is no

taken to fighting with the immortals.

but with the gods (the immortal gods) engage.

”

“bear it, my child,” replied dione, “and make the best of it.

dione then: “thy wrongs with patience bear,

we

and share those griefs inferior powers must share:

dwellers in olympus have to put up with much at the hands of men,

unnumber’d woes mankind from us sustain,

and we lay much suffering on one another.

and men with woes afflict the gods again.

mars had to suffer when

the mighty mars in mortal fetters bound,[149]

otus and ephialtes, children of aloeus, bound him in cruel bonds,

and lodged in brazen dungeons underground,

so that he lay thirteen months imprisoned in a vessel of bronze.

full thirteen moons imprison’d roar’d in vain;

mars would have then perished had not fair eeriboea, stepmother

otus and ephialtes held the chain:
perhaps had perish’d had not hermes’ care

to the sons of aloeus, told mercury, who stole him away when he

restored the groaning god to upper air.

was already well-nigh worn out by the severity of his bondage.
juno, again, suffered when the mighty son of amphitryon wounded
her on the right breast with a three-barbed arrow, and nothing
could assuage her pain.

great juno’s self has borne her weight of pain,

so, also, did huge hades, when this same

the imperial partner of the heavenly reign;

arrow in his brawny shoulder caused him great anguish till paeeon

where paeon, sprinkling heavenly balm around,

was not of mortal mould.

assuaged the glowing pangs, and closed the wound.

daring, headstrong, evildoer who recked

and drench his arrows in the blood of gods!

round this

and greece and troy with clashing shields engaged.

and calling mars, thus urged the raging god:

mars, bane of men, blood-stained stormer of cities, can you not

“stern power of arms, by whom the mighty fall;
who bathest in blood, and shakest the embattled wall,
rise in thy wrath!

he first went up to

the cyprian and wounded her in the hand near her wrist, and

me next he charged, and dares all heaven engage:

afterwards sprang upon me too, as though he were a god.

the wretch would brave high heaven’s immortal sire,
his triple thunder, and his bolts of fire.

”

”

he then took his seat on the top of pergamus, while murderous

”

haste all, and take the generous warrior’s part.

with these words he put heart and soul into them all.

he said;—new courage swell’d each hero’s heart.

then
sarpedon rebuked hector very sternly.

sarpedon first his ardent soul express’d,

“hector,” said he, “where

and, turn’d to hector, these bold words address’d:

is your prowess now?

“say, chief, is all thy ancient valour lost?

you used to say that though you had neither

where are thy threats, and where thy glorious boast,

people nor allies you could hold the town alone with your

that propp’d alone by priam’s race should stand
troy’s sacred walls, nor need a foreign hand?
now, now thy country calls her wonted friends,

brothers and brothers-in-law.

and the proud vaunt in just derision ends.

i see not one of them here; they

remote they stand while alien troops engage,

cower as hounds before a lion; it is we, your allies, who bear
the brunt of the battle.

like trembling hounds before the lion’s rage.

i have come from afar, even from lycia

far distant hence i held my wide command,

and the banks of the river xanthus, where i have left my wife, my

where foaming xanthus laves the lycian land;

infant son, and much wealth to tempt whoever is needy;

with ample wealth (the wish of mortals) bless’d,
a beauteous wife, and infant at her breast;

nevertheless, i head my lycian soldiers and stand my ground

with those i left whatever dear could be:

against any who would fight me though i have nothing here for the

greece, if she conquers, nothing wins from me;
yet first in fight my lycian bands i cheer,
and long to meet this mighty man ye fear;

achaeans to plunder, while you look on, without even bidding your

while hector idle stands, nor bids the brave

men stand firm in defence of their wives.

their wives, their infants, and their altars save.
haste, warrior, haste!

see that you fall not

preserve thy threaten’d state,

into the hands of your foes as men caught in the meshes of a net,

or one vast burst of all-involving fate

and they sack your fair city forthwith.

full o’er your towers shall fall, and sweep away

keep this before your

sons, sires, and wives, an undistinguish’d prey.

mind night and day, and beseech the captains of your allies to

rouse all thy trojans, urge thy aids to fight;
these claim thy thoughts by day, thy watch by night;

hold on without flinching, and thus put away their reproaches

with force incessant the brave greeks oppose;

from you.

such cares thy friends deserve, and such thy foes.

”

”

so spoke sarpedon, and hector smarted under his words.

stung to the heart the generous hector hears,
but just reproof with decent silence bears.

he sprang

from his proud car the prince impetuous springs,

from his chariot clad in his suit of armour, and went about among

on earth he leaps, his brazen armour rings.

the host brandishing his two spears, exhorting the men to fight

two shining spears are brandish’d in his hands;
thus arm’d, he animates his drooping bands,
revives their ardour, turns their steps from flight,

and raising the terrible cry of battle.

and wakes anew the dying flames of fight.

then they rallied and
again faced the achaeans, but the argives stood compact and firm,

they turn, they stand; the greeks their fury dare,

and were not driven back.

condense their powers, and wait the growing war.

as the breezes sport with the chaff
upon some goodly threshing-floor, when men are winnowing—while

as when, on ceres’ sacred floor, the swain

yellow ceres blows with the wind to sift the chaff from the

spreads the wide fan to clear the golden grain,
and the light chaff, before the breezes borne,
ascends in clouds from off the heapy corn;
the grey dust, rising with collected winds,

grain, and the chaff-heaps grow whiter and whiter—even so did the

drives o’er the barn, and whitens all the hinds:

achaeans whiten in the dust which the horses’ hoofs raised to the

so white with dust the grecian host appears,
from trampling steeds, and thundering charioteers.

firmament of heaven, as their drivers turned them back to battle,

the dusky clouds from labour’d earth arise,

and they bore down with might upon the foe.

and roll in smoking volumes to the skies.

fierce mars, to help

mars hovers o’er them with his sable shield,

the trojans, covered them in a veil of darkness, and went about

and adds new horrors to the darken’d field:
pleased with his charge, and ardent to fulfil,

everywhere among them, inasmuch as phoebus apollo had told him

in troy’s defence, apollo’s heavenly will:

that when he saw pallas minerva leave the fray he was to put
courage into the hearts of the trojans—for it was she who was

soon as from fight the blue-eyed maid retires,

helping the danaans.

each trojan bosom with new warmth he fires.

then apollo sent aeneas forth from his rich

and now the god, from forth his sacred fane,

sanctuary, and filled his heart with valour, whereon he took his

produced æneas to the shouting train;

place among his comrades, who were overjoyed at seeing him alive,

alive, unharm’d, with all his peers around,

sound, and of a good courage; but they could not ask him how it

erect he stood, and vigorous from his wound:
inquiries none they made; the dreadful day
no pause of words admits, no dull delay;

had all happened, for they were too busy with the turmoil raised

fierce discord storms, apollo loud exclaims,

by mars and by strife, who raged insatiably in their midst.

fame calls, mars thunders, and the field’s in flames.

the two ajaxes, ulysses and diomed, cheered the danaans on,

stern diomed with either ajax stood,
and great ulysses, bathed in hostile blood.
embodied close, the labouring grecian train

fearless of the fury and onset of the trojans.

the fiercest shock of charging hosts sustain.

they stood as

unmoved and silent, the whole war they wait

still as clouds which the son of saturn has spread upon the

serenely dreadful, and as fix’d as fate.
so when the embattled clouds in dark array,
along the skies their gloomy lines display;
when now the north his boisterous rage has spent,

mountain tops when there is no air and fierce boreas sleeps with

and peaceful sleeps the liquid element:
the low-hung vapours, motionless and still,
rest on the summits of the shaded hill;

the other boisterous winds whose shrill blasts scatter the clouds

till the mass scatters as the winds arise,
dispersed and broken through the ruffled skies.

in all directions—even so did the danaans stand firm and

nor was the general wanting to his train;
from troop to troop he toils through all the plain,

unflinching against the trojans.

“ye greeks, be men!

the son of atreus went about

the charge of battle bear;

among them and exhorted them.

your brave associates and yourselves revere!

“my friends,” said he, “quit

let glorious acts more glorious acts inspire,

yourselves like brave men, and shun dishonour in one another’s

and catch from breast to breast the noble fire!

eyes amid the stress of battle.

on valour’s side the odds of combat lie,

they that shun dishonour more

the brave live glorious, or lamented die;
the wretch who trembles in the field of fame,

often live than get killed, but they that fly save neither life

meets death, and worse than death, eternal shame!

nor name.
”

”

as he spoke he hurled his spear and hit one of those who were in

the front rank, the comrade of aeneas, deicoon son of pergasus,

for he was ever quick to place himself among the foremost.
the

these, when they grew up,

agamemnon sons of atreus, and there they both of them fell.

they fell with glory on the phrygian plain.

as

where hector march’d, the god of battles shined,

diomed shook with passion as he saw them.

tydides paused amidst his full career;
then first the hero’s manly breast knew fear.

as a man crossing a

and wide through fens an unknown journey takes:
if chance a swelling brook his passage stay,
and foam impervious ’cross the wanderer’s way,
confused he stops, a length of country pass’d,

river rolling swiftly to the sea—he sees its boiling waters and

eyes the rough waves, and tired, returns at last.

starts back in fear—even so did the son of tydeus give ground.

hector wields the spear so well?

man.

retire, but with your faces to the foe.
trust not too much your unavailing might;

ground backwards, for we dare not fight with gods.

’tis not with troy, but with the gods ye fight.

”

rage thus furiously.

mars, red with slaughter, aids our hated foes:

let us go into the fray at once.

haste, let us arm, and force with force oppose!

”

”

minerva did not gainsay her.

she spoke; minerva burns to meet the war:

meanwhile minerva flung her richly embroidered vesture, made with

(the laboured veil her heavenly fingers wove,)

of jove, arming herself for battle.

flows on the pavement of the court of jove.
now heaven’s dread arms her mighty limbs invest,

about her shoulders, wreathed round with rout as with a fringe,

deck’d in sad triumph for the mournful field,
o’er her broad shoulders hangs his horrid shield,
dire, black, tremendous!
round the margin roll’d,
a fringe of serpents hissing guards the gold:

and on it were strife, and strength, and panic whose blood runs

here all the terrors of grim war appear,
here rages force, here tremble flight and fear,

cold; moreover there was the head of the dread monster gorgon,

here storm’d contention, and here fury frown’d,

grim and awful to behold, portent of aegis-bearing jove.

and the dire orb portentous gorgon crown’d.

on her

the massy golden helm she next assumes,

head she set her helmet of gold, with four plumes, and coming to

that dreadful nods with four o’ershading plumes;

a peak both in front and behind—decked with the emblems of a

so vast, the broad circumference contains

hundred cities; then she stepped into her flaming chariot and

a hundred armies on a hundred plains.
the goddess thus the imperial car ascends;

grasped the spear, so stout and sturdy and strong, with which she

shook by her arm the mighty javelin bends,
ponderous and huge; that when her fury burns,

quells the ranks of heroes who have displeased her.

proud tyrants humbles, and whole hosts o’erturns.

juno lashed

swift at the scourge the ethereal coursers fly,

the horses on, and the gates of heaven bellowed as they flew open

while the smooth chariot cuts the liquid sky.
heaven’s gates spontaneous open to the powers,[155]
heaven’s golden gates, kept by the winged hours;[156]

of their own accord—gates over which the hours preside, in whose

commission’d in alternate watch they stand,

hands are heaven and olympus, either to open the dense cloud that

the sun’s bright portals and the skies command,
involve in clouds the eternal gates of day,

hides them, or to close it.

or the dark barrier roll with ease away.

through these the goddesses drove

the sounding hinges ring, on either side

their obedient steeds, and found the son of saturn sitting all

the gloomy volumes, pierced with light, divide.
the chariot mounts, where deep in ambient skies,

alone on the topmost ridges of olympus.

confused, olympus’ hundred heads arise;
where far apart the thunderer fills his throne,
o’er all the gods superior and alone.

there juno stayed her

“father

“o sire!

jove,” said she, “are you not angry with mars for these high

can no resentment touch thy soul?
can mars rebel, and does no thunder roll?
what lawless rage on yon forbidden plain,

doings?

what rash destruction!

and what heroes slain!

destroyed to my great grief, and without either right or reason,

venus, and phœbus with the dreadful bow,

while the cyprian and apollo are enjoying it all at their ease

smile on the slaughter, and enjoy my woe.

and setting this unrighteous madman on to do further mischief.

mad, furious power!

i

whose unrelenting mind

hope, father jove, that you will not be angry if i hit mars hard,

no god can govern, and no justice bind.
say, mighty father!
shall we scourge this pride,

and chase him out of the battle.

and drive from fight the impetuous homicide?

”

”

and jove answered, “set minerva on to him, for she punishes him

to whom assenting, thus the thunderer said:
“go!
and the great minerva be thy aid.
to tame the monster-god minerva knows,

more often than any one else does.

and oft afflicts his brutal breast with woes.

”

”

juno did as he had said.

he said; saturnia, ardent to obey,

she lashed her horses, and they flew

lash’d her white steeds along the aerial way.

forward nothing loth midway betwixt earth and sky.

swift down the steep of heaven the chariot rolls,
between the expanded earth and starry poles.

as far as a

far as a shepherd, from some point on high,[157]

man can see when he looks out upon the sea from some high beacon,

o’er the wide main extends his boundless eye,

so far can the loud-neighing horses of the gods spring at a

through such a space of air, with thundering sound,

single bound.

at every leap the immortal coursers bound

when they reached troy and the place where its two

where silver simois and scamander join.

flowing streams simois and scamander meet, there juno stayed them

of air condensed a vapour circumfused:

she hid them in a thick cloud,

for these, impregnate with celestial dew,

and simois made ambrosia spring up for them to eat; the two

goddesses then went on, flying like turtledoves in their
eagerness to help the argives.

thence to relieve the fainting argive throng,

when they came to the part where

smooth as the sailing doves they glide along.

the bravest and most in number were gathered about mighty diomed,

the best and bravest of the grecian band

fighting like lions or wild boars of great strength and

(a warlike circle) round tydides stand.
such was their look as lions bathed in blood,
or foaming boars, the terror of the wood.

endurance, there juno stood still and raised a shout like that of

heaven’s empress mingles with the mortal crowd,

brazen-voiced stentor, whose cry was as loud as that of fifty men

and shouts, in stentor’s sounding voice, aloud;
stentor the strong, endued with brazen lungs,[158]
whose throats surpass’d the force of fifty tongues.

together.

“inglorious argives!

“argives,” she cried; “shame on cowardly creatures,

to your race a shame,

brave in semblance only; as long as achilles was fighting, if his

and only men in figure and in name!

spear was so deadly that the trojans dared not show themselves

once from the walls your timorous foes engaged,
while fierce in war divine achilles raged;

outside the dardanian gates, but now they sally far from the city

now issuing fearless they possess the plain,

and fight even at your ships.

now win the shores, and scarce the seas remain.

”

”

with these words she put heart and soul into them all, while

her speech new fury to their hearts convey’d;

minerva sprang to the side of the son of tydeus, whom she found

while near tydides stood the athenian maid;
the king beside his panting steeds she found,
o’erspent with toil reposing on the ground;

near his chariot and horses, cooling the wound that pandarus had

)

whose ample belt, that o’er his shoulder lay,

the

son of tydeus is not such another as his father.

“degenerate prince!

tydeus was a

and not of tydeus’ kind,

little man, but he could fight, and rushed madly into the fray

whose little body lodged a mighty mind;
foremost he press’d in glorious toils to share,

even when i told him not to do so.

and scarce refrain’d when i forbade the war.

when he went all unattended as

alone, unguarded, once he dared to go,

envoy to the city of thebes among the cadmeans, i bade him feast
in their houses and be at peace; but with that high spirit which

and feast, incircled by the theban foe;

was ever present with him, he challenged the youth of the

there braved, and vanquish’d, many a hardy knight;

cadmeans, and at once beat them in all that he attempted, so
mightily did i help him.

such nerves i gave him, and such force in fight.

i stand by you too to protect you, and i

thou too no less hast been my constant care;

bid you be instant in fighting the trojans; but either you are

thy hands i arm’d, and sent thee forth to war:

tired out, or you are afraid and out of heart, and in that case i

but thee or fear deters, or sloth detains;

say that you are no true son of tydeus the son of oeneus.

no drop of all thy father warms thy veins.

”

”

mars

the smoking steel.
mars bellows with the pain:

roared as loudly as nine or ten thousand men in the thick of a

loud as the roar encountering armies yield,
when shouting millions shake the thundering field.

fight, and the achaeans and trojans were struck with panic, so

both armies start, and trembling gaze around;

terrible was the cry he raised.

and earth and heaven re-bellow to the sound.

as a dark cloud in the sky when it comes on to blow after heat,

as vapours blown by auster’s sultry breath,
pregnant with plagues, and shedding seeds of death,
beneath the rage of burning sirius rise,
choke the parch’d earth, and blacken all the skies;
in such a cloud the god from combat driven,

even so did diomed son of tydeus see mars ascend into the broad
heavens.

high o’er the dusky whirlwind scales the heaven.

with all speed he reached high olympus, home of the

wild with his pain, he sought the bright abodes,

gods, and in great pain sat down beside jove the son of saturn.

there sullen sat beneath the sire of gods,

he showed jove the immortal blood that was flowing from his

show’d the celestial blood, and with a groan
thus pour’d his plaints before the immortal throne:

wound, and spoke piteously, saying, “father jove, are you not

“can jove, supine, flagitious facts survey,

angered by such doings?

and brook the furies of this daring day?

we gods are continually suffering in the

for mortal men celestial powers engage,
and gods on gods exert eternal rage:

most cruel manner at one another’s hands while helping mortals;

from thee, o father!

and we all owe you a grudge for having begotten that mad

all these ills we bear,

termagant of a daughter, who is always committing outrage of some

and thy fell daughter with the shield and spear;
thou gavest that fury to the realms of light,

kind.

pernicious, wild, regardless of the right.

we other gods must all do as you bid us, but her you

all heaven beside reveres thy sovereign sway,
thy voice we hear, and thy behests obey:

neither scold nor punish; you encourage her because the pestilent

’tis hers to offend, and even offending share
thy breast, thy counsels, thy distinguish’d care:
so boundless she, and thou so partial grown,

creature is your daughter.

well may we deem the wondrous birth thy own.

see how she has been inciting proud

now frantic diomed, at her command,

diomed to vent his rage on the immortal gods.

against the immortals lifts his raging hand:

first he went up to

the heavenly venus first his fury found,

the cyprian and wounded her in the hand near her wrist, and then

me next encountering, me he dared to wound;

he sprang upon me too as though he were a god.

vanquish’d i fled; even i, the god of fight,

had i not run for

from mortal madness scarce was saved by flight.

it i must either have lain there for long enough in torments

else hadst thou seen me sink on yonder plain,

among the ghastly corpses, or have been eaten alive with spears

heap’d round, and heaving under loads of slain!
or pierced with grecian darts, for ages lie,

till i had no more strength left in me.

condemn’d to pain, though fated not to die.

”

”

jove looked angrily at him and said, “do not come whining here,

him thus upbraiding, with a wrathful look
the lord of thunders view’d, and stern bespoke:

sir facing-both-ways.

“to me, perfidious!

i hate you worst of all the gods in

this lamenting strain?
of lawless force shall lawless mars complain?
of all the gods who tread the spangled skies,
thou most unjust, most odious in our eyes!

olympus, for you are ever fighting and making mischief.

inhuman discord is thy dire delight,
the waste of slaughter, and the rage of fight.

you have

no bounds, no law, thy fiery temper quells,

the intolerable and stubborn spirit of your mother juno: it is

and all thy mother in thy soul rebels.
in vain our threats, in vain our power we use;

all i can do to manage her, and it is her doing that you are now

she gives the example, and her son pursues.

in this plight: still, i cannot let you remain longer in such

yet long the inflicted pangs thou shall not mourn,

great pain; you are my own offspring, and it was by me that your
mother conceived you; if, however, you had been the son of any

sprung since thou art from jove, and heavenly-born.

other god, you are so destructive that by this time you should

else, singed with lightning, hadst thou hence been thrown,

have been lying lower than the titans.

where chain’d on burning rocks the titans groan.

”

”

andromache.

helenus, the

the fight between trojans and achaeans was now left to rage as it

chief augur of troy, commands hector to return to the city, in order to

the
battle relaxing during the absence of hector, glaucus and diomed have
an interview between the two armies; where, coming to the knowledge, of
the friendship and hospitality passed between their ancestors, they
make exchange of their arms.
hector, having performed the orders of
helenus, prevails upon paris to return to the battle, and, taking a
tender leave of his wife andromache, hastens again to the field.
the scene is first in the field of battle, between the rivers
simois and scamander, and then changes to troy.
now heaven forsakes the fight: the immortals yield

would, and the tide of war surged hither and thither over the

to human force and human skill the field:

plain as they aimed their bronze-shod spears at one another

dark showers of javelins fly from foes to foes;

between the streams of simois and xanthus.

now here, now there, the tide of combat flows;
while troy’s famed streams, that bound the deathful plain
on either side, run purple to the main.

first, ajax son of telamon, tower of strength to the achaeans,

great ajax first to conquest led the way,

broke a phalanx of the trojans, and came to the assistance of his

broke the thick ranks, and turn’d the doubtful day.

comrades by killing acamas son of eussorus, the best man among

the thracian acamas his falchion found,

the thracians, being both brave and of great stature.

and hew’d the enormous giant to the ground;

the spear

his thundering arm a deadly stroke impress’d

where the black horse-hair nodded o’er his crest;

went through his forehead into the brain, and darkness veiled his

eyes.

and seals in endless shades his swimming eyes.

then diomed killed axylus son of teuthranus, a rich man who lived

next teuthras’ son distain’d the sands with blood,
axylus, hospitable, rich, and good:

in the strong city of arisbe, and was beloved by all men; for he

in fair arisbe’s walls (his native place)[161]
he held his seat!
a friend to human race.

had a house by the roadside, and entertained every one who

fast by the road, his ever-open door
obliged the wealthy, and relieved the poor.

passed; howbeit not one of his guests stood before him to save

to stern tydides now he falls a prey,
no friend to guard him in the dreadful day!
breathless the good man fell, and by his side

his life, and diomed killed both him and his squire calesius, who

his faithful servant, old calesius died.
by great euryalus was dresus slain,

was then his charioteer—so the pair passed beneath the earth.

and next he laid opheltius on the plain.

euryalus killed dresus and opheltius, and then went in pursuit of

and she conceived twin sons; these the son of mecisteus now slew,

and two fair infants crown’d his strong embrace:)
here dead they lay in all their youthful charms;

and he stripped the armour from their shoulders.

the ruthless victor stripp’d their shining arms.

then menelaus of the loud war-cry took adrestus alive, for his

unbless’d adrastus next at mercy lies
beneath the spartan spear, a living prize.
scared with the din and tumult of the fight,

horses ran into a tamarisk bush, as they were flying wildly over

his headlong steeds, precipitate in flight,
rush’d on a tamarisk’s strong trunk, and broke

the plain, and broke the pole from the car; they went on towards

the shatter’d chariot from the crooked yoke;

the city along with the others in full flight, but adrestus

wide o’er the field, resistless as the wind,
for troy they fly, and leave their lord behind.

thus did he plead, and menelaus was for yielding and giving him

as pity pleaded for his vanquish’d prize,

to a squire to take to the ships of the achaeans, but agamemnon

came running up to him and rebuked him.

and, furious, thus: “oh impotent of mind!

“my good menelaus,” said

[164]

he, “this is no time for giving quarter.

shall these, shall these atrides’ mercy find?

has, then, your house

well hast thou known proud troy’s perfidious land,

fared so well at the hands of the trojans?

and well her natives merit at thy hand!

let us not spare a

not one of all the race, nor sex, nor age,
shall save a trojan from our boundless rage:

single one of them—not even the child unborn and in its mother’s

ilion shall perish whole, and bury all;

womb; let not a man of them be left alive, but let all in ilius

her babes, her infants at the breast, shall fall;[165]

perish, unheeded and forgotten.

a dreadful lesson of exampled fate,
to warn the nations, and to curb the great!

”

”

thus did he speak, and his brother was persuaded by him, for his
words were just.

the monarch spoke; the words, with warmth address’d,

menelaus, therefore, thrust adrestus from him,

to rigid justice steel’d his brother’s breast.

whereon king agamemnon struck him in the flank, and he fell: then

fierce from his knees the hapless chief he thrust;
the monarch’s javelin stretch’d him in the dust,

the son of atreus planted his foot upon his breast to draw his

then pressing with his foot his panting heart,

spear from the body.

forth from the slain he tugg’d the reeking dart.

meanwhile nestor shouted to the argives, saying, “my friends,

old nestor saw, and roused the warrior’s rage;

danaan warriors, servants of mars, let no man lag that he may

“thus, heroes!
thus the vigorous combat wage;
no son of mars descend, for servile gains,

spoil the dead, and bring back much booty to the ships.
let us

to touch the booty, while a foe remains.

kill as many as we can; the bodies will lie upon the plain, and

behold yon glittering host, your future spoil!

you can despoil them later at your leisure.

first gain the conquest, then reward the toil.

”

”

with these words he put heart and soul into them all.
and now the

and now had greece eternal fame acquired,

and frighted troy within her walls, retired,

had not sage helenus her state redress’d,
taught by the gods that moved his sacred breast.
where hector stood, with great æneas join’d,
the seer reveal’d the counsels of his mind:

aeneas, “hector and aeneas, you two are the mainstays of the

“ye generous chiefs!
on whom the immortals lay
the cares and glories of this doubtful day;

trojans and lycians, for you are foremost at all times, alike in

on whom your aids, your country’s hopes depend;

fight and counsel; hold your ground here, and go about among the

wise to consult, and active to defend!

host to rally them in front of the gates, or they will fling

here, at our gates, your brave efforts unite,
turn back the routed, and forbid the flight,

themselves into the arms of their wives, to the great joy of our

ere yet their wives’ soft arms the cowards gain,

foes.

the sport and insult of the hostile train.

then, when you have put heart into all our companies, we

when your commands have hearten’d every band,

will stand firm here and fight the danaans however hard they

ourselves, here fix’d, will make the dangerous stand;
press’d as we are, and sore of former fight,

press us, for there is nothing else to be done.

these straits demand our last remains of might.

meanwhile do you,

meanwhile thou, hector, to the town retire,

hector, go to the city and tell our mother what is happening.

and teach our mother what the gods require:

tell her to bid the matrons gather at the temple of minerva in

of troy’s chief matrons to minerva’s fane;[166]

the acropolis; let her then take her key and open the doors of

the sacred building; there, upon the knees of minerva, let her

with offer’d vows, in ilion’s topmost tower.

lay the largest, fairest robe she has in her house—the one she

the largest mantle her rich wardrobes hold,

sets most store by; let her, moreover, promise to sacrifice

most prized for art, and labour’d o’er with gold,
before the goddess’ honour’d knees be spread,

twelve yearling heifers that have never yet felt the goad, in the

and twelve young heifers to her altars led:

temple of the goddess, if she will take pity on the town, with

if so the power, atoned by fervent prayer,

the wives and little ones of the trojans, and keep the son of

our wives, our infants, and our city spare,

tydeus from falling on the goodly city of ilius; for he fights
with fury and fills men’s souls with panic.

and far avert tydides’ wasteful ire,

i hold him mightiest

that mows whole troops, and makes all troy retire;

of them all; we did not fear even their great champion achilles,

not thus achilles taught our hosts to dread,

son of a goddess though he be, as we do this man: his rage is

sprung though he was from more than mortal bed;

beyond all bounds, and there is none can vie with him in

not thus resistless ruled the stream of fight,
in rage unbounded, and unmatch’d in might.

prowess.
”

”

hector did as his brother bade him.

hector obedient heard: and, with a bound,

he sprang from his chariot,

leap’d from his trembling chariot to the ground;

and went about everywhere among the host, brandishing his spears,

through all his host inspiring force he flies,

urging the men on to fight, and raising the dread cry of battle.

and bids the thunder of the battle rise.

thereon they rallied and again faced the achaeans, who gave

with rage recruited the bold trojans glow,
and turn the tide of conflict on the foe:
fierce in the front he shakes two dazzling spears;
all greece recedes, and ’midst her triumphs fears;

ground and ceased their murderous onset, for they deemed that

some god, they thought, who ruled the fate of wars,

some one of the immortals had come down from starry heaven to

shot down avenging from the vault of stars.

help the trojans, so strangely had they rallied.

then thus aloud: “ye dauntless dardans, hear!

and hector

and you whom distant nations send to war!

shouted to the trojans, “trojans and allies, be men, my friends,

be mindful of the strength your fathers bore;

and fight with might and main, while i go to ilius and tell the

be still yourselves, and hector asks no more.
one hour demands me in the trojan wall,

old men of our council and our wives to pray to the gods and vow

to bid our altars flame, and victims fall:
nor shall, i trust, the matrons’ holy train,

hecatombs in their honour.

and reverend elders, seek the gods in vain.

”

”

with this he went his way, and the black rim of hide that went

this said, with ample strides the hero pass’d;

round his shield beat against his neck and his ancles.

the shield’s large orb behind his shoulder cast,
his neck o’ershading, to his ankle hung;

then glaucus son of hippolochus, and the son of tydeus went into

and as he march’d the brazen buckler rung.

the open space between the hosts to fight in single combat.

now paused the battle (godlike hector gone),[167]

when

where daring glaucus and great tydeus’ son

they were close up to one another diomed of the loud war-cry was

between both armies met: the chiefs from far
observed each other, and had mark’d for war.

the first to speak.

near as they drew, tydides thus began:

“who, my good sir,” said he, “who are you
among men?

“what art thou, boldest of the race of man?

i have never seen you in battle until now, but you are

our eyes till now that aspect ne’er beheld,
where fame is reap’d amid the embattled field;
yet far before the troops thou dar’st appear,

daring beyond all others if you abide my onset.

and meet a lance the fiercest heroes fear.

woe to those

unhappy they, and born of luckless sires,

fathers whose sons face my might.

who tempt our fury when minerva fires!

if, however, you are one of the

but if from heaven, celestial, thou descend,

immortals and have come down from heaven, i will not fight you;

know with immortals we no more contend.

for even valiant lycurgus, son of dryas, did not live long when

not long lycurgus view’d the golden light,

he took to fighting with the gods.

that daring man who mix’d with gods in fight.

he it was that drove the

bacchus, and bacchus’ votaries, he drove,

nursing women who were in charge of frenzied bacchus through the

with brandish’d steel, from nyssa’s sacred grove:

land of nysa, and they flung their thyrsi on the ground as

their consecrated spears lay scatter’d round,

murderous lycurgus beat them with his oxgoad.

with curling vines and twisted ivy bound;

bacchus himself
plunged terror-stricken into the sea, and thetis took him to her
bosom to comfort him, for he was scared by the fury with which

while bacchus headlong sought the briny flood,

the man reviled him.

and thetis’ arms received the trembling god.

thereon the gods who live at ease were angry

nor fail’d the crime the immortals’ wrath to move;
(the immortals bless’d with endless ease above;)
deprived of sight by their avenging doom,

with lycurgus and the son of saturn struck him blind, nor did he

cheerless he breathed, and wander’d in the gloom,
then sunk unpitied to the dire abodes,

live much longer after he had become hateful to the immortals.

a wretch accursed, and hated by the gods!

therefore i will not fight with the blessed gods; but if you are

i brave not heaven: but if the fruits of earth

of them that eat the fruit of the ground, draw near and meet your

sustain thy life, and human be thy birth,
bold as thou art, too prodigal of breath,

doom.

approach, and enter the dark gates of death.

”

”

and the son of hippolochus answered, “son of tydeus, why ask me

“what, or from whence i am, or who my sire,

of my lineage?

(replied the chief,) can tydeus’ son inquire?

men come and go as leaves year by year upon the
trees.

like leaves on trees the race of man is found,

those of autumn the wind sheds upon the ground, but when

now green in youth, now withering on the ground;

spring returns the forest buds forth with fresh vines.

another race the following spring supplies;

even so is

they fall successive, and successive rise:

it with the generations of mankind, the new spring up as the old

so generations in their course decay;

are passing away.

so flourish these, when those are pass’d away.

if, then, you would learn my descent, it is one

but if thou still persist to search my birth,

that is well known to many.

then hear a tale that fills the spacious earth.

there is a city in the heart of

“a city stands on argos’ utmost bound,

argos, pasture land of horses, called ephyra, where sisyphus

(argos the fair, for warlike steeds renown’d,)
æolian sisyphus, with wisdom bless’d,

lived, who was the craftiest of all mankind.

in ancient time the happy wall possess’d,

he was the son of
aeolus, and had a son named glaucus, who was father to

then call’d ephyre: glaucus was his son;

bellerophon, whom heaven endowed with the most surpassing

comeliness and beauty.

who o’er the sons of men in beauty shined,

but proetus devised his ruin, and being

loved for that valour which preserves mankind.

stronger than he, drove him from the land of the argives, over

then mighty praetus argos’ sceptre sway’d,

which jove had made him ruler.

whose hard commands bellerophon obey’d.
with direful jealousy the monarch raged,
and the brave prince in numerous toils engaged.

for antea, wife of proetus, lusted

for him antaea burn’d with lawless flame,

after him, and would have had him lie with her in secret; but

and strove to tempt him from the paths of fame:

bellerophon was an honourable man and would not, so she told lies

in vain she tempted the relentless youth,
endued with wisdom, sacred fear, and truth.

about him to proetus.

first, dire chimaera’s conquest was enjoin’d;

monster, the chimaera, who was not a human being, but a goddess,

a mingled monster of no mortal kind!

for she had the head of a lion and the tail of a serpent, while

behind, a dragon’s fiery tail was spread;
a goat’s rough body bore a lion’s head;

her body was that of a goat, and she breathed forth flames of

her pitchy nostrils flaky flames expire;
her gaping throat emits infernal fire.

fire; but bellerophon slew her, for he was guided by signs from

“this pest he slaughter’d, (for he read the skies,

heaven.

and trusted heaven’s informing prodigies,)

he next fought the far-famed solymi, and this, he said,

then met in arms the solymæan crew,[169]
(fiercest of men,) and those the warrior slew;
next the bold amazons’ whole force defied;

was the hardest of all his battles.

and conquer’d still, for heaven was on his side.

thirdly, he killed the

“nor ended here his toils: his lycian foes,

amazons, women who were the peers of men, and as he was returning
thence the king devised yet another plan for his destruction; he

at his return, a treacherous ambush rose,

picked the bravest warriors in all lycia, and placed them in

with levell’d spears along the winding shore:

ambuscade, but not a man ever came back, for bellerophon killed
every one of them.

there fell they breathless, and return’d no more.

then the king knew that he must be the valiant

hippolochus, and laodameia.

(fair e’en in heavenly eyes: her fruitful love

but when at last, distracted in his mind,

came to be hated by all the gods, he wandered all desolate and

forsook by heaven, forsaking humankind,

dismayed upon the alean plain, gnawing at his own heart, and

wide o’er the aleian field he chose to stray,

shunning the path of man.

a long, forlorn, uncomfortable way!
[170]

mars, insatiate of battle, killed his

woes heap’d on woes consumed his wasted heart:

killed by diana of the golden reins, for she was angered with

in combat on the solymaean plain.

her; but hippolochus was father to myself, and when he sent me to

hippolochus survived: from him i came,
the honour’d author of my birth and name;

troy he urged me again and again to fight ever among the foremost

by his decree i sought the trojan town;
by his instructions learn to win renown,
to stand the first in worth as in command,

and outvie my peers, so as not to shame the blood of my fathers

to add new honours to my native land,
before my eyes my mighty sires to place,

who were the noblest in ephyra and in all lycia.

and emulate the glories of our race.

this, then, is
the descent i claim.
”

”

thus did he speak, and the heart of diomed was glad.

he spoke, and transport fill’d tydides’ heart;

he planted

in earth the generous warrior fix’d his dart,

his spear in the ground, and spoke to him with friendly words.

then friendly, thus the lycian prince address’d:

“then,” he said, “you are an old friend of my father’s house.

“welcome, my brave hereditary guest!
thus ever let us meet, with kind embrace,
nor stain the sacred friendship of our race.
know, chief, our grandsires have been guests of old;

great oeneus once entertained bellerophon for twenty days, and

œneus the strong, bellerophon the bold:
our ancient seat his honour’d presence graced,
where twenty days in genial rites he pass’d.

the two exchanged presents.

the parting heroes mutual presents left;

oeneus gave a belt rich with purple,

a golden goblet was thy grandsire’s gift;
œneus a belt of matchless work bestowed,
that rich with tyrian dye refulgent glow’d.

and bellerophon a double cup, which i left at home when i set out

(this from his pledge i learn’d, which, safely stored

for troy.

among my treasures, still adorns my board:

i do not remember tydeus, for he was taken from us

for tydeus left me young, when thebe’s wall

while i was yet a child, when the army of the achaeans was cut to

beheld the sons of greece untimely fall.

pieces before thebes.

)

henceforth, however, i must be your host in

mindful of this, in friendship let us join;

middle argos, and you mine in lycia, if i should ever go there;

if heaven our steps to foreign lands incline,
my guest in argos thou, and i in lycia thine.

let us avoid one another’s spears even during a general
