in the full harvest of yon ample field;

kill, if i overtake them and heaven delivers them into my hand;

enough of greeks shall dye thy spear with gore;

so again with yourself, there are many achaeans whose lives you

but thou and diomed be foes no more.

may take if you can; we two, then, will exchange armour, that all

now change we arms, and prove to either host

present may know of the old ties that subsist between us.

we guard the friendship of the line we boast.

hector went to the fair house of alexandrus, which he had built

gold.

his brother-chief, whose useless arms lay round,

he found alexandrus within the house, busied about his

his eyes delighting with their splendid show,

armour, his shield and cuirass, and handling his curved bow;

brightening the shield, and polishing the bow.

there, too, sat argive helen with her women, setting them their

beside him helen with her virgins stands,

several tasks; and as hector saw him he rebuked him with words of

guides their rich labours, and instructs their hands.
him thus inactive, with an ardent look

scorn.

the prince beheld, and high-resenting spoke.

“sir,” said he, “you do ill to nurse this rancour; the

“thy hate to troy, is this the time to show?
(o wretch ill-fated, and thy country’s foe!
)

people perish fighting round this our town; you would yourself

paris and greece against us both conspire,
thy close resentment, and their vengeful ire.
for thee great ilion’s guardian heroes fall,
till heaps of dead alone defend her wall,
for thee the soldier bleeds, the matron mourns,
and wasteful war in all its fury burns.
ungrateful man!
deserves not this thy care,

chide one whom you saw shirking his part in the combat.

our troops to hearten, and our toils to share?

up then,

rise, or behold the conquering flames ascend,

or ere long the city will be in a blaze.

and all the phrygian glories at an end.

”

”

and alexandrus answered, “hector, your rebuke is just; listen

“brother, ’tis just, (replied the beauteous youth,)
thy free remonstrance proves thy worth and truth:

therefore, and believe me when i tell you that i am not here so

yet charge my absence less, o generous chief!

much through rancour or ill-will towards the trojans, as from a

on hate to troy, than conscious shame and grief:
here, hid from human eyes, thy brother sate,

desire to indulge my grief.

and mourn’d, in secret, his and ilion’s fate.

my wife was even now gently urging me

’tis now enough; now glory spreads her charms,
and beauteous helen calls her chief to arms.

to battle, and i hold it better that i should go, for victory is

conquest to-day my happier sword may bless,

ever fickle.

’tis man’s to fight, but heaven’s to give success.

wait, then, while i put on my armour, or go first

but while i arm, contain thy ardent mind;

and i will follow.
i shall be sure to overtake you.

or go, and paris shall not lag behind.

”

”
[illustration: ] hector chiding paris

hector made no answer, but helen tried to soothe him.

he said, nor answer’d priam’s warlike son;
when helen thus with lowly grace begun:

“brother,”

“oh, generous brother!
(if the guilty dame
that caused these woes deserve a sister’s name!
)

said she, “to my abhorred and sinful self, would that a whirlwind

would heaven, ere all these dreadful deeds were done,

had caught me up on the day my mother brought me forth, and had

the day that show’d me to the golden sun
had seen my death!

borne me to some mountain or to the waves of the roaring sea that

why did not whirlwinds bear
the fatal infant to the fowls of air?

should have swept me away ere this mischief had come about.

why sunk i not beneath the whelming tide,

but,

and midst the roarings of the waters died?

since the gods have devised these evils, would, at any rate, that

heaven fill’d up all my ills, and i accursed
bore all, and paris of those ills the worst.

i had been wife to a better man—to one who could smart under

helen at least a braver spouse might claim,

dishonour and men’s evil speeches.

warm’d with some virtue, some regard of fame!

this fellow was never yet to

now tired with toils, thy fainting limbs recline,

be depended upon, nor never will be, and he will surely reap what

with toils, sustain’d for paris’ sake and mine

he has sown.

the gods have link’d our miserable doom,

still, brother, come in and rest upon this seat, for

our present woe, and infamy to come:

it is you who bear the brunt of that toil that has been caused by

wide shall it spread, and last through ages long,

my hateful self and by the sin of alexandrus—both of whom jove

example sad!

has doomed to be a theme of song among those that shall be born

and theme of future song.

hereafter.

”

and hector answered, “bid me not be seated, helen, for all the

the chief replied: “this time forbids to rest;
the trojan bands, by hostile fury press’d,

goodwill you bear me.

demand their hector, and his arm require;

i cannot stay.

the combat urges, and my soul’s on fire.

i am in haste to help the

urge thou thy knight to march where glory calls,

trojans, who miss me greatly when i am not among them; but urge

and timely join me, ere i leave the walls.

your husband, and of his own self also let him make haste to

ere yet i mingle in the direful fray,

overtake me before i am out of the city.

my wife, my infant, claim a moment’s stay;

i must go home to see my

this day (perhaps the last that sees me here)

household, my wife and my little son, for i know not whether i

demands a parting word, a tender tear:

shall ever again return to them, or whether the gods will cause

this day, some god who hates our trojan land

me to fall by the hands of the achaeans.

may vanquish hector by a grecian hand.

”

”

then hector left her, and forthwith was at his own house.

he said, and pass’d with sad presaging heart
to seek his spouse, his soul’s far dearer part;
at home he sought her, but he sought in vain;
she, with one maid of all her menial train,
had hence retired; and with her second joy,

he did

the young astyanax, the hope of troy,

not find andromache, for she was on the wall with her child and

pensive she stood on ilion’s towery height,
beheld the war, and sicken’d at the sight;

one of her maids, weeping bitterly.

there her sad eyes in vain her lord explore,
or weep the wounds her bleeding country bore.

seeing, then, that she was

but he who found not whom his soul desired,

whose virtue charm’d him as her beauty fired,

said, “women, tell me, and tell me true, where did andromache go

stood in the gates, and ask’d “what way she bent

if to the fane she went,
where late the mourning matrons made resort;

was it to my sisters, or to my brothers’

or is she at the temple of minerva where the other women

or sought her sisters in the trojan court?

his good housekeeper answered, “hector, since you bid me tell you

of ilius, for she had heard the trojans were being hard pressed,

to mark the fortunes of the doubtful day.
troy fled, she heard, before the grecian sword;
she heard, and trembled for her absent lord:

and that the achaeans were in great force: she went to the wall

distracted with surprise, she seem’d to fly,

fear on her cheek, and sorrow in her eye.
the nurse attended with her infant boy,

child.

the young astyanax, the hope of troy.

”

hector hurried from the house when she had done speaking, and

hector this heard, return’d without delay;

when he

through streets of palaces, and walks of state;

all i can ask of heaven, an early tomb!

comfort me when you are gone, save only sorrow.

so shall my days in one sad tenor run,
and end with sorrows as they first begun.

i have neither

no parent now remains my griefs to share,

father nor mother now.

no father’s aid, no mother’s tender care.

achilles slew my father when he sacked

the fierce achilles wrapt our walls in fire,
laid thebe waste, and slew my warlike sire!

thebe the goodly city of the cilicians.

his fate compassion in the victor bred;

he slew him, but did not

his radiant arms preserved from hostile spoil,

and hector answered, “wife, i too have thought upon all this, but

the chief replied: “that post shall be my care,
not that alone, but all the works of war.

with what face should i look upon the trojans, men or women, if i

how would the sons of troy, in arms renown’d,
and troy’s proud dames, whose garments sweep the ground
attaint the lustre of my former name,

shirked battle like a coward?

should hector basely quit the field of fame?
my early youth was bred to martial pains,

i cannot do so: i know nothing save

my soul impels me to the embattled plains!

to fight bravely in the forefront of the trojan host and win

let me be foremost to defend the throne,

renown alike for my father and myself.

and guard my father’s glories, and my own.
“yet come it will, the day decreed by fates!
(how my heart trembles while my tongue relates!

well do i know that the

)

day will surely come when mighty ilius shall be destroyed with

the day when thou, imperial troy!
must bend,
and see thy warriors fall, thy glories end.

priam and priam’s people, but i grieve for none of these—not even

and yet no dire presage so wounds my mind,
my mother’s death, the ruin of my kind,
not priam’s hoary hairs defiled with gore,

for hecuba, nor king priam, nor for my brothers many and brave
who may fall in the dust before their foes—for none of these do i

not all my brothers gasping on the shore;

grieve as for yourself when the day shall come on which some one

as thine, andromache!

of the achaeans shall rob you for ever of your freedom, and bear

thy griefs i dread:

you weeping away.

i see thee trembling, weeping, captive led!

it may be that you will have to ply the loom in

the thoughts of glory past, and present shame,

him who would have put away the day of captivity from you.

a thousand griefs shall waken at the name!

may i

may i lie cold before that dreadful day,

lie dead under the barrow that is heaped over my body ere i hear

press’d with a load of monumental clay!
thy hector, wrapt in everlasting sleep,

your cry as they carry you into bondage.

shall neither hear thee sigh, nor see thee weep.

his mother’s conscious heart o’erflows with joy.

”

with this he laid the child again in the arms of his wife, who

he spoke, and fondly gazing on her charms,
restored the pleasing burden to her arms;

took him to her own soft bosom, smiling through her tears.

soft on her fragrant breast the babe she laid,
hush’d to repose, and with a smile survey’d.
the troubled pleasure soon chastised by fear,
she mingled with a smile a tender tear.

as her

and dried the falling drops, and thus pursued:

bitterly to heart.

“andromache!
my soul’s far better part,
why with untimely sorrows heaves thy heart?

no one can hurry me down to hades before my

no hostile hand can antedate my doom,
till fate condemns me to the silent tomb.

time, but if a man’s hour is come, be he brave or be he coward,

fix’d is the term to all the race of earth;

there is no escape for him when he has once been born.

and such the hard condition of our birth:
no force can then resist, no flight can save,

go, then,

all sink alike, the fearful and the brave.

within the house, and busy yourself with your daily duties, your

no more—but hasten to thy tasks at home,

loom, your distaff, and the ordering of your servants; for war is

there guide the spindle, and direct the loom:
me glory summons to the martial scene,
the field of combat is the sphere for men.

man’s matter, and mine above all others of them that have been

where heroes war, the foremost place i claim,

born in ilius.

the first in danger as the first in fame.

”

”

he took his plumed helmet from the ground, and his wife went back

thus having said, the glorious chief resumes
his towery helmet, black with shading plumes.
his princess parts with a prophetic sigh,

again to her house, weeping bitterly and often looking back

unwilling parts, and oft reverts her eye

towards him.

that stream’d at every look; then, moving slow,

when she reached her home she found her maidens

sought her own palace, and indulged her woe.

within, and bade them all join in her lament; so they mourned

there, while her tears deplored the godlike man,
through all her train the soft infection ran;
the pious maids their mingled sorrows shed,

hector in his own house though he was yet alive, for they deemed

and mourn the living hector, as the dead.

paris did not remain long in his house.

as his feet could take him.

the wanton courser thus with reins unbound[176]

as a horse, stabled and fed, breaks

breaks from his stall, and beats the trembling ground;

loose and gallops gloriously over the plain to the place where he

pamper’d and proud, he seeks the wonted tides,
and laves, in height of blood his shining sides;

is wont to bathe in the fair-flowing river—he holds his head

high, and his mane streams upon his shoulders as he exults in his

in arms refulgent as the god of day,
the son of priam, glorying in his might,

speak.
“sir,” said he, “i fear that i have kept you waiting when

to whom the noble hector thus replied:

”

“o chief!

“my good brother,” answered hector, “you fight bravely, and no

in blood, and now in arms, allied!

man with any justice can make light of your doings in battle.
but

thy power in war with justice none contest;

you are careless and wilfully remiss.

known is thy courage, and thy strength confess’d.

it grieves me to the heart

what pity sloth should seize a soul so brave,

to hear the ill that the trojans speak about you, for they have

or godlike paris live a woman’s slave!
my heart weeps blood at what the trojans say,
and hopes thy deeds shall wipe the stain away.
haste then, in all their glorious labours share,

suffered much on your account.

for much they suffer, for thy sake, in war.

let us be going, and we will make
things right hereafter, should jove vouchsafe us to set the cup

these ills shall cease, whene’er by jove’s decree

of our deliverance before ever-living gods of heaven in our own

we crown the bowl to heaven and liberty:

and greece indignant through her seas returns.

book vii.

book vii.
argument

hector and ajax fight—hector is getting worsted when night comes

the single combat of hector and ajax.
the battle renewing with double ardour upon the return of hector,
minerva is under apprehensions for the greeks.
apollo, seeing her
descend from olympus, joins her near the scæan gate.
they agree to put
off the general engagement for that day, and incite hector to challenge
the greeks to a single combat.
nine of the princes accepting the
challenge, the lot is cast and falls upon ajax.
these heroes, after
several attacks, are parted by the night.
the trojans calling a
council, antenor purposes the delivery of helen to the greeks, to which
paris will not consent, but offers to restore them her riches.
priam
sends a herald to make this offer, and to demand a truce for burning
the dead, the last of which only is agreed to by agamemnon.
when the
funerals are performed, the greeks, pursuant to the advice of nestor,
erect a fortification to protect their fleet and camp, flanked with
towers, and defended by a ditch and palisades.
neptune testifies his
jealousy at this work, but is pacified by a promise from jupiter.
both
armies pass the night in feasting but jupiter disheartens the trojans
with thunder, and other signs of his wrath.
the three and twentieth day ends with the duel of hector and ajax,

on and parts them—they exchange presents—the burial of the dead,

the next day the truce is agreed; another is taken up in the
funeral rites of the slain and one more in building the

and the building of a wall round their ships by the achaeans—the

fortification before the ships.
so that somewhat about three days

achaeans buy their wine of agamemnon and menelaus.

is employed in this book.
the scene lies wholly in the field.

with these words hector passed through the gates, and his brother

so spoke the guardian of the trojan state,
then rush’d impetuous through the scæan gate.

alexandrus with him, both eager for the fray.

him paris follow’d to the dire alarms;
both breathing slaughter, both resolved in arms.

as when heaven

as when to sailors labouring through the main,

sends a breeze to sailors who have long looked for one in vain,

that long have heaved the weary oar in vain,
jove bids at length the expected gales arise;

and have laboured at their oars till they are faint with toil,

the gales blow grateful, and the vessel flies.

even so welcome was the sight of these two heroes to the trojans.

so welcome these to troy’s desiring train,
the bands are cheer’d, the war awakes again.

thereon alexandrus killed menesthius the son of areithous; he

bold paris first the work of death begun

lived in arne, and was son of areithous the mace-man, and of

on great menestheus, areithous’ son,

phylomedusa.

sprung from the fair philomeda’s embrace,

hector threw a spear at eioneus and struck him dead

the pleasing arnè was his native place.
then sunk eioneus to the shades below,

with a wound in the neck under the bronze rim of his helmet.

beneath his steely casque[177] he felt the blow
full on his neck, from hector’s weighty hand;

glaucus, moreover, son of hippolochus, captain of the lycians, in

and roll’d, with limbs relax’d, along the land.

hard hand-to-hand fight smote iphinous son of dexius on the

shoulder, as he was springing on to his chariot behind his fleet

fix’d in the shoulder as he mounts his steeds;

mares; so he fell to earth from the car, and there was no life

headlong he tumbles: his slack nerves unbound,

left in him.

drop the cold useless members on the ground.

when, therefore, minerva saw these men making havoc of the

from vast olympus to the gleaming plain

nor shot less swift from ilion’s towery height.

and apollo, who was looking on from pergamus, went out to meet

radiant they met, beneath the beechen shade;

her; for he wanted the trojans to be victorious.
the pair met by

when thus apollo to the blue-eyed maid:

the oak tree, and king apollo son of jove was first to speak.
“what would you have,” said he, “daughter of great jove, that

“what cause, o daughter of almighty jove!

your proud spirit has sent you hither from olympus?

thus wings thy progress from the realms above?

have you no
pity upon the trojans, and would you incline the scales of

victory in favour of the danaans?

to give to greece the long divided day?

let me persuade you—for it will

too much has troy already felt thy hate,

be better thus—stay the combat for to-day, but let them renew the

now breathe thy rage, and hush the stern debate;
this day, the business of the field suspend;

fight hereafter till they compass the doom of ilius, since you

war soon shall kindle, and great ilion bend;
since vengeful goddesses confederate join

goddesses have made up your minds to destroy the city.

to raze her walls, though built by hands divine.

”

”

and minerva answered, “so be it, far-darter; it was in this mind

to whom the progeny of jove replies:

that i came down from olympus to the trojans and achaeans.

“i left, for this, the council of the skies:

tell

but who shall bid conflicting hosts forbear,

me, then, how do you propose to end this present fighting?

what art shall calm the furious sons of war?

”

”

apollo, son of jove, replied, “let us incite great hector to

a warrior worthy to be hector’s foe.

”

”

sage helenus their secret counsels knew;

the gods; he therefore went up to hector and said, “hector son of

thus told the dictates of his sacred breast:

priam, peer of gods in counsel, i am your brother, let me then

“o son of priam!

persuade you.

let thy faithful ear
receive my words: thy friend and brother hear!

bid the other trojans and achaeans all of them take

their seats, and challenge the best man among the achaeans to

the warring nations to suspend their rage;

meet you in single combat.

then dare the boldest of the hostile train

i have heard the voice of the

to mortal combat on the listed plain.

ever-living gods, and the hour of your doom is not yet come.

for not this day shall end thy glorious date;
the gods have spoke it, and their voice is fate.

”

”

hector was glad when he heard this saying, and went in among the

he said: the warrior heard the word with joy;

trojans, grasping his spear by the middle to hold them back, and

then with his spear restrain’d the youth of troy,
held by the midst athwart.

they all sat down.

on either hand

agamemnon also bade the achaeans be seated.

the squadrons part; the expecting trojans stand;
great agamemnon bids the greeks forbear:

but minerva and apollo, in the likeness of vultures, perched on

they breathe, and hush the tumult of the war.
the athenian maid,[178] and glorious god of day,
with silent joy the settling hosts survey:

father jove’s high oak tree, proud of their men; and the ranks

in form of vultures, on the beech’s height

sat close ranged together, bristling with shield and helmet and

they sit conceal’d, and wait the future fight.
the thronging troops obscure the dusky fields,

spear.

horrid with bristling spears, and gleaming shields.

as when the rising west wind furs the face of the sea and

as when a general darkness veils the main,
(soft zephyr curling the wide wat’ry plain,)
the waves scarce heave, the face of ocean sleeps,

the waters grow dark beneath it, so sat the companies of trojans

and a still horror saddens all the deeps;
thus in thick orders settling wide around,

and achaeans upon the plain.

at length composed they sit, and shade the ground.

and hector spoke thus:—

great hector first amidst both armies broke
the solemn silence, and their powers bespoke:

“hear me, trojans and achaeans, that i may speak even as i am

“hear, all ye trojan, all ye grecian bands,
what my soul prompts, and what some god commands.

minded; jove on his high throne has brought our oaths and

great jove, averse our warfare to compose,

covenants to nothing, and foreshadows ill for both of us, till

o’erwhelms the nations with new toils and woes;
war with a fiercer tide once more returns,

you either take the towers of troy, or are yourselves vanquished

till ilion falls, or till yon navy burns.
you then, o princes of the greeks!

at your ships.

appear;

the princes of the achaeans are here present in

’tis hector speaks, and calls the gods to hear:
from all your troops select the boldest knight,

the midst of you; let him, then, that will fight me stand forward
as your champion against hector.

and him, the boldest, hector dares to fight.

thus i say, and may jove be
witness between us.
if your champion slay me, let him strip me of

here if i fall, by chance of battle slain,

my armour and take it to your ships, but let him send my body

be his my spoil, and his these arms remain;
but let my body, to my friends return’d,

home that the trojans and their wives may give me my dues of fire

by trojan hands and trojan flames be burn’d.

when i am dead.
in like manner, if apollo vouchsafe me glory and

and if apollo, in whose aid i trust,

i slay your champion, i will strip him of his armour and take it

shall stretch your daring champion in the dust;

to the city of ilius, where i will hang it in the temple of

if mine the glory to despoil the foe;

apollo, but i will give up his body, that the achaeans may bury

on phœbus’ temple i’ll his arms bestow:

him at their ships, and then build him a mound by the wide waters

the breathless carcase to your navy sent,

of the hellespont.

greece on the shore shall raise a monument;

then will one say hereafter as he sails his

which when some future mariner surveys,

ship over the sea, ‘this is the monument of one who died long

wash’d by broad hellespont’s resounding seas,
thus shall he say, ‘a valiant greek lies there,

since a champion who was slain by mighty hector.

by hector slain, the mighty man of war,’

’ thus will one

the stone shall tell your vanquish’d hero’s name

say, and my fame shall not be lost.

and distant ages learn the victor’s fame.

”

”

thus did he speak, but they all held their peace, ashamed to

this fierce defiance greece astonish’d heard,

decline the challenge, yet fearing to accept it, till at last

blush’d to refuse, and to accept it fear’d.

menelaus rose and rebuked them, for he was angry.

stern menelaus first the silence broke,

“alas,” he

and, inly groaning, thus opprobrious spoke:

cried, “vain braggarts, women forsooth not men, double-dyed

“women of greece!
o scandal of your race,

indeed will be the stain upon us if no man of the danaans will

whose coward souls your manly form disgrace,
how great the shame, when every age shall know
that not a grecian met this noble foe!

now face hector.

go then!

may you be turned every man of you into earth

resolve to earth, from whence ye grew,

and water as you sit spiritless and inglorious in your places.

a heartless, spiritless, inglorious crew!

i

be what ye seem, unanimated clay,

will myself go out against this man, but the upshot of the fight

myself will dare the danger of the day;
’tis man’s bold task the generous strife to try,

will be from on high in the hands of the immortal gods.

but in the hands of god is victory.

”

”

with these words he put on his armour; and then, o menelaus, your

these words scarce spoke, with generous ardour press’d,
his manly limbs in azure arms he dress’d.
that day, atrides!

life would have come to an end at the hands of hands of hector,

a superior hand

for he was far better the man, had not the princes of the

had stretch’d thee breathless on the hostile strand;

achaeans sprung upon you and checked you.

but all at once, thy fury to compose,

king agamemnon caught

the kings of greece, an awful band, arose;
even he their chief, great agamemnon, press’d

him by the right hand and said, “menelaus, you are mad; a truce

thy daring hand, and this advice address’d:

to this folly.

“whither, o menelaus!
wouldst thou run,

be patient in spite of passion, do not think of

and tempt a fate which prudence bids thee shun?
grieved though thou art, forbear the rash design;

fighting a man so much stronger than yourself as hector son of

great hector’s arm is mightier far than thine:

priam, who is feared by many another as well as you.
even
achilles, who is far more doughty than you are, shrank from

even fierce achilles learn’d its force to fear,

meeting him in battle.

and trembling met this dreadful son of war.

sit down your own people, and the achaeans

sit thou secure, amidst thy social band;

will send some other champion to fight hector; fearless and fond

greece in our cause shall arm some powerful hand.
the mightiest warrior of the achaian name,

of battle though he be, i ween his knees will bend gladly under

though bold and burning with desire of fame,
content the doubtful honour might forego,

him if he comes out alive from the hurly-burly of this fight.

so great the danger, and so brave the foe.

”

”

with these words of reasonable counsel he persuaded his brother,

he said, and turn’d his brother’s vengeful mind;

whereon his squires gladly stripped the armour from off his

he stoop’d to reason, and his rage resign’d,
no longer bent to rush on certain harms;
his joyful friends unbrace his azure arms.
he from whose lips divine persuasion flows,
grave nestor, then, in graceful act arose;
thus to the kings he spoke: “what grief, what shame

shoulders.

how shall, alas!

“the achaean land is fallen upon evil times.

her hoary heroes mourn
their sons degenerate, and their race a scorn!
what tears shall down thy silvery beard be roll’d,

the old knight

and arcadians were gathered in fight by the rapid river celadon

i led my troops to phea’s trembling wall,
and with the arcadian spears my prowess tried,

under the walls of pheia, and round about the waters of the river

where celadon rolls down his rapid tide.

iardanus.

great areithous, known from shore to shore

broke the battalions of the foe with his iron mace.

victory.

by heaven inspired,

then casts before him, and with transport cries:

when ajax saw his mark he knew it and was glad; he threw it to

“warriors!

the ground and said, “my friends, the lot is mine, and i rejoice,

i claim the lot, and arm with joy;

for i shall vanquish hector.

be mine the conquest of this chief of troy.

i will put on my armour; meanwhile,

now while my brightest arms my limbs invest,

pray to king jove in silence among yourselves that the trojans

to saturn’s son be all your vows address’d:
but pray in secret, lest the foes should hear,

may not hear you—or aloud if you will, for we fear no man.

and deem your prayers the mean effect of fear.

none

said i in secret?
no, your vows declare

shall overcome me, neither by force nor cunning, for i was born

in such a voice as fills the earth and air,
lives there a chief whom ajax ought to dread?

and bred in salamis, and can hold my own in all things.

ajax, in all the toils of battle bred!
from warlike salamis i drew my birth,
and, born to combats, fear no force on earth.

”

”
he said.

with this they fell praying to king jove the son of saturn, and

the troops with elevated eyes,

thus would one of them say as he looked into the vault of heaven,

implore the god whose thunder rends the skies:

“father jove that rulest from ida, most glorious in power,

“o father of mankind, superior lord!
on lofty ida’s holy hill adored:
who in the highest heaven hast fix’d thy throne,
supreme of gods!

vouchsafe victory to ajax, and let him win great glory: but if

unbounded and alone:

you wish well to hector also and would protect him, grant to each

grant thou, that telamon may bear away
the praise and conquest of this doubtful day;
or, if illustrious hector be thy care,

of them equal fame and prowess.

that both may claim it, and that both may share.

”

”

bronze.

sheathed in bright steel the giant-warrior shone:

he moves to combat with majestic pace;
so stalks in arms the grisly god of thrace,[182]

mars when he takes part among men whom jove has set fighting with

when jove to punish faithless men prepares,
and gives whole nations to the waste of wars,

one another—even so did huge ajax, bulwark of the achaeans,

thus march’d the chief, tremendous as a god;

his massy javelin quivering in his hand,

all troy stood trembling at the mighty man:

even of hector beat quickly, but he could not now retreat and

challenger.

a wall—a shield of bronze with seven folds of ox-hide—the work of

as from a brazen tower, o’erlook’d the field.
huge was its orb, with seven thick folds o’ercast,

(the work of tychius, who in hylè dwell’d

leather.

and in all arts of armoury excell’d,)

this ajax bore before his manly breast,

and over these he had set an eighth layer of bronze.

and, threatening, thus his adverse chief address’d:

holding this

“hector!

shield before him, ajax son of telamon came close up to hector,

approach my arm, and singly know

and menaced him saying, “hector, you shall now learn, man to man,

what strength thou hast, and what the grecian foe.

what kind of champions the danaans have among them even besides

achilles shuns the fight; yet some there are,

lion-hearted achilles cleaver of the ranks of men.

not void of soul, and not unskill’d in war:

he now abides

let him, unactive on the sea-beat shore,

at the ships in anger with agamemnon shepherd of his people, but

indulge his wrath, and aid our arms no more;
whole troops of heroes greece has yet to boast,
and sends thee one, a sample of her host,

there are many of us who are well able to face you; therefore

such as i am, i come to prove thy might;

begin the fight.

no more—be sudden, and begin the fight.

”

”

and hector answered, “noble ajax, son of telamon, captain of the

“o son of telamon, thy country’s pride!
(to ajax thus the trojan prince replied)

host, treat me not as though i were some puny boy or woman that

me, as a boy, or woman, wouldst thou fright,

cannot fight.

new to the field, and trembling at the fight?

i have been long used to the blood and butcheries

thou meet’st a chief deserving of thy arms,

of battle.

to combat born, and bred amidst alarms:

i am quick to turn my leathern shield either to right

i know to shift my ground, remount the car,

or left, for this i deem the main thing in battle.

turn, charge, and answer every call of war;
to right, to left, the dexterous lance i wield,

i can charge

and bear thick battle on my sounding shield/

among the chariots and horsemen, and in hand to hand fighting can

but open be our fight, and bold each blow;

delight the heart of mars; howbeit i would not take such a man as
you are off his guard—but i will smite you openly if i can.

i steal no conquest from a noble foe.

”

”

he poised his spear as he spoke, and hurled it from him.

“my sons, fight no longer, you are both of you valiant, and both

“forbear, my sons!
your further force to prove,
both dear to men, and both beloved of jove.
to either host your matchless worth is known,
each sounds your praise, and war is all your own.

are dear to jove; we know this; but night is now falling, and the

but now the night extends her awful shade;

behests of night may not be well gainsaid.

the goddess parts you; be the night obey’d.

ajax son of telamon answered, “idaeus, bid hector say so, for it

to whom great ajax his high soul express’d:
“o sage!
to hector be these words address’d.

was he that challenged our princes.

let him, who first provoked our chiefs to fight,
let him demand the sanction of the night;

let him speak first and i

if first he ask’d it, i content obey,

will accept his saying.

and cease the strife when hector shows the way.

“o first of greeks!

then hector said, “ajax, heaven has vouchsafed you stature and

(his noble foe rejoin’d)
whom heaven adorns, superior to thy kind,

strength, and judgement; and in wielding the spear you excel all

with strength of body, and with worth of mind!

others of the achaeans.

now martial law commands us to forbear;

let us for this day cease fighting;

hereafter we shall meet in glorious war,
some future day shall lengthen out the strife,

hereafter we will fight anew till heaven decide between us, and

and let the gods decide of death or life!

give victory to one or to the other; night is now falling, and

since, then, the night extends her gloomy shade,

the behests of night may not be well gainsaid.

and heaven enjoins it, be the night obey’d.

gladden, then, the

return, brave ajax, to thy grecian friends,

hearts of the achaeans at your ships, and more especially those
of your own followers and clansmen, while i, in the great city of

and joy the nations whom thy arm defends;

king priam, bring comfort to the trojans and their women, who vie

as i shall glad each chief, and trojan wife,

with one another in their prayers on my behalf.

who wearies heaven with vows for hector’s life.

let us, moreover,

but let us, on this memorable day,

exchange presents that it may be said among the achaeans and

exchange some gift: that greece and troy may say,

trojans, ‘they fought with might and main, but were reconciled

‘not hate, but glory, made these chiefs contend;

and parted in friendship.

and each brave foe was in his soul a friend.

’”

’”

as one that had been saved beyond their hopes.

their present triumph, as their late despair.

on the other side

but ajax, glorying in his hardy deed,

son of saturn.

of full five years, and of the nobler kind.

the victim falls; they strip the smoking hide,

divided it into joints; these they cut carefully up into smaller
pieces, putting them on the spits, roasting them sufficiently,

the beast they quarter, and the joints divide;

and then drawing them off.

then spread the tables, the repast prepare,

when they had done all this and had
prepared the feast, they ate it, and every man had his full and

each takes his seat, and each receives his share.

equal share, so that all were satisfied, and king agamemnon gave

the king himself (an honorary sign)

ajax some slices cut lengthways down the loin, as a mark of

before great ajax placed the mighty chine.

special honour.

[185]

as soon as they had had enough to eat and drink,

when now the rage of hunger was removed,

old nestor whose counsel was ever truest began to speak; with all

nestor, in each persuasive art approved,
the sage whose counsels long had sway’d the rest,

sincerity and goodwill, therefore, he addressed them thus:—

in words like these his prudent thought express’d:

“son of atreus, and other chieftains, inasmuch as many of the

“how dear, o kings!

achaeans are now dead, whose blood mars has shed by the banks of

this fatal day has cost,
what greeks are perish’d!
what a people lost!
what tides of blood have drench’d scamander’s shore!

the scamander, and their souls have gone down to the house of

what crowds of heroes sunk to rise no more!

hades, it will be well when morning comes that we should cease

then hear me, chief!
nor let the morrow’s light

fighting; we will then wheel our dead together with oxen and

awake thy squadrons to new toils of fight:
some space at least permit the war to breathe,

mules and burn them not far from the ships, that when we sail

while we to flames our slaughter’d friends bequeath,
from the red field their scatter’d bodies bear,
and nigh the fleet a funeral structure rear;

hence we may take the bones of our comrades home to their

so decent urns their snowy bones may keep,

children.

and pious children o’er their ashes weep.

hard by the funeral pyre we will build a barrow that

here, where on one promiscuous pile they blazed,

shall be raised from the plain for all in common; near this let

high o’er them all a general tomb be raised;

us set about building a high wall, to shelter ourselves and our

next, to secure our camp and naval powers,
raise an embattled wall, with lofty towers;

ships, and let it have well-made gates that there may be a way

from space to space be ample gates around,

through them for our chariots.
close outside we will dig a deep

for passing chariots; and a trench profound.

trench all round it to keep off both horse and foot, that the

so greece to combat shall in safety go,

trojan chieftains may not bear hard upon us.

nor fear the fierce incursions of the foe.

”

”

thus he spoke, and the princes shouted in applause.

’twas thus the sage his wholesome counsel moved;
the sceptred kings of greece his words approved.

meanwhile

meanwhile, convened at priam’s palace-gate,

the trojans held a council, angry and full of discord, on the

the trojan peers in nightly council sate;

acropolis by the gates of king priam’s palace; and wise antenor

a senate void of order, as of choice:

spoke.

their hearts were fearful, and confused their voice.

“hear me,” he said, “trojans, dardanians, and allies, that

antenor, rising, thus demands their ear:
“ye trojans, dardans, and auxiliars, hear!

i may speak even as i am minded.

’tis heaven the counsel of my breast inspires,

let us give up argive helen and

and i but move what every god requires:

her wealth to the sons of atreus, for we are now fighting in

let sparta’s treasures be this hour restored,
and argive helen own her ancient lord.

violation of our solemn covenants, and shall not prosper till we

the ties of faith, the sworn alliance, broke,
our impious battles the just gods provoke.

have done as i say.

as this advice ye practise, or reject,
so hope success, or dread the dire effect.

”

”

he then sat down and alexandrus husband of lovely helen rose to

the senior spoke and sate.

speak.

to whom replied

“antenor,” said he, “your words are not to my liking; you

the graceful husband of the spartan bride:
“cold counsels, trojan, may become thy years
but sound ungrateful in a warrior’s ears:
old man, if void of fallacy or art,
thy words express the purpose of thy heart,

can find a better saying than this if you will; if, however, you

thou, in thy time, more sound advice hast given;

have spoken in good earnest, then indeed has heaven robbed you of
your reason.

but wisdom has its date, assign’d by heaven.

i will speak plainly, and hereby notify to the

then hear me, princes of the trojan name!

trojans that i will not give up the woman; but the wealth that i

their treasures i’ll restore, but not the dame;

brought home with her from argos i will restore, and will add yet

my treasures too, for peace, i will resign;

further of my own.

but be this bright possession ever mine.

her slaughter’d heroes, and their bones inurn;

also be instant with them that they now cease fighting till we
burn our dead; hereafter we will fight anew, till heaven decide

that done, once more the fate of war be tried,

between us and give victory to one or to the other.

and whose the conquest, mighty jove decide!

with heroes’ corps: i war not with the dead:
go search your slaughtered chiefs on yonder plain,

the rites of fire.

”

when the two armies met.

them, and lifted them upon their waggons.

now in the twilight when it was not yet dawn, chosen bands of the

in shining circle round their father jove,
amazed beheld the wondrous works of man:

then he, whose trident shakes the earth, began:

what mortal in the whole world will again take the gods into his

our fanes frequent, our oracles implore,

if the proud grecians thus successful boast

their ships and driven a trench all round it, without offering

their rising bulwarks on the sea-beat coast?

the fame of this wall will reach as far as

see the long walls extending to the main,

dawn itself, and men will no longer think anything of the one

no god consulted, and no victim slain!
their fame shall fill the world’s remotest ends,

which phoebus apollo and myself built with so much labour for

wide as the morn her golden beam extends;
while old laomedon’s divine abodes,
those radiant structures raised by labouring gods,

laomedon.

shall, razed and lost, in long oblivion sleep.

”

jove was displeased and answered, “what, o shaker of the earth,

thus spoke the hoary monarch of the deep.
the almighty thunderer with a frown replies,

are you talking about?

that clouds the world, and blackens half the skies:

a god less powerful than yourself might be

“strong god of ocean!
thou, whose rage can make
the solid earth’s eternal basis shake!
what cause of fear from mortal works could move[187]
the meanest subject of our realms above?

alarmed at what they are doing, but your fame reaches as far as

where’er the sun’s refulgent rays are cast,
thy power is honour’d, and thy fame shall last.
but yon proud work no future age shall view,

dawn itself.

no trace remain where once the glory grew.

surely when the achaeans have gone home with their

the sapp’d foundations by thy force shall fall,

ships, you can shatter their wall and fling it into the sea; you

and, whelm’d beneath the waves, drop the huge wall:

can cover the beach with sand again, and the great wall of the

vast drifts of sand shall change the former shore:

achaeans will then be utterly effaced.

the ruin vanish’d, and the name no more.

”

”

thus did they converse, and by sunset the work of the achaeans

their supper.

pale fear got hold upon

while the deep thunder shook the aerial hall.

mighty son of saturn.

and large libations drench’d the thirsty ground:

then they laid themselves down to rest and

enjoyed the boon of sleep.

book viii.

book viii.
argument.

jove forbids the gods to interfere further—there is an even fight

the second battle, and the distress of the greeks.
jupiter assembles a council of the deities, and threatens them with the

till midday, but then jove inclines the scales of victory in

pains of tartarus if they assist either side: minerva only obtains of

favour of the trojans, who eventually chase the achaeans within

him that she may direct the greeks by her counsels.
the armies join
battle: jupiter on mount ida weighs in his balances the fates of both,
and affrights the greeks with his thunders and lightnings.
nestor alone
continues in the field in great danger: diomed relieves him; whose
exploits, and those of hector, are excellently described.
juno
endeavours to animate neptune to the assistance of the greeks, but in
vain.
the acts of teucer, who is at length wounded by hector, and
carried off.

their wall—juno and minerva set out to help the trojans: jove

juno and minerva prepare to aid the grecians, but are

sends iris to turn them back, but later on he promises juno that

restrained by iris, sent from jupiter.

she shall have her way in the end—hector’s triumph is stayed by

the night puts an end to the
battle.
hector continues in the field, (the greeks being driven to
their fortifications before the ships,) and gives orders to keep the
watch all night in the camp, to prevent the enemy from re-embarking and
escaping by flight.
they kindle fires through all the fields, and pass
the night under arms.
the time of seven and twenty days is employed from the opening of
the poem to the end of this book.
the scene here (except of the

nightfall—the trojans bivouac on the plain.

celestial machines) lies in the field towards the seashore.

now when morning, clad in her robe of saffron, had begun to

aurora now, fair daughter of the dawn,

suffuse light over the earth, jove called the gods in council on

sprinkled with rosy light the dewy lawn;
when jove convened the senate of the skies,

the topmost crest of serrated olympus.

where high olympus’ cloudy tops arise,
the sire of gods his awful silence broke;

then he spoke and all the

the heavens attentive trembled as he spoke:[189]

other gods gave ear.

“celestial states!
immortal gods!
give ear,

“hear me,” said he, “gods and goddesses,
that i may speak even as i am minded.

hear our decree, and reverence what ye hear;

let none of you neither

the fix’d decree which not all heaven can move;

goddess nor god try to cross me, but obey me every one of you

thou, fate!

that i may bring this matter to an end.

fulfil it!

if i see anyone acting

and, ye powers, approve!

apart and helping either trojans or danaans, he shall be beaten

what god but enters yon forbidden field,
who yields assistance, or but wills to yield,

inordinately ere he come back again to olympus; or i will hurl

back to the skies with shame he shall be driven,
gash’d with dishonest wounds, the scorn of heaven;
or far, oh far, from steep olympus thrown,

him down into dark tartarus far into the deepest pit under the

low in the dark tartarean gulf shall groan,

earth, where the gates are iron and the floor bronze, as far

with burning chains fix’d to the brazen floors,
and lock’d by hell’s inexorable doors;

beneath hades as heaven is high above the earth, that you may

as deep beneath the infernal centre hurl’d,[190]
as from that centre to the ethereal world.

learn how much the mightiest i am among you.

let him who tempts me, dread those dire abodes:
and know, the almighty is the god of gods.
league all your forces, then, ye powers above,

try me and find out

join all, and try the omnipotence of jove.

for yourselves.

let down our golden everlasting chain[191]

hangs me a golden chain from heaven, and lay hold

whose strong embrace holds heaven, and earth, and main

of it all of you, gods and goddesses together—tug as you will,

strive all, of mortal and immortal birth,

you will not drag jove the supreme counsellor from heaven to

to drag, by this, the thunderer down to earth:

earth; but were i to pull at it myself i should draw you up with

ye strive in vain!
if i but stretch this hand,

earth and sea into the bargain, then would i bind the chain about

i heave the gods, the ocean, and the land;
i fix the chain to great olympus’ height,

some pinnacle of olympus and leave you all dangling in the mid

and the vast world hangs trembling in my sight!

firmament.

for such i reign, unbounded and above;

so far am i above all others either of gods or men.

and such are men, and gods, compared to jove.

”

”

they were frightened and all of them of held their peace, for he

the all-mighty spoke, nor durst the powers reply:
a reverend horror silenced all the sky;
trembling they stood before their sovereign’s look;

had spoken masterfully; but at last minerva answered, “father,

at length his best-beloved, the power of wisdom, spoke:
“o first and greatest!

son of saturn, king of kings, we all know that your might is not

god, by gods adored
we own thy might, our father and our lord!

to be gainsaid, but we are also sorry for the danaan warriors,

but, ah!
permit to pity human state:

who are perishing and coming to a bad end.

if not to help, at least lament their fate.

we will, however,

from fields forbidden we submiss refrain,

since you so bid us, refrain from actual fighting, but we will

with arms unaiding mourn our argives slain;

make serviceable suggestions to the argives that they may not all

yet grant my counsels still their breasts may move,

of them perish in your displeasure.

or all must perish in the wrath of jove.

”

”

jove smiled at her and answered, “take heart, my child,

and smiled superior on his best beloved;

trito-born; i am not really in earnest, and i wish to be kind to

you.

the stedfast firmament beneath them shook:

”

rapt by the ethereal steeds the chariot roll’d;

refulgent, flash’d intolerable day.

midway twixt earth and starry heaven.

between the extended earth and starry sky.

after a while he reached

but when to ida’s topmost height he came,

many-fountained ida, mother of wild beasts, and gargarus, where

(fair nurse of fountains, and of savage game,)
where o’er her pointed summits proudly raised,

are his grove and fragrant altar.

his fane breathed odours, and his altar blazed:

there the father of gods and

there, from his radiant car, the sacred sire
of gods and men released the steeds of fire:

men stayed his horses, took them from the chariot, and hid them

blue ambient mists the immortal steeds embraced;

in a thick cloud; then he took his seat all glorious upon the

high on the cloudy point his seat he placed;
thence his broad eye the subject world surveys,

topmost crests, looking down upon the city of troy and the ships
of the achaeans.

the town, and tents, and navigable seas.

the achaeans took their morning meal hastily at the ships, and

now had the grecians snatch’d a short repast,

afterwards put on their armour.

and buckled on their shining arms with haste.

the trojans on the other hand

troy roused as soon; for on this dreadful day

likewise armed themselves throughout the city, fewer in numbers
but nevertheless eager perforce to do battle for their wives and
children.

the fate of fathers, wives, and infants lay.

all the gates were flung wide open, and horse and foot

the gates unfolding pour forth all their train;

sallied forth with the tramp as of a great multitude.

squadrons on squadrons cloud the dusky plain:
men, steeds, and chariots shake the trembling ground,
the tumult thickens, and the skies resound;

when they were got together in one place, shield clashed with

and now with shouts the shocking armies closed,

shield, and spear with spear, in the conflict of mail-clad men.

to lances lances, shields to shields opposed,

mighty was the din as the bossed shields pressed hard on one

host against host with shadowy legends drew,
the sounding darts in iron tempests flew;

another—death—cry and shout of triumph of slain and slayers, and

victors and vanquish’d join promiscuous cries,
triumphant shouts and dying groans arise;

the earth ran red with blood.

with streaming blood the slippery fields are dyed,
and slaughter’d heroes swell the dreadful tide.

now so long as the day waxed and it was still morning their

long as the morning beams, increasing bright,
o’er heaven’s clear azure spread the sacred light,

weapons beat against one another, and the people fell, but when

commutual death the fate of war confounds,
each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

the sun had reached mid-heaven, the sire of all balanced his

but when the sun the height of heaven ascends,

golden scales, and put two fates of death within them, one for

the sire of gods his golden scales suspends,[192]
with equal hand: in these explored the fate

the trojans and the other for the achaeans.

of greece and troy, and poised the mighty weight:

he took the balance
by the middle, and when he lifted it up the day of the achaeans
sank; the death-fraught scale of the achaeans settled down upon

press’d with its load, the grecian balance lies

the ground, while that of the trojans rose heavenwards.

low sunk on earth, the trojan strikes the skies.

then he

then jove from ida’s top his horrors spreads;

thundered aloud from ida, and sent the glare of his lightning

the clouds burst dreadful o’er the grecian heads;
thick lightnings flash; the muttering thunder rolls;

upon the achaeans; when they saw this, pale fear fell upon them

their strength he withers, and unmans their souls.
before his wrath the trembling hosts retire;

and they were sore afraid.

the gods in terrors, and the skies on fire.

idomeneus dared not stay nor yet agamemnon, nor did the two

nor great idomeneus that sight could bear,

ajaxes, servants of mars, hold their ground.

nor each stern ajax, thunderbolts of war:

neleus.

“great perils, father!

wait the unequal fight;
these younger champions will oppress thy might.

hard, your force is spent, and age is heavy upon you, your squire

thy veins no more with ancient vigour glow,

is naught, and your horses are slow to move.

weak is thy servant, and thy coursers slow.

see what the horses of tros can do—how cleverly they can scud

observe the steeds of tros, renown’d in war.

hither and thither over the plain either in flight or in pursuit.

practised alike to turn, to stop, to chase,
to dare the fight, or urge the rapid race:

i took them from the hero aeneas.

these late obey’d æneas’ guiding rein;

let our squires attend to your

leave thou thy chariot to our faithful train;

own steeds, but let us drive mine straight at the trojans, that

with these against yon trojans will we go,
nor shall great hector want an equal foe;

hector may learn how furiously i too can wield my spear.

fierce as he is, even he may learn to fear
the thirsty fury of my flying spear.

”

”

nestor knight of gerene hearkened to his words.

thus said the chief; and nestor, skill’d in war,

this day, averse, the sovereign of the skies
assists great hector, and our palm denies.
some other sun may see the happier hour,
when greece shall conquer by his heavenly power.

please him, he will again grant it to ourselves; no man, however

’tis not in man his fix’d decree to move:

brave, may thwart the purpose of jove, for he is far stronger

the great will glory to submit to jove.

your ships, for i shall kill you with my own hand.

thy once proud hopes, presumptuous prince!
are fled;
this arm shall reach thy heart, and stretch thee dead.

”

the son of tydeus was in two minds whether or no to turn his

now fears dissuade him, and now hopes invite.

horses round again and fight him.

to stop his coursers, and to stand the fight;

did jove thunder from the heights of ida in token to the trojans

on ida’s summits thunder’d from above.
great hector heard; he saw the flashing light,

that he would turn the battle in their favour.
hector then

(the sign of conquest,) and thus urged the fight:

shouted to them and said, “trojans, lycians, and dardanians,

“hear, every trojan, lycian, dardan band,

lovers of close fighting, be men, my friends, and fight with

all famed in war, and dreadful hand to hand.

might and with main; i see that jove is minded to vouchsafe

be mindful of the wreaths your arms have won,

victory and great glory to myself, while he will deal destruction

your great forefathers’ glories, and your own.
heard ye the voice of jove?
success and fame
await on troy, on greece eternal shame.

upon the danaans.

in vain they skulk behind their boasted wall,

fools, for having thought of building this weak

weak bulwarks; destined by this arm to fall.
high o’er their slighted trench our steeds shall bound,

and worthless wall.

and pass victorious o’er the levell’d mound.

it shall not stay my fury; my horses will
spring lightly over their trench, and when i am at their ships

soon as before yon hollow ships we stand,

forget not to bring me fire that i may burn them, while i

fight each with flames, and toss the blazing brand;
till, their proud navy wrapt in smoke and fires,

slaughter the argives who will be all dazed and bewildered by the

all greece, encompass’d, in one blaze expires.

smoke.

and thou, podargus!

aethon and goodly lampus, pay me for your keep now and for all

prove thy generous race;

and all your master’s well-spent care repay.

now swift pursue, now thunder uncontroll’d:

vulcanian arms, the labour of a god:

could we take these

these if we gain, then victory, ye powers!

two things, the achaeans would set sail in their ships this
self-same night.

this night, this glorious night, the fleet is ours!

”

”

thus did he vaunt, but queen juno made high olympus quake as she

that heard, deep anguish stung saturnia’s soul;

shook with rage upon her throne.

she shook her throne, that shook the starry pole:

then said she to the mighty god

and thus to neptune: “thou, whose force can make

of neptune, “what now, wide ruling lord of the earthquake?

the stedfast earth from her foundations shake,

can

seest thou the greeks by fates unjust oppress’d,

you find no compassion in your heart for the dying danaans, who
bring you many a welcome offering to helice and to aegae?

nor swells thy heart in that immortal breast?

wish

yet ægae, helicè, thy power obey,[195]

them well then.

and gifts unceasing on thine altars lay.

if all of us who are with the danaans were to

would all the deities of greece combine,

drive the trojans back and keep jove from helping them, he would

in vain the gloomy thunderer might repine:

have to sit there sulking alone on ida.

sole should he sit, with scarce a god to friend,
and see his trojans to the shades descend:
such be the scene from his idaean bower;
ungrateful prospect to the sullen power!

”

”

“what rage, what madness, furious queen!

tongue, what are you talking about?

is thine?

we other gods must not set

i war not with the highest.
all above

ourselves against jove, for he is far stronger than we are.

the hollow vessels to his voice replied,)

shame on you cowardly creatures, brave in semblance only; where
are now our vaunts that we should prove victorious—the vaunts we
made so vaingloriously in lemnos, when we ate the flesh of horned

where now are all your glorious boasts of yore,

cattle and filled our mixing-bowls to the brim?
you vowed that

your hasty triumphs on the lemnian shore?

you would each of you stand against a hundred or two hundred men,

each fearless hero dares a hundred foes,

and now you prove no match even for one—for hector, who will be

while the feast lasts, and while the goblet flows;
but who to meet one martial man is found,

ere long setting our ships in a blaze.

when the fight rages, and the flames surround?

father jove, did you ever

o mighty jove!

so ruin a great king and rob him so utterly of his greatness?

o sire of the distress’d!
was ever king like me, like me oppress’d?
with power immense, with justice arm’d in vain;
my glory ravish’d, and my people slain!

yet, when to my sorrow i was coming hither, i never let my ship

to thee my vows were breathed from every shore;

pass your altars without offering the fat and thigh-bones of

what altar smoked not with our victims’ gore?

heifers upon every one of them, so eager was i to sack the city

with fat of bulls i fed the constant flame,

of troy.

and ask’d destruction to the trojan name.
now, gracious god!

vouchsafe me then this prayer—suffer us to escape at any

far humbler our demand;

rate with our lives, and let not the achaeans be so utterly

give these at least to ’scape from hector’s hand,

vanquished by the trojans.

and save the relics of the grecian land!

”

”

thus did he pray, and father jove pitying his tears vouchsafed

thus pray’d the king, and heaven’s great father heard

him that his people should live, not die; forthwith he sent them

his vows, in bitterness of soul preferr’d:
the wrath appeased, by happy signs declares,
and gives the people to their monarch’s prayers.

an eagle, most unfailingly portentous of all birds, with a young

his eagle, sacred bird of heaven!

he sent,

)

who paid their vows to panomphaean jove;
then let the prey before his altar fall;
the greeks beheld, and transport seized on all:

therefore, the people saw that the bird had come from jove, they

encouraged by the sign, the troops revive,

sprang more fiercely upon the trojans and fought more boldly.

and fierce on troy with doubled fury drive.

the dart drove on, and issued at his breast:

him as he fell forward from his chariot.

his ponderous buckler thunders on the ground.

after him came agamemnon and menelaus, sons of atreus, the two

forth rush a tide of greeks, the passage freed;

secure behind the telamonian shield

when ajax lifted his shield teucer would peer round, and when he

the skilful archer wide survey’d the field,

had hit any one in the throng, the man would fall dead; then

with every shaft some hostile victim slew,
then close beneath the sevenfold orb withdrew:

teucer would hie back to ajax as a child to its mother, and again

the conscious infant so, when fear alarms,
retires for safety to the mother’s arms.
thus ajax guards his brother in the field,

duck down under his shield.

moves as he moves, and turns the shining shield.

which of the trojans did brave teucer first kill?

who first by teucer’s mortal arrows bled?

orsilochus, and

bow.

“o youth forever dear!
(the monarch cried)

he went up to him and said, “teucer, man after my own heart,

thus, always thus, thy early worth be tried;

son of telamon, captain among the host, shoot on, and be at once

thy brave example shall retrieve our host,

the saving of the danaans and the glory of your father telamon,

thy country’s saviour, and thy father’s boast!

who brought you up and took care of you in his own house when you

sprung from an alien’s bed thy sire to grace,

were a child, bastard though you were.

the vigorous offspring of a stolen embrace:

cover him with glory

proud of his boy, he own’d the generous flame,
and the brave son repays his cares with fame.

though he is far off; i will promise and i will assuredly

now hear a monarch’s vow: if heaven’s high powers

perform; if aegis-bearing jove and minerva grant me to sack the

give me to raze troy’s long-defended towers;
whatever treasures greece for me design,

city of ilius, you shall have the next best meed of honour after

the next rich honorary gift be thine:

my own—a tripod, or two horses with their chariot, or a woman who

some golden tripod, or distinguished car,
with coursers dreadful in the ranks of war:
or some fair captive, whom thy eyes approve,

shall go up into your bed.

shall recompense the warrior’s toils with love.

”

”

and teucer answered, “most noble son of atreus, you need not urge

to this the chief: “with praise the rest inspire,
nor urge a soul already fill’d with fire.

me; from the moment we began to drive them back to ilius, i have

what strength i have, be now in battle tried,
till every shaft in phrygian blood be dyed.
since rallying from our wall we forced the foe,

never ceased so far as in me lies to look out for men whom i can

still aim’d at hector have i bent my bow:

shoot and kill; i have shot eight barbed shafts, and all of them

eight forky arrows from this hand have fled,
and eight bold heroes by their points lie dead:
but sure some god denies me to destroy

have been buried in the flesh of warlike youths, but this mad dog

this fury of the field, this dog of troy.

i cannot hit.
”

”

as he spoke he aimed another arrow straight at hector, for he was

he said, and twang’d the string.

bent on hitting him; nevertheless he missed him, and the arrow

the weapon flies
at hector’s breast, and sings along the skies:
he miss’d the mark; but pierced gorgythio’s heart,

hit priam’s brave son gorgythion in the breast.

and drench’d in royal blood the thirsty dart.

his mother, fair

(fair castianira, nymph of form divine,
this offspring added to king priam’s line.
)

castianeira, lovely as a goddess, had been married from aesyme,

as full-blown poppies, overcharged with rain,[196]

and now he bowed his head as a garden poppy in full bloom when it

decline the head, and drooping kiss the plain;

is weighed down by showers in spring—even thus heavy bowed his

so sinks the youth: his beauteous head, depress’d

head beneath the weight of his helmet.

beneath his helmet, drops upon his breast.

again his arrow missed, for apollo turned it aside; but he hit

yet fell not dry or guiltless to the ground:

the feather in his hand, just wing’d for flight,

just where the collar-bone divides the neck from the chest, a

touch’d where the neck and hollow chest unite;
there, where the juncture knits the channel bone,

very deadly place, and broke the sinew of his arm so that his

the furious chief discharged the craggy stone:

wrist was less, and the bow dropped from his hand as he fell

the bow-string burst beneath the ponderous blow,

forward on his knees.

and his numb’d hand dismiss’d his useless bow.

ajax saw that his brother had fallen, and

he fell: but ajax his broad shield display’d,
and screen’d his brother with the mighty shade;

shield.

the batter’d archer groaning to the shore.

in his great pain.

the greeks repulsed, retreat behind their wall,

achaeans to their deep trench with hector in all his glory at

or in the trench on heaps confusedly fall.
first of the foe, great hector march’d along,

their head.

with terror clothed, and more than mortal strong.

as a hound grips a wild boar or lion in flank or

as the bold hound, that gives the lion chase,

buttock when he gives him chase, and watches warily for his

with beating bosom, and with eager pace,
hangs on his haunch, or fastens on his heels,

wheeling, even so did hector follow close upon the achaeans, ever

guards as he turns, and circles as he wheels;
thus oft the grecians turn’d, but still they flew;
thus following, hector still the hindmost slew.

killing the hindmost as they rushed panic-stricken onwards.
when

when flying they had pass’d the trench profound,

they had fled through the set stakes and trench and many achaeans

and many a chief lay gasping on the ground;

had been laid low at the hands of the trojans, they halted at
their ships, calling upon one another and praying every man

before the ships a desperate stand they made,

instantly as they lifted up their hands to the gods; but hector

and fired the troops, and called the gods to aid.

wheeled his horses this way and that, his eyes glaring like those

fierce on his rattling chariot hector came:
his eyes like gorgon shot a sanguine flame
that wither’d all their host: like mars he stood:

of gorgo or murderous mars.

dire as the monster, dreadful as the god!

juno when she saw them had pity upon them, and at once said to

their strong distress the wife of jove survey’d;

minerva, “alas, child of aegis-bearing jove, shall you and i take

then pensive thus, to war’s triumphant maid:
“o daughter of that god, whose arm can wield
the avenging bolt, and shake the sable shield!

no more thought for the dying danaans, though it be the last time

now, in this moment of her last despair,
shall wretched greece no more confess our care,
condemn’d to suffer the full force of fate,
and drain the dregs of heaven’s relentless hate?

we ever do so?

gods!
shall one raging hand thus level all?

see how they perish and come to a bad end before

what numbers fell!

the onset of but a single man.

what numbers yet shall fall!

hector the son of priam rages with

what power divine shall hector’s wrath assuage?

intolerable fury, and has already done great mischief.

still swells the slaughter, and still grows the rage!

”

”

minerva answered, “would, indeed, this fellow might die in his

so spake the imperial regent of the skies;
to whom the goddess with the azure eyes:
“long since had hector stain’d these fields with gore,

own land, and fall by the hands of the achaeans; but my father

stretch’d by some argive on his native shore:
but he above, the sire of heaven, withstands,

jove is mad with spleen, ever foiling me, ever headstrong and

mocks our attempts, and slights our just demands;

unjust.

the stubborn god, inflexible and hard,

he forgets how often i saved his son when he was worn out

forgets my service and deserved reward:
saved i, for this, his favourite son distress’d,

by the labours eurystheus had laid on him.

by stern eurystheus with long labours press’d?

he would weep till his

cry came up to heaven, and then jove would send me down to help

waters of the river styx.

nor styx been cross’d, nor hell explored in vain.

and now jove hates me, while he lets

saturnia lends the lash; the coursers fly;
smooth glides the chariot through the liquid sky.
heaven’s gates spontaneous open to the powers,
heaven’s golden gates, kept by the winged hours.

open of their own accord—gates over which the hours preside, in

commission’d in alternate watch they stand,

the sun’s bright portals and the skies command;

through these the goddesses

but father jove when he saw them from ida was very angry, and

but jove, incensed, from ida’s top survey’d,

sent winged iris with a message to them.

and thus enjoin’d the many-colour’d maid.

“thaumantia!

iris, turn them back, and see that they do not come near me, for

mount the winds, and stop their car;

if we come to fighting there will be mischief.

against the highest who shall wage the war?
if furious yet they dare the vain debate,

this is what i
say, and this is what i mean to do.

thus have i spoke, and what i speak is fate:

i will lame their horses for

their coursers crush’d beneath the wheels shall lie,

them; i will hurl them from their chariot, and will break it in

their car in fragments, scatter’d o’er the sky:
my lightning these rebellious shall confound,

pieces.

and hurl them flaming, headlong, to the ground,

it will take them all ten years to heal the wounds my

condemn’d for ten revolving years to weep

lightning shall inflict upon them; my grey-eyed daughter will

the wounds impress’d by burning thunder deep.

then learn what quarrelling with her father means.

so shall minerva learn to fear our ire,

i am less

nor dare to combat hers and nature’s sire.

surprised and angry with juno, for whatever i say she always

for juno, headstrong and imperious still,

contradicts me.

she claims some title to transgress our will.

”

”

”

with this she left them, and juno said to minerva, “of a truth,

then, mounting on the pinions of the wind,
she flew; and juno thus her rage resign’d:

child of aegis-bearing jove, i am not for fighting men’s battles

“o daughter of that god, whose arm can wield
the avenging bolt, and shake the saber shield!

further in defiance of jove.

no more let beings of superior birth
contend with jove for this low race of earth;
triumphant now, now miserably slain,

let them live or die as luck will

they breathe or perish as the fates ordain:

have it, and let jove mete out his judgements upon the trojans

but jove’s high counsels full effect shall find;

and danaans according to his own pleasure.

and, ever constant, ever rule mankind.

”

”

she turned her steeds; the hours presently unyoked them, made

she spoke, and backward turn’d her steeds of light,
adorn’d with manes of gold, and heavenly bright.
the hours unloosed them, panting as they stood,

and heap’d their mangers with ambrosial food.
there tied, they rest in high celestial stalls;

he, whose all-conscious eyes the world behold,

reeled beneath him.

high heaven the footstool of his feet he makes,
and wide beneath him all olympus shakes.

minerva and juno sat alone, apart from jove,

trembling afar the offending powers appear’d,

and neither spoke nor asked him questions, but jove knew what

confused and silent, for his frown they fear’d.

they meant, and said, “minerva and juno, why are you so angry?

he saw their soul, and thus his word imparts:
“pallas and juno!
say, why heave your hearts?

are you fatigued with killing so many of your dear friends the

soon was your battle o’er: proud troy retired
before your face, and in your wrath expired.

trojans?

but know, whoe’er almighty power withstand!

be this as it may, such is the might of my hands that

unmatch’d our force, unconquer’d is our hand:
who shall the sovereign of the skies control?

all the gods in olympus cannot turn me; you were both of you

not all the gods that crown the starry pole.

trembling all over ere ever you saw the fight and its terrible

your hearts shall tremble, if our arms we take,

doings.

and each immortal nerve with horror shake.

i tell you therefore-and it would have surely been—i

for thus i speak, and what i speak shall stand;

should have struck you with lightning, and your chariots would

what power soe’er provokes our lifted hand,

never have brought you back again to olympus.

on this our hill no more shall hold his place;
cut off, and exiled from the ethereal race.

”

”

minerva and juno groaned in spirit as they sat side by side and

juno and pallas grieving hear the doom,

brooded mischief for the trojans.

but feast their souls on ilion’s woes to come.

minerva sat silent without a

against her father; but juno could not contain herself and said,

“what, dread son of saturn, are you talking about?
we know how

“what hast thou said, o tyrant of the skies!

great your power is, nevertheless we have compassion upon the

strength and omnipotence invest thy throne;

danaan warriors who are perishing and coming to a bad end.

’tis thine to punish; ours to grieve alone.

we

for greece we grieve, abandon’d by her fate

will, however, since you so bid us, refrain from actual fighting,

to drink the dregs of thy unmeasured hate.
from fields forbidden we submiss refrain,
with arms unaiding see our argives slain;

but we will make serviceable suggestions to the argives, that

yet grant our counsels still their breasts may move,

they may not all of them perish in your displeasure.

lest all should perish in the rage of jove.

”

”

and jove answered, “to-morrow morning, juno, if you choose to do

who swells the clouds, and blackens all the skies:

for such is fate, nor canst thou turn its course
with all thy rage, with all thy rebel force.

to the lowest depths beneath earth and sea, where iapetus and

fly, if thy wilt, to earth’s remotest bound,
where on her utmost verge the seas resound;
where cursed iapetus and saturn dwell,

saturn dwell in lone tartarus with neither ray of light nor

fast by the brink, within the streams of hell;
no sun e’er gilds the gloomy horrors there;

breath of wind to cheer them.

no cheerful gales refresh the lazy air:

you may go on and on till you get

there arm once more the bold titanian band;

there, and i shall not care one whit for your displeasure; you
are the greatest vixen living.

and arm in vain; for what i will, shall stand.

”
juno made him no answer.

”

the sun’s glorious orb now sank into

where thinly scatter’d lay the heaps of dead.

attend his order, and their prince surround.

he grasped a spear eleven

a massy spear he bore of mighty strength,
of full ten cubits was the lance’s length;

cubits long, the bronze point of which gleamed in front of it,

the point was brass, refulgent to behold,

while the ring round the spear-head was of gold.

fix’d to the wood with circling rings of gold:

spear in hand he

the noble hector on his lance reclined,

spoke.

and, bending forward, thus reveal’d his mind:

“hear me,” said he, “trojans, dardanians, and allies.

“ye valiant trojans, with attention hear!
ye dardan bands, and generous aids, give ear!

i

this day, we hoped, would wrap in conquering flame

deemed but now that i should destroy the ships and all the

greece with her ships, and crown our toils with fame.

achaeans with them ere i went back to ilius, but darkness came on

it was this alone that saved them and their ships upon

the sea-shore.

and guards them trembling in their wooden walls.

now, therefore, let us obey the behests of night,

obey the night, and use her peaceful hours

and prepare our suppers.

our steeds to forage, and refresh our powers.

take your horses out of their chariots
and give them their feeds of corn; then make speed to bring sheep

straight from the town be sheep and oxen sought,

and cattle from the city; bring wine also and corn for your

and strengthening bread and generous wine be brought.

horses and gather much wood, that from dark till dawn we may burn

wide o’er the field, high blazing to the sky,
let numerous fires the absent sun supply,

watchfires whose flare may reach to heaven.

the flaming piles with plenteous fuel raise,

for the achaeans may

till the bright morn her purple beam displays;

try to fly beyond the sea by night, and they must not embark

lest, in the silence and the shades of night,
greece on her sable ships attempt her flight.
not unmolested let the wretches gain

scatheless and unmolested; many a man among them must take a dart

their lofty decks, or safely cleave the main;
some hostile wound let every dart bestow,
some lasting token of the phrygian foe,

with him to nurse at home, hit with spear or arrow as he is

wounds, that long hence may ask their spouses’ care.

leaping on board his ship, that others may fear to bring war and

and warn their children from a trojan war.

weeping upon the trojans.

now through the circuit of our ilion wall,

moreover let the heralds tell it about

let sacred heralds sound the solemn call;
to bid the sires with hoary honours crown’d,

the city that the growing youths and grey-bearded men are to camp

upon its heaven-built walls.

firm be the guard, while distant lie our powers,

lest, under covert of the midnight shade,

town be entered by surprise while the host is outside.

the insidious foe the naked town invade.

see to it,
brave trojans, as i have said, and let this suffice for the

moment; at daybreak i will instruct you further.

a nobler charge shall rouse the dawning day.

i pray in hope
to jove and to the gods that we may then drive those fate-sped

the gods, i trust, shall give to hector’s hand

from these detested foes to free the land,
who plough’d, with fates averse, the watery way:

their ships hither.

for trojan vultures a predestined prey.

this night, therefore, let us keep watch, but

our common safety must be now the care;

with early morning let us put on our armour and rouse fierce war

but soon as morning paints the fields of air,

at the ships of the achaeans; i shall then know whether brave

sheathed in bright arms let every troop engage,

diomed the son of tydeus will drive me back from the ships to the

and the fired fleet behold the battle rage.

wall, or whether i shall myself slay him and carry off his

then, then shall hector and tydides prove

whose fates are heaviest in the scales of jove.
