spear if he dare.

)

i ween that at break of day, he shall be among

shall see his bloody spoils in triumph borne,
with this keen javelin shall his breast be gored,

the first to fall and many another of his comrades round him.

and prostrate heroes bleed around their lord.

would that i were as sure of being immortal and never growing

certain as this, oh!
might my days endure,
from age inglorious, and black death secure;
so might my life and glory know no bound,

old, and of being worshipped like minerva and apollo, as i am

like pallas worshipp’d, like the sun renown’d!
as the next dawn, the last they shall enjoy,

that this day will bring evil to the argives.

shall crush the greeks, and end the woes of troy.

”

”

thus spoke hector and the trojans shouted applause.

the leader spoke.

they took

from all his host around

ungrateful offering to the immortal powers!

of sacrifice to heaven—but the blessed gods partook not thereof,

[197]
whose wrath hung heavy o’er the trojan towers:
nor priam nor his sons obtain’d their grace;

for they bitterly hated ilius with priam and priam’s people.

proud troy they hated, and her guilty race.

thus
high in hope they sat through the livelong night by the highways

the troops exulting sat in order round,

of war, and many a watchfire did they kindle.

and beaming fires illumined all the ground.

as when the stars

as when the moon, refulgent lamp of night,[198]

shine clear, and the moon is bright—there is not a breath of air,

o’er heaven’s pure azure spreads her sacred light,
when not a breath disturbs the deep serene,

not a peak nor glade nor jutting headland but it stands out in

and not a cloud o’ercasts the solemn scene,

the ineffable radiance that breaks from the serene of heaven; the

around her throne the vivid planets roll,

stars can all of them be told and the heart of the shepherd is

and stars unnumber’d gild the glowing pole,
o’er the dark trees a yellower verdure shed,
and tip with silver every mountain’s head:

glad—even thus shone the watchfires of the trojans before ilius

then shine the vales, the rocks in prospect rise,
a flood of glory bursts from all the skies:
the conscious swains, rejoicing in the sight,
eye the blue vault, and bless the useful light.
so many flames before proud ilion blaze,
and lighten glimmering xanthus with their rays.
the long reflections of the distant fires

midway between the ships and the river xanthus.

gleam on the walls, and tremble on the spires.

a thousand

a thousand piles the dusky horrors gild,

camp-fires gleamed upon the plain, and in the glow of each there

and shoot a shady lustre o’er the field.
full fifty guards each flaming pile attend,
whose umber’d arms, by fits, thick flashes send,

sat fifty men, while the horses, champing oats and corn beside

loud neigh the coursers o’er their heaps of corn,

their chariots, waited till dawn should come.

and ardent warriors wait the rising morn.

book ix.

[illustration: ] the shield of achilles
book ix.
argument.

the embassy to achilles.
thus did the trojans watch.

the embassy to achilles.

but panic, comrade of blood-stained

agamemnon, after the last day’s defeat, proposes to the greeks to quit

rout, had taken fast hold of the achaeans, and their princes were

the siege, and return to their country.
diomed opposes this, and nestor
seconds him, praising his wisdom and resolution.
he orders the guard to
be strengthened, and a council summoned to deliberate what measures are
to be followed in this emergency.
agamemnon pursues this advice, and
nestor further prevails upon him to send ambassadors to achilles, in
order to move him to a reconciliation.
ulysses and ajax are made choice
of, who are accompanied by old phœnix.
they make, each of them, very
moving and pressing speeches, but are rejected with roughness by
achilles, who notwithstanding retains phœnix in his tent.
the
ambassadors return unsuccessfully to the camp, and the troops betake
themselves to sleep.
this book, and the next following, take up the space of one night,
which is the twenty-seventh from the beginning of the poem.
the
scene lies on the sea-shore, the station of the grecian ships.
thus joyful troy maintain’d the watch of night;
while fear, pale comrade of inglorious flight,[199]
and heaven-bred horror, on the grecian part,

all of them in despair.

sat on each face, and sadden’d every heart.

as when the two winds that blow from

as from its cloudy dungeon issuing forth,

thrace—the north and the northwest—spring up of a sudden and

a double tempest of the west and north

rouse the fury of the main—in a moment the dark waves uprear

swells o’er the sea, from thracia’s frozen shore,
heaps waves on waves, and bids the ægean roar:

their heads and scatter their sea-wrack in all directions—even

this way and that the boiling deeps are toss’d:

thus troubled were the hearts of the achaeans.

such various passions urged the troubled host,

the son of atreus in dismay bade the heralds call the people to a

great agamemnon grieved above the rest;
superior sorrows swell’d his royal breast;
himself his orders to the heralds bears,
to bid to council all the grecian peers,

council man by man, but not to cry the matter aloud; he made

but bid in whispers: these surround their chief,

haste also himself to call them, and they sat sorry at heart in

in solemn sadness and majestic grief.

their assembly.

the king amidst the mournful circle rose:

agamemnon shed tears as it were a running stream

down his wan cheek a briny torrent flows.

or cataract on the side of some sheer cliff; and thus, with many

so silent fountains, from a rock’s tall head,

a heavy sigh he spoke to the achaeans.

in sable streams soft-trickling waters shed.
with more than vulgar grief he stood oppress’d;
words, mix’d with sighs, thus bursting from his breast:

“my friends,” said he,

“ye sons of greece!

“princes and councillors of the argives, the hand of heaven has

partake your leader’s care;
fellows in arms and princes of the war!

been laid heavily upon me.

of partial jove too justly we complain,

cruel jove gave me his solemn promise

and heavenly oracles believed in vain.

that i should sack the city of troy before returning, but he has

a safe return was promised to our toils,

played me false, and is now bidding me go ingloriously back to

with conquest honour’d and enrich’d with spoils:
now shameful flight alone can save the host;

argos with the loss of much people.

our wealth, our people, and our glory lost.

such is the will of jove, who

so jove decrees, almighty lord of all!
jove, at whose nod whole empires rise or fall,

has laid many a proud city in the dust as he will yet lay others,

who shakes the feeble props of human trust,

for his power is above all.

and towers and armies humbles to the dust.

now, therefore, let us all do as i

haste then, for ever quit these fatal fields,

say and sail back to our own country, for we shall not take

haste to the joys our native country yields;
spread all your canvas, all your oars employ,

troy.

nor hope the fall of heaven-defended troy.

”

”

thus he spoke, and the sons of the achaeans for a long while sat

he said: deep silence held the grecian band;

sorrowful there, but they all held their peace, till at last

silent, unmov’d in dire dismay they stand;

diomed of the loud battle-cry made answer saying, “son of atreus,

a pensive scene!
till tydeus’ warlike son
roll’d on the king his eyes, and thus begun:
“when kings advise us to renounce our fame,
first let him speak who first has suffer’d shame.

i will chide your folly, as is my right in council.

if i oppose thee, prince!

be not then

thy wrath withhold,

aggrieved that i should do so.

the laws of council bid my tongue be bold.

in the first place you attacked me

thou first, and thou alone, in fields of fight,

before all the danaans and said that i was a coward and no

durst brand my courage, and defame my might:
nor from a friend the unkind reproach appear’d,

soldier.

the greeks stood witness, all our army heard.

the argives young and old know that you did so.

the gods, o chief!

but the

from whom our honours spring,

son of scheming saturn endowed you by halves only.

the gods have made thee but by halves a king:

he gave you

they gave thee sceptres, and a wide command;
they gave dominion o’er the seas and land;

honour as the chief ruler over us, but valour, which is the

the noblest power that might the world control

highest both right and might he did not give you.

they gave thee not—a brave and virtuous soul.

sir, think you

is this a general’s voice, that would suggest

that the sons of the achaeans are indeed as unwarlike and

fears like his own to every grecian breast?

cowardly as you say they are?

confiding in our want of worth, he stands;

if your own mind is set upon going

and if we fly, ’tis what our king commands.

home—go—the way is open to you; the many ships that followed you

go thou, inglorious!

from mycene stand ranged upon the sea-shore; but the rest of us

from the embattled plain;

stay here till we have sacked troy.

ships thou hast store, and nearest to the main;

nay though these too should

a noble care the grecians shall employ,

turn homeward with their ships, sthenelus and myself will still

to combat, conquer, and extirpate troy.
here greece shall stay; or, if all greece retire,
myself shall stay, till troy or i expire;
myself, and sthenelus, will fight for fame;

fight on till we reach the goal of ilius, for heaven was with us
when we came.

god bade us fight, and ’twas with god we came.

”

”

the sons of the achaeans shouted applause at the words of diomed,

he ceased; the greeks loud acclamations raise,

and presently nestor rose to speak.

and voice to voice resounds tydides’ praise.
wise nestor then his reverend figure rear’d;

“son of tydeus,” said he, “in

he spoke: the host in still attention heard:[200]
“o truly great!

war your prowess is beyond question, and in council you excel all

in whom the gods have join’d

who are of your own years; no one of the achaeans can make light

such strength of body with such force of mind:

of what you say nor gainsay it, but you have not yet come to the

in conduct, as in courage, you excel,
still first to act what you advise so well.
these wholesome counsels which thy wisdom moves,

end of the whole matter.

applauding greece with common voice approves.

you are still young—you might be the

kings thou canst blame; a bold but prudent youth:

youngest of my own children—still you have spoken wisely and have

and blame even kings with praise, because with truth.
and yet those years that since thy birth have run
would hardly style thee nestor’s youngest son.
then let me add what yet remains behind,

counselled the chief of the achaeans not without discretion;

a thought unfinish’d in that generous mind;

nevertheless i am older than you and i will tell you everything;

age bids me speak!

therefore let no man, not even king agamemnon, disregard my

nor shall the advice i bring
distaste the people, or offend the king:
“cursed is the man, and void of law and right,
unworthy property, unworthy light,
unfit for public rule, or private care,

saying, for he that foments civil discord is a clanless,

that wretch, that monster, who delights in war;
whose lust is murder, and whose horrid joy,

hearthless outlaw.

to tear his country, and his kind destroy!

“now, however, let us obey the behests of night and get our

this night, refresh and fortify thy train;

suppers, but let the sentinels every man of them camp by the
trench that is without the wall.

between the trench and wall let guards remain:

i am giving these instructions
to the young men; when they have been attended to, do you, son of

be that the duty of the young and bold;

atreus, give your orders, for you are the most royal among us

but thou, o king, to council call the old;
great is thy sway, and weighty are thy cares;

all.

thy high commands must spirit all our wars.

prepare a feast for your councillors; it is right and
reasonable that you should do so; there is abundance of wine in
your tents, which the ships of the achaeans bring from thrace
daily.
you have everything at your disposal wherewith to
entertain guests, and you have many subjects.

with thracian wines recruit thy honour’d guests,

when many are got

for happy counsels flow from sober feasts.

together, you can be guided by him whose counsel is wisest—and

wise, weighty counsels aid a state distress’d,
and such a monarch as can choose the best.

sorely do we need shrewd and prudent counsel, for the foe has lit

see what a blaze from hostile tents aspires,

his watchfires hard by our ships.

how near our fleet approach the trojan fires!

who can be other than dismayed?

who can, unmoved, behold the dreadful light?
what eye beholds them, and can close to-night?

this night will either be the ruin of our host, or save it.

this dreadful interval determines all;
to-morrow, troy must flame, or greece must fall.

”

”

thus did he speak, and they did even as he had said.

thus spoke the hoary sage: the rest obey;

the

pronounce with judgment, with regard give ear,

all turns on

to see no wholesome motion be withstood,

you and on your commands, therefore i will say what i think will
be best.

and ratify the best for public good.

no man will be of a truer mind than that which has been

nor, though a meaner give advice, repine,
but follow it, and make the wisdom thine.
hear then a thought, not now conceived in haste,

mine from the hour when you, sir, angered achilles by taking the
girl briseis from his tent against my judgment.

at once my present judgment and my past.

i urged you not

when from pelides’ tent you forced the maid,

i first opposed, and faithful, durst dissuade;

hero whom heaven itself had honoured—for you still hold the prize

but bold of soul, when headlong fury fired,

that had been awarded to him.

you wronged the man, by men and gods admired:

now, however, let us think how we

may appease him, both with presents and fair speeches that may

with prayers to move him, or with gifts to bend.

”

and king agamemnon answered, “sir, you have reproved my folly
justly.

to whom the king.

i was wrong.

“with justice hast thou shown

i own it.

a prince’s faults, and i with reason own.

one whom heaven befriends is in

that happy man, whom jove still honours most,

himself a host, and jove has shown that he befriends this man by

is more than armies, and himself a host.
bless’d in his love, this wondrous hero stands;

destroying much people of the achaeans.

heaven fights his war, and humbles all our bands.

i was blinded with

fain would my heart, which err’d through frantic rage,

passion and yielded to my worser mind; therefore i will make

the wrathful chief and angry gods assuage.

amends, and will give him great gifts by way of atonement.

i will
tell them in the presence of you all.

hear, all ye greeks, and witness what i vow.

i will give him seven

ten weighty talents of the purest gold,

tripods that have never yet been on the fire, and ten talents of

and twice ten vases of refulgent mould:
seven sacred tripods, whose unsullied frame

gold.

yet knows no office, nor has felt the flame;

i will give him twenty iron cauldrons and twelve strong

twelve steeds unmatch’d in fleetness and in force,

horses that have won races and carried off prizes.

and still victorious in the dusty course;

rich, indeed,

(rich were the man whose ample stores exceed

both in land and gold is he that has as many prizes as my horses
have won me.

the prizes purchased by their winged speed;)

i will give him seven excellent workwomen, lesbians,

seven lovely captives of the lesbian line,

whom i chose for myself when he took lesbos—all of surpassing

skill’d in each art, unmatch’d in form divine,
the same i chose for more than vulgar charms,
when lesbos sank beneath the hero’s arms:

beauty.

all these, to buy his friendship, shall be paid,

i will give him these, and with them her whom i erewhile

and join’d with these the long-contested maid;

took from him, the daughter of briseus; and i swear a great oath

with all her charms, briseïs i resign,

that i never went up into her couch, nor have been with her after

and solemn swear those charms were never mine;
untouch’d she stay’d, uninjured she removes,

the manner of men and women.

pure from my arms, and guiltless of my loves,[202]

“all these things will i give him now, and if hereafter the gods

these instant shall be his; and if the powers

vouchsafe me to sack the city of priam, let him come when we

give to our arms proud ilion’s hostile towers,
then shall he store (when greece the spoil divides)

achaeans are dividing the spoil, and load his ship with gold and

with gold and brass his loaded navy’s sides:

bronze to his liking; furthermore let him take twenty trojan

besides, full twenty nymphs of trojan race

women, the loveliest after helen herself.

with copious love shall crown his warm embrace,
such as himself will choose; who yield to none,
or yield to helen’s heavenly charms alone.

then, when we reach

yet hear me further: when our wars are o’er,

achaean argos, wealthiest of all lands, he shall be my son-in-law

if safe we land on argos’ fruitful shore,

and i will show him like honour with my own dear son orestes, who

there shall he live my son, our honours share,

is being nurtured in all abundance.

and with orestes’ self divide my care.

i have three daughters,

the rich meadows of anthea; aepea also, and the vine-clad slopes

and sacred pedasus for vines renown’d;

and rich antheia with her flowery fields:[204]

of pedasus, all near the sea, and on the borders of sandy pylos.

the whole extent to pylos’ sandy plain,
along the verdant margin of the main.

the men that dwell there are rich in cattle and sheep; they will

there heifers graze, and labouring oxen toil;
bold are the men, and generous is the soil;

honour him with gifts as though he were a god, and be obedient to

there shall he reign, with power and justice crown’d,

his comfortable ordinances.

and rule the tributary realms around.

all this will i do if he will now
forgo his anger.

all this i give, his vengeance to control,

let him then yield; it is only hades who is

and sure all this may move his mighty soul.

utterly ruthless and unyielding—and hence he is of all gods the

pluto, the grisly god, who never spares,
who feels no mercy, and who hears no prayers,
lives dark and dreadful in deep hell’s abodes,

one most hateful to mankind.

and mortals hate him, as the worst of gods.

moreover i am older and more royal

great though he be, it fits him to obey,

than himself.
therefore, let him now obey me.

since more than his my years, and more my sway.

achilles.

“health to achilles!

“hail,” said he, “achilles, we have had no scant of good cheer,

happy are thy guests!

neither in the tent of agamemnon, nor yet here; there has been

not those more honour’d whom atrides feasts:
though generous plenty crown thy loaded boards,
that, agamemnon’s regal tent affords;

plenty to eat and drink, but our thought turns upon no such

but greater cares sit heavy on our souls,
nor eased by banquets or by flowing bowls.

matter.

what scenes of slaughter in yon fields appear!

sir, we are in the face of great disaster, and without

the dead we mourn, and for the living fear;
greece on the brink of fate all doubtful stands,

your help know not whether we shall save our fleet or lose it.

and owns no help but from thy saving hands:

the trojans and their allies have camped hard by our ships and by

troy and her aids for ready vengeance call;

the wall; they have lit watchfires throughout their host and deem

their threatening tents already shade our wall:
hear how with shouts their conquest they proclaim,

that nothing can now prevent them from falling on our fleet.

and point at every ship their vengeful flame!

jove, moreover, has sent his lightnings on their right; hector,

for them the father of the gods declares,
theirs are his omens, and his thunder theirs.

in all his glory, rages like a maniac; confident that jove is

see, full of jove, avenging hector rise!

with him he fears neither god nor man, but is gone raving mad,

see!

and prays for the approach of day.

heaven and earth the raging chief defies;

he vows that he will hew the

what fury in his breast, what lightning in his eyes!
he waits but for the morn, to sink in flame

high sterns of our ships in pieces, set fire to their hulls, and

the ships, the greeks, and all the grecian name.

make havoc of the achaeans while they are dazed and smothered in

heavens!
how my country’s woes distract my mind,
lest fate accomplish all his rage design’d!

smoke; i much fear that heaven will make good his boasting, and

and must we, gods!

it will prove our lot to perish at troy far from our home in

our heads inglorious lay

argos.

in trojan dust, and this the fatal day?

up, then, and late though it be, save the sons of the

return, achilles: oh return, though late,

achaeans who faint before the fury of the trojans.

to save thy greeks, and stop the course of fate;

you will

if in that heart or grief or courage lies,

repent bitterly hereafter if you do not, for when the harm is

rise to redeem; ah, yet to conquer, rise!
the day may come, when, all our warriors slain,

done there will be no curing it; consider ere it be too late, and

that heart shall melt, that courage rise in vain:

save the danaans from destruction.

regard in time, o prince divinely brave!

“my good friend, when your father peleus sent you from phthia to

those wholesome counsels which thy father gave.
when peleus in his aged arms embraced

agamemnon, did he not charge you saying, ‘son, minerva and juno

his parting son, these accents were his last:
“‘my child!

will make you strong if they choose, but check your high temper,

with strength, with glory, and success,
thy arms may juno and minerva bless!
trust that to heaven: but thou, thy cares engage
to calm thy passions, and subdue thy rage:

for the better part is in goodwill.

from gentler manners let thy glory grow,

eschew vain quarrelling, and

and shun contention, the sure source of woe;

the achaeans old and young will respect you more for doing so.

that young and old may in thy praise combine,

’

the virtues of humanity be thine—’

these were his words, but you have forgotten them.

this now-despised advice thy father gave;

even now,

ah!

however, be appeased, and put away your anger from you.

check thy anger; and be truly brave.

agamemnon
will make you great amends if you will forgive him; listen, and i

if thou wilt yield to great atrides’ prayers,

will tell you what he has said in his tent that he will give you.

gifts worthy thee his royal hand prepares;

he will give you seven tripods that have never yet been on the

if not—but hear me, while i number o’er

fire, and ten talents of gold; twenty iron cauldrons, and twelve

the proffer’d presents, an exhaustless store.
ten weighty talents of the purest gold,
and twice ten vases of refulgent mould;
seven sacred tripods, whose unsullied frame
yet knows no office, nor has felt the flame;
twelve steeds unmatched in fleetness and in force,

strong horses that have won races and carried off prizes.

and still victorious in the dusty course;

rich

(rich were the man, whose ample stores exceed

indeed both in land and gold is he who has as many prizes as
these horses have won for agamemnon.
moreover he will give you

the prizes purchased by their winged speed;)

seven excellent workwomen, lesbians, whom he chose for himself,

seven lovely captives of the lesbian line,
skill’d in each art, unmatch’d in form divine,
the same he chose for more than vulgar charms,

when you took lesbos—all of surpassing beauty.

when lesbos sank beneath thy conquering arms.

he will give you

all these, to buy thy friendship shall be paid,

and women.

son orestes, who is being nurtured in all abundance.

agamemnon

”

achilles answered, “ulysses, noble son of laertes, i should give

then thus the goddess-born: “ulysses, hear
a faithful speech, that knows nor art nor fear;
what in my secret soul is understood,
my tongue shall utter, and my deeds make good.

you formal notice plainly and in all fixity of purpose that there

let greece then know, my purpose i retain:

be no more of this cajoling, from whatsoever quarter it may come.

nor with new treaties vex my peace in vain.

him do i hate even as the gates of hell who says one thing while

who dares think one thing, and another tell,
my heart detests him as the gates of hell.

he hides another in his heart; therefore i will say what i mean.

“then thus in short my fix’d resolves attend,

i will be appeased neither by agamemnon son of atreus nor by any

which nor atrides nor his greeks can bend;

other of the danaans, for i see that i have no thanks for all my

long toils, long perils in their cause i bore,
but now the unfruitful glories charm no more.

fighting.
he that fights fares no better than he that does not;

fight or not fight, a like reward we claim,

coward and hero are held in equal honour, and death deals like

the wretch and hero find their prize the same.

measure to him who works and him who is idle.

alike regretted in the dust he lies,
who yields ignobly, or who bravely dies.

i have taken

of all my dangers, all my glorious pains,

nothing by all my hardships—with my life ever in my hand; as a

a life of labours, lo!
what fruit remains?

bird when she has found a morsel takes it to her nestlings, and

as the bold bird her helpless young attends,
from danger guards them, and from want defends;
in search of prey she wings the spacious air,
and with the untasted food supplies her care:

herself fares hardly, even so many a long night have i been
wakeful, and many a bloody battle have i waged by day against

for thankless greece such hardships have i braved,

those who were fighting for their women.

her wives, her infants, by my labours saved;

with my ships i have

long sleepless nights in heavy arms i stood,

taken twelve cities, and eleven round about troy have i stormed

and sweat laborious days in dust and blood.
i sack’d twelve ample cities on the main,[207]
and twelve lay smoking on the trojan plain:
then at atrides’ haughty feet were laid

with my men by land; i took great store of wealth from every one

the wealth i gathered, and the spoils i made.
your mighty monarch these in peace possess’d;

of them, but i gave all up to agamemnon son of atreus.

some few my soldiers had, himself the rest.

he stayed

some present, too, to every prince was paid;

where he was by his ships, yet of what came to him he gave

and every prince enjoys the gift he made:

little, and kept much himself.

i only must refund, of all his train;

“nevertheless he did distribute some meeds of honour among the

see what pre-eminence our merits gain!

chieftains and kings, and these have them still; from me alone of

my spoil alone his greedy soul delights:

the achaeans did he take the woman in whom i delighted—let him

my spouse alone must bless his lustful nights:

keep her and sleep with her.

the woman, let him (as he may) enjoy;

why, pray, must the argives needs
fight the trojans?

but what’s the quarrel, then, of greece to troy?

what made the son of atreus gather the host
and bring them?

what to these shores the assembled nations draws,

was it not for the sake of helen?

what calls for vengeance but a woman’s cause?

are the sons of

are fair endowments and a beauteous face

atreus the only men in the world who love their wives?

beloved by none but those of atreus’ race?
the wife whom choice and passion doth approve,

any man of
common right feeling will love and cherish her who is his own, as
i this woman, with my whole heart, though she was but a fruitling

sure every wise and worthy man will love.

of my spear.

nor did my fair one less distinction claim;

agamemnon has taken her from me; he has played me

slave as she was, my soul adored the dame.

false; i know him; let him tempt me no further, for he shall not

wrong’d in my love, all proffers i disdain;
deceived for once, i trust not kings again.

move me.

ye have my answer—what remains to do,

let him look to you, ulysses, and to the other princes

your king, ulysses, may consult with you.

to save his ships from burning.

what needs he the defence this arm can make?

he has done much without me

has he not walls no human force can shake?

already.

has he not fenced his guarded navy round

he has built a wall; he has dug a trench deep and wide

with piles, with ramparts, and a trench profound?

all round it, and he has planted it within with stakes; but even

and will not these (the wonders he has done)

so he stays not the murderous might of hector.

but now those ancient enmities are o’er;

gods; i will draw my ships into the water and then victual them

then shall you see our parting vessels crown’d,

and main.

and hear with oars the hellespont resound.

if great neptune vouchsafes me a fair passage, in three

the third day hence shall pythia greet our sails,[208]
if mighty neptune send propitious gales;

days i shall be in phthia.

pythia to her achilles shall restore

i have much there that i left behind

the wealth he left for this detested shore:

me when i came here to my sorrow, and i shall bring back still

thither the spoils of this long war shall pass,

further store of gold, of red copper, of fair women, and of iron,

the ruddy gold, the steel, and shining brass:

my share of the spoils that we have taken; but one prize, he who

my beauteous captives thither i’ll convey,
and all that rests of my unravish’d prey.
one only valued gift your tyrant gave,

gave has insolently taken away.

and that resumed—the fair lyrnessian slave.

tell him all as i now bid you,

then tell him: loud, that all the greeks may hear,

and tell him in public that the achaeans may hate him and beware

and learn to scorn the wretch they basely fear;

of him should he think that he can yet dupe others for his

(for arm’d in impudence, mankind he braves,

effrontery never fails him.

and meditates new cheats on all his slaves;

“as for me, hound that he is, he dares not look me in the face.

though shameless as he is, to face these eyes
is what he dares not: if he dares he dies;)

i

tell him, all terms, all commerce i decline,

will take no counsel with him, and will undertake nothing in
common with him.

nor share his council, nor his battle join;

he has wronged me and deceived me enough, he

for once deceiv’d, was his; but twice were mine,

shall not cozen me further; let him go his own way, for jove has

no—let the stupid prince, whom jove deprives

robbed him of his reason.

of sense and justice, run where frenzy drives;

i loathe his presents, and for himself

his gifts are hateful: kings of such a kind

care not one straw.

stand but as slaves before a noble mind,

he may offer me ten or even twenty times what
he has now done, nay—not though it be all that he has in the

not though he proffer’d all himself possess’d,

world, both now or ever shall have; he may promise me the wealth

and all his rapine could from others wrest:

of orchomenus or of egyptian thebes, which is the richest city in

not all the golden tides of wealth that crown
the many-peopled orchomenian town;[209]
not all proud thebes’ unrivall’d walls contain,
the world’s great empress on the egyptian plain

the whole world, for it has a hundred gates through each of which

(that spreads her conquests o’er a thousand states,
and pours her heroes through a hundred gates,
two hundred horsemen and two hundred cars
from each wide portal issuing to the wars);[210]

two hundred men may drive at once with their chariots and horses;

though bribes were heap’d on bribes, in number more

he may offer me gifts as the sands of the sea or the dust of the

than dust in fields, or sands along the shore;

plain in multitude, but even so he shall not move me till i have

should all these offers for my friendship call,

been revenged in full for the bitter wrong he has done me.
i will

’tis he that offers, and i scorn them all.

not marry his daughter; she may be fair as venus, and skilful as

atrides’ daughter never shall be led

minerva, but i will have none of her: let another take her, who

(an ill-match’d consort) to achilles’ bed;
like golden venus though she charm’d the heart,

may be a good match for her and who rules a larger kingdom.

and vied with pallas in the works of art;
some greater greek let those high nuptials grace,
i hate alliance with a tyrant’s race.

if

if heaven restore me to my realms with life,

the gods spare me to return home, peleus will find me a wife;

the reverend peleus shall elect my wife;

there are achaean women in hellas and phthia, daughters of kings

thessalian nymphs there are of form divine,

that have cities under them; of these i can take whom i will and

and kings that sue to mix their blood with mine.
bless’d in kind love, my years shall glide away,

marry her.

content with just hereditary sway;

many a time was i minded when at home in phthia to woo

there, deaf for ever to the martial strife,

and wed a woman who would make me a suitable wife, and to enjoy

enjoy the dear prerogative of life.

the riches of my old father peleus.
my life is more to me than

life is not to be bought with heaps of gold.

all the wealth of ilius while it was yet at peace before the

not all apollo’s pythian treasures hold,

achaeans went there, or than all the treasure that lies on the

or troy once held, in peace and pride of sway,

stone floor of apollo’s temple beneath the cliffs of pytho.

can bribe the poor possession of a day!

cattle and sheep are to be had for harrying, and a man buy both

lost herds and treasures we by arms regain,
and steeds unrivall’d on the dusty plain:

tripods and horses if he wants them, but when his life has once

but from our lips the vital spirit fled,

left him it can neither be bought nor harried back again.

returns no more to wake the silent dead.

“my mother thetis tells me that there are two ways in which i may

my fates long since by thetis were disclosed,

meet my end.

and each alternate, life or fame, proposed;

if i stay here and fight, i shall not return alive

here, if i stay, before the trojan town,

but my name will live for ever: whereas if i go home my name will

short is my date, but deathless my renown:
if i return, i quit immortal praise

die, but it will be long ere death shall take me.

for years on years, and long-extended days.
convinced, though late, i find my fond mistake,

to the rest of

and warn the greeks the wiser choice to make;

nor hope the fall of heaven-defended troy.

has held his hand over her to protect her, and her people have

taken heart.

her hearts are strengthen’d, and her glories rise.

have now hit upon may not be.

ye find, achilles is unconquer’d still.

as for phoenix, let him sleep here

but here this night let reverend phœnix stay:
his tedious toils and hoary hairs demand
a peaceful death in pythia’s friendly land.

that he may sail with me in the morning if he so will.
but i will

but whether he remain or sail with me,

not take him by force.

his age be sacred, and his will be free.

they all held their peace, dismayed at the sternness with which

the son of peleus ceased: the chiefs around
in silence wrapt, in consternation drown’d,
attend the stern reply.

he had denied them, till presently the old knight phoenix in his

then phœnix rose;

(down his white beard a stream of sorrow flows;)
and while the fate of suffering greece he mourn’d,

with accent weak these tender words return’d.
[illustration: ] proserpine
“divine achilles!
wilt thou then retire,

the fierceness of your anger will do nothing to save the ships

and leave our hosts in blood, our fleets on fire?
if wrath so dreadful fill thy ruthless mind,

from burning, how, my son, can i remain here without you?

how shall thy friend, thy phœnix, stay behind?

your

the royal peleus, when from pythia’s coast

father peleus bade me go with you when he sent you as a mere lad

he sent thee early to the achaian host;
thy youth as then in sage debates unskill’d,

from phthia to agamemnon.

and new to perils of the direful field:

you knew nothing neither of war nor of

he bade me teach thee all the ways of war,

the arts whereby men make their mark in council, and he sent me
with you to train you in all excellence of speech and action.

to shine in councils, and in camps to dare.

therefore, my son, i will not stay here without you—no, not

never, ah, never let me leave thy side!
no time shall part us, and no fate divide,

though heaven itself vouchsafe to strip my years from off me, and

not though the god, that breathed my life, restore
the bloom i boasted, and the port i bore,

make me young as i was when i first left hellas the land of fair

when greece of old beheld my youthful flames

women.

(delightful greece, the land of lovely dames),

i was then flying the anger of father amyntor, son of

my father faithless to my mother’s arms,

ormenus, who was furious with me in the matter of his concubine,
of whom he was enamoured to the wronging of his wife my mother.

old as he was, adored a stranger’s charms.

my mother, therefore, prayed me without ceasing to lie with the

i tried what youth could do (at her desire)

woman myself, that so she hate my father, and in the course of
time i yielded.

to win the damsel, and prevent my sire.

but my father soon came to know, and cursed me

my sire with curses loads my hated head,

bitterly, calling the dread erinyes to witness.

and cries, ‘ye furies!

he prayed that no

barren be his bed.
’

son of mine might ever sit upon knees—and the gods, jove of the

infernal jove, the vengeful fiends below,

world below and awful proserpine, fulfilled his curse.

and ruthless proserpine, confirm’d his vow.
despair and grief distract my labouring mind!

i took

gods!

counsel to kill him, but some god stayed my rashness and bade me

what a crime my impious heart design’d!

think on men’s evil tongues and how i should be branded as the

i thought (but some kind god that thought suppress’d)

murderer of my father; nevertheless i could not bear to stay in
my father’s house with him so bitter against me.

to plunge the poniard in my father’s breast;

my cousins and

then meditate my flight: my friends in vain

clansmen came about me, and pressed me sorely to remain; many a

with prayers entreat me, and with force detain.

sheep and many an ox did they slaughter, and many a fat hog did

on fat of rams, black bulls, and brawny swine,

they set down to roast before the fire; many a jar, too, did they
broach of my father’s wine.

they daily feast, with draughts of fragrant wine;

nine whole nights did they set a

strong guards they placed, and watch’d nine nights entire;

guard over me taking it in turns to watch, and they kept a fire
always burning, both in the cloister of the outer court and in

the roofs and porches flamed with constant fire.

the inner court at the doors of the room wherein i lay; but when
the darkness of the tenth night came, i broke through the closed

the tenth, i forced the gates, unseen of all:

doors of my room, and climbed the wall of the outer court after

and, favour’d by the night, o’erleap’d the wall,

passing quickly and unperceived through the men on guard and the

my travels thence through spacious greece extend;

women servants.
i then fled through hellas till i came to fertile

in phthia’s court at last my labours end.

phthia, mother of sheep, and to king peleus, who made me welcome
and treated me as a father treats an only son who will be heir to

your sire received me, as his son caress’d,

all his wealth.

with gifts enrich’d, and with possessions bless’d.

he made me rich and set me over much people,
establishing me on the borders of phthia where i was chief ruler

the strong dolopians thenceforth own’d my reign,

over the dolopians.

and all the coast that runs along the main.

“it was i, achilles, who had the making of you; i loved you with

by love to thee his bounties i repaid,
and early wisdom to thy soul convey’d:
great as thou art, my lessons made thee brave:
a child i took thee, but a hero gave.
thy infant breast a like affection show’d;

all my heart: for you would eat neither at home nor when you had

still in my arms (an ever-pleasing load)

gone out elsewhere, till i had first set you upon my knees, cut

or at my knee, by phœnix wouldst thou stand;

up the dainty morsel that you were to eat, and held the wine-cup

no food was grateful but from phœnix’ hand.

to your lips.

[211]

many a time have you slobbered your wine in baby

i pass my watchings o’er thy helpless years,

helplessness over my shirt; i had infinite trouble with you, but

the tender labours, the compliant cares,

i knew that heaven had vouchsafed me no offspring of my own, and

the gods (i thought) reversed their hard decree,
and phœnix felt a father’s joys in thee:

i made a son of you, achilles, that in my hour of need you might

thy growing virtues justified my cares,

protect me.

and promised comfort to my silver hairs.

now, therefore, i say battle with your pride and beat

now be thy rage, thy fatal rage, resign’d;

it; cherish not your anger for ever; the might and majesty of

a cruel heart ill suits a manly mind:

heaven are more than ours, but even heaven may be appeased; and

the gods (the only great, and only wise)

if a man has sinned he prays the gods, and reconciles them to

are moved by offerings, vows, and sacrifice;

himself by his piteous cries and by frankincense, with

offending man their high compassion wins,

drink-offerings and the savour of burnt sacrifice.
for prayers

and daily prayers atone for daily sins.

are as daughters to great jove; halt, wrinkled, with eyes

prayers are jove’s daughters, of celestial race,
lame are their feet, and wrinkled is their face;
with humble mien, and with dejected eyes,

askance, they follow in the footsteps of sin, who, being fierce

constant they follow, where injustice flies.

and fleet of foot, leaves them far behind him, and ever baneful

injustice swift, erect, and unconfined,

to mankind outstrips them even to the ends of the world; but

sweeps the wide earth, and tramples o’er mankind,

nevertheless the prayers come hobbling and healing after.

while prayers, to heal her wrongs, move slow behind.

if a
man has pity upon these daughters of jove when they draw near

who hears these daughters of almighty jove,

him, they will bless him and hear him too when he is praying; but

for him they mediate to the throne above:

if he deny them and will not listen to them, they go to jove the

when man rejects the humble suit they make,

son of saturn and pray that he may presently fall into sin—to his

the sire revenges for the daughters’ sake;

ruing bitterly hereafter.

from jove commission’d, fierce injustice then
descends to punish unrelenting men.
o let not headlong passion bear the sway

therefore, achilles, give these

these reconciling goddesses obey:

daughters of jove due reverence, and bow before them as all good

due honours to the seed of jove belong,

men will bow.

due honours calm the fierce, and bend the strong.

were not the son of atreus offering you gifts and

were these not paid thee by the terms we bring,

promising others later—if he were still furious and implacable—i

were rage still harbour’d in the haughty king;

am not he that would bid you throw off your anger and help the

nor greece nor all her fortunes should engage
thy friend to plead against so just a rage.

achaeans, no matter how great their need; but he is giving much

but since what honour asks the general sends,

now, and more hereafter; he has sent his captains to urge his

and sends by those whom most thy heart commends;

suit, and has chosen those who of all the argives are most

the best and noblest of the grecian train;

acceptable to you; make not then their words and their coming to
be of none effect.

permit not these to sue, and sue in vain!

your anger has been righteous so far.

let me (my son) an ancient fact unfold,

we have
heard in song how heroes of old time quarrelled when they were

a great example drawn from times of old;

roused to fury, but still they could be won by gifts, and fair

hear what our fathers were, and what their praise,

words could soothe them.

who conquer’d their revenge in former days.

“i have an old story in my mind—a very old one—but you are all

“where calydon on rocky mountains stands[212]

friends and i will tell it.
the curetes and the aetolians were
fighting and killing one another round calydon—the aetolians

once fought the ætolian and curetian bands;

defending the city and the curetes trying to destroy it.
for
diana of the golden throne was angry and did them hurt because
oeneus had not offered her his harvest first-fruits.

to guard it those; to conquer, these advance;

the other

and mutual deaths were dealt with mutual chance.

gods had all been feasted with hecatombs, but to the daughter of

the silver cynthia bade contention rise,

great jove alone he had made no sacrifice.

in vengeance of neglected sacrifice;

he had forgotten her,
or somehow or other it had escaped him, and this was a grievous
sin.
thereon the archer goddess in her displeasure sent a
prodigious creature against him—a savage wild boar with great

on œneus fields she sent a monstrous boar,

white tusks that did much harm to his orchard lands, uprooting
apple-trees in full bloom and throwing them to the ground.

that levell’d harvests, and whole forests tore:

but
meleager son of oeneus got huntsmen and hounds from many cities
and killed it—for it was so monstrous that not a few were needed,
and many a man did it stretch upon his funeral pyre.
on this the

this beast (when many a chief his tusks had slain)

goddess set the curetes and the aetolians fighting furiously

great meleager stretch’d along the plain,

about the head and skin of the boar.

then, for his spoils, a new debate arose,

“so long as meleager was in the field things went badly with the

the neighbour nations thence commencing foes.

curetes, and for all their numbers they could not hold their

strong as they were, the bold curetes fail’d,

ground under the city walls; but in the course of time meleager

while meleager’s thundering arm prevail’d:

was angered as even a wise man will sometimes be.

till rage at length inflamed his lofty breast
(for rage invades the wisest and the best).

he was incensed

“cursed by althaea, to his wrath he yields,

with his mother althaea, and therefore stayed at home with his

and in his wife’s embrace forgets the fields.

wedded wife fair cleopatra, who was daughter of marpessa daughter

(she from marpessa sprung, divinely fair,

of euenus, and of ides the man then living.

and matchless idas, more than man in war:

he it was who took

his bow and faced king apollo himself for fair marpessa’s sake;

against the god the father bent his arms:
the afflicted pair, their sorrows to proclaim,

her father and mother then named her alcyone, because her mother

from cleopatra changed their daughter’s name,

whose luckless hand his royal uncle slew;

brother, prayed the gods, and beat the earth with her hands,

they would kill her son—and erinys that walks in darkness and

on her own son to wreak her brother’s death;

knows no ruth heard her from erebus.

hell heard her curses from the realms profound,

and the red fiends that walk the nightly round.
in vain ætolia her deliverer waits,

war shakes her walls, and thunders at her gates.

thereon the

she sent ambassadors, a chosen band,

elders of the aetolians besought meleager; they sent the chiefest

besought the chief to save the sinking state:

of their priests, and begged him to come out and help them,
promising him a great reward.

their prayers were urgent, and their proffers great:

they bade him choose fifty
plough-gates, the most fertile in the plain of calydon, the

(full fifty acres of the richest ground,

one-half vineyard and the other open plough-land.

half pasture green, and half with vineyards crown’d:)

the old warrior
oeneus implored him, standing at the threshold of his room and
beating the doors in supplication.

his suppliant father, aged œneus, came;

his sisters and his mother

his sisters follow’d; even the vengeful dame,

herself besought him sore, but he the more refused them; those of

althaea, sues; his friends before him fall:

his comrades who were nearest and dearest to him also prayed him,

he stands relentless, and rejects them all.

but they could not move him till the foe was battering at the

meanwhile the victor’s shouts ascend the skies;

very doors of his chamber, and the curetes had scaled the walls
and were setting fire to the city.

the walls are scaled; the rolling flames arise;

then at last his sorrowing

at length his wife (a form divine) appears,

wife detailed the horrors that befall those whose city is taken;

with piercing cries, and supplicating tears;

she reminded him how the men are slain, and the city is given

she paints the horrors of a conquer’d town,

over to the flames, while the women and children are carried into

the heroes slain, the palaces o’erthrown,

captivity; when he heard all this, his heart was touched, and he

the matrons ravish’d, the whole race enslaved:

donned his armour to go forth.

the warrior heard, he vanquish’d, and he saved.

thus of his own inward motion he
saved the city of the aetolians; but they now gave him nothing of
those rich rewards that they had offered earlier, and though he

the ætolians, long disdain’d, now took their turn,

saved the city he took nothing by it.

and left the chief their broken faith to mourn.

be not then, my son, thus
minded; let not heaven lure you into any such course.
when the

ships are burning it will be a harder matter to save them.

and be amongst our guardian gods adored.

and achilles answered, “phoenix, old friend and father, i have no

thus he: the stern achilles thus replied:
“my second father, and my reverend guide:
thy friend, believe me, no such gifts demands,

need of such honour.

and asks no honours from a mortal’s hands;

i have honour from jove himself, which will

jove honours me, and favours my designs;
his pleasure guides me, and his will confines;
and here i stay (if such his high behest)

abide with me at my ships while i have breath in my body, and my
limbs are strong.

while life’s warm spirit beats within my breast.

i say further—and lay my saying to your

yet hear one word, and lodge it in thy heart:

heart—vex me no more with this weeping and lamentation, all in

no more molest me on atrides’ part:

the cause of the son of atreus.

is it for him these tears are taught to flow,

love him so well, and you may

for him these sorrows?

lose the love i bear you.

for my mortal foe?
a generous friendship no cold medium knows,
burns with one love, with one resentment glows;

you ought to help me rather in

one should our interests and our passions be;

troubling those that trouble me; be king as much as i am, and

my friend must hate the man that injures me.

share like honour with myself; the others shall take my answer;

do this, my phœnix, ’tis a generous part;
and share my realms, my honours, and my heart.

stay here yourself and sleep comfortably in your bed; at daybreak

let these return: our voyage, or our stay,

we will consider whether to remain or go.

rest undetermined till the dawning day.

”

”

on this he nodded quietly to patroclus as a sign that he was to
prepare a bed for phoenix, and that the others should take their

he ceased; then order’d for the sage’s bed

leave.

a warmer couch with numerous carpets spread.

ajax son of telamon then said, “ulysses, noble son of

with that, stern ajax his long silence broke,
and thus, impatient, to ulysses spoke:

laertes, let us be gone, for i see that our journey is vain.

“hence let us go—why waste we time in vain?
see what effect our low submissions gain!

we
must now take our answer, unwelcome though it be, to the danaans

liked or not liked, his words we must relate,

who are waiting to receive it.

the greeks expect them, and our heroes wait.

achilles is savage and

proud as he is, that iron heart retains

remorseless; he is cruel, and cares nothing for the love his
comrades lavished upon him more than on all the others.

its stubborn purpose, and his friends disdains.

he is

stern and unpitying!

implacable—and yet if a man’s brother or son has been slain he

if a brother bleed,

will accept a fine by way of amends from him that killed him, and

on just atonement, we remit the deed;
a sire the slaughter of his son forgives;
the price of blood discharged, the murderer lives:

the wrong-doer having paid in full remains in peace among his own

the haughtiest hearts at length their rage resign,
and gifts can conquer every soul but thine.

people; but as for you, achilles, the gods have put a wicked

else into the bargain.

who honour worth, and prize thy valour most.

”

“ajax,” replied achilles, “noble son of telamon, you have spoken

“o soul of battles, and thy people’s guide!
(to ajax thus the first of greeks replied)
well hast thou spoke; but at the tyrant’s name

much to my liking, but my blood boils when i think it all over,

my rage rekindles, and my soul’s on flame:

and remember how the son of atreus treated me with contumely as

’tis just resentment, and becomes the brave:

though i were some vile tramp, and that too in the presence of

disgraced, dishonour’d, like the vilest slave!

the argives.

return, then, heroes!

go, then, and deliver your message; say that i will

and our answer bear,

have no concern with fighting till hector, son of noble priam,

the glorious combat is no more my care;
not till, amidst yon sinking navy slain,

reaches the tents of the myrmidons in his murderous course, and

the blood of greeks shall dye the sable main;

flings fire upon their ships.

not till the flames, by hector’s fury thrown,
consume your vessels, and approach my own;

for all his lust of battle, i take

just there, the impetuous homicide shall stand,

it he will be held in check when he is at my own tent and ship.

there cease his battle, and there feel our hand.

”

”

“say what success?
divine laertes’ son!

ulysses,” said he, “will he save the ships from burning, or did

achilles’ high resolves declare to all:

he refuse, and is he still furious?

returns the chief, or must our navy fall?

”

ulysses answered, “most noble son of atreus, king of men,

“great king of nations!

agamemnon, achilles will not be calmed, but is more fiercely

(ithacus replied)

angry than ever, and spurns both you and your gifts.

fix’d is his wrath, unconquer’d is his pride;

he bids you

he slights thy friendship, thy proposals scorns,

take counsel with the achaeans to save the ships and host as you

and, thus implored, with fiercer fury burns.
to save our army, and our fleets to free,
is not his care; but left to greece and thee.

best may; as for himself, he said that at daybreak he should draw

your eyes shall view, when morning paints the sky,

his ships into the water.

beneath his oars the whitening billows fly;

he said further that he should advise
every one to sail home likewise, for that you will not reach the

us too he bids our oars and sails employ,

goal of ilius.

nor hope the fall of heaven-protected troy;

‘jove,’ he said, ‘has laid his hand over the city

for jove o’ershades her with his arm divine,

to protect it, and the people have taken heart.

inspires her war, and bids her glory shine.

’ this is what he
said, and the others who were with me can tell you the same

they all held their peace, sitting for a long time silent and

tydides broke

the general silence, and undaunted spoke.

atreus, king of men, agamemnon, you ought not to have sued the

“why should we gifts to proud achilles send,

son of peleus nor offered him gifts.

or strive with prayers his haughty soul to bend?

he is proud enough as it is,

his country’s woes he glories to deride,

and you have encouraged him in his pride still further.

and prayers will burst that swelling heart with pride.

let him

be the fierce impulse of his rage obey’d,

stay or go as he will.

our battles let him or desert or aid;

he will fight later when he is in the

then let him arm when jove or he think fit:

humour, and heaven puts it in his mind to do so.
now, therefore,

that, to his madness, or to heaven commit:

let us all do as i say; we have eaten and drunk our fill, let us

what for ourselves we can, is always ours;

then take our rest, for in rest there is both strength and stay.

this night, let due repast refresh our powers;
(for strength consists in spirits and in blood,
and those are owed to generous wine and food;)

but when fair rosy-fingered morn appears, forthwith bring out

but when the rosy messenger of day

your host and your horsemen in front of the ships, urging them

strikes the blue mountains with her golden ray,
ranged at the ships, let all our squadrons shine
in flaming arms, a long-extended line:
in the dread front let great atrides stand,

on, and yourself fighting among the foremost.

the first in danger, as in high command.

”

”

thus he spoke, and the other chieftains approved his words.

shouts of acclaim the listening heroes raise,

they
then made their drink-offerings and went every man to his own

then each to heaven the due libations pays;

tent, where they laid down to rest and enjoyed the boon of sleep.

till sleep, descending o’er the tents, bestows
the grateful blessings of desired repose.

book x.

[214]
[illustration: ] achilles
book x.
argument.

ulysses and diomed go out as spies, and meet dolon, who gives

the night-adventure of diomed and ulysses.
upon the refusal of achilles to return to the army, the distress of
agamemnon is described in the most lively manner.
he takes no rest that
night, but passes through the camp, awaking the leaders, and contriving
all possible methods for the public safety.
menelaus, nestor, ulysses,
and diomed are employed in raising the rest of the captains.
they call
a council of war, and determine to send scouts into the enemies’ camp,
to learn their posture, and discover their intentions.
diomed
undertakes this hazardous enterprise, and makes choice of ulysses for
his companion.
in their passage they surprise dolon, whom hector had
sent on a like design to the camp of the grecians.
from him they are
informed of the situation of the trojan and auxiliary forces, and
particularly of rhesus, and the thracians who were lately arrived.

them information: they then kill him, and profiting by what he

they
pass on with success; kill rhesus, with several of his officers, and

had told them, kill rhesus king of the thracians and take his

seize the famous horses of that prince, with which they return in

horses.

triumph to the camp.

now the other princes of the achaeans slept soundly the whole

the same night continues; the scene lies in the two camps.
all night the chiefs before their vessels lay,
and lost in sleep the labours of the day:

night through, but agamemnon son of atreus was troubled, so that

all but the king: with various thoughts oppress’d,[215]

he could get no rest.

his country’s cares lay rolling in his breast.

as when fair juno’s lord flashes his

as when by lightnings jove’s ethereal power

lightning in token of great rain or hail or snow when the

foretels the rattling hail, or weighty shower,

snow-flakes whiten the ground, or again as a sign that he will

or sends soft snows to whiten all the shore,

open the wide jaws of hungry war, even so did agamemnon heave

or bids the brazen throat of war to roar;
by fits one flash succeeds as one expires,

many a heavy sigh, for his soul trembled within him.

and heaven flames thick with momentary fires:
so bursting frequent from atrides’ breast,
sighs following sighs his inward fears confess’d.

when he

now o’er the fields, dejected, he surveys

looked upon the plain of troy he marvelled at the many watchfires

from thousand trojan fires the mounting blaze;

burning in front of ilius, and at the sound of pipes and flutes

hears in the passing wind their music blow,
and marks distinct the voices of the foe.

and of the hum of men, but when presently he turned towards the

now looking backwards to the fleet and coast,

ships and hosts of the achaeans, he tore his hair by handfuls

anxious he sorrows for the endangered host.
he rends his hair, in sacrifice to jove,

before jove on high, and groaned aloud for the very disquietness

and sues to him that ever lives above:
inly he groans; while glory and despair

of his soul.

divide his heart, and wage a double war.

in the end he deemed it best to go at once to nestor

a thousand cares his labouring breast revolves;
to seek sage nestor now the chief resolves,

son of neleus, and see if between them they could find any way of

with him, in wholesome counsels, to debate

the achaeans from destruction.

what yet remains to save the afflicted state.

he therefore rose, put on his

he rose, and first he cast his mantle round,

shirt, bound his sandals about his comely feet, flung the skin of

next on his feet the shining sandals bound;

a huge tawny lion over his shoulders—a skin that reached his

a lion’s yellow spoils his back conceal’d;

feet—and took his spear in his hand.

his warlike hand a pointed javelin held.

neither could menelaus sleep, for he, too, boded ill for the

meanwhile his brother, press’d with equal woes,
alike denied the gifts of soft repose,

argives who for his sake had sailed from far over the seas to

laments for greece, that in his cause before

fight the trojans.

so much had suffer’d and must suffer more.

he covered his broad back with the skin of a

a leopard’s spotted hide his shoulders spread:

spotted panther, put a casque of bronze upon his head, and took

a brazen helmet glitter’d on his head:

his spear in his brawny hand.
then he went to rouse his brother,

thus (with a javelin in his hand) he went

who was by far the most powerful of the achaeans, and was

to wake atrides in the royal tent.

honoured by the people as though he were a god.
he found him by

already waked, atrides he descried,

the stern of his ship already putting his goodly array about his

his armour buckling at his vessel’s side.

shoulders, and right glad was he that his brother had come.
menelaus spoke first.

joyful they met; the spartan thus begun:

“why,” said he, “my dear brother, are you
thus arming?

“why puts my brother his bright armour on?

are you going to send any of our comrades to exploit

sends he some spy, amidst these silent hours,

the trojans?

to try yon camp, and watch the trojan powers?

i greatly fear that no one will do you this service,

but say, what hero shall sustain that task?
such bold exploits uncommon courage ask;

and spy upon the enemy alone in the dead of night.

guideless, alone, through night’s dark shade to go,
and midst a hostile camp explore the foe.

it will be a
deed of great daring.
”

”

and king agamemnon answered, “menelaus, we both of us need shrewd

to whom the king: “in such distress we stand,

counsel to save the argives and our ships, for jove has changed

no vulgar counsel our affairs demand;

his mind, and inclines towards hector’s sacrifices rather than

greece to preserve, is now no easy part,
but asks high wisdom, deep design, and art.
for jove, averse, our humble prayer denies,
and bows his head to hector’s sacrifice.

ours.
i never saw nor heard tell of any man as having wrought

what eye has witness’d, or what ear believed,

such ruin in one day as hector has now wrought against the sons

in one great day, by one great arm achieved,
such wondrous deeds as hector’s hand has done,
and we beheld, the last revolving sun?

of the achaeans—and that too of his own unaided self, for he is

what honours the beloved of jove adorn!

son neither to god nor goddess.

sprung from no god, and of no goddess born;

the argives will rue it long and

yet such his acts, as greeks unborn shall tell,

deeply.

and curse the battle where their fathers fell.

run, therefore, with all speed by the line of the ships,

“now speed thy hasty course along the fleet,

and call ajax and idomeneus.

there call great ajax, and the prince of crete;

meanwhile i will go to nestor, and
bid him rise and go about among the companies of our sentinels to

ourself to hoary nestor will repair;

give them their instructions; they will listen to him sooner than
to any man, for his own son, and meriones brother in arms to
idomeneus, are captains over them.

to keep the guards on duty be his care,

it was to them more

(for nestor’s influence best that quarter guides,

particularly that we gave this charge.

whose son with merion, o’er the watch presides.

”

”)

menelaus replied, “how do i take your meaning?

to whom the spartan: “these thy orders borne,

am i to stay with
them and wait your coming, or shall i return here as soon as i

say, shall i stay, or with despatch return?

have given your orders?

”

” “wait,” answered king agamemnon, “for

“there shall thou stay, (the king of men replied,)

there are so many paths about the camp that we might miss one

else may we miss to meet, without a guide,

another.

the paths so many, and the camp so wide.

call every man on your way, and bid him be stirring;

still, with your voice the slothful soldiers raise,

name him by his lineage and by his father’s name, give each all

urge by their fathers’ fame their future praise.

titular observance, and stand not too much upon your own dignity;

forget we now our state and lofty birth;

we must take our full share of toil, for at our birth jove laid

not titles here, but works, must prove our worth.

this heavy burden upon us.

to labour is the lot of man below;
and when jove gave us life, he gave us woe.

”

”

with these instructions he sent his brother on his way, and went

this said, each parted to his several cares:

on to nestor shepherd of his people.

the king to nestor’s sable ship repairs;

he found him sleeping in his

the sage protector of the greeks he found

tent hard by his own ship; his goodly armour lay beside him—his

stretch’d in his bed with all his arms around;

shield, his two spears and his helmet; beside him also lay the

the various-colour’d scarf, the shield he rears,
the shining helmet, and the pointed spears;

gleaming girdle with which the old man girded himself when he

the dreadful weapons of the warrior’s rage,

armed to lead his people into battle—for his age stayed him not.

that, old in arms, disdain’d the peace of age.

he raised himself on his elbow and looked up at agamemnon.

then, leaning on his hand his watchful head,
the hoary monarch raised his eyes and said:

“who
is it,” said he, “that goes thus about the host and the ships

“what art thou, speak, that on designs unknown,

alone and in the dead of night, when men are sleeping?

while others sleep, thus range the camp alone;

are you
looking for one of your mules or for some comrade?

seek’st thou some friend or nightly sentinel?

do not stand
there and say nothing, but speak.

stand off, approach not, but thy purpose tell.

what is your business?
”

”

and agamemnon answered, “nestor, son of neleus, honour to the

“o son of neleus, (thus the king rejoin’d,)
pride of the greeks, and glory of thy kind!

achaean name, it is i, agamemnon son of atreus, on whom jove has

lo, here the wretched agamemnon stands,
the unhappy general of the grecian bands,
whom jove decrees with daily cares to bend,

laid labour and sorrow so long as there is breath in my body and

and woes, that only with his life shall end!

my limbs carry me.

scarce can my knees these trembling limbs sustain,
and scarce my heart support its load of pain.

i am thus abroad because sleep sits not upon

no taste of sleep these heavy eyes have known,

my eyelids, but my heart is big with war and with the jeopardy of

confused, and sad, i wander thus alone,

the achaeans.

with fears distracted, with no fix’d design;

i am in great fear for the danaans.

and all my people’s miseries are mine.

i am at sea,

if aught of use thy waking thoughts suggest,

and without sure counsel; my heart beats as though it would leap

(since cares, like mine, deprive thy soul of rest,)

out of my body, and my limbs fail me.

impart thy counsel, and assist thy friend;

if then you can do

now let us jointly to the trench descend,

anything—for you too cannot sleep—let us go the round of the

at every gate the fainting guard excite,

watch, and see whether they are drowsy with toil and sleeping to
the neglect of their duty.

tired with the toils of day and watch of night;

the enemy is encamped hard and we know

else may the sudden foe our works invade,

not but he may attack us by night.

so near, and favour’d by the gloomy shade.

”

”

nestor replied, “most noble son of atreus, king of men,

to him thus nestor: “trust the powers above,

agamemnon, jove will not do all for hector that hector thinks he

nor think proud hector’s hopes confirm’d by jove:
how ill agree the views of vain mankind,

will; he will have troubles yet in plenty if achilles will lay

and the wise counsels of the eternal mind!
audacious hector, if the gods ordain
that great achilles rise and rage again,
what toils attend thee, and what woes remain!

aside his anger.

lo, faithful nestor thy command obeys;

i will go with you, and we will rouse others,

the care is next our other chiefs to raise:

either the son of tydeus, or ulysses, or fleet ajax and the

ulysses, diomed, we chiefly need;

valiant son of phyleus.

meges for strength, oïleus famed for speed.

some one had also better go and call ajax

some other be despatch’d of nimbler feet,

and king idomeneus, for their ships are not near at hand but the

to those tall ships, remotest of the fleet,
where lie great ajax and the king of crete.

farthest of all.

[216]

i cannot however refrain from blaming menelaus,

to rouse the spartan i myself decree;

much as i love him and respect him—and i will say so plainly,

dear as he is to us, and dear to thee,

even at the risk of offending you—for sleeping and leaving all

yet must i tax his sloth, that claims no share

this trouble to yourself.

with his great brother in his martial care:

he ought to be going about imploring

him it behoved to every chief to sue,

aid from all the princes of the achaeans, for we are in extreme

preventing every part perform’d by you;
for strong necessity our toils demands,
claims all our hearts, and urges all our hands.

danger.
”

”

and agamemnon answered, “sir, you may sometimes blame him justly,

to whom the king: “with reverence we allow

for he is often remiss and unwilling to exert himself—not indeed

thy just rebukes, yet learn to spare them now:

from sloth, nor yet heedlessness, but because he looks to me and

my generous brother is of gentle kind,
he seems remiss, but bears a valiant mind;
through too much deference to our sovereign sway,

expects me to take the lead.

content to follow when we lead the way:

on this occasion, however, he was

but now, our ills industrious to prevent,

awake before i was, and came to me of his own accord.
i have

long ere the rest he rose, and sought my tent.

already sent him to call the very men whom you have named.

the chiefs you named, already at his call,

and
now let us be going.
we shall find them with the watch outside

prepare to meet us near the navy-wall;

the gates, for it was there i said that we would meet them.

assembling there, between the trench and gates,
near the night-guards, our chosen council waits.

”

”

“in that case,” answered nestor, “the argives will not blame him
nor disobey his orders when he urges them to fight or gives them

“then none (said nestor) shall his rule withstand,

instructions.

for great examples justify command.

”

”

with this he put on his shirt, and bound his sandals about his

thus leads you wandering in the silent night?

” and

”

nestor knight of gerene answered, “ulysses, noble son of laertes,

“o prudent chief!
(the pylian sage replied)

take it not amiss, for the achaeans are in great straits.

wise as thou art, be now thy wisdom tried:

come

whatever means of safety can be sought,

with me and let us wake some other, who may advise well with us

whatever counsels can inspire our thought,

whether we shall fight or fly.

whatever methods, or to fly or fight;
all, all depend on this important night!

”

”

on this ulysses went at once into his tent, put his shield about

he heard, return’d, and took his painted shield;

his shoulders and came out with them.

then join’d the chiefs, and follow’d through the field.

first they went to diomed
son of tydeus, and found him outside his tent clad in his armour

without his tent, bold diomed they found,

with his comrades sleeping round him and using their shields as

all sheathed in arms, his brave companions round:
each sunk in sleep, extended on the field,
his head reclining on his bossy shield.

pillows; as for their spears, they stood upright on the spikes of
their butts that were driven into the ground, and the burnished

a wood of spears stood by, that, fix’d upright,

bronze flashed afar like the lightning of father jove.

shot from their flashing points a quivering light.

the hero

a bull’s black hide composed the hero’s bed;

was sleeping upon the skin of an ox, with a piece of fine carpet
under his head; nestor went up to him and stirred him with his

a splendid carpet roll’d beneath his head.

heel to rouse him, upbraiding him and urging him to bestir

then, with his foot, old nestor gently shakes

himself.

the slumbering chief, and in these words awakes:

“wake up,” he exclaimed, “son of tydeus.

“rise, son of tydeus!

how can you

to the brave and strong

sleep on in this way?

rest seems inglorious, and the night too long.

can you not see that the trojans are

but sleep’st thou now, when from yon hill the foe

encamped on the brow of the plain hard by our ships, with but a
little space between us and them?

hangs o’er the fleet, and shades our walls below?

”

”

on these words diomed leaped up instantly and said, “old man,

at this, soft slumber from his eyelids fled;
the warrior saw the hoary chief, and said:
“wondrous old man!

your heart is of iron; you rest not one moment from your labours.

whose soul no respite knows,

are there no younger men among the achaeans who could go about to

though years and honours bid thee seek repose,

rouse the princes?

let younger greeks our sleeping warriors wake;

there is no tiring you.

ill fits thy age these toils to undertake.

”

”

and nestor knight of gerene made answer, “my son, all that you
have said is true.

“my friend, (he answered,) generous is thy care;

i have good sons, and also much people who

these toils, my subjects and my sons might bear;

might call the chieftains, but the achaeans are in the gravest

their loyal thoughts and pious love conspire
to ease a sovereign and relieve a sire:
but now the last despair surrounds our host;

danger; life and death are balanced as it were on the edge of a

no hour must pass, no moment must be lost;
each single greek, in this conclusive strife,

razor.

stands on the sharpest edge of death or life:

go then, for you are younger than i, and of your courtesy

yet, if my years thy kind regard engage,
employ thy youth as i employ my age;
succeed to these my cares, and rouse the rest;

rouse ajax and the fleet son of phyleus.

he serves me most, who serves his country best.

”

”

diomed threw the skin of a great tawny lion about his shoulders—a

when he had

meges the bold, with ajax famed for speed,

the round of those who were on guard, and found the captains not

and now the chiefs approach the nightly guard;
a wakeful squadron, each in arms prepared:
the unwearied watch their listening leaders keep,

sleeping at their posts but wakeful and sitting with their arms

and, couching close, repel invading sleep.
so faithful dogs their fleecy charge maintain,

about them.

with toil protected from the prowling train;

as sheep dogs that watch their flocks when they are

when the gaunt lioness, with hunger bold,

yarded, and hear a wild beast coming through the mountain forest

springs from the mountains toward the guarded fold:
through breaking woods her rustling course they hear;
loud, and more loud, the clamours strike their ear

towards them—forthwith there is a hue and cry of dogs and men,

of hounds and men: they start, they gaze around,

and slumber is broken—even so was sleep chased from the eyes of

watch every side, and turn to every sound.

the achaeans as they kept the watches of the wicked night, for

thus watch’d the grecians, cautious of surprise,

they turned constantly towards the plain whenever they heard any

each voice, each motion, drew their ears and eyes:
each step of passing feet increased the affright;

stir among the trojans.

and hostile troy was ever full in sight.

the old man was glad and bade them be of

good cheer.

and thus accosted through the gloomy shade.

“watch on, my children,” said he, “and let not sleep

“’tis well, my sons!
your nightly cares employ;

get hold upon you, lest our enemies triumph over us.

else must our host become the scorn of troy.
watch thus, and greece shall live.

”

” the hero said;

nestor spoke first.

the council opening, in these words begun:

“my friends,” said he, “is there any man bold

“is there (said he) a chief so greatly brave,
his life to hazard, and his country save?
lives there a man, who singly dares to go

enough to venture among the trojans, and cut off some straggler,

to yonder camp, or seize some straggling foe?

or bring us news of what the enemy mean to do whether they will

or favour’d by the night approach so near,
their speech, their counsels, and designs to hear?

stay here by the ships away from the city, or whether, now that
they have worsted the achaeans, they will retire within their

if to besiege our navies they prepare,

walls.

or troy once more must be the seat of war?

if he could learn all this and come back safely here, his

this could he learn, and to our peers recite,
and pass unharm’d the dangers of the night;

fame would be high as heaven in the mouths of all men, and he

what fame were his through all succeeding days,
while phœbus shines, or men have tongues to praise!

would be rewarded richly; for the chiefs from all our ships would

what gifts his grateful country would bestow!
what must not greece to her deliverer owe?
a sable ewe each leader should provide,

each of them give him a black ewe with her lamb—which is a

with each a sable lambkin by her side;

present of surpassing value—and he would be asked as a guest to

all feasts and clan-gatherings.

and his the foremost honours of the feast.
