through yon black camps to bend my dangerous way,

against us, but if another will go with me i shall do so in

some god within commands, and i obey.
but let some other chosen warrior join,

greater confidence and comfort.

to raise my hopes, and second my design.

when two men are together, one of

by mutual confidence and mutual aid,

them may see some opportunity which the other has not caught

great deeds are done, and great discoveries made;

sight of; if a man is alone he is less full of resource, and his

the wise new prudence from the wise acquire,

wit is weaker.

and one brave hero fans another’s fire.

”

”

on this several offered to go with diomed.

the two ajaxes,

each generous breast with emulation glows;

among the host of the trojans, for he was ever full of daring,

and great ulysses wish’d, nor wish’d in vain.

“son of tydeus, man after my own heart, choose your comrade for

“thou first of warriors, and thou best of friends,

would now go with you.

undaunted diomed!
what chief to join

do not through delicacy reject the better

in this great enterprise, is only thine.
just be thy choice, without affection made;

man, and take the worst out of respect for his lineage, because

to birth, or office, no respect be paid;
let worth determine here.

he is of more royal blood.
”

” the monarch spake,

he said this because he feared for menelaus.

and inly trembled for his brother’s sake.

diomed answered, “if

“then thus (the godlike diomed rejoin’d)

you bid me take the man of my own choice, how in that case can i

my choice declares the impulse of my mind.

fail to think of ulysses, than whom there is no man more eager to

how can i doubt, while great ulysses stands

face all kinds of danger—and pallas minerva loves him well?

to lend his counsels and assist our hands?
a chief, whose safety is minerva’s care;

if he

so famed, so dreadful, in the works of war:

were to go with me we should pass safely through fire itself, for

bless’d in his conduct, i no aid require;

he is quick to see and understand.

wisdom like his might pass through flames of fire.

”

”

“son of tydeus,” replied ulysses, “say neither good nor ill about

“it fits thee not, before these chiefs of fame,
(replied the sage,) to praise me, or to blame:

me, for you are among argives who know me well.

praise from a friend, or censure from a foe,
are lost on hearers that our merits know.

let us be going,

but let us haste—night rolls the hours away,

for the night wanes and dawn is at hand.

the reddening orient shows the coming day,

the stars have gone

the stars shine fainter on the ethereal plains,

forward, two-thirds of the night are already spent, and the third
is alone left us.

and of night’s empire but a third remains.

”

”

they then put on their armour.

by the achaeans.

of greece he left, and sought the theban towers,

peace was his charge; received with peaceful show,

cadmeians; on his return thence, with your help, goddess, he did

he went a legate, but return’d a foe:
then help’d by thee, and cover’d by thy shield,

great deeds of daring, for you were his ready helper.

he fought with numbers, and made numbers yield.

even so

so now be present, o celestial maid!

guide me and guard me now, and in return i will offer you in

so still continue to the race thine aid!

sacrifice a broad-browed heifer of a year old, unbroken, and

a youthful steer shall fall beneath the stroke,

never yet brought by man under the yoke.

untamed, unconscious of the galling yoke,

i will gild her horns

with ample forehead, and with spreading horns,

and will offer her up to you in sacrifice.

whose taper tops refulgent gold adorns.

”

”

thus they prayed, and pallas minerva heard their prayer.
when

the heroes pray’d, and pallas from the skies

they had done praying to the daughter of great jove, they went

accords their vow, succeeds their enterprise.

their way like two lions prowling by night amid the armour and

now, like two lions panting for the prey,
with dreadful thoughts they trace the dreary way,

blood-stained bodies of them that had fallen.

through the black horrors of the ensanguined plain,
through dust, through blood, o’er arms, and hills of slain.

neither again did hector let the trojans sleep; for he too called

nor less bold hector, and the sons of troy,
on high designs the wakeful hours employ;

the princes and councillors of the trojans that he might set his

the assembled peers their lofty chief enclosed;

counsel before them.

who thus the counsels of his breast proposed:

“is there one,” said he, “who for a great

“what glorious man, for high attempts prepared,

reward will do me the service of which i will tell you?

dares greatly venture for a rich reward?
of yonder fleet a bold discovery make,
what watch they keep, and what resolves they take?

he shall

if now subdued they meditate their flight,

be well paid if he will.

and, spent with toil, neglect the watch of night?

i will give him a chariot and a couple
of horses, the fleetest that can be found at the ships of the
achaeans, if he will dare this thing; and he will win infinite
honour to boot; he must go to the ships and find out whether they

his be the chariot that shall please him most,

are still guarded as heretofore, or whether now that we have

of all the plunder of the vanquish’d host;

beaten them the achaeans design to fly, and through sheer

his the fair steeds that all the rest excel,

exhaustion are neglecting to keep their watches.

and his the glory to have served so well.

”

”

they all held their peace; but there was among the trojans a

a youth there was among the tribes of troy,

certain man named dolon, son of eumedes, the famous herald—a man

dolon his name, eumedes’ only boy,
(five girls beside the reverend herald told.

rich in gold and bronze.

)
rich was the son in brass, and rich in gold;

he was ill-favoured, but a good runner,

not bless’d by nature with the charms of face,

and was an only son among five sisters.

but swift of foot, and matchless in the race.

he it was that now
addressed the trojans.

“hector!

“i, hector,” said he, “will to the ships

(he said) my courage bids me meet

and will exploit them.

this high achievement, and explore the fleet:

but first hold up your sceptre and swear

but first exalt thy sceptre to the skies,

that you will give me the chariot, bedight with bronze, and the

and swear to grant me the demanded prize;
the immortal coursers, and the glittering car,

horses that now carry the noble son of peleus.

that bear pelides through the ranks of war.

i will make you a

encouraged thus, no idle scout i go,

good scout, and will not fail you.

fulfil thy wish, their whole intention know,

i will go through the host
from one end to the other till i come to the ship of agamemnon,
where i take it the princes of the achaeans are now consulting

even to the royal tent pursue my way,

whether they shall fight or fly.

and all their counsels, all their aims betray.

”

”

when he had done speaking hector held up his sceptre, and swore

the chief then heaved the golden sceptre high,

him his oath saying, “may jove the thundering husband of juno

attesting thus the monarch of the sky:

bear witness that no other trojan but yourself shall mount those

“be witness thou!
immortal lord of all!
whose thunder shakes the dark aerial hall:
by none but dolon shall this prize be borne,

steeds, and that you shall have your will with them for ever.

and him alone the immortal steeds adorn.

”

”

the oath he swore was bootless, but it made dolon more keen on

thus hector swore: the gods were call’d in vain,

going.

but the rash youth prepares to scour the plain:

he hung his bow over his shoulder, and as an overall he

across his back the bended bow he flung,

a wolf’s grey hide around his shoulders hung,

ferret skin.

a ferret’s downy fur his helmet lined,

then he took a pointed javelin, and left the camp

and in his hand a pointed javelin shined.

for the ships, but he was not to return with any news for hector.

then (never to return) he sought the shore,

when he had left the horses and the troops behind him, he made

and trod the path his feet must tread no more.

all speed on his way, but ulysses perceived his coming and said

scarce had he pass’d the steeds and trojan throng,
(still bending forward as he coursed along,)
when, on the hollow way, the approaching tread

to diomed, “diomed, here is some one from the camp; i am not sure

ulysses mark’d, and thus to diomed;
“o friend!
i hear some step of hostile feet,

whether he is a spy, or whether it is some thief who would

moving this way, or hastening to the fleet;
some spy, perhaps, to lurk beside the main;
or nightly pillager that strips the slain.

plunder the bodies of the dead; let him get a little past us, we

yet let him pass, and win a little space;

can then spring upon him and take him.

then rush behind him, and prevent his pace.

if, however, he is too

but if too swift of foot he flies before,

quick for us, go after him with your spear and hem him in towards

confine his course along the fleet and shore,
betwixt the camp and him our spears employ,

the ships away from the trojan camp, to prevent his getting back

and intercept his hoped return to troy.

to the town.
”

”

with this they turned out of their way and lay down among the

with that they stepp’d aside, and stoop’d their head,

corpses.

(as dolon pass’d,) behind a heap of dead:

dolon suspected nothing and soon passed them, but when

along the path the spy unwary flew;

he had got about as far as the distance by which a mule-plowed

soft, at just distance, both the chiefs pursue.
so distant they, and such the space between,

furrow exceeds one that has been ploughed by oxen (for mules can

as when two teams of mules divide the green,
(to whom the hind like shares of land allows,)

plow fallow land quicker than oxen) they ran after him, and when

when now new furrows part the approaching ploughs.

he heard their footsteps he stood still, for he made sure they

now dolon, listening, heard them as they pass’d;

were friends from the trojan camp come by hector’s orders to bid

hector (he thought) had sent, and check’d his haste,

him return; when, however, they were only a spear’s cast, or
less, away from him, he saw that they were enemies and ran as

till scarce at distance of a javelin’s throw,

fast as his legs could take him.

no voice succeeding, he perceived the foe.

the others gave chase at once,
and as a couple of well-trained hounds press forward after a doe

as when two skilful hounds the leveret wind;

or hare that runs screaming in front of them, even so did the son

or chase through woods obscure the trembling hind;

of tydeus and ulysses pursue dolon and cut him off from his own

now lost, now seen, they intercept his way,
and from the herd still turn the flying prey:

people.

so fast, and with such fears, the trojan flew;

but when he had fled so far towards the ships that he

so close, so constant, the bold greeks pursue.

would soon have fallen in with the outposts, minerva infused

now almost on the fleet the dastard falls,
and mingles with the guards that watch the walls;

fresh strength into the son of tydeus for fear some other of the

when brave tydides stopp’d; a gen’rous thought

achaeans might have the glory of being first to hit him, and he

(inspired by pallas) in his bosom wrought,

might himself be only second; he therefore sprang forward with

lest on the foe some forward greek advance,

his spear and said, “stand, or i shall throw my spear, and in

and snatch the glory from his lifted lance.
then thus aloud: “whoe’er thou art, remain;

that case i shall soon make an end of you.

this javelin else shall fix thee to the plain.

”

”

he threw as he spoke, but missed his aim on purpose.

he said, and high in air the weapon cast,

the dart

which wilful err’d, and o’er his shoulder pass’d;

flew over the man’s right shoulder, and then stuck in the ground.

then fix’d in earth.

he stood stock still, trembling and in great fear; his teeth

against the trembling wood
the wretch stood propp’d, and quiver’d as he stood;

chattered, and he turned pale with fear.

a sudden palsy seized his turning head;
his loose teeth chatter’d, and his colour fled;

the two came breathless

the panting warriors seize him as he stands,

up to him and seized his hands, whereon he began to weep and

and with unmanly tears his life demands.

said, “take me alive; i will ransom myself; we have great store

“o spare my youth, and for the breath i owe,

of gold, bronze, and wrought iron, and from this my father will

large gifts of price my father shall bestow:

satisfy you with a very large ransom, should he hear of my being

vast heaps of brass shall in your ships be told,

alive at the ships of the achaeans.

and steel well-temper’d and refulgent gold.

”

”

“fear not,” replied ulysses, “let no thought of death be in your

to whom ulysses made this wise reply:
“whoe’er thou art, be bold, nor fear to die.

mind; but tell me, and tell me true, why are you thus going about

what moves thee, say, when sleep has closed the sight,

alone in the dead of night away from your camp and towards the
ships, while other men are sleeping?

to roam the silent fields in dead of night?

is it to plunder the bodies

cam’st thou the secrets of our camp to find,

of the slain, or did hector send you to spy out what was going on

by hector prompted, or thy daring mind?
or art some wretch by hopes of plunder led,

at the ships?
or did you come here of your own mere notion?

through heaps of carnage, to despoil the dead?

”

”

dolon answered, his limbs trembling beneath him: “hector, with

then thus pale dolon, with a fearful look:
(still, as he spoke, his limbs with horror shook:)
“hither i came, by hector’s words deceived;

his vain flattering promises, lured me from my better judgement.

much did he promise, rashly i believed:

he said he would give me the horses of the noble son of peleus

no less a bribe than great achilles’ car,

and his bronze-bedizened chariot; he bade me go through the

and those swift steeds that sweep the ranks of war,
urged me, unwilling, this attempt to make;

darkness of the flying night, get close to the enemy, and find

to learn what counsels, what resolves you take:

out whether the ships are still guarded as heretofore, or
whether, now that we have beaten them, the achaeans design to
fly, and through sheer exhaustion are neglecting to keep their

if now subdued, you fix your hopes on flight,

watches.

and, tired with toils, neglect the watch of night.

”

”

ulysses smiled at him and answered, “you had indeed set your

“bold was thy aim, and glorious was the prize,
(ulysses, with a scornful smile, replies,)

heart upon a great reward, but the horses of the descendant of

far other rulers those proud steeds demand,

aeacus are hardly to be kept in hand or driven by any other

and scorn the guidance of a vulgar hand;
even great achilles scarce their rage can tame,

mortal man than achilles himself, whose mother was an immortal.

achilles sprung from an immortal dame.

but tell me, and tell me true, where did you leave hector when

but say, be faithful, and the truth recite!

you started?

where lies encamp’d the trojan chief to-night?

where stand his coursers?

how, too, are

the watches and sleeping-ground of the trojans ordered?

their other princes?

what are

their plans?

say, since this conquest, what their counsels are;

will they stay here by the ships and away from the
city, or now that they have worsted the achaeans, will they

or here to combat, from their city far,

retire within their walls?

or back to ilion’s walls transfer the war?

”

”

and dolon answered, “i will tell you truly all.

ulysses thus, and thus eumedes’ son:
“what dolon knows, his faithful tongue shall own.

hector and the

hector, the peers assembling in his tent,

other councillors are now holding conference by the monument of

a council holds at ilus’ monument.

great ilus, away from the general tumult; as for the guards about
which you ask me, there is no chosen watch to keep guard over the
host.

no certain guards the nightly watch partake;

the trojans have their watchfires, for they are bound to

where’er yon fires ascend, the trojans wake:

have them; they, therefore, are awake and keep each other to
their duty as sentinels; but the allies who have come from other

anxious for troy, the guard the natives keep;

places are asleep and leave it to the trojans to keep guard, for

safe in their cares, the auxiliar forces sleep,

their wives and children are not here.

whose wives and infants, from the danger far,
discharge their souls of half the fears of war.

”

”

ulysses then said, “now tell me; are they sleeping among the

trojan troops, or do they lie apart?

explain this that i may
understand it.
”

”

“i will tell you truly all,” replied dolon.

to whom the spy: “their powers they thus dispose

“to the seaward lie

the paeons, dreadful with their bended bows,

and leleges, encamp along the coast.

the lycians and proud mysians, with the

thymbra; but why ask about all this?

the lycian, mysian, and mæonian band,

if you want to find your way

and phrygia’s horse, by thymbras’ ancient wall;

into the host of the trojans, there are the thracians, who have

the thracians utmost, and apart from all.

lately come here and lie apart from the others at the far end of

these troy but lately to her succour won,

the camp; and they have rhesus son of eioneus for their king.

led on by rhesus, great eioneus’ son:

his
horses are the finest and strongest that i have ever seen, they

i saw his coursers in proud triumph go,

are whiter than snow and fleeter than any wind that blows.

swift as the wind, and white as winter-snow;

his

rich silver plates his shining car infold;

chariot is bedight with silver and gold, and he has brought his

his solid arms, refulgent, flame with gold;

marvellous golden armour, of the rarest workmanship—too splendid

no mortal shoulders suit the glorious load,

for any mortal man to carry, and meet only for the gods.

celestial panoply, to grace a god!

now,

let me, unhappy, to your fleet be borne,

therefore, take me to the ships or bind me securely here, until

or leave me here, a captive’s fate to mourn,

you come back and have proved my words whether they be false or

in cruel chains, till your return reveal
the truth or falsehood of the news i tell.

true.
”

”

diomed looked sternly at him and answered, “think not, dolon, for

to this tydides, with a gloomy frown:

all the good information you have given us, that you shall escape

“think not to live, though all the truth be shown:

now you are in our hands, for if we ransom you or let you go, you

shall we dismiss thee, in some future strife
to risk more bravely thy now forfeit life?

will come some second time to the ships of the achaeans either as

or that again our camps thou may’st explore?

a spy or as an open enemy, but if i kill you and an end of you,
you will give no more trouble.

no—once a traitor, thou betray’st no more.

”

”

on this dolon would have caught him by the beard to beseech him

sternly he spoke, and as the wretch prepared
with humble blandishment to stroke his beard,

further, but diomed struck him in the middle of his neck with his

like lightning swift the wrathful falchion flew,

sword and cut through both sinews so that his head fell rolling

divides the neck, and cuts the nerves in two;
one instant snatch’d his trembling soul to hell,

in the dust while he was yet speaking.

the head, yet speaking, mutter’d as it fell.

they took the ferret skin

the furry helmet from his brow they tear,

cap from his head, and also the wolf-skin, the bow, and his long

the wolf’s grey hide, the unbended bow and spear;

these great ulysses lifting to the skies,
to favouring pallas dedicates the prize:

goddess of plunder, and prayed saying, “accept these, goddess,

“great queen of arms, receive this hostile spoil,

for we give them to you in preference to all the gods in olympus:

and let the thracian steeds reward our toil;
thee, first of all the heavenly host, we praise;

therefore speed us still further towards the horses and

o speed our labours, and direct our ways!

sleeping-ground of the thracians.

through the flying hours of darkness.
the two then went onwards

whom we killed told us.

now, brave tydides!

now thy courage try,

yourself, while i see to the horses.

urge thou the slaughter, while i seize the steeds.

”

”

thereon minerva put courage into the heart of diomed, and he

pallas (this said) her hero’s bosom warms,
breathed in his heart, and strung his nervous arms;
where’er he pass’d, a purple stream pursued
his thirsty falchion, fat with hostile blood,
bathed all his footsteps, dyed the fields with gore,

smote them right and left.

and a low groan remurmur’d through the shore.

they made a hideous groaning as they

so the grim lion, from his nightly den,

were being hacked about, and the earth was red with their blood.

o’erleaps the fences, and invades the pen,

as a lion springs furiously upon a flock of sheep or goats when

on sheep or goats, resistless in his way,

he finds them without their shepherd, so did the son of tydeus

he falls, and foaming rends the guardless prey;
nor stopp’d the fury of his vengeful hand,

set upon the thracian soldiers till he had killed twelve.

till twelve lay breathless of the thracian band.

as he

killed them ulysses came and drew them aside by their feet one by

back by the foot each slaughter’d warrior drew;

one, that the horses might go forward freely without being

safe to the ships, he wisely cleared the way:
lest the fierce steeds, not yet to battles bred,

yet used to them.

should start, and tremble at the heaps of dead.

when the son of tydeus came to the king, he

now twelve despatch’d, the monarch last they found;

killed him too (which made thirteen), as he was breathing hard,

tydides’ falchion fix’d him to the ground.

for by the counsel of minerva an evil dream, the seed of oeneus,

just then a deathful dream minerva sent,
a warlike form appear’d before his tent,
whose visionary steel his bosom tore:
so dream’d the monarch, and awaked no more.

hovered that night over his head.

from the chariot.

(the scourge forgot, on rhesus’ chariot hung;)

then gave his friend the signal to retire;

but diomed stayed where he was, thinking what other daring deed
he might accomplish.

but him, new dangers, new achievements fire;

nor tempt too far the hostile gods of troy.

the yet-warm thracians panting on the coast;
for each he wept, but for his rhesus most:

and called upon his friend by name.

now while on rhesus’ name he calls in vain,

then the whole trojan camp

free will.

[illustration: ] diomed and ulysses returning with the spoils of rhesus

nestor was first to hear the tramp of their feet.
“my

old nestor first perceived the approaching sound,

friends,” said he, “princes and counsellors of the argives, shall

bespeaking thus the grecian peers around:

i guess right or wrong?
—but i must say what i think: there is a

“methinks the noise of trampling steeds i hear,

sound in my ears as of the tramp of horses.

thickening this way, and gathering on my ear;
perhaps some horses of the trojan breed

i hope it may be

(so may, ye gods!
my pious hopes succeed)

diomed and ulysses driving in horses from the trojans, but i much

the great tydides and ulysses bear,

fear that the bravest of the argives may have come to some harm

return’d triumphant with this prize of war.
yet much i fear (ah, may that fear be vain!

at their hands.

)
the chiefs outnumber’d by the trojan train;
perhaps, even now pursued, they seek the shore;

”

or, oh!
perhaps those heroes are no more.
”

he had hardly done speaking when the two men came in and

scarce had he spoke, when, lo!

dismounted, whereon the others shook hands right gladly with them

the chiefs appear,
and spring to earth; the greeks dismiss their fear:
with words of friendship and extended hands

and congratulated them.
nestor knight of gerene was first to
question them.

they greet the kings; and nestor first demands:

“tell me,” said he, “renowned ulysses, how did you

“say thou, whose praises all our host proclaim,
thou living glory of the grecian name!

two come by these horses?

say whence these coursers?

did you steal in among the trojan

by what chance bestow’d,

forces, or did some god meet you and give them to you?

the spoil of foes, or present of a god?

they are

not those fair steeds, so radiant and so gay,

like sunbeams.

that draw the burning chariot of the day.

i am well conversant with the trojans, for old

old as i am, to age i scorn to yield,

warrior though i am i never hold back by the ships, but i never

and daily mingle in the martial field;
but sure till now no coursers struck my sight

yet saw or heard of such horses as these are.

like these, conspicuous through the ranks of fight.

surely some god

some god, i deem, conferred the glorious prize,

must have met you and given them to you, for you are both of you

bless’d as ye are, and favourites of the skies;

dear to jove, and to jove’s daughter minerva.

the care of him who bids the thunder roar,
and her, whose fury bathes the world with gore.

”

”

and ulysses answered, “nestor son of neleus, honour to the

“father!

achaean name, heaven, if it so will, can give us even better

not so, (sage ithacus rejoin’d,)

horses than these, for the gods are far mightier than we are.

the gifts of heaven are of a nobler kind.

these horses, however, about which you ask me, are freshly come

of thracian lineage are the steeds ye view,

from thrace.
diomed killed their king with the twelve bravest of

whose hostile king the brave tydides slew;

his companions.

sleeping he died, with all his guards around,

hard by the ships we took a thirteenth man—a

and twelve beside lay gasping on the ground.

scout whom hector and the other trojans had sent as a spy upon

these other spoils from conquer’d dolon came,
a wretch, whose swiftness was his only fame;
by hector sent our forces to explore,

our ships.

he now lies headless on the sandy shore.

”

”

he laughed as he spoke and drove the horses over the ditch, while

then o’er the trench the bounding coursers flew;

the other achaeans followed him gladly.

the joyful greeks with loud acclaim pursue.

when they reached the

straight to tydides’ high pavilion borne,

strongly built quarters of the son of tydeus, they tied the

the matchless steeds his ample stalls adorn:

horses with thongs of leather to the manger, where the steeds of

the neighing coursers their new fellows greet,

diomed stood eating their sweet corn, but ulysses hung the

and the full racks are heap’d with generous wheat.

blood-stained spoils of dolon at the stern of his ship, that they

but dolon’s armour, to his ships convey’d,
high on the painted stern ulysses laid,

might prepare a sacred offering to minerva.

a trophy destin’d to the blue-eyed maid.

as for themselves,

now from nocturnal sweat and sanguine stain

they went into the sea and washed the sweat from their bodies,
and from their necks and thighs.

they cleanse their bodies in the neighb’ring main:

when the sea-water had taken all
the sweat from off them, and had refreshed them, they went into
the baths and washed themselves.

then in the polished bath, refresh’d from toil,

after they had so done and had

their joints they supple with dissolving oil,
in due repast indulge the genial hour,
and first to pallas the libations pour:

anointed themselves with oil, they sat down to table, and drawing

they sit, rejoicing in her aid divine,

from a full mixing-bowl, made a drink-offering of wine to

and the crown’d goblet foams with floods of wine.

minerva.

book xi.

book xi.

argument

in the forenoon the fight is equal, but agamemnon turns the

the third battle, and the acts of agamemnon.
agamemnon, having armed himself, leads the grecians to battle; hector

fortune of the day towards the achaeans until he gets wounded and

prepares the trojans to receive them, while jupiter, juno, and minerva
give the signals of war.

leaves the field—hector then drives everything before him till he

agamemnon bears all before him and hector is
commanded by jupiter (who sends iris for that purpose) to decline the
engagement, till the king shall be wounded and retire from the field.
he then makes a great slaughter of the enemy.

is wounded by diomed—paris wounds diomed—ulysses, nestor, and

ulysses and diomed put a
stop to him for a time but the latter, being wounded by paris, is
obliged to desert his companion, who is encompassed by the trojans,
wounded, and in the utmost danger, till menelaus and ajax rescue him.

idomeneus perform prodigies of valour—machaon is wounded—nestor

hector comes against ajax, but that hero alone opposes multitudes, and
rallies the greeks.
in the meantime machaon, in the other wing of the
army, is pierced with an arrow by paris, and carried from the fight in

drives him off in his chariot—achilles sees the pair driving

nestor’s chariot.
achilles (who overlooked the action from his ship)

towards the camp and sends patroclus to ask who it is that is

sent patroclus to inquire which of the greeks was wounded in that
manner; nestor entertains him in his tent with an account of the
accidents of the day, and a long recital of some former wars which he
remembered, tending to put patroclus upon persuading achilles to fight
for his countrymen, or at least to permit him to do it, clad in

wounded—this is the beginning of evil for patroclus—nestor makes

achilles’ armour.
patroclus, on his return, meets eurypylus also
wounded, and assists him in that distress.
this book opens with the eight-and-twentieth day of the poem, and

a long speech.

the same day, with its various actions and adventures is extended
through the twelfth, thirteenth, fourteenth, fifteenth, sixteenth,
seventeenth, and part of the eighteenth books.
the scene lies in
the field near the monument of ilus.

and now as dawn rose from her couch beside tithonus, harbinger of

the saffron morn, with early blushes spread,[219]
now rose refulgent from tithonus’ bed;

light alike to mortals and immortals, jove sent fierce discord

with new-born day to gladden mortal sight,
and gild the courts of heaven with sacred light:
when baleful eris, sent by jove’s command,

with the ensign of war in her hands to the ships of the achaeans.

the torch of discord blazing in her hand,

she took her stand by the huge black hull of ulysses’ ship which

through the red skies her bloody sign extends,
and, wrapt in tempests, o’er the fleet descends.

was middlemost of all, so that her voice might carry farthest on

high on ulysses’ bark her horrid stand

either side, on the one hand towards the tents of ajax son of

and fair proportion match’d the ethereal race.

hector’s round shield showed in the front rank, and as some

great hector, cover’d with his spacious shield,
plies all the troops, and orders all the field.

baneful star that shines for a moment through a rent in the

as the red star now shows his sanguine fires

clouds and is again hidden beneath them; even so was hector now

through the dark clouds, and now in night retires,

seen in the front ranks and now again in the hindermost, and his

thus through the ranks appear’d the godlike man,
plunged in the rear, or blazing in the van;
while streamy sparkles, restless as he flies,

bronze armour gleamed like the lightning of aegis-bearing jove.

flash from his arms, as lightning from the skies.

and now as a band of reapers mow swathes of wheat or barley upon
a rich man’s land, and the sheaves fall thick before them, even

as sweating reapers in some wealthy field,

so did the trojans and achaeans fall upon one another; they were

ranged in two bands, their crooked weapons wield,
bear down the furrows, till their labours meet;
thick fall the heapy harvests at their feet:
so greece and troy the field of war divide,
and falling ranks are strow’d on every side.

in no mood for yielding but fought like wolves, and neither side

none stoop’d a thought to base inglorious flight;[221]
but horse to horse, and man to man they fight,
not rabid wolves more fierce contest their prey;

got the better of the other.

each wounds, each bleeds, but none resign the day.

discord was glad as she beheld them,

discord with joy the scene of death descries,

for she was the only god that went among them; the others were

and drinks large slaughter at her sanguine eyes:

not there, but stayed quietly each in his own home among the

discord alone, of all the immortal train,
swells the red horrors of this direful plain:
the gods in peace their golden mansions fill,

dells and valleys of olympus.

ranged in bright order on the olympian hill:

now soil’d with dust, and naked to the sky,

as a lion

and grinds the quivering flesh with bloody jaws;

to his lair—the hind can do nothing for them even though she be
close by, for she is in an agony of fear, and flies through the

the frighted hind beholds, and dares not stay,

thick forest, sweating, and at her utmost speed before the mighty

but swift through rustling thickets bursts her way;

and the big tears roll trickling from her eyes.

the sons of false antimachus were slain;

with such piteous words and tears did they beseech the king, but

these words, attended with the flood of tears,

they heard no pitiful answer in return.

the youths address’d to unrelenting ears:
the vengeful monarch gave this stern reply:

“if,” said agamemnon,

“if from antimachus ye spring, ye die;

“you are sons of antimachus, who once at a council of trojans

the daring wretch who once in council stood

proposed that menelaus and ulysses, who had come to you as

to shed ulysses’ and my brother’s blood,

envoys, should be killed and not suffered to return, you shall

for proffer’d peace!

now pay for the foul iniquity of your father.

and sues his seed for grace?
no, die, and pay the forfeit of your race.

”

”

as he spoke he felled pisander from his chariot to the earth,

this said, pisander from the car he cast,

smiting him on the chest with his spear, so that he lay face

and pierced his breast: supine he breathed his last.

uppermost upon the ground.
hippolochus fled, but him too did

his brother leap’d to earth; but, as he lay,

as when the winds with raging flames conspire,

in blazing heaps the grove’s old honours fall,
and one refulgent ruin levels all:

are consumed before the blast of the flame—even so fell the heads

array and they stood face to face with one another, agamemnon

new force, new spirit, to each breast returns;

ever pressing forward in his eagerness to be ahead of all others.

the fight renew’d with fiercer fury burns:

tell me now ye muses that dwell in the mansions of olympus, who,

the king leads on: all fix on him their eye,

whether of the trojans or of their allies, was first to face

and learn from him to conquer, or to die.

agamemnon?

ye sacred nine!
celestial muses!
tell,

it was iphidamas son of antenor, a man both brave and

who faced him first, and by his prowess fell?
the great iphidamas, the bold and young,
from sage antenor and theano sprung;

of great stature, who was brought up in fertile thrace, the

whom from his youth his grandsire cisseus bred,

mother of sheep.

and nursed in thrace where snowy flocks are fed.

cisses, his mother’s father, brought him up in

scarce did the down his rosy cheeks invest,
and early honour warm his generous breast,

his own house when he was a child—cisses, father to fair theano.

when the kind sire consign’d his daughter’s charms
(theano’s sister) to his youthful arms.
but call’d by glory to the wars of troy,

when he reached manhood, cisses would have kept him there, and

he leaves untasted the first fruits of joy;

was for giving him his daughter in marriage, but as soon as he

from his loved bride departs with melting eyes,
and swift to aid his dearer country flies.

had married he set out to fight the achaeans with twelve ships
that followed him: these he had left at percote and had come on

with twelve black ships he reach’d percope’s strand,

by land to ilius.

thence took the long laborious march by land.

he it was that now met agamemnon son of atreus.

now fierce for fame, before the ranks he springs,

when they were close up with one another, the son of atreus

towering in arms, and braves the king of kings.

the trojan stoop’d, the javelin pass’d in air.

then near the corslet, at the monarch’s heart,

full on his neck, that fell’d him to the ground.

so there the poor fellow lay, sleeping a sleep as it were

stretch’d in the dust the unhappy warrior lies,
and sleep eternal seals his swimming eyes.
oh worthy better fate!
oh early slain!

of bronze, killed in the defence of his fellow-citizens, far from

thy country’s friend; and virtuous, though in vain!
no more the youth shall join his consort’s side,

his wedded wife, of whom he had had no joy though he had given

at once a virgin, and at once a bride!
no more with presents her embraces meet,

much for her: he had given a hundred head of cattle down, and had

or lay the spoils of conquest at her feet,
on whom his passion, lavish of his store,

promised later on to give a thousand sheep and goats mixed, from

bestow’d so much, and vainly promised more!

the countless flocks of which he was possessed.

host of the achaeans.
when noble coon, antenor’s eldest son, saw this, sore indeed were

coon, antenor’s eldest hope, was nigh:

his eyes at the sight of his fallen brother.

tears, at the sight, came starting from his eye,
while pierced with grief the much-loved youth he view’d,

unseen by agamemnon

and the pale features now deform’d with blood.

he got beside him, spear in hand, and wounded him in the middle

then, with his spear, unseen, his time he took,
aim’d at the king, and near his elbow strook.

of his arm below the elbow, the point of the spear going right

the thrilling steel transpierced the brawny part,

through the arm.

and through his arm stood forth the barbed dart.

agamemnon was convulsed with pain, but still not

surprised the monarch feels, yet void of fear

even for this did he leave off struggling and fighting, but
grasped his spear that flew as fleet as the wind, and sprang upon

on coon rushes with his lifted spear:

coon who was trying to drag off the body of his brother—his

his brother’s corpse the pious trojan draws,

father’s son—by the foot, and was crying for help to all the

and calls his country to assert his cause;

bravest of his comrades; but agamemnon struck him with a

bronze-shod spear and killed him as he was dragging the dead body

and o’er the body spreads his ample shield.

through the press of men under cover of his shield: he then cut

atrides, marking an unguarded part,
transfix’d the warrior with his brazen dart;
prone on his brother’s bleeding breast he lay,

off his head, standing over the body of iphidamas.

the monarch’s falchion lopp’d his head away:

thus did the
sons of antenor meet their fate at the hands of the son of

the social shades the same dark journey go,

atreus, and go down into the house of hades.

and join each other in the realms below.

as long as the blood still welled warm from his wound agamemnon

the vengeful victor rages round the fields,

went about attacking the ranks of the enemy with spear and sword

with every weapon art or fury yields:
by the long lance, the sword, or ponderous stone,
whole ranks are broken, and whole troops o’erthrown.

and with great handfuls of stone, but when the blood had ceased

this, while yet warm distill’d the purple flood;
but when the wound grew stiff with clotted blood,

to flow and the wound grew dry, the pain became great.

then grinding tortures his strong bosom rend,

as the

less keen those darts the fierce ilythiae send:

sharp pangs which the eilithuiae, goddesses of childbirth,

(the powers that cause the teeming matron’s throes,

daughters of juno and dispensers of cruel pain, send upon a woman
when she is in labour—even so sharp were the pangs of the son of

sad mothers of unutterable woes!

atreus.

)

he sprang on to his chariot, and bade his charioteer

stung with the smart, all-panting with the pain,

drive to the ships, for he was in great agony.

he mounts the car, and gives his squire the rein;

with a loud clear

then with a voice which fury made more strong,

“o friends!

assert your honours won;

lo!
angry jove forbids your chief to stay,

has not suffered me to fight the whole day through against the

and envies half the glories of the day.

trojans.

”

he said: the driver whirls his lengthful thong;

they flew forward nothing loth.

the horses fly; the chariot smokes along.

the battle.

the wounded monarch at his tent they place.
no sooner hector saw the king retired,

but thus his trojans and his aids he fired:
“hear, all ye dardan, all ye lycian race!

warriors, be men, my friends, and acquit yourselves in battle

famed in close fight, and dreadful face to face:
now call to mind your ancient trophies won,

bravely; their best man has left them, and jove has vouchsafed me

your great forefathers’ virtues, and your own.
behold, the general flies!
deserts his powers!
lo, jove himself declares the conquest ours!

a great triumph; charge the foe with your chariots that you may

now on yon ranks impel your foaming steeds;

win still greater glory.

and, sure of glory, dare immortal deeds.

”

”

with these words he put heart and soul into them all, and as a

with words like these the fiery chief alarms
his fainting host, and every bosom warms.

huntsman hounds his dogs on against a lion or wild boar, even so

as the bold hunter cheers his hounds to tear
the brindled lion, or the tusky bear:

did hector, peer of mars, hound the proud trojans on against the

with voice and hand provokes their doubting heart,
and springs the foremost with his lifted dart:
so godlike hector prompts his troops to dare;

achaeans.

nor prompts alone, but leads himself the war.

full of hope he plunged in among the foremost, and fell

on the black body of the foe he pours;

on the fight like some fierce tempest that swoops down upon the

as from the cloud’s deep bosom, swell’d with showers,

sea, and lashes its deep blue waters into fury.

a sudden storm the purple ocean sweeps,
drives the wild waves, and tosses all the deeps.

what, then is the full tale of those whom hector son of priam

say, muse!

killed in the hour of triumph which jove then vouchsafed him?

when jove the trojan’s glory crown’d,
beneath his arm what heroes bit the ground?

first asaeus, autonous, and opites; dolops son of clytius,
opheltius and agelaus; aesymnus, orus and hipponous steadfast in

assaeus, dolops, and autonous died,

battle; these chieftains of the achaeans did hector slay, and

opites next was added to their side;
then brave hipponous, famed in many a fight,
opheltius, orus, sunk to endless night;
æsymnus, agelaus; all chiefs of name;

then he fell upon the rank and file.

the rest were vulgar deaths unknown to fame.

as when the west wind

as when a western whirlwind, charged with storms,

hustles the clouds of the white south and beats them down with

dispels the gather’d clouds that notus forms:

the fierceness of its fury—the waves of the sea roll high, and

the gust continued, violent and strong,

the spray is flung aloft in the rage of the wandering wind—even

rolls sable clouds in heaps on heaps along;
now to the skies the foaming billows rears,

so thick were the heads of them that fell by the hand of hector.

now breaks the surge, and wide the bottom bares:
thus, raging hector, with resistless hands,

all had then been lost and no help for it, and the achaeans would

now the last ruin the whole host appals;

now greece had trembled in her wooden walls;

his soul rekindled, and awaked his worth.

“and stand we deedless, o eternal shame!

help me, we shall be shamed for ever if hector takes the ships.

till hector’s arm involve the ships in flame?
haste, let us join, and combat side by side.

”

”

and diomed answered, “come what may, i will stand firm; but we

the warrior thus, and thus the friend replied:
“no martial toil i shun, no danger fear;
let hector come; i wait his fury here.

shall have scant joy of it, for jove is minded to give victory to

but jove with conquest crowns the trojan train:

the trojans rather than to us.

and, jove our foe, all human force is vain.

his death ennobled by ulysses’ sword.

these they let lie, now

that they had stopped their fighting; the two heroes then went on

and rend the hounds that hunt them.

so two wild boars outstrip the following hounds,

divination.

in deep prophetic arts their father skill’d,

he had forbidden his sons to go to the war, but they

had warn’d his children from the trojan field.

would not obey him, for fate lured them to their fall.

fate urged them on: the father warn’d in vain;
they rush’d to fight, and perish’d on the plain;

diomed son

their breasts no more the vital spirit warms;

of tydeus slew them both and stripped them of their armour, while

the stern tydides strips their shining arms.

ulysses killed hippodamus and hypeirochus.

hypirochus by great ulysses dies,
and rich hippodamus becomes his prize.

and now the son of saturn as he looked down from ida ordained

and level hangs the doubtful scale of fight.

his chariot was not at

his

his steeds too distant, and the foe too nigh:

squire was in charge of it at some distance and he was fighting

through broken orders, swifter than the wind,

on foot among the foremost until he lost his life.

he fled, but flying left his life behind.

hector soon

this hector sees, as his experienced eyes

shouts, as he pass’d, the crystal regions rend,
and moving armies on his march attend.

and fixing itself in the ground.

but pierced his foot, and nail’d it to the plain.

thereon paris with a hearty

the laughing trojan, with a joyful spring.

laugh sprang forward from his hiding-place, and taunted him

leaps from his ambush, and insults the king.

saying, “you are wounded—my arrow has not been shot in vain;

“he bleeds!
(he cries) some god has sped my dart!

would that it had hit you in the belly and killed you, for thus

would the same god had fix’d it in his heart!
so troy, relieved from that wide-wasting hand,
should breathe from slaughter and in combat stand:
whose sons now tremble at his darted spear,

the trojans, who fear you as goats fear a lion, would have had a

as scatter’d lambs the rushing lion fear.

truce from evil.
”

”

diomed all undaunted answered, “archer, you who without your bow

he dauntless thus: “thou conqueror of the fair,

are nothing, slanderer and seducer, if you were to be tried in

thou woman-warrior with the curling hair;

single combat fighting in full armour, your bow and your arrows
would serve you in little stead.

vain archer!

vain is your boast in that you

trusting to the distant dart,

have scratched the sole of my foot.

unskill’d in arms to act a manly part!

i care no more than if a girl
or some silly boy had hit me.

thou hast but done what boys or women can;

a worthless coward can inflict but

such hands may wound, but not incense a man.

a light wound; when i wound a man though i but graze his skin it

nor boast the scratch thy feeble arrow gave,

is another matter, for my weapon will lay him low.

a coward’s weapon never hurts the brave.

his wife will

not so this dart, which thou may’st one day feel;

tear her cheeks for grief and his children will be fatherless:

fate wings its flight, and death is on the steel:
where this but lights, some noble life expires;
its touch makes orphans, bathes the cheeks of sires,

there will he rot, reddening the earth with his blood, and

steeps earth in purple, gluts the birds of air,

vultures, not women, will gather round him.

and leaves such objects as distract the fair.

”

”

thus he spoke, but ulysses came up and stood over him.

ulysses hastens with a trembling heart,

under this
cover he sat down to draw the arrow from his foot, and sharp was
the pain he suffered as he did so.
then he sprang on to his

before him steps, and bending draws the dart:

chariot and bade the charioteer drive him to the ships, for he

forth flows the blood; an eager pang succeeds;

was sick at heart.

tydides mounts, and to the navy speeds.

ulysses was now alone; not one of the argives stood by him, for

now on the field ulysses stands alone,

they were all panic-stricken.

the greeks all fled, the trojans pouring on;

“alas,” said he to himself in his

but stands collected in himself, and whole,
and questions thus his own unconquer’d soul:

dismay, “what will become of me?

“what further subterfuge, what hopes remain?
what shame, inglorious if i quit the plain?

it is ill if i turn and fly
before these odds, but it will be worse if i am left alone and

what danger, singly if i stand the ground,

taken prisoner, for the son of saturn has struck the rest of the

my friends all scatter’d, all the foes around?

danaans with panic.
but why talk to myself in this way?

yet wherefore doubtful?

well do i

let this truth suffice,

know that though cowards quit the field, a hero, whether he wound

the brave meets danger, and the coward flies.
to die or conquer, proves a hero’s heart;

or be wounded, must stand firm and hold his own.

and, knowing this, i know a soldier’s part.

”

”

while he was thus in two minds, the ranks of the trojans advanced

such thoughts revolving in his careful breast,
near, and more near, the shady cohorts press’d;

and hemmed him in, and bitterly did they come to rue it.

these, in the warrior, their own fate enclose;
and round him deep the steely circle grows.

as

so fares a boar whom all the troop surrounds

hounds and lusty youths set upon a wild boar that sallies from

of shouting huntsmen and of clamorous hounds;

his lair whetting his white tusks—they attack him from every side

he grinds his ivory tusks; he foams with ire;

and can hear the gnashing of his jaws, but for all his fierceness

his sanguine eye-balls glare with living fire;

they still hold their ground—even so furiously did the trojans

by these, by those, on every part is plied;

attack ulysses.

and the red slaughter spreads on every side.

ah, wretch!

whereas

body towards him; he therefore gave ground, and called his

now troops on troops the fainting chief invade,

comrades to come and help him.

forced he recedes, and loudly calls for aid.

thrice did he cry as loudly as man

thrice to its pitch his lofty voice he rears;

can cry, and thrice did brave menelaus hear him; he turned,

the well-known voice thrice menelaus hears:
alarm’d, to ajax telamon he cried,

therefore, to ajax who was close beside him and said, “ajax,

who shares his labours, and defends his side:

noble son of telamon, captain of your people, the cry of ulysses

“o friend!

rings in my ears, as though the trojans had cut him off and were

ulysses’ shouts invade my ear;

worsting him while he is single-handed.

distressed he seems, and no assistance near;

let us make our way

strong as he is, yet one opposed to all,

through the throng; it will be well that we defend him; i fear he

oppress’d by multitudes, the best may fall.

may come to harm for all his valour if he be left without

greece robb’d of him must bid her host despair,

support, and the danaans would miss him sorely.

and feel a loss not ages can repair.

”

”

he led the way and mighty ajax went with him.

then, where the cry directs, his course he bends;
great ajax, like the god of war, attends,

the trojans had

the prudent chief in sore distress they found,
with bands of furious trojans compass’d round.
[223]

gathered round ulysses like ravenous mountain jackals round the

as when some huntsman, with a flying spear,

carcase of some horned stag that has been hit with an arrow—the

from the blind thicket wounds a stately deer;

stag has fled at full speed so long as his blood was warm and his

down his cleft side, while fresh the blood distils,
he bounds aloft, and scuds from hills to hills,

strength has lasted, but when the arrow has overcome him, the

till life’s warm vapour issuing through the wound,

savage jackals devour him in the shady glades of the forest.

wild mountain-wolves the fainting beast surround:

then

just as their jaws his prostrate limbs invade,

heaven sends a fierce lion thither, whereon the jackals fly in

the lion rushes through the woodland shade,

terror and the lion robs them of their prey—even so did trojans
many and brave gather round crafty ulysses, but the hero stood at

the wolves, though hungry, scour dispersed away;

bay and kept them off with his spear.

the lordly savage vindicates his prey.

ajax then came up with his

ulysses thus, unconquer’d by his pains,

shield before him like a wall, and stood hard by, whereon the

a single warrior half a host sustains:
but soon as ajax leaves his tower-like shield,

the scattered crowds fly frighted o’er the field;

and first doryclus, priam’s son, he slew,
on strong pandocus next inflicts a wound,

lysandrus, pyrasus, and pylartes; as some swollen torrent comes

and lays lysander bleeding on the ground.
as when a torrent, swell’d with wintry rains,

rushing in full flood from the mountains on to the plain, big

pours from the mountains o’er the deluged plains,

with the rain of heaven—many a dry oak and many a pine does it

and pines and oaks, from their foundations torn,

engulf, and much mud does it bring down and cast into the

a country’s ruins!

sea—even so did brave ajax chase the foe furiously over the

to the seas are borne:
fierce ajax thus o’erwhelms the yielding throng;

plain, slaying both men and horses.

men, steeds, and chariots, roll in heaps along.

hector did not yet know what ajax was doing, for he was fighting

but hector, from this scene of slaughter far,

on the extreme left of the battle by the banks of the river

raged on the left, and ruled the tide of war:

scamander, where the carnage was thickest and the war-cry loudest

loud groans proclaim his progress through the plain,

round nestor and brave idomeneus.

and deep scamander swells with heaps of slain.
there nestor and idomeneus oppose

among these hector was making

the warrior’s fury; there the battle glows;

great slaughter with his spear and furious driving, and was

there fierce on foot, or from the chariot’s height,

destroying the ranks that were opposed to him; still the achaeans

his sword deforms the beauteous ranks of fight.

would have given no ground, had not alexandrus husband of lovely

the spouse of helen, dealing darts around,

helen stayed the prowess of machaon, shepherd of his people, by

had pierced machaon with a distant wound:

wounding him in the right shoulder with a triple-barbed arrow.

in his right shoulder the broad shaft appear’d,

the achaeans were in great fear that as the fight had turned

and trembling greece for her physician fear’d.

against them the trojans might take him prisoner, and idomeneus

to nestor then idomeneus begun:

said to nestor, “nestor son of neleus, honour to the achaean

“glory of greece, old neleus’ valiant son!

name, mount your chariot at once; take machaon with you and drive

ascend thy chariot, haste with speed away,

your horses to the ships as fast as you can.

and great machaon to the ships convey;

a physician is worth

a wise physician skill’d our wounds to heal,

more than several other men put together, for he can cut out
arrows and spread healing herbs.

is more than armies to the public weal.

”

”

nestor knight of gerene did as idomeneus had counselled; he at

old nestor mounts the seat; beside him rode

once mounted his chariot, and machaon son of the famed physician

the wounded offspring of the healing god.

aesculapius, went with him.

he lends the lash; the steeds with sounding feet

he lashed his horses and they flew

shake the dry field, and thunder toward the fleet.

onward nothing loth towards the ships, as though of their own

but now cebriones, from hector’s car,

free will.

survey’d the various fortune of the war:

then cebriones seeing the trojans in confusion said to hector

“while here (he cried) the flying greeks are slain,
trojans on trojans yonder load the plain.
before great ajax see the mingled throng
of men and chariots driven in heaps along!

from his place beside him, “hector, here are we two fighting on

i know him well, distinguish’d o’er the field

the extreme wing of the battle, while the other trojans are in

by the broad glittering of the sevenfold shield.

pell-mell rout, they and their horses.
ajax son of telamon is

thither, o hector, thither urge thy steeds,

driving them before him; i know him by the breadth of his shield:

there danger calls, and there the combat bleeds;

let us turn our chariot and horses thither, where horse and foot

there horse and foot in mingled deaths unite,

are fighting most desperately, and where the cry of battle is

and groans of slaughter mix with shouts of fight.

loudest.
”

”

with this he lashed his goodly steeds, and when they felt the

thus having spoke, the driver’s lash resounds;

whip they drew the chariot full speed among the achaeans and

swift through the ranks the rapid chariot bounds;

trojans, over the bodies and shields of those that had fallen:

stung by the stroke, the coursers scour the fields,
o’er heaps of carcases, and hills of shields.
the horses’ hoofs are bathed in heroes’ gore,

the axle was bespattered with blood, and the rail round the car

and, dashing, purple all the car before;

was covered with splashes both from the horses’ hoofs and from

the groaning axle sable drops distils,

the tyres of the wheels.

and mangled carnage clogs the rapid wheels.

hector tore his way through and flung
himself into the thick of the fight, and his presence threw the

here hector, plunging through the thickest fight,

danaans into confusion, for his spear was not long idle;

broke the dark phalanx, and let in the light:

nevertheless though he went among the ranks with sword and spear,

(by the long lance, the sword, or ponderous stone,
the ranks he scatter’d and the troops o’erthrown:)

and throwing great stones, he avoided ajax son of telamon, for

ajax he shuns, through all the dire debate,

jove would have been angry with him if he had fought a better man

and fears that arm whose force he felt so late.

than himself.

but partial jove, espousing hector’s part,

then father jove from his high throne struck fear into the heart

shot heaven-bred horror through the grecian’s heart;

of ajax, so that he stood there dazed and threw his shield behind

confused, unnerved in hector’s presence grown,

him—looking fearfully at the throng of his foes as though he were

amazed he stood, with terrors not his own.

some wild beast, and turning hither and thither but crouching

o’er his broad back his moony shield he threw,

slowly backwards.

and, glaring round, by tardy steps withdrew.

as peasants with their hounds chase a lion from

thus the grim lion his retreat maintains,
beset with watchful dogs, and shouting swains;

their stockyard, and watch by night to prevent his carrying off

repulsed by numbers from the nightly stalls,

the pick of their herd—he makes his greedy spring, but in vain,

though rage impels him, and though hunger calls,

for the darts from many a strong hand fall thick around him, with

long stands the showering darts, and missile fires;

burning brands that scare him for all his fury, and when morning

then sourly slow the indignant beast retires:

comes he slinks foiled and angry away—even so did ajax, sorely

so turn’d stern ajax, by whole hosts repell’d,

against his will, retreat angrily before the trojans, fearing for

while his swoln heart at every step rebell’d.
as the slow beast, with heavy strength endued,

the ships of the achaeans.

in some wide field by troops of boys pursued,

or as some lazy ass that has had many

though round his sides a wooden tempest rain,

a cudgel broken about his back, when he into a field begins

crops the tall harvest, and lays waste the plain;
thick on his hide the hollow blows resound,
the patient animal maintains his ground,
scarce from the field with all their efforts chased,

eating the corn—boys beat him but he is too many for them, and
though they lay about with their sticks they cannot hurt him;
still when he has had his fill they at last drive him from the

and stirs but slowly when he stirs at last:

field—even so did the trojans and their allies pursue great ajax,

on ajax thus a weight of trojans hung,

ever smiting the middle of his shield with their darts.

the strokes redoubled on his buckler rung;

now and

confiding now in bulky strength he stands,

again he would turn and show fight, keeping back the battalions

now turns, and backward bears the yielding bands;

of the trojans, and then he would again retreat; but he prevented

now stiff recedes, yet hardly seems to fly,

any of them from making his way to the ships.

and threats his followers with retorted eye.

single-handed he

fix’d as the bar between two warring powers,

stood midway between the trojans and achaeans: the spears that

while hissing darts descend in iron showers:

sped from their hands stuck some of them in his mighty shield,

in his broad buckler many a weapon stood,
its surface bristled with a quivering wood;

while many, though thirsting for his blood, fell to the ground

and many a javelin, guiltless on the plain,

ere they could reach him to the wounding of his fair flesh.

marks the dry dust, and thirsts for blood in vain.

now when eurypylus the brave son of euaemon saw that ajax was

but bold eurypylus his aid imparts,

and dauntless springs beneath a cloud of darts;
whose eager javelin launch’d against the foe,

hurled his spear.

great apisaon felt the fatal blow;

he struck apisaon son of phausius in the liver

from his torn liver the red current flow’d,

below the midriff, and laid him low.

and his slack knees desert their dying load.

eurypylus sprang upon him,

the victor rushing to despoil the dead,

from paris’ bow a vengeful arrow fled;

in evil hour!

that had feet of cyanus; on it there was a vessel of bronze and

full, but nestor could do so quite easily.

this is not half the story of our woe.

and stern eurypylus, already bleed.

with an arrow.

but, ah!

nevertheless, achilles, so valiant though he be,

what flattering hopes i entertain!

cares not and knows no ruth.

achilles heeds not, but derides our pain:

will he wait till the ships, do what

even till the flames consume our fleet he stays,

we may, are in a blaze, and we perish one upon the other?

and waits the rising of the fatal blaze.

as for

chief after chief the raging foe destroys;

me, i have no strength nor stay in me any longer; would that i

calm he looks on, and every death enjoys.

were still young and strong as in the days when there was a fight

now the slow course of all-impairing time

fear.

then from my fury fled the trembling swains,

we drove off a vast quantity of booty from the plain, fifty

and ours was all the plunder of the plains:

herds of cattle and as many flocks of sheep; fifty droves also of

fifty white flocks, full fifty herds of swine,

pigs, and as many wide-spreading flocks of goats.
of horses,

as many goats, as many lowing kine:

moreover, we seized a hundred and fifty, all of them mares, and
many had foals running with them.

and thrice the number of unrivall’d steeds,

all these did we drive by night
to pylus, the city of neleus, taking them within the city; and

all teeming females, and of generous breeds.

the heart of neleus was glad in that i had taken so much, though
it was the first time i had ever been in the field.

these, as my first essay of arms, i won;

at daybreak

old neleus gloried in his conquering son.

the heralds went round crying that all in elis to whom there was
a debt owing should come; and the leading pylians assembled to

thus elis forced, her long arrears restored,

divide the spoils.
there were many to whom the epeans owed

with wrong; in former years hercules had come, and had laid his

the state of pyle was sunk to last despair,

when the proud elians first commenced the war:

neleus

for neleus’ sons alcides’ rage had slain;

had had twelve sons, but i alone was left; the others had all

of twelve bold brothers, i alone remain!

been killed.
the epeans presuming upon all this had looked down
upon us and had done us much evil.

my father chose a herd of

(young as they were) the vengeful squadrons led.

now there is a certain town,

high on the rock fair thryoessa stands,

our utmost frontier on the pylian lands:

city of pylus.

not far the streams of famed alphaeus flow:

about it, but when they had crossed their whole plain, minerva

pallas, descending in the shades of night,

array; and she found willing soldiers in pylos, for the men meant

alarms the pylians and commands the fight.

fighting.

each burns for fame, and swells with martial pride,

neleus would not let me arm, and hid my horses, for he

myself the foremost; but my sire denied;

said that as yet i could know nothing about war; nevertheless

fear’d for my youth, exposed to stern alarms;

minerva so ordered the fight that, all on foot as i was, i fought

and stopp’d my chariot, and detain’d my arms.
my sire denied in vain: on foot i fled

among our mounted forces and vied with the foremost of them.

amidst our chariots; for the goddess led.

there is a river minyeius that falls into the sea near arene, and

“along fair arene’s delightful plain
soft minyas rolls his waters to the main:

there they that were mounted (and i with them) waited till
morning, when the companies of foot soldiers came up with us in

there, horse and foot, the pylian troops unite,

force.

and sheathed in arms, expect the dawning light.

thence in full panoply and equipment we came towards noon

thence, ere the sun advanced his noon-day flame,

to the sacred waters of the alpheus, and there we offered victims

to great alphaeus’ sacred source we came.
there first to jove our solemn rites were paid;

to almighty jove, with a bull to alpheus, another to neptune, and

an untamed heifer pleased the blue-eyed maid;
a bull, alphaeus; and a bull was slain

a herd-heifer to minerva.

to the blue monarch of the watery main.

after this we took supper in our

river.

the nations meet; there pylos, elis here.

fight had begun, i was the first to kill my man and take his

the first who fell, beneath my javelin bled;

he was son-in-law to augeas,
having married his eldest daughter, golden-haired agamede, who

king augias’ son, and spouse of agamede:

knew the virtues of every herb which grows upon the face of the

(she that all simples’ healing virtues knew,

earth.

and every herb that drinks the morning dew:)

i speared him as he was coming towards me, and when he
fell headlong in the dust, i sprang upon his chariot and took my
place in the front ranks.

i seized his car, the van of battle led;

the epeans fled in all directions when

the epeians saw, they trembled, and they fled.

they saw the captain of their horsemen (the best man they had)

the foe dispersed, their bravest warrior kill’d,

laid low, and i swept down on them like a whirlwind, taking fifty

fierce as the whirlwind now i swept the field:
full fifty captive chariots graced my train;

chariots—and in each of them two men bit the dust, slain by my
spear.

two chiefs from each fell breathless to the plain.

i should have even killed the two moliones, sons of actor,
unless their real father, neptune lord of the earthquake, had

then actor’s sons had died, but neptune shrouds

hidden them in a thick mist and borne them out of the fight.

the youthful heroes in a veil of clouds.

thereon jove vouchsafed the pylians a great victory, for we

o’er heapy shields, and o’er the prostrate throng,

chased them far over the plain, killing the men and bringing in

collecting spoils, and slaughtering all along,

their armour, till we had brought our horses to buprasium, rich

through wide buprasian fields we forced the foes,

in wheat, and to the olenian rock, with the hill that is called

where o’er the vales the olenian rocks arose;

alision, at which point minerva turned the people back.

till pallas stopp’d us where alisium flows.

there i

even there the hindmost of the rear i slay,

and the same arm that led concludes the day;

then back to pyle triumphant take my way.
there to high jove were public thanks assign’d,

the gods, and among mortal men to nestor.

as first of gods; to nestor, of mankind.

“such was i among my peers, as surely as ever was, but achilles

such then i was, impell’d by youthful blood;
so proved my valour for my country’s good.
“achilles with unactive fury glows,

is for keeping all his valour for himself; bitterly will he rue

and gives to passion what to greece he owes.
how shall he grieve, when to the eternal shade

it hereafter when the host is being cut to pieces.

her hosts shall sink, nor his the power to aid!

my good

o friend!

when, gathering aids along the grecian sea,

and achilles with you.
the old knight peleus was in the outer

and entered peleus’ hospitable court.

of thunder; and he held a gold chalice in his hand from which he

and pour’d libations on the flaming thighs.

you

thyself, achilles, and thy reverend sire

two were busy cutting up the heifer, and at that moment we stood

at the gates, whereon achilles sprang to his feet, led us by the

when we had satisfied

achilles sees us, to the feast invites;

ourselves with meat and drink, i said my say and urged both of

social we sit, and share the genial rites.

you to join us.

we then explained the cause on which we came,

you were ready enough to do so, and the two old
men charged you much and straitly.

urged you to arms, and found you fierce for fame.

old peleus bade his son

your ancient fathers generous precepts gave;
peleus said only this:—‘my son!

achilles fight ever among the foremost and outvie his peers,

be brave.

while menoetius the son of actor spoke thus to you: ‘my son,’

’

said he, ‘achilles is of nobler birth than you are, but you are

menoetius thus: ‘though great achilles shine
in strength superior, and of race divine,

older than he, though he is far the better man of the two.

yet cooler thoughts thy elder years attend;

counsel him wisely, guide him in the right way, and he will

let thy just counsels aid, and rule thy friend.

follow you to his own profit.

’

’ thus did your father charge you,

thus spoke your father at thessalia’s court:

but you have forgotten; nevertheless, even now, say all this to

words now forgot, though now of vast import.

achilles if he will listen to you.

ah!

who knows but with heaven’s
help you may talk him over, for it is good to take a friend’s

try the utmost that a friend can say:

advice.

such gentle force the fiercest minds obey;

if, however, he is fearful about some oracle, or if his

some favouring god achilles’ heart may move;
though deaf to glory, he may yield to love.

mother has told him something from jove, then let him send you,

if some dire oracle his breast alarm,

and let the rest of the myrmidons follow with you, if perchance

if aught from heaven withhold his saving arm,

you may bring light and saving to the danaans.

some beam of comfort yet on greece may shine,

and let him send

if thou but lead the myrmidonian line;

you into battle clad in his own armour, that the trojans may

clad in achilles’ arms, if thou appear,

mistake you for him and leave off fighting; the sons of the
achaeans may thus have time to get their breath, for they are
hard pressed and there is little breathing time in battle.

proud troy may tremble, and desist from war;

you,

press’d by fresh forces, her o’er-labour’d train

who are fresh, might easily drive a tired enemy back to his walls
and away from the tents and ships.

shall seek their walls, and greece respire again.

”

check, or will they fall now before his spear?

shall greece yet stand?
resists she yet the raging hector’s hand?
or are her heroes doom’d to die with shame,
and this the period of our wars and fame?

”

”

wounded eurypylus made answer, “noble patroclus, there is no hope

greece is no more!

left for the achaeans but they will perish at their ships.

this day her glories end;
even to the ships victorious troy pursues,

all

her force increasing as her toil renews.

they that were princes among us are lying struck down and wounded

those chiefs, that used her utmost rage to meet,

but, thou, patroclus!

stronger.

act a friendly part,

but save me and take me to your ship; cut out the arrow

lead to my ships, and draw this deadly dart;

from my thigh; wash the black blood from off it with warm water,

with lukewarm water wash the gore away;

and lay upon it those gracious herbs which, so they say, have

with healing balms the raging smart allay,

been shown you by achilles, who was himself shown them by chiron,

such as sage chiron, sire of pharmacy,

most righteous of all the centaurs.

once taught achilles, and achilles thee.

for of the physicians

virtuous herb which killed all pain; so the wound presently dried

the closing flesh that instant ceased to glow,

yet battle and turmoil were still raging round the wall till its

as yet the bulwark stood, and braved the storm;

the argives,

the strokes yet echoed of contending powers;

war thunder’d at the gates, and blood distain’d the towers.
smote by the arm of jove with dire dismay,
close by their hollow ships the grecians lay:
hector’s approach in every wind they hear,

and hector’s fury every moment fear.

fought with the force and fury of a whirlwind.

he, like a whirlwind, toss’d the scattering throng,
mingled the troops, and drove the field along.

as a lion or wild

so ’midst the dogs and hunters’ daring bands,
fierce of his might, a boar or lion stands;

boar turns fiercely on the dogs and men that attack him, while

arm’d foes around a dreadful circle form,

these form a solid wall and shower their javelins as they face

and hissing javelins rain an iron storm:

him—his courage is all undaunted, but his high spirit will be the

his powers untamed, their bold assault defy,

death of him; many a time does he charge at his pursuers to

and where he turns the rout disperse or die:

scatter them, and they fall back as often as he does so—even so

he foams, he glares, he bounds against them all,
and if he falls, his courage makes him fall.

did hector go about among the host exhorting his men, and

with equal rage encompass’d hector glows;
exhorts his armies, and the trenches shows.
the panting steeds impatient fury breathe,

and snort and tremble at the gulf beneath;

and the turf trembles, and the skies resound.

proud of the favours mighty jove has shown,

anger will utterly destroy the achaeans, i would myself gladly

on certain dangers we too rashly run:
if ’tis his will our haughty foes to tame,
oh may this instant end the grecian name!
here, far from argos, let their heroes fall,
and one great day destroy and bury all!

see them perish now and here far from argos; but if they should

but should they turn, and here oppress our train,

tell the tale.

nor shall a trojan live to tell the tale.

now, therefore, let us all do as i say; let our

hear then, ye warriors!
and obey with speed;

squires hold our horses by the trench, but let us follow hector

back from the trenches let your steeds be led;

in a body on foot, clad in full armour, and if the day of their

then all alighting, wedged in firm array,
proceed on foot, and hector lead the way.

doom is at hand the achaeans will not be able to withstand us.

so greece shall stoop before our conquering power,
and this (if jove consent) her fatal hour.

as two tall oaks, before the wall they rise;

mountains, that tower from their wide-spreading roots, and year

their roots in earth, their heads amidst the skies:
whose spreading arms with leafy honours crown’d,
forbid the tempest, and protect the ground;
high on the hills appears their stately form,

after year battle with wind and rain—even so did these two men

and their deep roots for ever brave the storm.

“father jove,” he

with shame repulsed, with grief and fury driven,

the frantic asius thus accuses heaven:

i made

“in powers immortal who shall now believe?

sure the argive heroes could not withstand us, whereas like

can those too flatter, and can jove deceive?
what man could doubt but troy’s victorious power
should humble greece, and this her fatal hour?

slim-waisted wasps, or bees that have their nests in the rocks by

but like when wasps from hollow crannies drive,
to guard the entrance of their common hive,
darkening the rock, while with unwearied wings

the wayside—they leave not the holes wherein they have built

they strike the assailants, and infix their stings;

undefended, but fight for their little ones against all who would

a race determined, that to death contend:
so fierce these greeks their last retreats defend.
gods!

take them—even so these men, though they be but two, will not be

slain.

”

he spoke, but moved not the mind of jove, whose counsel it then

nor moved great jove’s unalterable mind;

was to give glory to hector.

meanwhile the rest of the trojans

like deeds of arms through all the forts were tried,

were fighting about the other gates; i, however, am no god to be

and all the gates sustain’d an equal tide;

able to tell about all these things, for the battle raged

through the long walls the stony showers were heard,

everywhere about the stone wall as it were a fiery furnace.

the blaze of flames, the flash of arms appear’d.

the

the spirit of a god my breast inspire,
to raise each act to life, and sing with fire!

argives, discomfited though they were, were forced to defend

while greece unconquer’d kept alive the war,
secure of death, confiding in despair;

their ships, and all the gods who were defending the achaeans

and all her guardian gods, in deep dismay,

were vexed in spirit; but the lapithae kept on fighting with

even yet the dauntless lapithae maintain

might and main.

the dreadful pass, and round them heap the slain.

him, for the point of the spear went through it, and broke the

fighting.

the warrior sinks, tremendous now no more!

he then slew pylon and ormenus.

next ormenus and pylon yield their breath:
