first upon antiphates whom he killed in combat, and who fell face

antiphates, as through the ranks he broke,

upwards on the earth.

the falchion struck, and fate pursued the stroke:

after him he killed menon, iamenus, and

iamenus, orestes, menon, bled;

orestes, and laid them low one after the other.

and round him rose a monument of dead.

while they were busy stripping the armour from these heroes, the

meantime, the bravest of the trojan crew,

youths who were led on by polydamas and hector (and these were

bold hector and polydamas, pursue;

the greater part and the most valiant of those that were trying

fierce with impatience on the works to fall,

to break through the wall and fire the ships) were still standing

and wrap in rolling flames the fleet and wall.

by the trench, uncertain what they should do; for they had seen a

these on the farther bank now stood and gazed,

sign from heaven when they had essayed to cross it—a soaring

by heaven alarm’d, by prodigies amazed:
a signal omen stopp’d the passing host,
their martial fury in their wonder lost.

eagle that flew skirting the left wing of their host, with a

jove’s bird on sounding pinions beat the skies;

monstrous blood-red snake in its talons still alive and

a bleeding serpent of enormous size,
his talons truss’d; alive, and curling round,

struggling to escape.
the snake was still bent on revenge,
wriggling and twisting itself backwards till it struck the bird
that held it, on the neck and breast; whereon the bird being in

he stung the bird, whose throat received the wound:

pain, let it fall, dropping it into the middle of the host, and

mad with the smart, he drops the fatal prey,
in airy circles wings his painful way,

then flew down the wind with a sharp cry.

floats on the winds, and rends the heaven with cries:

the trojans were struck

amidst the host the fallen serpent lies.

with terror when they saw the snake, portent of aegis-bearing

they, pale with terror, mark its spires unroll’d,

jove, writhing in the midst of them, and polydamas went up to

and jove’s portent with beating hearts behold.
then first polydamas the silence broke,

hector and said, “hector, at our councils of war you are ever

long weigh’d the signal, and to hector spoke:

given to rebuke me, even when i speak wisely, as though it were

“how oft, my brother, thy reproach i bear,
for words well meant, and sentiments sincere?
true to those counsels which i judge the best,
i tell the faithful dictates of my breast.

not well, forsooth, that one of the people should cross your will

to speak his thoughts is every freeman’s right,

either in the field or at the council board; you would have them

in peace, in war, in council, and in fight;

support you always: nevertheless i will say what i think will be

and all i move, deferring to thy sway,
but tends to raise that power which i obey.
then hear my words, nor may my words be vain!

best; let us not now go on to fight the danaans at their ships,

seek not this day the grecian ships to gain;

for i know what will happen if this soaring eagle which skirted

for sure, to warn us, jove his omen sent,
and thus my mind explains its clear event:
the victor eagle, whose sinister flight

the left wing of our host with a monstrous blood-red snake in its

retards our host, and fills our hearts with fright,

talons (the snake being still alive) was really sent as an omen
to the trojans on their essaying to cross the trench.

dismiss’d his conquest in the middle skies,

the eagle
let go her hold; she did not succeed in taking it home to her

allow’d to seize, but not possess the prize;

little ones, and so will it be—with ourselves; even though by a

thus, though we gird with fires the grecian fleet,

mighty effort we break through the gates and wall of the

though these proud bulwalks tumble at our feet,

achaeans, and they give way before us, still we shall not return

toils unforeseen, and fiercer, are decreed;

in good order by the way we came, but shall leave many a man
behind us whom the achaeans will do to death in defence of their
ships.

more woes shall follow, and more heroes bleed.

thus would any seer who was expert in these matters, and

so bodes my soul, and bids me thus advise;

was trusted by the people, read the portent.

for thus a skilful seer would read the skies.

”

”

hector looked fiercely at him and said, “polydamas, i like not of

to him then hector with disdain return’d:
(fierce as he spoke, his eyes with fury burn’d:)

your reading.

“are these the faithful counsels of thy tongue?

you can find a better saying than this if you will.

thy will is partial, not thy reason wrong:

if, however, you have spoken in good earnest, then indeed has

or if the purpose of thy heart thou vent,

heaven robbed you of your reason.

sure heaven resumes the little sense it lent.

you would have me pay no heed

what coward counsels would thy madness move

to the counsels of jove, nor to the promises he made me—and he

against the word, the will reveal’d of jove?

bowed his head in confirmation; you bid me be ruled rather by the

the leading sign, the irrevocable nod,
and happy thunders of the favouring god,
these shall i slight, and guide my wavering mind

flight of wild-fowl.

by wandering birds that flit with every wind?
ye vagrants of the sky!
your wings extend,

what care i whether they fly towards dawn or
dark, and whether they be on my right hand or on my left?

or where the suns arise, or where descend;

let us

to right, to left, unheeded take your way,

put our trust rather in the counsel of great jove, king of
mortals and immortals.

while i the dictates of high heaven obey.

there is one omen, and one only—that a man

without a sign his sword the brave man draws,

should fight for his country.

and asks no omen but his country’s cause.

why are you so fearful?

but why should’st thou suspect the war’s success?
none fears it more, as none promotes it less:

though we
be all of us slain at the ships of the argives you are not likely

though all our chiefs amidst yon ships expire,

to be killed yourself, for you are not steadfast nor courageous.

trust thy own cowardice to escape their fire.
troy and her sons may find a general grave,
but thou canst live, for thou canst be a slave.
yet should the fears that wary mind suggests

if you will not fight, or would talk others over from doing so,

spread their cold poison through our soldiers’ breasts,

you shall fall forthwith before my spear.

my javelin can revenge so base a part,
and free the soul that quivers in thy heart.

”

”

with these words he led the way, and the others followed after

furious he spoke, and, rushing to the wall,

with a cry that rent the air.

calls on his host; his host obey the call;

then jove the lord of thunder sent

with ardour follow where their leader flies:

the blast of a mighty wind from the mountains of ida, that bore

redoubling clamours thunder in the skies.
jove breathes a whirlwind from the hills of ide,

the dust down towards the ships; he thus lulled the achaeans into

and drifts of dust the clouded navy hide;

security, and gave victory to hector and to the trojans, who,

he fills the greeks with terror and dismay,
and gives great hector the predestined day.

trusting to their own might and to the signs he had shown them,

strong in themselves, but stronger in his aid,

essayed to break through the great wall of the achaeans.
they

but the danaans still showed no sign of giving ground; they still

and heaps on heaps the smoky ruins fall.

the bold ajaces fly from tower to tower,

“fellows in arms!
whose deeds are known to fame,

“argives one and all—good bad and indifferent, for there was

and you, whose ardour hopes an equal name!

never fight yet, in which all were of equal prowess—there is now

since not alike endued with force or art;

work enough, as you very well know, for all of you.

behold a day when each may act his part!

see that you

a day to fire the brave, and warm the cold,

none of you turn in flight towards the ships, daunted by the

to gain new glories, or augment the old.

shouting of the foe, but press forward and keep one another in

urge those who stand, and those who faint, excite;
drown hector’s vaunts in loud exhorts of fight;
conquest, not safety, fill the thoughts of all;
seek not your fleet, but sally from the wall;

heart, if it may so be that olympian jove the lord of lightning

will vouchsafe us to repel our foes, and drive them back towards

and troy lie trembling in her walls again.

the city.
”

”

thus did the two go about shouting and cheering the achaeans on.

their ardour kindles all the grecian powers;
and now the stones descend in heavier showers.

as the flakes that fall thick upon a winter’s day, when jove is

as when high jove his sharp artillery forms,
and opes his cloudy magazine of storms;
in winter’s bleak uncomfortable reign,

minded to snow and to display these his arrows to mankind—he

a snowy inundation hides the plain;

lulls the wind to rest, and snows hour after hour till he has

he stills the winds, and bids the skies to sleep;

buried the tops of the high mountains, the headlands that jut

then pours the silent tempest thick and deep;
and first the mountain-tops are cover’d o’er,

into the sea, the grassy plains, and the tilled fields of men;

then the green fields, and then the sandy shore;

the snow lies deep upon the forelands, and havens of the grey

bent with the weight, the nodding woods are seen,
and one bright waste hides all the works of men:

sea, but the waves as they come rolling in stay it that it can
come no further, though all else is wrapped as with a mantle, so

the circling seas, alone absorbing all,

heavy are the heavens with snow—even thus thickly did the stones

drink the dissolving fleeces as they fall:

fall on one side and on the other, some thrown at the trojans,

so from each side increased the stony rain,

and some by the trojans at the achaeans; and the whole wall was
in an uproar.

and the white ruin rises o’er the plain.

still the trojans and brave hector would not yet have broken down

thus godlike hector and his troops contend
to force the ramparts, and the gates to rend:
nor troy could conquer, nor the greeks would yield,

the gates and the great bar, had not jove turned his son sarpedon

till great sarpedon tower’d amid the field;
for mighty jove inspired with martial flame
his matchless son, and urged him on to fame.

against the argives as a lion against a herd of horned cattle.

in arms he shines, conspicuous from afar,

before him he held his shield of hammered bronze, that the smith

and bears aloft his ample shield in air;

had beaten so fair and round, and had lined with ox-hides which

within whose orb the thick bull-hides were roll’d,

he had made fast with rivets of gold all round the shield; this

ponderous with brass, and bound with ductile gold:

he held in front of him, and brandishing his two spears came on

and while two pointed javelins arm his hands,
majestic moves along, and leads his lycian bands.

like some lion of the wilderness, who has been long famished for

so press’d with hunger, from the mountain’s brow
descends a lion on the flocks below;
so stalks the lordly savage o’er the plain,

want of meat and will dare break even into a well-fenced

in sullen majesty, and stern disdain:

homestead to try and get at the sheep.
he may find the shepherds

in vain loud mastiffs bay him from afar,

keeping watch over their flocks with dogs and spears, but he is

and shepherds gall him with an iron war;

in no mind to be driven from the fold till he has had a try for

regardless, furious, he pursues his way;

it; he will either spring on a sheep and carry it off, or be hit

he foams, he roars, he rends the panting prey.

he views the towers, and meditates their fall,
to sure destruction dooms the aspiring wall;

then he said to

then casting on his friend an ardent look,
fired with the thirst of glory, thus he spoke:

glaucus son of hippolochus, “glaucus, why in lycia do we receive

“why boast we, glaucus!
our extended reign,[226]
where xanthus’ streams enrich the lycian plain,
our numerous herds that range the fruitful field,
and hills where vines their purple harvest yield,
our foaming bowls with purer nectar crown’d,

especial honour as regards our place at table?

our feasts enhanced with music’s sprightly sound?

why are the
choicest portions served us and our cups kept brimming, and why

why on those shores are we with joy survey’d,

do men look up to us as though we were gods?

admired as heroes, and as gods obey’d,
unless great acts superior merit prove,
and vindicate the bounteous powers above?
’tis ours, the dignity they give to grace;
the first in valour, as the first in place;
that when with wondering eyes our martial bands

moreover we hold a

behold our deeds transcending our commands,

large estate by the banks of the river xanthus, fair with orchard

such, they may cry, deserve the sovereign state,

lawns and wheat-growing land; it becomes us, therefore, to take

whom those that envy dare not imitate!

our stand at the head of all the lycians and bear the brunt of

could all our care elude the gloomy grave,

the fight, that one may say to another, ‘our princes in lycia eat

which claims no less the fearful and the brave,

the fat of the land and drink best of wine, but they are fine

for lust of fame i should not vainly dare

fellows; they fight well and are ever at the front in battle.

in fighting fields, nor urge thy soul to war.

’ my

but since, alas!

good friend, if, when we were once out of this fight, we could
escape old age and death thenceforward and forever, i should

ignoble age must come,

neither press forward myself nor bid you do so, but death in ten

disease, and death’s inexorable doom,

thousand shapes hangs ever over our heads, and no man can elude

the life, which others pay, let us bestow,

him; therefore let us go forward and either win glory for

and give to fame what we to nature owe;
brave though we fall, and honour’d if we live,

ourselves, or yield it to another.

or let us glory gain, or glory give!

”

“o where, ye lycians, is the strength you boast?

for all my prowess i

single-handed.

attempts alone the guarded pass to gain:

come close on behind me, for the more there are of

unite, and soon that hostile fleet shall fall:

us the better.

the force of powerful union conquers all.

”

”

the lycians, shamed by his rebuke, pressed closer round him who

this just rebuke inflamed the lycian crew;

was their counsellor and their king.

they join, they thicken, and the assault renew:

the argives on their part

as on the confines of adjoining grounds,

as two men, measuring-rods in hand, quarrel about their
boundaries in a field that they own in common, and stickle for

two stubborn swains with blows dispute their bounds;

their rights though they be but in a mere strip, even so did the

they tug, they sweat; but neither gain, nor yield,

battlements now serve as a bone of contention, and they beat one

one foot, one inch, of the contended field;
thus obstinate to death, they fight, they fall;

another’s round shields for their possession.

nor these can keep, nor those can win the wall.

many a man’s body
was wounded with the pitiless bronze, as he turned round and
bared his back to the foe, and many were struck clean through

their manly breasts are pierced with many a wound,

their shields; the wall and battlements were everywhere deluged

loud strokes are heard, and rattling arms resound;
the copious slaughter covers all the shore,

with the blood alike of trojans and of achaeans.

and the high ramparts drip with human gore.

but even so the

as when two scales are charged with doubtful loads,

trojans could not rout the achaeans, who still held on; and as

from side to side the trembling balance nods,

some honest hard-working woman weighs wool in her balance and

(while some laborious matron, just and poor,

sees that the scales be true, for she would gain some pitiful

with nice exactness weighs her woolly store,)

earnings for her little ones, even so was the fight balanced

till poised aloft, the resting beam suspends
each equal weight; nor this, nor that, descends:[227]

evenly between them till the time came when jove gave the greater

with fates prevailing, turn’d the scale of fight.

wall of the achaeans.

”

thus did he hound them on, and in one body they rushed straight

at the wall as he had bidden them, and scaled the battlements

with sharp spears in their hands.

around the works a wood of glittering spears
shoots up, and all the rising host appears.

hector laid hold of a stone

a ponderous stone bold hector heaved to throw,

that lay just outside the gates and was thick at one end but

pointed above, and rough and gross below:

pointed at the other; two of the best men in a town, as men now

not two strong men the enormous weight could raise,
such men as live in these degenerate days:

are, could hardly raise it from the ground and put it on to a

of scheming saturn made it light for him.

the snowy fleece, he toss’d, and shook in air;

as a shepherd picks up
a ram’s fleece with one hand and finds it no burden, so easily

for jove upheld, and lighten’d of its load

did hector lift the great stone and drive it right at the doors

the unwieldy rock, the labour of a god.

that closed the gates so strong and so firmly set.
these doors

thus arm’d, before the folded gates he came,

were double and high, and were kept closed by two cross-bars to

of massy substance, and stupendous frame;
with iron bars and brazen hinges strong,

which there was but one key.

on lofty beams of solid timber hung:

when he had got close up to them,
hector strode towards them that his blow might gain in force and
struck them in the middle, leaning his whole weight against them.

then thundering through the planks with forceful sway,

he broke both hinges, and the stone fell inside by reason of its
great weight.

drives the sharp rock; the solid beams give way,

the portals re-echoed with the sound, the bars held
no longer, and the doors flew open, one one way, and the other

the folds are shatter’d; from the crackling door

the other, through the force of the blow.

leap the resounding bars, the flying hinges roar.

then brave hector

now rushing in, the furious chief appears,

leaped inside with a face as dark as that of flying night.

gloomy as night!

the

and seems a match for more than mortal force.

then he turned round towards the trojans and called on them to

a tide of trojans flows, and fills the place;

climbing over the wall, while others passed through the gates.

the greeks behold, they tremble, and they fly;

the danaans then fled panic-stricken towards their ships, and all

the shore is heap’d with death, and tumult rends the sky.

was uproar and confusion.

book xiii.

book xiii.
argument.

neptune helps the achaeans—the feats of idomeneus—hector at the

the fourth battle continued, in which neptune assists the greeks: the
acts of idomeneus.
neptune, concerned for the loss of the grecians, upon seeing the
fortification forced by hector, (who had entered the gate near the
station of the ajaces,) assumes the shape of calchas, and inspires
those heroes to oppose him: then, in the form of one of the generals,

ships.

encourages the other greeks who had retired to their vessels.
the

now when jove had thus brought hector and the trojans to the

ajaces form their troops in a close phalanx, and put a stop to hector
and the trojans.
several deeds of valour are performed; meriones,
losing his spear in the encounter, repairs to seek another at the tent
of idomeneus: this occasions a conversation between those two warriors,
who return together to the battle.
idomeneus signalizes his courage
above the rest; he kills othryoneus, asius, and alcathous: deiphobus
and æneas march against him, and at length idomeneus retires.
menelaus
wounds helenus, and kills pisander.
the trojans are repulsed on the
left wing; hector still keeps his ground against the ajaces, till,
being galled by the locrian slingers and archers, polydamas advises to
call a council of war: hector approves of his advice, but goes first to
rally the trojans; upbraids paris, rejoins polydamas, meets ajax again,
and renews the attack.
the eight-and-twentieth day still continues.
the scene is between
the grecian wall and the sea-shore.
when now the thunderer on the sea-beat coast
had fix’d great hector and his conquering host,

ships, he left them to their never-ending toil, and turned his

he left them to the fates, in bloody fray
to toil and struggle through the well-fought day.

keen eyes away, looking elsewhither towards the horse-breeders of

then turn’d to thracia from the field of fight
those eyes that shed insufferable light,

thrace, the mysians, fighters at close quarters, the noble

to where the mysians prove their martial force,
and hardy thracians tame the savage horse;
and where the far-famed hippomolgian strays,
renown’d for justice and for length of days;[229]
thrice happy race!
that, innocent of blood,

hippemolgi, who live on milk, and the abians, justest of mankind.

from milk, innoxious, seek their simple food:

he no longer turned so much as a glance towards troy, for he did

of guilty troy, of arms, and dying men:

trojans or danaans.

while his high law suspends the powers of heaven.

glittering golden palace, imperishable, in the depths of the sea.

eternal frame!
not raised by mortal hands:

raiment of gold, grasped his gold whip, and took his stand upon

refulgent arms his mighty limbs infold,
immortal arms of adamant and gold.
he mounts the car, the golden scourge applies,

his chariot.

he sits superior, and the chariot flies:

favouring descends, and wills to stand the storm.

it was not calchas the seer and diviner of omens; i

not calchas this, the venerable seer;

knew him at once by his feet and knees as he turned away, for the

short as he turned, i saw the power appear:
i mark’d his parting, and the steps he trod;

gods are soon recognised.

his own bright evidence reveals a god.

moreover i feel the lust of battle burn
more fiercely within me, while my hands and my feet under me are

even now some energy divine i share,

more eager for the fray.

and seem to walk on wings, and tread in air!

my soul is kindled, and my bosom burns;
new rising spirits all my force alarm,
lift each impatient limb, and brace my arm.
this ready arm, unthinking, shakes the dart;
the blood pours back, and fortifies my heart:

nimble; i long, moreover, to meet furious hector son of priam,

singly, methinks, yon towering chief i meet,

even in single combat.

and stretch the dreadful hector at my feet.

heavens!
what a prodigy these eyes survey,

and terrible portent which i had never thought to see—the trojans

unseen, unthought, till this amazing day!

at our ships—they, who were heretofore like panic-stricken hinds,

fly we at length from troy’s oft-conquer’d bands?
and falls our fleet by such inglorious hands?

the prey of jackals and wolves in a forest, with no strength but

a rout undisciplined, a straggling train,

in flight for they cannot defend themselves.

not born to glories of the dusty plain;

hitherto the trojans

like frighted fawns from hill to hill pursued,

dared not for one moment face the attack of the achaeans, but now

a prey to every savage of the wood:

they have sallied far from their city and are fighting at our

’tis not your cause, achilles’ injured fame:
another’s is the crime, but yours the shame.
grant that our chief offend through rage or lust,

this is no reason why we should leave off fighting.

must you be cowards, if your king’s unjust?

and levell’d at the skies with pointing rays,
their brandish’d lances at each motion blaze.
thus breathing death, in terrible array,

they brandished in their strong hands were interlaced, and their

hearts were set on battle.

troy charged the first, and hector first of troy.

the trojans advanced in a dense body, with hector at their head

as from some mountain’s craggy forehead torn,

pressing right on as a rock that comes thundering down the side

a rock’s round fragment flies, with fury borne,

of some mountain from whose brow the winter torrents have torn

(which from the stubborn stone a torrent rends,)

it; the foundations of the dull thing have been loosened by

precipitate the ponderous mass descends:

floods of rain, and as it bounds headlong on its way it sets the

from steep to steep the rolling ruin bounds;

whole forest in an uproar; it swerves neither to right nor left

at every shock the crackling wood resounds;

till it reaches level ground, but then for all its fury it can go

still gathering force, it smokes; and urged amain,
whirls, leaps, and thunders down, impetuous to the plain:

no further—even so easily did hector for a while seem as though

there stops—so hector.

have it in their fangs, and bear it through thick brushwood high

in their fell jaws high-lifting through the wood,

the body of imbrius, and strip it of its armour.

and sprinkling all the shrubs with drops of blood;

then the son of

so these, the chief: great ajax from the dead

oileus severed the head from the neck in revenge for the death of

strips his bright arms; oïleus lops his head:

amphimachus, and sent it whirling over the crowd as though it had

toss’d like a ball, and whirl’d in air away,

been a ball, till it fell in the dust at hector’s feet.

at hector’s feet the gory visage lay.

neptune was exceedingly angry that his grandson amphimachus

the god of ocean, fired with stern disdain,

should have fallen; he therefore went to the tents and ships of

and pierced with sorrow for his grandson slain,

the achaeans to urge the danaans still further, and to devise

inspires the grecian hearts, confirms their hands,

evil for the trojans.

and breathes destruction on the trojan bands.

idomeneus met him, as he was taking leave

swift as a whirlwind rushing to the fleet,
he finds the lance-famed idomen of crete,
his pensive brow the generous care express’d

of a comrade, who had just come to him from the fight, wounded in

with which a wounded soldier touch’d his breast,

the knee.

whom in the chance of war a javelin tore,

his fellow-soldiers bore him off the field, and

and his sad comrades from the battle bore;

idomeneus having given orders to the physicians went on to his

him to the surgeons of the camp he sent:
that office paid, he issued from his tent

tent, for he was still thirsting for battle.

fierce for the fight: to whom the god begun,

neptune spoke in the
likeness and with the voice of thoas son of andraemon who ruled

in thoas’ voice, andræmon’s valiant son,

the aetolians of all pleuron and high calydon, and was honoured

who ruled where calydon’s white rocks arise,

among his people as though he were a god.

and pleuron’s chalky cliffs emblaze the skies:

“idomeneus,” said he,
“lawgiver to the cretans, what has now become of the threats with

“where’s now the imperious vaunt, the daring boast,

which the sons of the achaeans used to threaten the trojans?

of greece victorious, and proud ilion lost?

”

”

and idomeneus chief among the cretans answered, “thoas, no one,

to whom the king: “on greece no blame be thrown;

so far as i know, is in fault, for we can all fight.

arms are her trade, and war is all her own.

none are

her hardy heroes from the well-fought plains

held back neither by fear nor slackness, but it seems to be the

nor fear withholds, nor shameful sloth detains:

will of almighty jove that the achaeans should perish

’tis heaven, alas!
and jove’s all-powerful doom,

ingloriously here far from argos: you, thoas, have been always

that far, far distant from our native home
wills us to fall inglorious!
oh, my friend!

staunch, and you keep others in heart if you see any fail in

once foremost in the fight, still prone to lend

duty; be not then remiss now, but exhort all to do their utmost.

or arms or counsels, now perform thy best,
and what thou canst not singly, urge the rest.

”

”

to this neptune lord of the earthquake made answer, “idomeneus,

thus he: and thus the god whose force can make
the solid globe’s eternal basis shake:
“ah!

may he never return from troy, but remain here for dogs to batten

never may he see his native land,
but feed the vultures on this hateful strand,
who seeks ignobly in his ships to stay,

upon, who is this day wilfully slack in fighting.

nor dares to combat on this signal day!

get your armour

for this, behold!
in horrid arms i shine,

and go, we must make all haste together if we may be of any use,

and urge thy soul to rival acts with mine.
together let us battle on the plain;

though we are only two.

two, not the worst; nor even this succour vain:

even cowards gain courage from

not vain the weakest, if their force unite;

companionship, and we two can hold our own with the bravest.

but ours, the bravest have confess’d in fight.

”

”

therewith the god went back into the thick of the fight, and

this said, he rushes where the combat burns;

idomeneus when he had reached his tent donned his armour, grasped

swift to his tent the cretan king returns:

his two spears, and sallied forth.

from thence, two javelins glittering in his hand,

as the lightning which the son

and clad in arms that lighten’d all the strand,
fierce on the foe the impetuous hero drove,
like lightning bursting from the arm of jove,
which to pale man the wrath of heaven declares,
or terrifies the offending world with wars;

of saturn brandishes from bright olympus when he would show a

in streamy sparkles, kindling all the skies,

sign to mortals, and its gleam flashes far and wide—even so did

from pole to pole the trail of glory flies:

his armour gleam about him as he ran.

thus his bright armour o’er the dazzled throng

meriones his sturdy squire

gleam’d dreadful, as the monarch flash’d along.

met him while he was still near his tent (for he was going to

him, near his tent, meriones attends;

fetch his spear) and idomeneus said:

whom thus he questions: “ever best of friends!

“meriones, fleet son of molus, best of comrades, why have you

o say, in every art of battle skill’d,

left the field?

what holds thy courage from so brave a field?

are you wounded, and is the point of the weapon

on some important message art thou bound,

hurting you?
or have you been sent to fetch me?

or bleeds my friend by some unhappy wound?

i want no

inglorious here, my soul abhors to stay,

fetching; i had far rather fight than stay in my tent.

and glows with prospects of th’ approaching day.

”

”
“o prince!

“idomeneus,” answered meriones, “i come for a spear, if i can

(meriones replies) whose care
leads forth the embattled sons of crete to war;

find one in my tent; i have broken the one i had, in throwing it

this speaks my grief: this headless lance i wield;

at the shield of deiphobus.

the rest lies rooted in a trojan shield.

”

”

and idomeneus captain of the cretans answered, “you will find one

to whom the cretan: “enter, and receive

spear, or twenty if you so please, standing up against the end

the wonted weapons; those my tent can give;
spears i have store, (and trojan lances all,)

wall of my tent.

that shed a lustre round the illumined wall,

i have taken them from trojans whom i have

though i, disdainful of the distant war,

killed, for i am not one to keep my enemy at arm’s length;

nor trust the dart, nor aim the uncertain spear,
yet hand to hand i fight, and spoil the slain;

therefore i have spears, bossed shields, helmets, and burnished

and thence these trophies, and these arms i gain.
enter, and see on heaps the helmets roll’d,
and high-hung spears, and shields that flame with gold.

corslets.
”

”

then meriones said, “i too in my tent and at my ship have spoils

“nor vain (said merion) are our martial toils;

taken from the trojans, but they are not at hand.

we too can boast of no ignoble spoils:

i have been at

but those my ship contains; whence distant far,

all times valorous, and wherever there has been hard fighting

i fight conspicuous in the van of war,

have held my own among the foremost.

what need i more?

there may be those among the

if any greek there be

achaeans who do not know how i fight, but you know it well enough

who knows not merion, i appeal to thee.

yourself.
”

”

idomeneus answered, “i know you for a brave man: you need not

to this, idomeneus: “the fields of fight

tell me.

have proved thy valour, and unconquer’d might:

if the best men at the ships were being chosen to go on

and were some ambush for the foes design’d,

an ambush—and there is nothing like this for showing what a man

even there thy courage would not lag behind:
in that sharp service, singled from the rest,

is made of; it comes out then who is cowardly and who brave; the

the fear of each, or valour, stands confess’d.
no force, no firmness, the pale coward shows;

coward will change colour at every touch and turn; he is full of

he shifts his place: his colour comes and goes:

fears, and keeps shifting his weight first on one knee and then

a dropping sweat creeps cold on every part;

on the other; his heart beats fast as he thinks of death, and one

against his bosom beats his quivering heart;
terror and death in his wild eye-balls stare;

can hear the chattering of his teeth; whereas the brave man will

with chattering teeth he stands, and stiffening hair,

not change colour nor be frightened on finding himself in ambush,

and looks a bloodless image of despair!
not so the brave—still dauntless, still the same,
unchanged his colour, and unmoved his frame:
composed his thought, determined is his eye,
and fix’d his soul, to conquer or to die:
if aught disturb the tenour of his breast,

but is all the time longing to go into action—if the best men

’tis but the wish to strike before the rest.

were being chosen for such a service, no one could make light of

“in such assays thy blameless worth is known,

your courage nor feats of arms.

and every art of dangerous war thy own.

if you were struck by a dart or

by chance of fight whatever wounds you bore,

smitten in close combat, it would not be from behind, in your

those wounds were glorious all, and all before;

neck nor back, but the weapon would hit you in the chest or belly

such as may teach, ’twas still thy brave delight

as you were pressing forward to a place in the front ranks.

t’oppose thy bosom where thy foremost fight.

but

but why, like infants, cold to honour’s charms,

let us no longer stay here talking like children, lest we be ill

stand we to talk, when glory calls to arms?

spoken of; go, fetch your spear from the tent at once.

go—from my conquer’d spears the choicest take,
and to their owners send them nobly back.

”

”

on this meriones, peer of mars, went to the tent and got himself

swift at the word bold merion snatch’d a spear

a spear of bronze.

and, breathing slaughter, follow’d to the war.

he then followed after idomeneus, big with

so mars armipotent invades the plain,

great deeds of valour.
as when baneful mars sallies forth to

(the wide destroyer of the race of man,)

battle, and his son panic so strong and dauntless goes with him,

terror, his best-beloved son, attends his course,
arm’d with stern boldness, and enormous force;

to strike terror even into the heart of a hero—the pair have gone

the pride of haughty warriors to confound,

from thrace to arm themselves among the ephyri or the brave

and lay the strength of tyrants on the ground:
from thrace they fly, call’d to the dire alarms
of warring phlegyans, and ephyrian arms;

phlegyans, but they will not listen to both the contending hosts,

invoked by both, relentless they dispose,

and will give victory to one side or to the other—even so did

to these glad conquest, murderous rout to those.

meriones and idomeneus, captains of men, go out to battle clad in

so march’d the leaders of the cretan train,

their bronze armour.

and their bright arms shot horror o’er the plain.

meriones was first to speak.

on

or combat in the centre of the fight?

the right wing of the host, in the centre, or on the left wing,

or to the left our wonted succour lend?

where i take it the achaeans will be weakest?

hazard and fame all parts alike attend.

”

”

idomeneus answered, “there are others to defend the centre—the

two ajaxes and teucer, who is the finest archer of all the

our ablest chieftains the main battle guide;
each godlike ajax makes that post his care,

achaeans, and is good also in a hand-to-hand fight.

and gallant teucer deals destruction there,

these will

skill’d or with shafts to gall the distant field,

give hector son of priam enough to do; fight as he may, he will

or bear close battle on the sounding shield.

find it hard to vanquish their indomitable fury, and fire the

these can the rage of haughty hector tame:

ships, unless the son of saturn fling a firebrand upon them with

safe in their arms, the navy fears no flame,
till jove himself descends, his bolts to shed,

his own hand.

and hurl the blazing ruin at our head.

great ajax son of telamon will yield to no man who

great must he be, of more than human birth,

is in mortal mould and eats the grain of ceres, if bronze and

nor feed like mortals on the fruits of earth.

great stones can overthrow him.

him neither rocks can crush, nor steel can wound,

he would not yield even to

whom ajax fells not on the ensanguined ground.

achilles in hand-to-hand fight, and in fleetness of foot there is

in standing fight he mates achilles’ force,
excell’d alone in swiftness in the course.

none to beat him; let us turn therefore towards the left wing,

then to the left our ready arms apply,

that we may know forthwith whether we are to give glory to some
other, or he to us.

and live with glory, or with glory die.

”

”

meriones, peer of fleet mars, then led the way till they came to

he said: and merion to th’ appointed place,

the part of the host which idomeneus had named.

fierce as the god of battles, urged his pace.

now when the trojans saw idomeneus coming on like a flame of

soon as the foe the shining chiefs beheld

fire, him and his squire clad in their richly wrought armour,

rush like a fiery torrent o’er the field,

they shouted and made towards him all in a body, and a furious

their force embodied in a tide they pour;

hand-to-hand fight raged under the ships’ sterns.

the rising combat sounds along the shore.

fierce as the

as warring winds, in sirius’ sultry reign,

shrill winds that whistle upon a day when dust lies deep on the

from different quarters sweep the sandy plain;
on every side the dusty whirlwinds rise,

roads, and the gusts raise it into a thick cloud—even such was

and the dry fields are lifted to the skies:

the fury of the combat, and might and main did they hack at each

thus by despair, hope, rage, together driven,

other with spear and sword throughout the host.

met the black hosts, and, meeting, darken’d heaven.

the field

all dreadful glared the iron face of war,

bristled with the long and deadly spears which they bore.

bristled with upright spears, that flash’d afar;

dazzling was the sheen of their gleaming helmets, their

dire was the gleam of breastplates, helms, and shields,

fresh-burnished breastplates, and glittering shields as they

and polish’d arms emblazed the flaming fields:

joined battle with one another.

tremendous scene!

iron indeed must be his courage

that general horror gave,

who could take pleasure in the sight of such a turmoil, and look
on it without being dismayed.

but touch’d with joy the bosoms of the brave.

thus did the two mighty sons of saturn devise evil for mortal

saturn’s great sons in fierce contention vied,

heroes.

and crowds of heroes in their anger died.

jove was minded to give victory to the trojans and to

the sire of earth and heaven, by thetis won

hector, so as to do honour to fleet achilles, nevertheless he did

to crown with glory peleus’ godlike son,

not mean to utterly overthrow the achaean host before ilius, and

will’d not destruction to the grecian powers,

only wanted to glorify thetis and her valiant son.

but spared awhile the destined trojan towers;

neptune on the
other hand went about among the argives to incite them, having

while neptune, rising from his azure main,

come up from the grey sea in secret, for he was grieved at seeing

warr’d on the king of heaven with stern disdain,

them vanquished by the trojans, and was furiously angry with

and breathed revenge, and fired the grecian train.

jove.

gods of one source, of one ethereal race,

both were of the same race and country, but jove was elder

alike divine, and heaven their native place;
but jove the greater; first-born of the skies,

born and knew more, therefore neptune feared to defend the

and more than men, or gods, supremely wise.
for this, of jove’s superior might afraid,

argives openly, but in the likeness of man, he kept on
encouraging them throughout their host.

neptune in human form conceal’d his aid.

thus, then, did these two

these powers enfold the greek and trojan train

devise a knot of war and battle, that none could unloose or

in war and discord’s adamantine chain,
indissolubly strong: the fatal tie

break, and set both sides tugging at it, to the failing of men’s
knees beneath them.

is stretch’d on both, and close compell’d they die.

and now idomeneus, though his hair was already flecked with grey,
called loud on the danaans and spread panic among the trojans as

dreadful in arms, and grown in combats grey,

he leaped in among them.

the bold idomeneus controls the day.

he slew othryoneus from cabesus, a

first by his hand othryoneus was slain,
swell’d with false hopes, with mad ambition vain;

sojourner, who had but lately come to take part in the war.

call’d by the voice of war to martial fame,

he

from high cabesus’ distant walls he came;

sought cassandra, the fairest of priam’s daughters, in marriage,

cassandra’s love he sought, with boasts of power,

but offered no gifts of wooing, for he promised a great thing, to

and promised conquest was the proffer’d dower.

wit, that he would drive the sons of the achaeans willy nilly

the king consented, by his vaunts abused;

from troy; old king priam had given his consent and promised her

the king consented, but the fates refused.

to him, whereon he fought on the strength of the promises thus

proud of himself, and of the imagined bride,

made to him.

the field he measured with a larger stride.

idomeneus aimed a spear, and hit him as he came

him as he stalk’d, the cretan javelin found;

striding on.

vain was his breastplate to repel the wound:

his cuirass of bronze did not protect him, and the

his dream of glory lost, he plunged to hell;

spear stuck in his belly, so that he fell heavily to the ground.

his arms resounded as the boaster fell.

then idomeneus vaunted over him saying, “othryoneus, there is no

the great idomeneus bestrides the dead;

one in the world whom i shall admire more than i do you, if you

“and thus (he cries) behold thy promise sped!

indeed perform what you have promised priam son of dardanus in

such is the help thy arms to ilion bring,

return for his daughter.

and such the contract of the phrygian king!

we too will make you an offer; we will

receive;

thick of the fight, but asius came up to protect the body, on

this asius view’d, unable to contain,

foot, in front of his horses which his esquire drove so close

before his chariot warring on the plain:
(his crowded coursers, to his squire consign’d,

behind him that he could feel their breath upon his shoulder.

impatient panted on his neck behind:)

he

to vengeance rising with a sudden spring,

was longing to strike down idomeneus, but ere he could do so

he hoped the conquest of the cretan king.

idomeneus smote him with his spear in the throat under the chin,

the wary cretan, as his foe drew near,
full on his throat discharged the forceful spear:
beneath the chin the point was seen to glide,

and the bronze point went clean through it.

and glitter’d, extant at the further side.

he fell as an oak, or

as when the mountain-oak, or poplar tall,

poplar, or pine which shipwrights have felled for ship’s timber

or pine, fit mast for some great admiral,

upon the mountains with whetted axes—even thus did he lie full

groans to the oft-heaved axe, with many a wound,
then spreads a length of ruin o’er the ground:
so sunk proud asius in that dreadful day,

length in front of his chariot and horses, grinding his teeth and

and stretch’d before his much-loved coursers lay.

clutching at the blood-stained dust.

he grinds the dust distain’d with streaming gore,
and, fierce in death, lies foaming on the shore.

his charioteer was struck

deprived of motion, stiff with stupid fear,
stands all aghast his trembling charioteer,

with panic and did not dare turn his horses round and escape:

nor shuns the foe, nor turns the steeds away,
but falls transfix’d, an unresisting prey:

thereupon antilochus hit him in the middle of his body with a
spear; his cuirass of bronze did not protect him, and the spear
stuck in his belly.

pierced by antilochus, he pants beneath

he fell gasping from his chariot and

the stately car, and labours out his breath.

antilochus, great nestor’s son, drove his horses from the trojans

thus asius’ steeds (their mighty master gone)

to the achaeans.

remain the prize of nestor’s youthful son.

deiphobus then came close up to idomeneus to avenge asius, and

stabb’d at the sight, deiphobus drew nigh,
and made, with force, the vengeful weapon fly.

took aim at him with a spear, but idomeneus was on the look-out

the cretan saw; and, stooping, caused to glance

and avoided it, for he was covered by the round shield he always

inside.

he lay collected in defensive shade.

liver under the midriff, and his limbs failed beneath him.

warm’d in his liver, to the ground it bore

deiphobus vaunted over him and cried with a loud voice saying,

the chief, his people’s guardian now no more!

“of a truth asius has not fallen unavenged; he will be glad even

“not unattended (the proud trojan cries)
nor unrevenged, lamented asius lies:

while passing into the house of hades, strong warden of the gate,

for thee, through hell’s black portals stand display’d,

that i have sent some one to escort him.

this mate shall joy thy melancholy shade.

”

”

thus did he vaunt, and the argives were stung by his saying.

heart-piercing anguish, at the haughty boast,

noble antilochus was more angry than any one, but grief did not

touch’d every greek, but nestor’s son the most.

make him forget his friend and comrade.
he ran up to him,

grieved as he was, his pious arms attend,

bestrode him, and covered him with his shield; then two of his

and his broad buckler shields his slaughter’d friend:

staunch comrades, mecisteus son of echius, and alastor, stooped

till sad mecistheus and alastor bore

down, and bore him away groaning heavily to the ships.

his honour’d body to the tented shore.

but
idomeneus ceased not his fury.

nor yet from fight idomeneus withdraws;

he kept on striving continually

resolved to perish in his country’s cause,

either to enshroud some trojan in the darkness of death, or

or find some foe, whom heaven and he shall doom
to wail his fate in death’s eternal gloom.

himself to fall while warding off the evil day from the achaeans.

he sees alcathous in the front aspire:

then fell alcathous son of noble aesyetes; he was son-in-law to

great æsyetes was the hero’s sire;

anchises, having married his eldest daughter hippodameia, who was

his spouse hippodame, divinely fair,
anchises’ eldest hope, and darling care:

the darling of her father and mother, and excelled all her

who charm’d her parents’ and her husband’s heart

generation in beauty, accomplishments, and understanding,

with beauty, sense, and every work of art:
he once of ilion’s youth the loveliest boy,

wherefore the bravest man in all troy had taken her to wife—him

the fairest she of all the fair of troy.

did neptune lay low by the hand of idomeneus, blinding his bright

by neptune now the hapless hero dies,

eyes and binding his strong limbs in fetters so that he could

who covers with a cloud those beauteous eyes,

neither go back nor to one side, but stood stock still like

and fetters every limb: yet bent to meet

pillar or lofty tree when idomeneus struck him with a spear in

his fate he stands; nor shuns the lance of crete.
fix’d as some column, or deep-rooted oak,

the middle of his chest.

while the winds sleep; his breast received the stroke.

the coat of mail that had hitherto

before the ponderous stroke his corslet yields,

protected his body was now broken, and rang harshly as the spear

long used to ward the death in fighting fields.

tore through it.

the riven armour sends a jarring sound;

he fell heavily to the ground, and the spear

his labouring heart heaves with so strong a bound,
the long lance shakes, and vibrates in the wound;

stuck in his heart, which still beat, and made the butt-end of

fast flowing from its source, as prone he lay,

the spear quiver till dread mars put an end to his life.

life’s purple tide impetuous gush’d away.

idomeneus vaunted over him and cried with a loud voice saying,

then idomen, insulting o’er the slain:

“deiphobus, since you are in a mood to vaunt, shall we cry quits

“behold, deiphobus!
nor vaunt in vain:

now that we have killed three men to your one?

see!
on one greek three trojan ghosts attend;
this, my third victim, to the shades i send.

nay, sir, stand in
fight with me yourself, that you may learn what manner of

approaching now thy boasted might approve,

jove-begotten man am i that have come hither.

and try the prowess of the seed of jove.

jove first begot

from jove, enamour’d of a mortal dame,

minos, chief ruler in crete, and minos in his turn begot a son,

great minos, guardian of his country, came:
deucalion, blameless prince, was minos’ heir;

noble deucalion.

his first-born i, the third from jupiter:

deucalion begot me to be a ruler over many men

o’er spacious crete, and her bold sons, i reign,

in crete, and my ships have now brought me hither, to be the bane

and thence my ships transport me through the main:
lord of a host, o’er all my host i shine,

of yourself, your father, and the trojans.

a scourge to thee, thy father, and thy line.

”

”

thus did he speak, and deiphobus was in two minds, whether to go

the trojan heard; uncertain or to meet,

back and fetch some other trojan to help him, or to take up the

alone, with venturous arms the king of crete,
or seek auxiliar force; at length decreed

challenge single-handed.

to call some hero to partake the deed,

in the end, he deemed it best to go and

forthwith æneas rises to his thought:

fetch aeneas, whom he found standing in the rear, for he had long

for him in troy’s remotest lines he sought,
where he, incensed at partial priam, stands,

been aggrieved with priam because in spite of his brave deeds he

and sees superior posts in meaner hands.

did not give him his due share of honour.

to him, ambitious of so great an aid,

deiphobus went up to

the bold deiphobus approach’d, and said:

him and said, “aeneas, prince among the trojans, if you know any

“now, trojan prince, employ thy pious arms,
if e’er thy bosom felt fair honour’s charms.

ties of kinship, help me now to defend the body of your sister’s

alcathous dies, thy brother and thy friend;

husband; come with me to the rescue of alcathous, who being

come, and the warrior’s loved remains defend.

husband to your sister brought you up when you were a child in

beneath his cares thy early youth was train’d,

his house, and now idomeneus has slain him.

one table fed you, and one roof contain’d.
this deed to fierce idomeneus we owe;
haste, and revenge it on th’ insulting foe.

”

”

with these words he moved the heart of aeneas, and he went in

æneas heard, and for a space resign’d
to tender pity all his manly mind;

pursuit of idomeneus, big with great deeds of valour; but

then rising in his rage, he burns to fight:

idomeneus was not to be thus daunted as though he were a mere

the greek awaits him with collected might.

child; he held his ground as a wild boar at bay upon the

as the fell boar, on some rough mountain’s head,
arm’d with wild terrors, and to slaughter bred,

mountains, who abides the coming of a great crowd of men in some

when the loud rustics rise, and shout from far,
attends the tumult, and expects the war;

lonely place—the bristles stand upright on his back, his eyes

o’er his bent back the bristly horrors rise;

flash fire, and he whets his tusks in his eagerness to defend

fires stream in lightning from his sanguine eyes,

himself against hounds and men—even so did famed idomeneus hold
his ground and budge not at the coming of aeneas.

his foaming tusks both dogs and men engage;

he cried aloud

but most his hunters rouse his mighty rage:

to his comrades looking towards ascalaphus, aphareus, deipyrus,

lo, great æneas rushes to the fight:

moreover he is in the

he fresh in youth, and i in arms grown old.

should soon bear away the prize of victory.

the great dispute, of glory, or of life.

and burn’d to drench the ground with mutual blood.

aeneas took aim first,

the trojan weapon whizz’d along in air;

the cretan saw, and shunn’d the brazen spear:

and, furious, grasps the bloody dust in death.

idomeneus drew his spear

the victor from his breast the weapon tears;

out of the body, but could not strip him of the rest of his
armour for the rain of darts that were showered upon him:

his spoils he could not, for the shower of spears.

moreover his strength was now beginning to fail him so that he

though now unfit an active war to wage,

could no longer charge, and could neither spring forward to

heavy with cumbrous arms, stiff with cold age,

recover his own weapon nor swerve aside to avoid one that was

his listless limbs unable for the course,

aimed at him; therefore, though he still defended himself in
hand-to-hand fight, his heavy feet could not bear him swiftly out
of the battle.

in standing fight he yet maintains his force;

deiphobus aimed a spear at him as he was

and he clutched the earth in the palms of his hands as he fell

have bound with ropes of withes and are taking away perforce.

his bulk enormous on the field displays;

his heaving heart beats thick as ebbing life decays.

he fell backwards to the ground, and

and fierce atrides spurn’d him as he bled,

menelaus set his heel upon him, stripped him of his armour, and

tore off his arms, and, loud-exulting, said:

vaunted over him saying, “even thus shall you trojans leave the

“thus, trojans, thus, at length be taught to fear;

ships of the achaeans, proud and insatiate of battle though you

o race perfidious, who delight in war!

be, nor shall you lack any of the disgrace and shame which you

already noble deeds ye have perform’d;

have heaped upon myself.

a princess raped transcends a navy storm’d:

cowardly she-wolves that you are, you

in such bold feats your impious might approve,

feared not the anger of dread jove, avenger of violated

without th’ assistance, or the fear of jove.

hospitality, who will one day destroy your city; you stole my
wedded wife and wickedly carried off much treasure when you were

the violated rites, the ravish’d dame;

her guest, and now you would fling fire upon our ships, and kill
our heroes.

our heroes slaughter’d and our ships on flame,

a day will come when, rage as you may, you shall be

crimes heap’d on crimes, shall bend your glory down,

stayed.

and whelm in ruins yon flagitious town.

o father jove, you, who they say art above all, both gods

o thou, great father!
lord of earth and skies,

and men, in wisdom, and from whom all things that befall us do

above the thought of man, supremely wise!

proceed, how can you thus favour the trojans—men so proud and

if from thy hand the fates of mortals flow,
from whence this favour to an impious foe?
a godless crew, abandon’d and unjust,

overweening, that they are never tired of fighting?

still breathing rapine, violence, and lust?

all things

the best of things, beyond their measure, cloy;

pall after a while—sleep, love, sweet song, and stately

sleep’s balmy blessing, love’s endearing joy;

dance—still these are things of which a man would surely have his

the feast, the dance; whate’er mankind desire,

fill rather than of battle, whereas it is of battle that the

even the sweet charms of sacred numbers tire.

trojans are insatiate.

but troy for ever reaps a dire delight
in thirst of slaughter, and in lust of fight.

”

”

so saying menelaus stripped the blood-stained armour from the

this said, he seized (while yet the carcase heaved)

body of pisander, and handed it over to his men; then he again

the bloody armour, which his train received:

ranged himself among those who were in the front of the fight.

then sudden mix’d among the warring crew,

harpalion son of king pylaemenes then sprang upon him; he had

and the bold son of pylæmenes slew.
harpalion had through asia travell’d far,

come to fight at troy along with his father, but he did not go

following his martial father to the war:
through filial love he left his native shore,

home again.

never, ah, never to behold it more!

he struck the middle of menelaus’s shield with his

his wound.

the brave paphlagonians tended him with all due care;

city of troy; his father went also with him weeping bitterly, but

the pensive father, father now no more!
attends the mournful pomp along the shore;
and unavailing tears profusely shed;

there was no ransom that could bring his dead son to life again.

and, unrevenged, deplored his offspring dead.

paris was deeply grieved by the death of harpalion, who was his

paris from far the moving sight beheld,
with pity soften’d and with fury swell’d:

host when he went among the paphlagonians; he aimed an arrow,

his honour’d host, a youth of matchless grace,
and loved of all the paphlagonian race!
with his full strength he bent his angry bow,

therefore, in order to avenge him.

and wing’d the feather’d vengeance at the foe.

now there was a certain man
named euchenor, son of polyidus the prophet, a brave man and

a chief there was, the brave euchenor named,

wealthy, whose home was in corinth.

for riches much, and more for virtue famed.

this euchenor had set sail

who held his seat in corinth’s stately town;

for troy well knowing that it would be the death of him, for his

polydus’ son, a seer of old renown.

good old father polyidus had often told him that he must either

by arms abroad, or slow disease at home:

suffering of disease.

and chose the certain glorious path to death.

and where low walls confine the beating tides,

the fight both of man and horse raged most fiercely.

whose humble barrier scarce the foe divides;
where late in fight both foot and horse engaged,

the

ajax son of oileus, never for a moment left the side of ajax, son

now side by side, with like unwearied care,
each ajax laboured through the field of war:

of telamon, but as two swart oxen both strain their utmost at the

so when two lordly bulls, with equal toil,

plough which they are drawing in a fallow field, and the sweat

force the bright ploughshare through the fallow soil,

steams upwards from about the roots of their horns—nothing but

join’d to one yoke, the stubborn earth they tear,

the yoke divides them as they break up the ground till they reach

and trace large furrows with the shining share;

the end of the field—even so did the two ajaxes stand shoulder to

o’er their huge limbs the foam descends in snow,

shoulder by one another.

and streams of sweat down their sour foreheads flow.

many and brave comrades followed the son

a train of heroes followed through the field,

of telamon, to relieve him of his shield when he was overcome

who bore by turns great ajax’ sevenfold shield;
whene’er he breathed, remissive of his might,

tired with the incessant slaughters of the fight.

after the son of oileus, for they could not hold their own in a

hand-to-hand fight.

in close engagement an unpractised race,

they had no bronze helmets with plumes of

the locrian squadrons nor the javelin wield,

horse-hair, neither had they shields nor ashen spears, but they

nor bear the helm, nor lift the moony shield;

had come to troy armed with bows, and with slings of twisted wool

but skill’d from far the flying shaft to wing,
or whirl the sounding pebble from the sling,

from which they showered their missiles to break the ranks of the

trojans.

the others, therefore, with their heavy armour bore the

whose stones and arrows intercept the sky,

confusion.

troy’s scattering orders open to the shower.

the trojans would now have been driven in sorry plight from the

and the gall’d ilians to their walls retired;

said to hector, “hector, there is no persuading you to take

but sage polydamas, discreetly brave,
address’d great hector, and this counsel gave:
“though great in all, thou seem’st averse to lend

advice.

impartial audience to a faithful friend;

because heaven has so richly endowed you with the arts of

to gods and men thy matchless worth is known,
and every art of glorious war thy own;

war, you think that you must therefore excel others in counsel;

but in cool thought and counsel to excel,

but you cannot thus claim preeminence in all things.

how widely differs this from warring well!

heaven has

content with what the bounteous gods have given,
seek not alone to engross the gifts of heaven.

made one man an excellent soldier; of another it has made a

to some the powers of bloody war belong,

dancer or a singer and player on the lyre; while yet in another

to some sweet music and the charm of song;

jove has implanted a wise understanding of which men reap fruit

to few, and wondrous few, has jove assign’d
a wise, extensive, all-considering mind;

to the saving of many, and he himself knows more about it than

their guardians these, the nations round confess,
and towns and empires for their safety bless.

any one; therefore i will say what i think will be best.

if heaven have lodged this virtue in my breast,

the

attend, o hector!
what i judge the best,

fight has hemmed you in as with a circle of fire, and even now

see, as thou mov’st, on dangers dangers spread,
and war’s whole fury burns around thy head.

that the trojans are within the wall some of them stand aloof in

behold!
distress’d within yon hostile wall,

full armour, while others are fighting scattered and outnumbered

how many trojans yield, disperse, or fall!
what troops, out-number’d, scarce the war maintain!

near the ships.

and what brave heroes at the ships lie slain!

draw back, therefore, and call your chieftains

here cease thy fury: and, the chiefs and kings

round you, that we may advise together whether to fall now upon

convoked to council, weigh the sum of things.

the ships in the hope that heaven may vouchsafe us victory, or to

whether (the gods succeeding our desires)
to yon tall ships to bear the trojan fires;
or quit the fleet, and pass unhurt away,

beat a retreat while we can yet safely do so.

contented with the conquest of the day.

i greatly fear that

i fear, i fear, lest greece, not yet undone,

the achaeans will pay us their debt of yesterday in full, for

pay the large debt of last revolving sun;

there is one abiding at their ships who is never weary of battle,

achilles, great achilles, yet remains

and who will not hold aloof much longer.

on yonder decks, and yet o’erlooks the plains!

”

”

thus spoke polydamas, and his words pleased hector well.

the counsel pleased; and hector, with a bound,

he

leap’d from his chariot on the trembling ground;

sprang in full armour from his chariot and said, “polydamas,

swift as he leap’d his clanging arms resound.

gather the chieftains here; i will go yonder into the fight, but

“to guard this post (he cried) thy art employ,
and here detain the scatter’d youth of troy;
where yonder heroes faint, i bend my way,

will return at once when i have given them their orders.

and hasten back to end the doubtful day.

”

”

he then sped onward, towering like a snowy mountain, and with a

this said, the towering chief prepares to go,
shakes his white plumes that to the breezes flow,
and seems a moving mountain topp’d with snow.

loud cry flew through the ranks of the trojans and their allies.

through all his host, inspiring force, he flies,
and bids anew the martial thunder rise.
to panthus’ son, at hector’s high command
haste the bold leaders of the trojan band:

when they heard his voice they all hastened to gather round

but round the battlements, and round the plain,

polydamas, the excellent son of panthous, but hector kept on

for many a chief he look’d, but look’d in vain;

among the foremost, looking everywhere to find deiphobus and

deiphobus, nor helenus the seer,

prince helenus, adamas son of asius, and asius son of hyrtacus;

nor asius’ son, nor asius’ self appear:

living, indeed, and scatheless he could no longer find them, for

for these were pierced with many a ghastly wound,

the two last were lying by the sterns of the achaean ships, slain

some cold in death, some groaning on the ground;

by the argives, while the others had been also stricken and

some low in dust, (a mournful object) lay;
high on the wall some breathed their souls away.

wounded by them; but upon the left wing of the dread battle he
found alexandrus, husband of lovely helen, cheering his men and

far on the left, amid the throng he found

urging them on to fight.

(cheering the troops, and dealing deaths around)

he went up to him and upbraided him.

the graceful paris; whom, with fury moved,

“paris,” said he, “evil-hearted paris, fair to see but woman-mad

opprobrious thus, th’ impatient chief reproved:
“ill-fated paris!
slave to womankind,

and false of tongue, where are deiphobus and king helenus?

as smooth of face as fraudulent of mind!

where

where is deiphobus, where asius gone?

are adamas son of asius, and asius son of hyrtacus?

the godlike father, and th’ intrepid son?
the force of helenus, dispensing fate;
and great othryoneus, so fear’d of late?

where too is

black fate hang’s o’er thee from th’ avenging gods,

othryoneus?

imperial troy from her foundations nods;

ilius is undone and will now surely fall!

whelm’d in thy country’s ruin shalt thou fall,
and one devouring vengeance swallow all.

”

”

alexandrus answered, “hector, why find fault when there is no one

when paris thus: “my brother and my friend,

to find fault with?

thy warm impatience makes thy tongue offend,

i should hold aloof from battle on any day

in other battles i deserved thy blame,

rather than this, for my mother bore me with nothing of the

though then not deedless, nor unknown to fame:
but since yon rampart by thy arms lay low,

coward about me.

i scatter’d slaughter from my fatal bow.

from the moment when you set our men fighting
about the ships we have been staying here and doing battle with

the chiefs you seek on yonder shore lie slain;

the danaans.
our comrades about whom you ask me are dead;

of all those heroes, two alone remain;

deiphobus and king helenus alone have left the field, wounded

deiphobus, and helenus the seer,

both of them in the hand, but the son of saturn saved them alive.

each now disabled by a hostile spear.

now, therefore, lead on where you would have us go, and we will

go then, successful, where thy soul inspires:
this heart and hand shall second all thy fires:
what with this arm i can, prepare to know,

follow with right goodwill; you shall not find us fail you in so

till death for death be paid, and blow for blow.

far as our strength holds out, but no man can do more than in him

but ’tis not ours, with forces not our own

lies, no matter how willing he may be.

to combat: strength is of the gods alone.

”

”

with these words he satisfied his brother, and the two went

towards the part of the battle where the fight was thickest,

then fierce they mingle where the thickest rage.

the former day; the next engaged in war).

they flew forth like

as when from gloomy clouds a whirlwind springs,

the blasts of some fierce wind that strike earth in the van of a

that bears jove’s thunder on its dreadful wings,
wide o’er the blasted fields the tempest sweeps;

thunderstorm—they buffet the salt sea into an uproar; many and

then, gather’d, settles on the hoary deeps;
the afflicted deeps tumultuous mix and roar;

mighty are the great waves that come crashing in one after the

the waves behind impel the waves before,

other upon the shore with their arching heads all crested with

wide rolling, foaming high, and tumbling to the shore:

foam—even so did rank behind rank of trojans arrayed in gleaming

thus rank on rank, the thick battalions throng,

armour follow their leaders onward.

chief urged on chief, and man drove man along.

the way was led by hector son

far o’er the plains, in dreadful order bright,

of priam, peer of murderous mars, with his round shield before

the brazen arms reflect a beamy light:
full in the blazing van great hector shined,
like mars commission’d to confound mankind.
before him flaming his enormous shield,

him—his shield of ox-hides covered with plates of bronze—and his

like the broad sun, illumined all the field;

gleaming helmet upon his temples.

his nodding helm emits a streamy ray;
his piercing eyes through all the battle stray,

he kept stepping forward under

and, while beneath his targe he flash’d along,

cover of his shield in every direction, making trial of the ranks

shot terrors round, that wither’d e’en the strong.

to see if they would give way before him, but he could not daunt

thus stalk’d he, dreadful; death was in his look:

the courage of the achaeans.

whole nations fear’d; but not an argive shook.

ajax was the first to stride out and

the towering ajax, with an ample stride,
advanced the first, and thus the chief defied:

challenge him.

“hector!

“sir,” he cried, “draw near; why do you think thus

come on; thy empty threats forbear;

vainly to dismay the argives?

’tis not thy arm, ’tis thundering jove we fear:

we achaeans are excellent soldiers,

the skill of war to us not idly given,
lo!

but the scourge of jove has fallen heavily upon us.

greece is humbled, not by troy, but heaven.

your heart,

vain are the hopes that haughty mind imparts,

forsooth, is set on destroying our ships, but we too have hands

to force our fleet: the greeks have hands and hearts.
long ere in flames our lofty navy fall,

that can keep you at bay, and your own fair town shall be sooner

your boasted city, and your god-built wall,

taken and sacked by ourselves.

shall sink beneath us, smoking on the ground;
and spread a long unmeasured ruin round.

the time is near when you shall

the time shall come, when, chased along the plain,

pray jove and all the gods in your flight, that your steeds may

even thou shalt call on jove, and call in vain;
even thou shalt wish, to aid thy desperate course,

be swifter than hawks as they raise the dust on the plain and

the wings of falcons for thy flying horse;
shalt run, forgetful of a warrior’s fame,

bear you back to your city.

while clouds of friendly dust conceal thy shame.

”

”

as he was thus speaking a bird flew by upon his right hand, and

as thus he spoke, behold, in open view,
on sounding wings a dexter eagle flew.

the host of the achaeans shouted, for they took heart at the

to jove’s glad omen all the grecians rise,
and hail, with shouts, his progress through the skies:
far-echoing clamours bound from side to side;
they ceased; and thus the chief of troy replied:
“from whence this menace, this insulting strain?

omen.

enormous boaster!
doom’d to vaunt in vain.

but hector answered, “ajax, braggart and false of tongue,

so may the gods on hector life bestow,

would that i were as sure of being son for evermore to

(not that short life which mortals lead below,

aegis-bearing jove, with queen juno for my mother, and of being

but such as those of jove’s high lineage born,

held in like honour with minerva and apollo, as i am that this

the blue-eyed maid, or he that gilds the morn,)

day is big with the destruction of the achaeans; and you shall

as this decisive day shall end the fame
of greece, and argos be no more a name.
and thou, imperious!

fall among them if you dare abide my spear; it shall rend your

if thy madness wait
the lance of hector, thou shalt meet thy fate:

fair body and bid you glut our hounds and birds of prey with your

that giant-corse, extended on the shore,

fat and your flesh, as you fall by the ships of the achaeans.

shall largely feast the fowls with fat and gore.

”

”

with these words he led the way and the others followed after

he said; and like a lion stalk’d along:
with shouts incessant earth and ocean rung,
sent from his following host: the grecian train

with a cry that rent the air, while the host shouted behind them.
the argives on their part raised a shout likewise, nor did they
forget their prowess, but stood firm against the onslaught of the

with answering thunders fill’d the echoing plain;

trojan chieftains, and the cry from both the hosts rose up to

a shout that tore heaven’s concave, and, above,

heaven and to the brightness of jove’s presence.

shook the fix’d splendours of the throne of jove.

book xiv.

[illustration: ] greek earrings
book xiv.
argument.
[231]

agamemnon proposes that the achaeans should sail home, and is

juno deceives jupiter by the girdle of venus.
nestor, sitting at the table with machaon, is alarmed with the
increasing clamour of war, and hastens to agamemnon; on his way he
meets that prince with diomed and ulysses, whom he informs of the
extremity of the danger.
agamemnon proposes to make their escape by
night, which ulysses withstands; to which diomed adds his advice, that,
wounded as they were, they should go forth and encourage the army with
their presence, which advice is pursued.
juno, seeing the partiality of
jupiter to the trojans, forms a design to over-reach him: she sets off
her charms with the utmost care, and (the more surely to enchant him)
obtains the magic girdle of venus.
she then applies herself to the god
of sleep, and, with some difficulty, persuades him to seal the eyes of
jupiter: this done, she goes to mount ida, where the god, at first
sight, is ravished with her beauty, sinks in her embraces, and is laid
asleep.
neptune takes advantage of his slumber, and succours the

rebuked by ulysses—juno beguiles jupiter—hector is wounded.

greeks: hector is struck to the ground with a prodigious stone by ajax,

nestor was sitting over his wine, but the cry of battle did not

and carried off from the battle: several actions succeed, till the
trojans, much distressed, are obliged to give way: the lesser ajax
signalizes himself in a particular manner.
but not the genial feast, nor flowing bowl,
could charm the cares of nestor’s watchful soul;
his startled ears the increasing cries attend;

escape him, and he said to the son of aesculapius, “what, noble

then thus, impatient, to his wounded friend:

machaon, is the meaning of all this?

“what new alarm, divine machaon, say,
what mix’d events attend this mighty day?
hark!

the shouts of men fighting

how the shouts divide, and how they meet,

by our ships grow stronger and stronger; stay here, therefore,

and now come full, and thicken to the fleet!

and sit over your wine, while fair hecamede heats you a bath and

here with the cordial draught dispel thy care,
let hecamede the strengthening bath prepare,

washes the clotted blood from off you.

refresh thy wound, and cleanse the clotted gore;

i will go at once to the
look-out station and see what it is all about.

while i the adventures of the day explore.

”

”

he said: and, seizing thrasymedes’ shield,

(his valiant offspring,) hasten’d to the field;

soon as the prospect open’d to his view,

the achaeans who, now that their wall was overthrown, were flying

dire disarray!
the tumult of the fight,

pell-mell before the trojans.

the wall in ruins, and the greeks in flight.

as when there is a heavy swell upon

the sea, but the waves are dumb—they keep their eyes on the watch

the waves just heaving on the purple deeps:

for the quarter whence the fierce winds may spring upon them, but

while yet the expected tempest hangs on high,

they stay where they are and set neither this way nor that, till

weighs down the cloud, and blackens in the sky,

some particular wind sweeps down from heaven to determine

the mass of waters will no wind obey;

them—even so did the old man ponder whether to make for the crowd

jove sends one gust, and bids them roll away.
while wavering counsels thus his mind engage,
fluctuates in doubtful thought the pylian sage,

i fear

is all coming true.

such was his threat, ah!

alas!

now too soon made good,

others of the achaeans, like achilles,

on many a grecian bosom writ in blood.

are in such anger with me that they refuse to fight by the sterns

against your king, nor will one chief engage?
and have i lived to see with mournful eyes

of our ships.

in every greek a new achilles rise?

”

”

then nestor knight of gerene, answered, “it is indeed as you say;

gerenian nestor then: “so fate has will’d;

it is all coming true at this moment, and even jove who thunders

and all-confirming time has fate fulfill’d.
not he that thunders from the aerial bower,

from on high cannot prevent it.

not jove himself, upon the past has power.

fallen is the wall on which we
relied as an impregnable bulwark both for us and our fleet.

the wall, our late inviolable bound,

the

and best defence, lies smoking on the ground:

trojans are fighting stubbornly and without ceasing at the ships;

even to the ships their conquering arms extend,
and groans of slaughter’d greeks to heaven ascend.

look where you may you cannot see from what quarter the rout of

on speedy measures then employ your thought

the achaeans is coming; they are being killed in a confused mass

in such distress!

and the battle-cry ascends to heaven; let us think, if counsel
