can be of any use, what we had better do; but i do not advise our

arms cannot much: though mars our souls incite,

going into battle ourselves, for a man cannot fight when he is

these gaping wounds withhold us from the fight.

wounded.
”

”

and king agamemnon answered, “nestor, if the trojans are indeed

to him the monarch: “that our army bends,

fighting at the rear of our ships, and neither the wall nor the
trench has served us—over which the danaans toiled so hard, and

that troy triumphant our high fleet ascends,

which they deemed would be an impregnable bulwark both for us and

and that the rampart, late our surest trust
and best defence, lies smoking in the dust;

our fleet—i see it must be the will of jove that the achaeans

all this from jove’s afflictive hand we bear,

should perish ingloriously here, far from argos.

who, far from argos, wills our ruin here.

i knew when jove

past are the days when happier greece was blest,

was willing to defend us, and i know now that he is raising the

and all his favour, all his aid confess’d;

trojans to like honour with the gods, while us, on the other

now heaven averse, our hands from battle ties,

hand, he has bound hand and foot.

and lifts the trojan glory to the skies.

now, therefore, let us all do

cease we at length to waste our blood in vain,

as i say; let us bring down the ships that are on the beach and
draw them into the water; let us make them fast to their

and launch what ships lie nearest to the main;

mooring-stones a little way out, against the fall of night—if

leave these at anchor, till the coming night:

even by night the trojans will desist from fighting; we may then

then, if impetuous troy forbear the fight,

draw down the rest of the fleet.
there is nothing wrong in flying

bring all to sea, and hoist each sail for flight.

ruin even by night.
it is better for a man that he should fly and

better from evils, well foreseen, to run,

be saved than be caught and killed.

than perish in the danger we may shun.

”

”
thus he.

ulysses looked fiercely at him and said, “son of atreus, what are

the sage ulysses thus replies,
while anger flash’d from his disdainful eyes:
“what shameful words (unkingly as thou art)

you talking about?

fall from that trembling tongue and timorous heart?

wretch, you should have commanded some other

oh were thy sway the curse of meaner powers,

and baser army, and not been ruler over us to whom jove has

and thou the shame of any host but ours!
a host, by jove endued with martial might,
and taught to conquer, or to fall in fight:

allotted a life of hard fighting from youth to old age, till we

adventurous combats and bold wars to wage,

every one of us perish.

employ’d our youth, and yet employs our age.

is it thus that you would quit the city

and wilt thou thus desert the trojan plain?

of troy, to win which we have suffered so much hardship?

and have whole streams of blood been spilt in vain?

hold

in such base sentence if thou couch thy fear,

your peace, lest some other of the achaeans hear you say what no

lips.

the banded legions of all greece obey?

hands of the conquering trojans?

and owe destruction to a prince like thee.

”

agamemnon answered, “ulysses, your rebuke has stung me to the

“thy just reproofs (atrides calm replies)

heart.

like arrows pierce me, for thy words are wise.

i am not, however, ordering the achaeans to draw their

unwilling as i am to lose the host,

ships into the sea whether they will or no.

i force not greece to quit this hateful coast;

someone, it may be,

glad i submit, whoe’er, or young, or old,

aught, more conducive to our weal, unfold.

”

then said diomed, “such an one is at hand; he is not far to seek,

tydides cut him short, and thus began:
“such counsel if you seek, behold the man

if you will listen to me and not resent my speaking though i am

who boldly gives it, and what he shall say,

younger than any of you.

young though he be, disdain not to obey:

i am by lineage son to a noble sire,

a youth, who from the mighty tydeus springs,
may speak to councils and assembled kings.
hear then in me the great oenides’ son,
whose honoured dust (his race of glory run)

tydeus, who lies buried at thebes.

lies whelm’d in ruins of the theban wall;
brave in his life, and glorious in his fall.

he married into the family of adrastus, and

he pass’d to argos, and in exile dwell’d;
the monarch’s daughter there (so jove ordain’d)
he won, and flourish’d where adrastus reign’d;

his house was one of great abundance, for he had large estates of
rich corn-growing land, with much orchard ground as well, and he

there, rich in fortune’s gifts, his acres till’d,

had many sheep; moreover he excelled all the argives in the use

beheld his vines their liquid harvest yield,
and numerous flocks that whiten’d all the field.

of the spear.

such tydeus was, the foremost once in fame!

you must yourselves have heard whether these things

nor lives in greece a stranger to his name.

are true or no; therefore when i say well despise not my words as
though i were a coward or of ignoble birth.

then, what for common good my thoughts inspire,

i say, then, let us

though sore of battle, though with wounds oppress’d,

a golden zone her swelling bosom bound.

that had a hundred tassels: then she fastened her earrings, three

”

then sleep answered, “juno, great queen of goddesses, daughter of

“imperial dame (the balmy power replies),
great saturn’s heir, and empress of the skies!

mighty saturn, i would lull any other of the gods to sleep

o’er other gods i spread my easy chain;

without compunction, not even excepting the waters of oceanus

the sire of all, old ocean, owns my reign.
and his hush’d waves lie silent on the main.

from whom all of them proceed, but i dare not go near jove, nor

but how, unbidden, shall i dare to steep
jove’s awful temples in the dew of sleep?

send him to sleep unless he bids me.

long since, too venturous, at thy bold command,

i have had one lesson

on those eternal lids i laid my hand;

already through doing what you asked me, on the day when jove’s

what time, deserting ilion’s wasted plain,

mighty son hercules set sail from ilius after having sacked the

his conquering son, alcides, plough’d the main.

city of the trojans.

when lo!

the deeps arise, the tempests roar,

meanwhile you hatched a plot against hercules, and set the blasts
of the angry winds beating upon the sea, till you took him to the
goodly city of cos, away from all his friends.

and drive the hero to the coan shore:

jove was furious

when he awoke, and began hurling the gods about all over the

he spoke; the goddess with the charming eyes

“most dread son of
saturn,” she exclaimed, “what are you talking about?

“is this a scene for love?

would you
have us enjoy one another here on the top of mount ida, where

on ida’s height,

everything can be seen?

exposed to mortal and immortal sight!
our joys profaned by each familiar eye;

what if one of the ever-living gods

the sport of heaven, and fable of the sky:
how shall i e’er review the blest abodes,

should see us sleeping together, and tell the others?

or mix among the senate of the gods?

it would be

shall i not think, that, with disorder’d charms,

such a scandal that when i had risen from your embraces i could
never show myself inside your house again; but if you are so

all heaven beholds me recent from thy arms?

minded, there is a room which your son vulcan has made me, and he

with skill divine has vulcan form’d thy bower,

has given it good strong doors; if you would so have it, let us

sacred to love and to the genial hour;
if such thy will, to that recess retire,

go thither and lie down.

in secret there indulge thy soft desire.

“nor god nor mortal shall our joys behold,

dense golden cloud, that the very sun for all his bright piercing

shaded with clouds, and circumfused in gold;
not even the sun, who darts through heaven his rays,

beams shall not see through it.

and whose broad eye the extended earth surveys.

”

”

with this the son of saturn caught his wife in his embrace;

gazing he spoke, and, kindling at the view,
his eager arms around the goddess threw.

whereon the earth sprouted them a cushion of young grass, with

glad earth perceives, and from her bosom pours

unbidden herbs and voluntary flowers:
thick new-born violets a soft carpet spread,

that it raised them well above the ground.

and clustering lotos swell’d the rising bed,

the panting thunderer nods, and sinks to rest.

bed with her.

have closed those awful and eternal eyes.

”

”

sleep now departed and went his ways to and fro among mankind,

thus having said, the power of slumber flew,
on human lids to drop the balmy dew.
neptune, with zeal increased, renews his care,
and towering in the foremost ranks of war,

leaving neptune more eager than ever to help the danaans.

indignant thus—“oh once of martial fame!

he

o greeks!

darted forward among the first ranks and shouted saying,

if yet ye can deserve the name!

“argives, shall we let hector son of priam have the triumph of

this half-recover’d day shall troy obtain?

taking our ships and covering himself with glory?

shall hector thunder at your ships again?

this is what he

lo!

says that he shall now do, seeing that achilles is still in

still he vaunts, and threats the fleet with fires,
while stern achilles in his wrath retires.

dudgeon at his ship; we shall get on very well without him if we

one hero’s loss too tamely you deplore,

keep each other in heart and stand by one another.

be still yourselves, and ye shall need no more.

now,

oh yet, if glory any bosom warms,

therefore, let us all do as i say.

brace on your firmest helms, and stand to arms:

let us each take the best and

his strongest spear each valiant grecian wield,

largest shield we can lay hold of, put on our helmets, and sally

each valiant grecian seize his broadest shield;

forth with our longest spears in our hands; i will lead you on,

let to the weak the lighter arms belong,
the ponderous targe be wielded by the strong.

and hector son of priam, rage as he may, will not dare to hold
out against us.
if any good staunch soldier has only a small
shield, let him hand it over to a worse man, and take a larger

thus arm’d, not hector shall our presence stay;

one for himself.

myself, ye greeks!
myself will lead the way.

”

”
[illustration: ] greek shield

thus did he speak, and they did even as he had said.

the troops assent; their martial arms they change:

the son of

the busy chiefs their banded legions range.

when they had donned their

in his

the legions march, and neptune leads the way:

flashing like lightning; woe to him who comes across it in the

his brandish’d falchion flames before their eyes,
like lightning flashing through the frighted skies.
clad in his might, the earth-shaking power appears;

day of battle; all men quake for fear and keep away from it.

pale mortals tremble, and confess their fears.

hector on the other side set the trojans in array.

troy’s great defender stands alone unawed,
arms his proud host, and dares oppose a god:

thereon

and lo!

neptune and hector waged fierce war on one another—hector on the

the god, and wondrous man, appear:

trojan and neptune on the argive side.

the sea’s stern ruler there, and hector here.

mighty was the uproar as

the roaring main, at her great master’s call,

the two forces met; the sea came rolling in towards the ships and

rose in huge ranks, and form’d a watery wall
around the ships: seas hanging o’er the shores,
both armies join: earth thunders, ocean roars.

tents of the achaeans, but waves do not thunder on the shore more

not half so loud the bellowing deeps resound,
when stormy winds disclose the dark profound;

loudly when driven before the blast of boreas, nor do the flames

less loud the winds that from the æolian hall

of a forest fire roar more fiercely when it is well alight upon

roar through the woods, and make whole forests fall;
less loud the woods, when flames in torrents pour,

the mountains, nor does the wind bellow with ruder music as it

catch the dry mountain, and its shades devour;

tears on through the tops of when it is blowing its hardest, than
the terrible shout which the trojans and achaeans raised as they

with such a rage the meeting hosts are driven,

sprang upon one another.

and such a clamour shakes the sounding heaven.

book xv.

[illustration: ] bacchus
book xv.
argument.

jove awakes, tells apollo to heal hector, and the trojans again

the fifth battle at the ships; and the acts of ajax.
jupiter, awaking, sees the trojans repulsed from the trenches, hector
in a swoon, and neptune at the head of the greeks: he is highly
incensed at the artifice of juno, who appeases him by her submissions;
she is then sent to iris and apollo.
juno, repairing to the assembly of
the gods, attempts, with extraordinary address, to incense them against
jupiter; in particular she touches mars with a violent resentment; he
is ready to take arms, but is prevented by minerva.
iris and apollo
obey the orders of jupiter; iris commands neptune to leave the battle,

become victorious.

to which, after much reluctance and passion, he consents.
apollo
reinspires hector with vigour, brings him back to the battle, marches
before him with his ægis, and turns the fortune of the fight.
he

but when their flight had taken them past the trench and the set

breaks down great part of the grecian wall: the trojans rush in, and
attempt to fire the first line of the fleet, but are, as yet, repelled
by the greater ajax with a prodigious slaughter.
now in swift flight they pass the trench profound,

stakes, and many had fallen by the hands of the danaans, the

and many a chief lay gasping on the ground:

trojans made a halt on reaching their chariots, routed and pale

then stopp’d and panted, where the chariots lie

with fear.

fear on their cheek, and horror in their eye.

jove now woke on the crests of ida, where he was lying

meanwhile, awaken’d from his dream of love,

with golden-throned juno by his side, and starting to his feet he

on ida’s summit sat imperial jove:

saw the trojans and achaeans, the one thrown into confusion, and

round the wide fields he cast a careful view,
there saw the trojans fly, the greeks pursue;

the others driving them pell-mell before them with king neptune

these proud in arms, those scatter’d o’er the plain

in their midst.

and, ’midst the war, the monarch of the main.

he saw hector lying on the ground with his

not far, great hector on the dust he spies,

comrades gathered round him, gasping for breath, wandering in

(his sad associates round with weeping eyes,)

mind and vomiting blood, for it was not the feeblest of the

ejecting blood, and panting yet for breath,

achaeans who struck him.

his senses wandering to the verge of death.

the sire of gods and men had pity on him, and looked fiercely on

the god beheld him with a pitying look,

juno.
“i see, juno,” said he, “you mischief-making trickster,

and thus, incensed, to fraudful juno spoke:

that your cunning has stayed hector from fighting and has caused

“o thou, still adverse to the eternal will,
for ever studious in promoting ill!
thy arts have made the godlike hector yield,

the rout of his host.

and driven his conquering squadrons from the field.

i am in half a mind to thrash you, in which
case you will be the first to reap the fruits of your scurvy

canst thou, unhappy in thy wiles, withstand

knavery.

our power immense, and brave the almighty hand?

do you not remember how once upon a time i had you

hast thou forgot, when, bound and fix’d on high,

hanged?

from the vast concave of the spangled sky,

i fastened two anvils on to your feet, and bound your
hands in a chain of gold which none might break, and you hung in

i hung thee trembling in a golden chain,

mid-air among the clouds.
all the gods in olympus were in a fury,

and all the raging gods opposed in vain?

but they could not reach you to set you free; when i caught any

headlong i hurl’d them from the olympian hall,

one of them i gripped him and hurled him from the heavenly

stunn’d in the whirl, and breathless with the fall.

threshold till he came fainting down to earth; yet even this did

for godlike hercules these deeds were done,

not relieve my mind from the incessant anxiety which i felt about

nor seem’d the vengeance worthy such a son:

noble hercules whom you and boreas had spitefully conveyed beyond

when, by thy wiles induced, fierce boreas toss’d

the seas to cos, after suborning the tempests; but i rescued him,

the shipwreck’d hero on the coan coast,

and notwithstanding all his mighty labours i brought him back

him through a thousand forms of death i bore,

again to argos.

and sent to argos, and his native shore.

i would remind you of this that you may learn to

hear this, remember, and our fury dread,

leave off being so deceitful, and discover how much you are

nor pull the unwilling vengeance on thy head;
lest arts and blandishments successless prove,

likely to gain by the embraces out of which you have come here to

thy soft deceits, and well-dissembled love.

trick me.
”

”

juno trembled as he spoke, and said, “may heaven above and earth

the thunderer spoke: imperial juno mourn’d,
and, trembling, these submissive words return’d:
“by every oath that powers immortal ties,
the foodful earth and all-infolding skies;

below be my witnesses, with the waters of the river styx—and this

by thy black waves, tremendous styx!
that flow
through the drear realms of gliding ghosts below;

is the most solemn oath that a blessed god can take—nay, i swear

by the dread honours of thy sacred head,

also by your own almighty head and by our bridal bed—things over

and that unbroken vow, our virgin bed!

which i could never possibly perjure myself—that neptune is not

not by my arts the ruler of the main

punishing hector and the trojans and helping the achaeans through

steeps troy in blood, and ranges round the plain:

any doing of mine; it is all of his own mere motion because he

by his own ardour, his own pity sway’d,

was sorry to see the achaeans hard pressed at their ships: if i

to help his greeks, he fought and disobey’d:

were advising him, i should tell him to do as you bid him.

else had thy juno better counsels given,
and taught submission to the sire of heaven.

”

”
“think’st thou with me?

the sire of gods and men smiled and answered, “if you, juno, were

fair empress of the skies!
(the immortal father with a smile replies;)

always to support me when we sit in council of the gods, neptune,

then soon the haughty sea-god shall obey,

like it or no, would soon come round to your and my way of
thinking.

nor dare to act but when we point the way.

if, then, you are speaking the truth and mean what you

if truth inspires thy tongue, proclaim our will

say, go among the rank and file of the gods, and tell iris and

to yon bright synod on the olympian hill;
our high decree let various iris know,
and call the god that bears the silver bow.
let her descend, and from the embattled plain

apollo lord of the bow, that i want them—iris, that she may go to

command the sea-god to his watery reign:

the achaean host and tell neptune to leave off fighting and go

while phœbus hastes great hector to prepare

home, and apollo, that he may send hector again into battle and

to rise afresh, and once more wake the war:

give him fresh strength; he will thus forget his present

his labouring bosom re-inspires with breath,

sufferings, and drive the achaeans back in confusion till they

and calls his senses from the verge of death.

fall among the ships of achilles son of peleus.

achilles will

he, not untouch’d with pity, to the plain

him in front of ilius after he has slain many warriors, and among

them my own noble son sarpedon.

even my loved son, divine sarpedon, falls!

achilles will kill hector to

vanquish’d at last by hector’s lance he lies.

avenge patroclus, and from that time i will bring it about that

then, nor till then, shall great achilles rise:
and lo!
that instant, godlike hector dies.

the achaeans shall persistently drive the trojans back till they

from that great hour the war’s whole fortune turns,

fulfil the counsels of minerva and take ilius.

pallas assists, and lofty ilion burns.

but i will not

not till that day shall jove relax his rage,

stay my anger, nor permit any god to help the danaans till i have

nor one of all the heavenly host engage

in aid of greece.

promise i made by bowing my head on the day when thetis touched

my knees and besought me to give him honour.

i gave, and seal’d it with the almighty nod,
achilles’ glory to the stars to raise;
such was our word, and fate the word obeys.

”

”

juno heeded his words and went from the heights of ida to great

the trembling queen (the almighty order given)

olympus.

swift from the idaean summit shot to heaven.

swift as the thought of one whose fancy carries him over

as some wayfaring man, who wanders o’er
in thought a length of lands he trod before,
sends forth his active mind from place to place,

vast continents, and he says to himself, “now i will be here, or

joins hill to dale, and measures space with space:

there,” and he would have all manner of things—even so swiftly
did juno wing her way till she came to high olympus and went in

so swift flew juno to the bless’d abodes,

among the gods who were gathered in the house of jove.

if thought of man can match the speed of gods.
there sat the powers in awful synod placed;

when they
saw her they all of them came up to her, and held out their cups
to her by way of greeting.
she let the others be, but took the

you know what

“enough thou know’st the tyrant of the skies,

a proud and cruel disposition my husband has.

severely bent his purpose to fulfil,
unmoved his mind, and unrestrain’d his will.

lead the gods to

go thou, the feasts of heaven attend thy call;

table, where you and all the immortals can hear the wicked

bid the crown’d nectar circle round the hall:
but jove shall thunder through the ethereal dome

designs which he has avowed.

such stern decrees, such threaten’d woes to come,

many a one, mortal and immortal,

as soon shall freeze mankind with dire surprise,

will be angered by them, however peaceably he may be feasting

and damp the eternal banquets of the skies.

now.
”

”

on this juno sat down, and the gods were troubled throughout the

the goddess said, and sullen took her place;
black horror sadden’d each celestial face.

house of jove.

to see the gathering grudge in every breast,

but know, ’tis madness to contest with jove:

go up to him and stay him by force or by persuasion, but he sits

supreme he sits; and sees, in pride of sway.
your vassal godheads grudgingly obey:

aloof and cares for nobody, for he knows that he is much stronger

fierce in the majesty of power controls;

than any other of the immortals.

shakes all the thrones of heaven, and bends the poles.
submiss, immortals!

make the best, therefore, of

all he wills, obey:

but dare not murmur, dare not vent a sigh;
thy own loved boasted offspring lies o’erthrown,

and whose father he owns himself to be.

if that loved boasted offspring be thy own.

”

”

when he heard this mars smote his two sturdy thighs with the flat

stern mars, with anguish for his slaughter’d son,
smote his rebelling breast, and fierce begun:
“thus then, immortals!

the god of battles dares avenge the slain;

should hurl me blazing on those heaps of dead.

as he spoke he gave orders to yoke his horses panic and rout,

to join his rapid coursers for the fight:
then grim in arms, with hasty vengeance flies;
arms that reflect a radiance through the skies.

on this, jove would have been roused

from frantic mars she snatch’d the shield and spear;

report to yon mad tyrant of the main.

bid him leave off

into the sea.

or breathe from slaughter in the fields of air.

if he takes no heed and disobeys me, let him
consider well whether he is strong enough to hold his own against
me if i attack him.

if he refuse, then let him timely weigh

i am older and much stronger than he is; yet

our elder birthright, and superior sway.

he is not afraid to set himself up as on a level with myself, of

how shall his rashness stand the dire alarms,
if heaven’s omnipotence descend in arms?
strives he with me, by whom his power was given,

whom all the other gods stand in awe.

and is there equal to the lord of heaven?

”

”

“attend the mandate of the sire above!

he bids you leave off fighting, and

he bids thee from forbidden wars repair

either join the company of the gods or go down into the sea; if,

to thine own deeps, or to the fields of air.

however, you take no heed and disobey him, he says he will come

this if refused, he bids thee timely weigh

his elder birthright, and superior sway.

for he is older and much stronger than you are, and yet you are

if heaven’s omnipotence descend in arms?

not afraid to set yourself up as on a level with himself, of whom

striv’st thou with him by whom all power is given?

all the other gods stand in awe.

and art thou equal to the lord of heaven?

”

”

neptune was very angry and said, “great heavens!

“what means the haughty sovereign of the skies?

strong as jove

(the king of ocean thus, incensed, replies;)

may be, he has said more than he can do if he has threatened

rule as he will his portion’d realms on high;

violence against me, who am of like honour with himself.
we were

no vassal god, nor of his train, am i.

three brothers whom rhea bore to saturn—jove, myself, and hades

three brother deities from saturn came,

who rules the world below.
heaven and earth were divided into

and ancient rhea, earth’s immortal dame:

three parts, and each of us was to have an equal share.

assign’d by lot, our triple rule we know;

when we

infernal pluto sways the shades below;

cast lots, it fell to me to have my dwelling in the sea for

o’er the wide clouds, and o’er the starry plain,

evermore; hades took the darkness of the realms under the earth,

ethereal jove extends his high domain;
my court beneath the hoary waves i keep,

while air and sky and clouds were the portion that fell to jove;

and hush the roarings of the sacred deep;

but earth and great olympus are the common property of all.

olympus, and this earth, in common lie:

therefore i will not walk as jove would have me.

what claim has here the tyrant of the sky?

for all his
strength, let him keep to his own third share and be contented

far in the distant clouds let him control,

without threatening to lay hands upon me as though i were nobody.

and awe the younger brothers of the pole;

let him keep his bragging talk for his own sons and daughters,

there to his children his commands be given,

who must perforce obey him.

the trembling, servile, second race of heaven.

”

”

sensible people are open to argument, and

a noble mind disdains not to repent.

“great is the profit (thus the god rejoin’d)

it is well when a messenger shows so much discretion.

when ministers are blest with prudent mind:

nevertheless it cuts me to the very heart that any one should

warn’d by thy words, to powerful jove i yield,

” the godhead said;

flying like a falcon, bane of doves and swiftest of all birds.

he

that drives a turtle through the liquid skies,

found hector no longer lying upon the ground, but sitting up, for

as phœbus, shooting from the idaean brow,
glides down the mountain to the plain below.
there hector seated by the stream he sees,

he had just come to himself again.

his sense returning with the coming breeze;
again his pulses beat, his spirits rise;

he knew those who were about

struck me on the chest with a stone as i was killing his comrades

bathed greece in slaughter, and her battle gored,

fighting?

the mighty ajax with a deadly blow

i made sure that this very day i should breathe my last

had almost sunk me to the shades below?
even yet, methinks, the gliding ghosts i spy,

and go down into the house of hades.

and hell’s black horrors swim before my eye.

”

”

thus to bold hector spoke the son of jove,

people.

and breathed immortal ardour from above.

and as a horse, stabled and full-fed, breaks loose and

as when the pamper’d steed, with reins unbound,

gallops gloriously over the plain to the place where he is wont

breaks from his stall, and pours along the ground;

to take his bath in the river—he tosses his head, and his mane

with ample strokes he rushes to the flood,
to bathe his sides, and cool his fiery blood;
his head, now freed, he tosses to the skies;

streams over his shoulders as in all the pride of his strength he

his mane dishevell’d o’er his shoulders flies:
he snuffs the females in the well-known plain,

flies full speed to the pastures where the mares are feeding—even

and springs, exulting, to his fields again:

so hector, when he heard what the god said, urged his horsemen

urged by the voice divine, thus hector flew,

on, and sped forward as fast as his limbs could take him.

full of the god; and all his hosts pursue.

as

those of us who profess to be the flower of the army stand firm,

to scatter hosts and terrify mankind,

led on the trojans.

the greeks expect the shock, the clamours rise

from different parts, and mingle in the skies.

the cry of

dire was the hiss of darts, by heroes flung,

battle rose high from either side, and the arrows flew from the

many a spear sped from strong hands and fastened in

and arrows leaping from the bow-string sung;

the bodies of many a valiant warrior, while others fell to earth

these drink the life of generous warriors slain:

midway, before they could taste of man’s fair flesh and glut
themselves with blood.

those guiltless fall, and thirst for blood in vain.

so long as phoebus apollo held his aegis

quietly and without shaking it, the weapons on either side took

sat doubtful conquest hovering o’er the field;

effect and the people fell, but when he shook it straight in the

but when aloft he shakes it in the skies,

face of the danaans and raised his mighty battle-cry their hearts

shouts in their ears, and lightens in their eyes,
deep horror seizes every grecian breast,

fainted within them and they forgot their former prowess.

their force is humbled, and their fear confess’d.

as when

so flies a herd of oxen, scatter’d wide,

two wild beasts spring in the dead of night on a herd of cattle

no swain to guard them, and no day to guide,
when two fell lions from the mountain come,

or a large flock of sheep when the herdsman is not there—even so

and spread the carnage through the shady gloom.

were the danaans struck helpless, for apollo filled them with

impending phœbus pours around them fear,

panic and gave victory to hector and the trojans.

and troy and hector thunder in the rear.

the fight then became more scattered and they killed one another

heaps fall on heaps: the slaughter hector leads,

where they best could.

first great arcesilas, then stichius bleeds;

hector killed stichius and arcesilaus, the

one to the bold bœotians ever dear,

pierced through the shoulder as he basely flies.

while they were spoiling these heroes of their armour, the

polites’ arm laid echius on the plain;

achaeans were flying pell-mell to the trench and the set stakes,

the greeks dismay’d, confused, disperse or fall,

and were forced back within their wall.

some seek the trench, some skulk behind the wall.

hector then cried out to

while these fly trembling, others pant for breath,
and o’er the slaughter stalks gigantic death.
on rush’d bold hector, gloomy as the night;

the trojans, “forward to the ships, and let the spoils be.

forbids to plunder, animates the fight,
points to the fleet: “for, by the gods!

if i

who flies,[240]

see any man keeping back on the other side the wall away from the

who dares but linger, by this hand he dies;

ships i will have him killed: his kinsmen and kinswomen shall not

no weeping sister his cold eye shall close,

give him his dues of fire, but dogs shall tear him in pieces in

no friendly hand his funeral pyre compose.
who stops to plunder at this signal hour,
the birds shall tear him, and the dogs devour.

front of our city.
”

”

as he spoke he laid his whip about his horses’ shoulders and

furious he said; the smarting scourge resounds;

called to the trojans throughout their ranks; the trojans shouted

the coursers fly; the smoking chariot bounds;
the hosts rush on; loud clamours shake the shore;

with a cry that rent the air, and kept their horses neck and neck
with his own.

the horses thunder, earth and ocean roar!

phoebus apollo went before, and kicked down the

apollo, planted at the trench’s bound,

banks of the deep trench into its middle so as to make a great

push’d at the bank: down sank the enormous mound:

broad bridge, as broad as the throw of a spear when a man is

a sudden road!
a long and ample way.
o’er the dread fosse (a late impervious space)

trying his strength.

bridge, and apollo with his redoubtable aegis led the way.

then with his hand he shook the mighty wall;

he

and lo!

kicked down the wall of the achaeans as easily as a child who

the turrets nod, the bulwarks fall:
easy as when ashore an infant stands,

playing on the sea-shore has built a house of sand and then kicks

and draws imagined houses in the sands;

it down again and destroys it—even so did you, o apollo, shed

the sportive wanton, pleased with some new play,

toil and trouble upon the argives, filling them with panic and

sweeps the slight works and fashion’d domes away:
thus vanish’d at thy touch, the towers and walls;

confusion.

the toil of thousands in a moment falls.

thus then were the achaeans hemmed in at their ships, calling out

the grecians gaze around with wild despair,

to one another and raising their hands with loud cries every man

confused, and weary all the powers with prayer:
exhort their men, with praises, threats, commands;

to heaven.

and urge the gods, with voices, eyes, and hands.

nestor of gerene, tower of strength to the achaeans,

experienced nestor chief obtests the skies,

lifted up his hands to the starry firmament of heaven, and prayed

and weeps his country with a father’s eyes.

more fervently than any of them.

“o jove!

“father jove,” said he, “if ever

if ever, on his native shore,

any one in wheat-growing argos burned you fat thigh-bones of

one greek enrich’d thy shrine with offer’d gore;
if e’er, in hope our country to behold,
we paid the fattest firstlings of the fold;

sheep or heifer and prayed that he might return safely home,

if e’er thou sign’st our wishes with thy nod:

whereon you bowed your head to him in assent, bear it in mind

perform the promise of a gracious god!

now, and suffer not the trojans to triumph thus over the

this day preserve our navies from the flame,

achaeans.

and save the relics of the grecian name.

”

”

all-counselling jove thundered loudly in answer to the prayer of

the aged son of neleus.

and peals of thunder shook the firmament.

when they heard jove thunder they flung

presumptuous troy mistook the accepting sign,

themselves yet more fiercely on the achaeans.

and catch’d new fury at the voice divine.

as a wave breaking

as, when black tempests mix the seas and skies,

over the bulwarks of a ship when the sea runs high before a

above the sides of some tall ship ascend,

great—even so did the trojans spring over the wall with a shout,

thus loudly roaring, and o’erpowering all,
mount the thick trojans up the grecian wall;

and drive their chariots onwards.
the two sides fought with their

legions on legions from each side arise:

their chariots, and the achaeans climbing up into their ships and

fierce on the ships above, the cars below,

wielding the long pikes that were lying on the decks ready for

these wield the mace, and those the javelin throw.

now patroclus, so long as the achaeans and trojans were fighting

while thus the thunder of the battle raged,

about the wall, but were not yet within it and at the ships,

and labouring armies round the works engaged,

the good eurypylus, his wounded friend.

his pain.

and adds discourse, the medicine of the mind.

flat of his hands.

he wrings his hands, he beats his manly breast.

“eurypylus,” said he in his dismay, “i know

“though yet thy state require redress (he cries)

you want me badly, but i cannot stay with you any longer, for

depart i must: what horrors strike my eyes!

there is hard fighting going on; a servant shall take care of you

charged with achilles’ high command i go,
a mournful witness of this scene of woe;

now, for i must make all speed to achilles, and induce him to

i haste to urge him by his country’s care

fight if i can; who knows but with heaven’s help i may persuade

to rise in arms, and shine again in war.

him.

perhaps some favouring god his soul may bend;

a man does well to listen to the advice of a friend.

the voice is powerful of a faithful friend.

”

”

when he had thus spoken he went his way.

he spoke; and, speaking, swifter than the wind

struck by an arm unseen, it burst in two;
down dropp’d the bow: the shaft with brazen head

fell from his hands.

fell innocent, and on the dust lay dead.

“some god prevents our destined enterprise:

broken my bowstring and snatched the bow from my hand, though i

has, from my arm unfailing, struck the bow,
and broke the nerve my hands had twined with art,

strung it this self-same morning that it might serve me for many

strong to impel the flight of many a dart.

an arrow.

”

ajax son of telamon answered, “my good fellow, let your bow and

“since heaven commands it (ajax made reply)

your arrows be, for jove has made them useless in order to spite

dismiss the bow, and lay thy arrows by:
thy arms no less suffice the lance to wield,

the danaans.

and quit the quiver for the ponderous shield.

take your spear, lay your shield upon your shoulder,

in the first ranks indulge thy thirst of fame,

and both fight the trojans yourself and urge others to do so.

thy brave example shall the rest inflame.

they may be successful for the moment but if we fight as we ought

fierce as they are, by long successes vain;
to force our fleet, or even a ship to gain,
asks toil, and sweat, and blood: their utmost might

they will find it a hard matter to take the ships.

shall find its match—no more: ’tis ours to fight.

”

”

teucer then took his bow and put it by in his tent.

then teucer laid his faithless bow aside;

he hung a
shield four hides thick about his shoulders, and on his comely

the fourfold buckler o’er his shoulder tied;

head he set his helmet well wrought with a crest of horse-hair

on his brave head a crested helm he placed,
with nodding horse-hair formidably graced;

that nodded menacingly above it; he grasped his redoubtable

a dart, whose point with brass refulgent shines,

bronze-shod spear, and forthwith he was by the side of ajax.

the warrior wields; and his great brother joins.

when hector saw that teucer’s bow was of no more use to him, he

this hector saw, and thus express’d his joy:

shouted out to the trojans and lycians, “trojans, lycians, and

“ye troops of lycia, dardanus, and troy!

dardanians good in close fight, be men, my friends, and show your

be mindful of yourselves, your ancient fame,

mettle here at the ships, for i see the weapon of one of their

and spread your glory with the navy’s flame.

chieftains made useless by the hand of jove.

jove is with us; i saw his hand, but now,
from the proud archer strike his vaunted bow:

it is easy to see

indulgent jove!
how plain thy favours shine,

when jove is helping people and means to help them still further,

when happy nations bear the marks divine!

or again when he is bringing them down and will do nothing for

how easy then, to see the sinking state

them; he is now on our side, and is going against the argives.

of realms accursed, deserted, reprobate!
such is the fate of greece, and such is ours:

therefore swarm round the ships and fight.
if any of you is

behold, ye warriors, and exert your powers.

struck by spear or sword and loses his life, let him die; he dies

death is the worst; a fate which all must try;

with honour who dies fighting for his country; and he will leave

and for our country, ’tis a bliss to die.
the gallant man, though slain in fight he be,
yet leaves his nation safe, his children free;
entails a debt on all the grateful state;
his own brave friends shall glory in his fate;

his wife and children safe behind him, with his house and
allotment unplundered if only the achaeans can be driven back to

his wife live honour’d, all his race succeed,

their own land, they and their ships.

and late posterity enjoy the deed!

”

”

with these words he put heart and soul into them all.

this roused the soul in every trojan breast:

ajax on the

the godlike ajax next his greeks address’d:

other side exhorted his comrades saying, “shame on you argives,

“how long, ye warriors of the argive race,
(to generous argos what a dire disgrace!
)

we are now utterly undone, unless we can save ourselves by

how long on these cursed confines will ye lie,
yet undetermined, or to live or die?
what hopes remain, what methods to retire,

driving the enemy from our ships.

if once your vessels catch the trojan fire?

do you think, if hector takes

mark how the flames approach, how near they fall,

them, that you will be able to get home by land?

how hector calls, and troy obeys his call!

can you not hear

not to the dance that dreadful voice invites,

him cheering on his whole host to fire our fleet, and bidding

it calls to death, and all the rage of fights.

them remember that they are not at a dance but in battle?

’tis now no time for wisdom or debates;

our

to your own hands are trusted all your fates;

only course is to fight them with might and main; we had better

and better far in one decisive strife,

chance it, life or death, once for all, than fight long and

one day should end our labour or our life,

without issue hemmed in at our ships by worse men than

than keep this hard-got inch of barren sands,
still press’d, and press’d by such inglorious hands.

ourselves.
”

”

with these words he put life and soul into them all.

the listening grecians feel their leader’s flame,
and every kindling bosom pants for fame.

hector then

then mutual slaughters spread on either side;

killed schedius son of perimedes, leader of the phoceans, and

by hector here the phocian schedius died;

ajax killed laodamas captain of foot soldiers and son to antenor.

there, pierced by ajax, sunk laodamas,
chief of the foot, of old antenor’s race.

own sons.

“lo, melanippus!

hector now rebuked him and said, “why, melanippus, are

lo, where dolops lies;

we thus remiss?

and is it thus our royal kinsman dies?

do you take no note of the death of your kinsman,

o’ermatch’d he falls; to two at once a prey,

and do you not see how they are trying to take dolops’s armour?

and lo!
they bear the bloody arms away!

follow me; there must be no fighting the argives from a distance

come on—a distant war no longer wage,

now, but we must do so in close combat till either we kill them

but hand to hand thy country’s foes engage:

or they take the high wall of ilius and slay her people.

till greece at once, and all her glory end;
or ilion from her towery height descend,
heaved from the lowest stone; and bury all
in one sad sepulchre, one common fall.

”

”

he led on as he spoke, and the hero melanippus followed after.

hector (this said) rush’d forward on the foes:
with equal ardour melanippus glows:

meanwhile ajax son of telamon was cheering on the argives.

then ajax thus—“o greeks!

“my

respect your fame,

friends,” he cried, “be men, and fear dishonour; quit yourselves

respect yourselves, and learn an honest shame:

in battle so as to win respect from one another.

let mutual reverence mutual warmth inspire,
and catch from breast to breast the noble fire,
on valour’s side the odds of combat lie;

men who respect

the brave live glorious, or lamented die;

each other’s good opinion are less likely to be killed than those

the wretch that trembles in the field of fame,

who do not, but in flight there is neither gain nor glory.

meets death, and worse than death, eternal shame.

”

”

thus did he exhort men who were already bent upon driving back

his generous sense he not in vain imparts;

the trojans.

it sunk, and rooted in the grecian hearts:

they laid his words to heart and hedged the ships as

they join, they throng, they thicken at his call,

with a wall of bronze, while jove urged on the trojans.

and flank the navy with a brazen wall;
shields touching shields, in order blaze above,
and stop the trojans, though impell’d by jove.

menelaus

the fiery spartan first, with loud applause.

of the loud battle-cry urged antilochus on.

”

he hurried away when he had thus spurred antilochus, who at once

he said; and backward to the lines retired;

carefully round him.

and round the black battalions cast his view.

while the swift javelin hiss’d along in air.

melanippus the proud son of hiketaon in the breast by the nipple

with his bold breast, and felt it in his heart:

as he was coming forward, and his armour rang rattling round him

as he fell heavily to the ground.

and his broad buckler rings against the ground.

antilochus sprang upon him as a

the distant hunter sent into his heart.

but noble hector marked him, and came running up to him through

observing hector to the rescue flew;

the thick of the battle.
antilochus, brave soldier though he was,
would not stay to face him, but fled like some savage creature

bold as he was, antilochus withdrew.

which knows it has done wrong, and flies, when it has killed a

so when a savage, ranging o’er the plain,

dog or a man who is herding his cattle, before a body of men can

has torn the shepherd’s dog, or shepherd’s swain,

be gathered to attack it.

while conscious of the deed, he glares around,
and hears the gathering multitude resound,

even so did the son of nestor fly, and

timely he flies the yet-untasted food,
and gains the friendly shelter of the wood:
so fears the youth; all troy with shouts pursue,

the trojans and hector with a cry that rent the air showered

while stones and darts in mingled tempest flew;

their weapons after him; nor did he turn round and stay his

but enter’d in the grecian ranks, he turns

flight till he had reached his comrades.

his manly breast, and with new fury burns.

the trojans, fierce as lions, were still rushing on towards the

and drives him, like a lightning, on the foe.
so mars, when human crimes for vengeance call,

is raging in the glades of some dense forest upon the mountains;

shakes his huge javelin, and whole armies fall.
not with more rage a conflagration rolls,
wraps the vast mountains, and involves the poles.

he foamed at the mouth, his eyes glared under his terrible

unhappy glories!

glory; for he was doomed to an early death, and already pallas

and gave what fate allow’d, the honours of a day!

the grecian phalanx, moveless as a tower,
on all sides batter’d, yet resists his power:

through them, for they stood as a tower foursquare, or as some

he fell upon

as when a wave,

bursts as a wave that from the cloud impends,

raised mountain high by wind and storm, breaks over a ship and

and, swell’d with tempests, on the ship descends;

covers it deep in foam, the fierce winds roar against the mast,

white are the decks with foam; the winds aloud
howl o’er the masts, and sing through every shroud:

the hearts of the sailors fail them for fear, and they are saved

pale, trembling, tired, the sailors freeze with fears;

but by a very little from destruction—even so were the hearts of

and instant death on every wave appears.

the chief so thunders, and so shakes the fleet.

against alcides, copreus was his sire:

but the son was a far better man than the father in every way; he

the son redeem’d the honours of the race,

was fleet of foot, a valiant warrior, and in understanding ranked

a son as generous as the sire was base;

among the foremost men of mycenae.

these,

being broken up and scattered; shame and fear restrained them.

wall’d round with sterns, a gloomy, desperate band.
now manly shame forbids the inglorious flight;
now fear itself confines them to the fight:

they kept shouting incessantly to one another, and nestor of

man courage breathes in man; but nestor most

(the sage preserver of the grecian host)

firm.

“oh friends!

opinion.

with mutual honour, and with mutual shame!

think, all of you, on your children, your wives, your

think of your hopes, your fortunes; all the care
your wives, your infants, and your parents share:

property, and your parents whether these be alive or dead.

think of each living father’s reverend head;

on

think of each ancestor with glory dead;

their behalf though they are not here, i implore you to stand

absent, by me they speak, by me they sue,
they ask their safety, and their fame, from you:
the gods their fates on this one action lay,

firm, and not to turn in flight.

and all are lost, if you desert the day.

”

”

with these words he put heart and soul into them all.

he spoke, and round him breathed heroic fires;

minerva seconds what the sage inspires.

lifted the thick veil of darkness from their eyes, and much light

she clear’d, restoring all the war to view;
a sudden ray shot beaming o’er the plain,
and show’d the shores, the navy, and the main:
hector they saw, and all who fly, or fight,

his port majestic, and his ample size:

the fight was raging.

a ponderous mace with studs of iron crown’d,

those who were fighting by the ships.

nor fights, like others, fix’d to certain stands

but looks a moving tower above the bands;

strode from deck to deck with a great sea-pike in his hands

high on the decks with vast gigantic stride,

twelve cubits long and jointed with rings.

the godlike hero stalks from side to side.

as a man skilled in

so when a horseman from the watery mead
(skill’d in the manage of the bounding steed)

feats of horsemanship couples four horses together and comes

tearing full speed along the public way from the country into
some large town—many both men and women marvel as they see him

to some great city through the public way;

for he keeps all the time changing his horse, springing from one

safe in his art, as side by side they run,
he shifts his seat, and vaults from one to one;
and now to this, and now to that he flies;

to another without ever missing his feet while the horses are at

you would

they did

and bathed their generous breasts with mutual blood.

not fight at a distance with bows and javelins, but with one mind

no room to poise the lance or bend the bow;

hacked at one another in close combat with their mighty swords

but hand to hand, and man to man, they grow:

and spears pointed at both ends; they fought moreover with keen

wounded, they wound; and seek each other’s hearts

with falchions, axes, swords, and shorten’d darts.

many a good stout blade hilted and

the falchions ring, shields rattle, axes sound,

scabbarded with iron, fell from hand or shoulder as they fought,

swords flash in air, or glitter on the ground;

and the earth ran red with blood.

with streaming blood the slippery shores are dyed,
and slaughter’d heroes swell the dreadful tide.

that toil of ten long years

me back and forbade the host to follow me; if jove did then

too long jove lull’d us with lethargic charms,

indeed warp our judgements, himself now commands me and cheers me

but now in peals of thunder calls to arms:
in this great day he crowns our full desires,
wakes all our force, and seconds all our fires.

on.

doomed.

we are on the

our own country.

far, far from hence: your fates are in your hands.

book xvi.

[illustration: ] castor and pollux
book xvi.
argument

fire being now thrown on the ship of protesilaus, patroclus

the sixth battle, the acts and death of patroclus

fights in the armour of achilles—he drives the trojans back, but

patroclus (in pursuance of the request of nestor in the eleventh book)
entreats achilles to suffer him to go to the assistance of the greeks
with achilles’ troops and armour.
he agrees to it, but at the same time
charges him to content himself with rescuing the fleet, without further
pursuit of the enemy.
the armour, horses, soldiers, and officers are
described.
achilles offers a libation for the success of his friend,
after which patroclus leads the myrmidons to battle.
the trojans, at
the sight of patroclus in achilles’ armour, taking him for that hero,
are cast into the uttermost consternation; he beats them off from the
vessels, hector himself flies, sarpedon is killed, though jupiter was
averse to his fate.
several other particulars of the battle are
described; in the heat of which, patroclus, neglecting the orders of
achilles, pursues the foe to the walls of troy, where apollo repulses

is in the end killed by euphorbus and hector.

and disarms him, euphorbus wounds him, and hector kills him, which
concludes the book.

thus did they fight about the ship of protesilaus.

so warr’d both armies on the ensanguined shore,
while the black vessels smoked with human gore.

then patroclus

the streaming tears fall copious from his eyes.

some spring whose crystal stream falls over the ledges of a high

precipice.

divine pelides, with compassion moved.

when achilles saw him thus weeping he was sorry for

thus spoke, indulgent, to his best beloved:[243]

him and said, “why, patroclus, do you stand there weeping like

“patroclus, say, what grief thy bosom bears,
that flows so fast in these unmanly tears?

some silly child that comes running to her mother, and begs to be
taken up and carried—she catches hold of her mother’s dress to

no girl, no infant whom the mother keeps

stay her though she is in a hurry, and looks tearfully up until

from her loved breast, with fonder passion weeps;

her mother carries her—even such tears, patroclus, are you now

not more the mother’s soul, that infant warms,
clung to her knees, and reaching at her arms,

shedding.

than thou hast mine!

have you anything to say to the myrmidons or to myself?

oh tell me, to what end
thy melting sorrows thus pursue thy friend?
“griev’st thou for me, or for my martial band?

or have you had news from phthia which you alone know?

or come sad tidings from our native land?

they tell

our fathers live (our first, most tender care),

me menoetius son of actor is still alive, as also peleus son of

thy good menoetius breathes the vital air,
and hoary peleus yet extends his days;

aeacus, among the myrmidons—men whose loss we two should bitterly

pleased in their age to hear their children’s praise.

deplore; or are you grieving about the argives and the way in

or may some meaner cause thy pity claim?
perhaps yon relics of the grecian name,

which they are being killed at the ships, through their own

doom’d in their ships to sink by fire and sword,

high-handed doings?

and pay the forfeit of their haughty lord?

do not hide anything from me but tell me that

whate’er the cause, reveal thy secret care,

both of us may know about it.

and speak those sorrows which a friend would share.

”

”

then, o knight patroclus, with a deep sigh you answered,

a sigh that instant from his bosom broke,
another follow’d, and patroclus spoke:

“achilles, son of peleus, foremost champion of the achaeans, do

“let greece at length with pity touch thy breast,

not be angry, but i weep for the disaster that has now befallen

thyself a greek; and, once, of greeks the best!

the argives.

lo!

all those who have been their champions so far are

every chief that might her fate prevent,

lies pierced with wounds, and bleeding in his tent:

brave diomed son

and wise ulysses, at the navy groan,

more for their country’s wounds than for their own.

struck with an arrow in the thigh; skilled apothecaries are
attending to these heroes, and healing them of their wounds; are

their pain soft arts of pharmacy can ease,

you still, o achilles, so inexorable?

thy breast alone no lenitives appease.

may it never be my lot to

good name.

o great in vain!

“o man unpitying!
if of man thy race;

was not your father nor thetis your mother, but the grey sea bore

but sure thou spring’st not from a soft embrace,
nor ever amorous hero caused thy birth,
nor ever tender goddess brought thee forth:

you and the sheer cliffs begot you, so cruel and remorseless are

some rugged rock’s hard entrails gave thee form,
and raging seas produced thee in a storm,
a soul well suiting that tempestuous kind,

you.

so rough thy manners, so untamed thy mind.

if however you are kept back through knowledge of some
oracle, or if your mother thetis has told you something from the

mouth of jove, at least send me and the myrmidons with me, if i

some beam of comfort yet on greece may shine,
if i but lead the myrmidonian line:
clad in thy dreadful arms if i appear,

may bring deliverance to the danaans.

proud troy shall tremble, and desert the war;

“patroclus!

i know no prophesyings which i am

thy achilles knows no fears;

heeding, nor has my mother told me anything from the mouth of

nor words from jove nor oracles he hears;
nor aught a mother’s caution can suggest;

jove, but i am cut to the very heart that one of my own rank

the tyrant’s pride lies rooted in my breast.
my wrongs, my wrongs, my constant thought engage,
those, my sole oracles, inspire my rage:

should dare to rob me because he is more powerful than i am.

i made him tyrant: gave him power to wrong

this, after all that i have gone through, is more than i can
endure.

even me: i felt it; and shall feel it long.

the girl whom the sons of the achaeans chose for me, whom

the maid, my black-eyed maid, he forced away,

i won as the fruit of my spear on having sacked a city—her has

due to the toils of many a well-fought day;
due to my conquest of her father’s reign;
due to the votes of all the grecian train.

king agamemnon taken from me as though i were some common

from me he forced her; me, the bold and brave,

vagrant.

disgraced, dishonour’d, like the meanest slave.

still, let bygones be bygones: no man may keep his anger

but bear we this—the wrongs i grieve are past;
’tis time our fury should relent at last:

for ever; i said i would not relent till battle and the cry of

i fix’d its date; the day i wish’d appears:

war had reached my own ships; nevertheless, now gird my armour
about your shoulders, and lead the myrmidons to battle, for the

how hector to my ships his battle bears,

dark cloud of trojans has burst furiously over our fleet; the

the flames my eyes, the shouts invade my ears.

argives are driven back on to the beach, cooped within a narrow

space, and the whole people of troy has taken heart to sally out

against them, because they see not the visor of my helmet

gleaming near them.

go save the fleets, and conquer in my right.

at the last edge of yon deserted land!

hector rings in my cars as he gives orders to the trojans, who

no more your general calls his heroes on:

triumph over the achaeans and fill the whole plain with their cry

hector, alone, i hear; his dreadful breath

of battle.

commands your slaughter, or proclaims your death.

but even so, patroclus, fall upon them and save the

fleet, lest the trojans fire it and prevent us from being able to

return.

and give the greeks to visit greece again.

do, however, as i now bid you, that you may win me great

but heed my words, and mark a friend’s command,

honour from all the danaans, and that they may restore the girl
to me again and give me rich gifts into the bargain.

who trusts his fame and honours in thy hand,

when you

and from thy deeds expects the achaian host

have driven the trojans from the ships, come back again.

shall render back the beauteous maid he lost:
rage uncontroll’d through all the hostile crew,

though

but touch not hector, hector is my due.

juno’s thundering husband should put triumph within your reach,

though jove in thunder should command the war,

do not fight the trojans further in my absence, or you will rob
me of glory that should be mine.

be just, consult my glory, and forbear.

and do not for lust of battle go

the fleet once saved, desist from further chase,

on killing the trojans nor lead the achaeans on to ilius, lest

nor lead to ilion’s walls the grecian race;

one of the ever-living gods from olympus attack you—for phoebus

some adverse god thy rashness may destroy;
some god, like phœbus, ever kind to troy.

apollo loves them well: return when you have freed the ships from

let greece, redeem’d from this destructive strait,

peril, and let others wage war upon the plain.

do her own work; and leave the rest to fate.

would, by father

o!
would to all the immortal powers above,

apollo, pallas, and almighty jove!

and not a greek of all the race survive:

brow of troy.

and only we destroy the accursed town!

”

”

thus did they converse.

such conference held the chiefs; while on the strand

but ajax could no longer hold his ground

great jove with conquest crown’d the trojan band.
ajax no more the sounding storm sustain’d,

for the shower of darts that rained upon him; the will of jove

so thick the darts an iron tempest rain’d:

and the javelins of the trojans were too much for him; the helmet

on his tired arm the weighty buckler hung;

that gleamed about his temples rang with the continuous clatter

his hollow helm with falling javelins rung;

of the missiles that kept pouring on to it and on to the

his breath, in quick short pantings, comes and goes;

cheek-pieces that protected his face.
moreover his left shoulder

and painful sweat from all his members flows.

was tired with having held his shield so long, yet for all this,
let fly at him as they would, they could not make him give
ground.
he could hardly draw his breath, the sweat rained from

spent and o’erpower’d, he barely breathes at most;

every pore of his body, he had not a moment’s respite, and on all

yet scarce an army stirs him from his post;

sides he was beset by danger upon danger.

dangers on dangers all around him glow,

and now, tell me, o muses that hold your mansions on olympus, how

and toil to toil, and woe succeeds to woe.
say, muses, throned above the starry frame,

fire was thrown upon the ships of the achaeans.

how first the navy blazed with trojan flame?

hector came close

stern hector waved his sword, and standing near,

up and let drive with his great sword at the ashen spear of ajax.

where furious ajax plied his ashen spear,

he cut it clean in two just behind where the point was fastened
on to the shaft of the spear.
ajax, therefore, had now nothing

full on the lance a stroke so justly sped,

but a headless spear, while the bronze point flew some way off

that the broad falchion lopp’d its brazen head;
his pointless spear the warrior shakes in vain;

and came ringing down on to the ground.

the brazen head falls sounding on the plain.

ajax knew the hand of

great ajax saw, and own’d the hand divine;

heaven in this, and was dismayed at seeing that jove had now left

confessing jove, and trembling at the sign,

the hissing brands; thick streams the fiery shower;

divine achilles view’d the rising flames,

and smote his thigh, and thus aloud exclaims:
“arm, arm, patroclus!

for i see the glare of hostile fire at our fleet; up, lest they

lo, the blaze aspires!
the glowing ocean reddens with the fires.
arm, ere our vessels catch the spreading flame;

destroy our ships, and there be no way by which we may retreat.

arm, ere the grecians be no more a name;

gird on your armour at once while i call our people together.

i haste to bring the troops.

”

”—the hero said;

many myrmidons.

and safe return him to these eyes again!

”

”

thus did he pray, and all-counselling jove heard his prayer.
part

great jove consents to half the chief’s request,

of it he did indeed vouchsafe him—but not the whole.

but heaven’s eternal doom denies the rest;

he granted
that patroclus should thrust back war and battle from the ships,

to free the fleet was granted to his prayer;

but refused to let him come safely out of the fight.

his safe return, the winds dispersed in air.

when he had made his drink-offering and had thus prayed, achilles

they sprang high in hope upon the trojans.

invade the trojans, and commence the war.

they came swarming out
like wasps whose nests are by the roadside, and whom silly
children love to tease, whereon any one who happens to be passing

as wasps, provoked by children in their play,

may get stung—or again, if a wayfarer going along the road vexes

pour from their mansions by the broad highway,

them by accident, every wasp will come flying out in a fury to

in swarms the guiltless traveller engage,

defend his little ones—even with such rage and courage did the

whet all their stings, and call forth all their rage:

myrmidons swarm from their ships, and their cry of battle rose

all rise in arms, and, with a general cry,

heavenwards.

”

and from the half-burn’d ship proud troy retires;

the

clear’d from the smoke the joyful navy lies;

trojans were now driven back with a shout that rent the skies,

in heaps on heaps the foe tumultuous flies;

while the danaans poured after them from their ships, shouting

triumphant greece her rescued decks ascends,

also without ceasing.

and loud acclaim the starry region rends.

as when jove, gatherer of the

so when thick clouds enwrap the mountain’s head,

thunder-cloud, spreads a dense canopy on the top of some lofty

o’er heaven’s expanse like one black ceiling spread;
sudden the thunderer, with a flashing ray,
bursts through the darkness, and lets down the day:

mountain, and all the peaks, the jutting headlands, and forest

the hills shine out, the rocks in prospect rise,
and streams, and vales, and forests, strike the eyes;

glades show out in the great light that flashes from the bursting

the smiling scene wide opens to the sight,
and all the unmeasured ether flames with light.

heavens, even so when the danaans had now driven back the fire

but troy repulsed, and scatter’d o’er the plains,

from their ships, they took breath for a little while; but the
fury of the fight was not yet over, for the trojans were not
driven back in utter rout, but still gave battle, and were ousted

forced from the navy, yet the fight maintains.

from their ground only by sheer fighting.

now every greek some hostile hero slew,

the fight then became more scattered, and the chieftains killed

but still the foremost, bold patroclus flew:

one another when and how they could.
the valiant son of menoetius

as areilycus had turn’d him round,

first drove his spear into the thigh of areilycus just as he was

sharp in his thigh he felt the piercing wound;

turning round; the point went clean through, and broke the bone

the brazen-pointed spear, with vigour thrown,
the thigh transfix’d, and broke the brittle bone:

so that he fell forward.

headlong he fell.

meanwhile menelaus struck thoas in the

next, thoas was thy chance;

chest, where it was exposed near the rim of his shield, and he

thy breast, unarm’d, received the spartan lance.

fell dead.
the son of phyleus saw amphiclus about to attack him,

phylides’ dart (as amphidus drew nigh)

and ere he could do so took aim at the upper part of his thigh,

his blow prevented, and transpierced his thigh,

where the muscles are thicker than in any other part; the spear
tore through all the sinews of the leg, and his eyes were closed

tore all the brawn, and rent the nerves away;

in darkness.

in darkness, and in death, the warrior lay.

of the sons of nestor one, antilochus, speared

in equal arms two sons of nestor stand,
and two bold brothers of the lycian band:
by great antilochus, atymnius dies,

atymnius, driving the point of the spear through his throat, and

pierced in the flank, lamented youth!

down he fell.

he lies,

maris then sprang on antilochus in hand-to-hand

kind maris, bleeding in his brother’s wound,
defends the breathless carcase on the ground;

fight to avenge his brother, and bestrode the body spear in hand;

furious he flies, his murderer to engage:

but valiant thrasymedes was too quick for him, and in a moment

but godlike thrasimed prevents his rage,

had struck him in the shoulder ere he could deal his blow; his
aim was true, and the spear severed all the muscles at the root

between his arm and shoulder aims a blow;

of his arm, and tore them right down to the bone, so he fell

his arm falls spouting on the dust below:

heavily to the ground and his eyes were closed in darkness.

he sinks, with endless darkness cover’d o’er:

thus

and vents his soul, effused with gushing gore.

did these two noble comrades of sarpedon go down to erebus slain
by the two sons of nestor; they were the warrior sons of

amisodorus, who had reared the invincible chimaera, to the bane

amisodarus, who, by furies led,
the bane of men, abhorr’d chimaera bred;
skill’d in the dart in vain, his sons expire,

of many.

and pay the forfeit of their guilty sire.

ajax son of oileus sprang on cleobulus and took him

stopp’d in the tumult cleobulus lies,

alive as he was entangled in the crush; but he killed him then

beneath oïleus’ arm, a living prize;
a living prize not long the trojan stood;

and there by a sword-blow on the neck.

the thirsty falchion drank his reeking blood:

the sword reeked with his

plunged in his throat the smoking weapon lies;

blood, while dark death and the strong hand of fate gripped him
and closed his eyes.

black death, and fate unpitying, seal his eyes.

peneleos and lycon now met in close fight, for they had missed

amid the ranks, with mutual thirst of fame,

each other with their spears.
they had both thrown without

was no more life left in him.

hung by the skin; the body sunk to dust.

he drove a spear through his right shoulder so that he fell

back from the car he tumbles to the ground:

headlong from the car, and his eyes were closed in darkness.

his swimming eyes eternal shades surround.

he sobs his soul out in the gush of blood.

thus did these chieftains of the danaans each of them kill his
man.

and on his buckler caught the ringing shower:

“glaucus, be bold; thy task be first to dare

then as a friend, and as a warrior fight;

that i have fallen at their ships.

defend my body, conquer in my right:

do your very utmost and call

that, taught by great examples, all may try

all my people together.

like thee to vanquish, or like me to die.

death closed his eyes as he spoke.

we have speared at the ships.

nor on his corse revenge her heroes lost!

the chief who taught our lofty walls to yield,
lies pale in death, extended on the field.
to guard his body troy in numbers flies;
’tis half the glory to maintain our prize.

and outrage it; let us strip the armour from his shoulders, and

haste, strip his arms, the slaughter round him spread,

kill his comrades if they try to rescue his body.

and send the living lycians to the dead.

”

”

he spoke to men who of themselves were full eager; both sides,

the heroes kindle at his fierce command;

he pays due vengeance to his kinsman’s shade.

“o valiant leader of the dardan host!
(insulted merion thus retorts the boast)
strong as you are, ’tis mortal force you trust,

not be able to make an end of every one who comes against you.

an arm as strong may stretch thee in the dust.

you are only a mortal like myself, and if i were to hit you in

and if to this my lance thy fate be given,

the middle of your shield with my spear, however strong and

vain are thy vaunts; success is still from heaven:

self-confident you may be, i should soon vanquish you, and you

this, instant, sends thee down to pluto’s coast;

would yield your life to hades of the noble steeds.

mine is the glory, his thy parting ghost.

”

”

on this the son of menoetius rebuked him and said, “meriones,

“o friend (menoetius’ son this answer gave)

hero though you be, you should not speak thus; taunting speeches,

with words to combat, ill befits the brave;

my good friend, will not make the trojans draw away from the dead

not empty boasts the sons of troy repel,

body; some of them must go under ground first; blows for battle,

your swords must plunge them to the shades of hell.

and words for council; fight, therefore, and say nothing.

to speak, beseems the council; but to dare
in glorious action, is the task of war.

”

”

he led the way as he spoke and the hero went forward with him.

this said, patroclus to the battle flies;
great merion follows, and new shouts arise:

on the phrygian plain,
and from the fight convey sarpedon slain;

then bathe his body in the crystal flood,
with dust dishonour’d, and deform’d with blood;

may wash him in the river, anoint him with ambrosia, and clothe

o’er all his limbs ambrosial odours shed,

him in immortal raiment; this done, commit him to the arms of the

and with celestial robes adorn the dead.
those rites discharged, his sacred corse bequeath

two fleet messengers, death, and sleep, who will carry him

to the soft arms of silent sleep and death.

straightway to the rich land of lycia, where his brothers and

they to his friends the immortal charge shall bear;

kinsmen will inter him, and will raise both mound and pillar to

his friends a tomb and pyramid shall rear:

his memory, in due honour to the dead.

what honour mortals after death receive,
those unavailing honours we may give!

”

”

thus he spoke.

lycia

swift to the field precipitates his flight;

took sarpedon out of range of the weapons, and then bore him a

thence from the war the breathless hero bore,

long way off, where he washed him in the river, anointed him with

veil’d in a cloud, to silver simois’ shore;

ambrosia and clothed him in immortal raiment; this done, he

there bathed his honourable wounds, and dress’d
his manly members in the immortal vest;
and with perfumes of sweet ambrosial dews
restores his freshness, and his form renews.

committed him to the arms of the two fleet messengers, death, and

then sleep and death, two twins of winged race,
of matchless swiftness, but of silent pace,
received sarpedon, at the god’s command,

sleep, who presently set him down in the rich land of lycia.

and in a moment reach’d the lycian land;
the corse amidst his weeping friends they laid,
where endless honours wait the sacred shade.

first adrestus,

the slaughter, elasus and mulius crown’d:
then sunk pylartes to eternal night;

these he slew, but the rest saved themselves by flight.

the rest, dispersing, trust their fates to flight.

were, of a lion that while attacking a stockyard is himself

swift as a lion, terrible and bold,

that sweeps the field, depopulates the fold;

and from his fatal courage finds his bane.

the pair then

as two lions fight fiercely on

while all around, confusion, rage, and fright,
mix the contending hosts in mortal fight.

as the
east and south wind buffet one another when they beat upon some
dense forest on the mountains—there is beech and ash and

so pent by hills, the wild winds roar aloud

spreading cornel; the top of the trees roar as they beat on one

in the deep bosom of some gloomy wood;
leaves, arms, and trees, aloft in air are blown,
the broad oaks crackle, and the sylvans groan;

another, and one can hear the boughs cracking and breaking—even

this way and that, the rattling thicket bends,

so did the trojans and achaeans spring upon one another and lay

and the whole forest in one crash descends.

about each other, and neither side would give way.

now flights of arrows bounding from the string:

bowstring about the body of cebriones; many a great stone,

stones follow stones; some clatter on the fields,

moreover, beat on many a shield as they fought around his body,

some hard, and heavy, shake the sounding shields.

but there he lay in the whirling clouds of dust, all huge and

but where the rising whirlwind clouds the plains,
sunk in soft dust the mighty chief remains,

hugely, heedless of his driving now.

and, stretch’d in death, forgets the guiding reins!

so long as the sun was still high in mid-heaven the weapons of

now flaming from the zenith, sol had driven
his fervid orb through half the vault of heaven;

either side were alike deadly, and the people fell; but when he

there ends thy glory!

apollo dreadful stops thy middle way;
death calls, and heaven allows no longer day!

earnest.

for lo!

off under the horses’ feet, where its horse-hair plumes were all

achilles’ plume is stain’d with dust and gore;

never indeed had that helmet fared

that plume which never stoop’d to earth before;

so before, for it had served to protect the head and comely

long used, untouch’d, in fighting fields to shine,

nevertheless the end of
hector also was near.

not long—for fate pursues him, and the god.

the bronze-shod spear, so great and so
strong, was broken in the hand of patroclus, while his shield

his spear in shivers falls; his ample shield

that covered him from head to foot fell to the ground as did also

drops from his arm: his baldric strows the field:

the band that held it, and apollo undid the fastenings of his

the corslet his astonish’d breast forsakes:

corslet.

loose is each joint; each nerve with horror shakes;

on this his mind became clouded; his limbs failed him, and he

stupid he stares, and all-assistless stands:
such is the force of more than mortal hands!

stood as one dazed; whereon euphorbus son of panthous a

a dardan youth there was, well known to fame,

dardanian, the best spearman of his time, as also the finest

from panthus sprung, euphorbus was his name;

horseman and fleetest runner, came behind him and struck him in

famed for the manage of the foaming horse,

the back with a spear, midway between the shoulders.

skill’d in the dart, and matchless in the course:

this man as
soon as ever he had come up with his chariot had dismounted

full twenty knights he tumbled from the car,

twenty men, so proficient was he in all the arts of war—he it

while yet he learn’d his rudiments of war.

was, o knight patroclus, that first drove a weapon into you, but

his venturous spear first drew the hero’s gore;

he did not quite overpower you.

he struck, he wounded, but he durst no more.

euphorbus then ran back into the

but swift withdrew the long-protended wood.

crowd, after drawing his ashen spear out of the wound; he would

and turn’d him short, and herded in the crowd.

not stand firm and wait for patroclus, unarmed though he now was,

to attack him; but patroclus unnerved, alike by the blow the god
