had given him and by the spear-wound, drew back under cover of

retires for succour to his social train,

his men in fear for his life.

and flies the fate, which heaven decreed, in vain.

hector on this, seeing him to be

stern hector, as the bleeding chief he views,

wounded and giving ground, forced his way through the ranks, and

breaks through the ranks, and his retreat pursues:
the lance arrests him with a mortal wound;
he falls, earth thunders, and his arms resound.

when close up with him struck him in the lower part of the belly
with a spear, driving the bronze point right through it, so that

with him all greece was sunk; that moment all

he fell heavily to the ground to the great grief of the achaeans.

her yet-surviving heroes seem’d to fall.

as when a lion has fought some fierce wild boar and worsted

so, scorch’d with heat, along the desert score,
the roaming lion meets a bristly boar,

him—the two fight furiously upon the mountains over some little

fast by the spring; they both dispute the flood,

fountain at which they would both drink, and the lion has beaten

with flaming eyes, and jaws besmear’d with blood;

the boar till he can hardly breathe—even so did hector son of

at length the sovereign savage wins the strife;

priam take the life of the brave son of menoetius who had killed

and the torn boar resigns his thirst and life.

so many, striking him from close at hand, and vaunting over him

patroclus thus, so many chiefs o’erthrown,
so many lives effused, expires his own.

the while.

as dying now at hector’s feet he lies,

“patroclus,” said he, “you deemed that you should sack

he sternly views him, and triumphant cries:
“lie there, patroclus!

our city, rob our trojan women of their freedom, and carry them

and with thee, the joy

off in your ships to your own country.

thy pride once promised, of subverting troy;

fool; hector and his fleet

the fancied scenes of ilion wrapt in flames,

horses were ever straining their utmost to defend them.

and thy soft pleasures served with captive dames.

i am

unthinking man!

foremost of all the trojan warriors to stave the day of bondage

i fought those towers to free,

from off them; as for you, vultures shall devour you here.

and guard that beauteous race from lords like thee:
but thou a prey to vultures shalt be made;

poor
wretch, achilles with all his bravery availed you nothing; and

thy own achilles cannot lend thee aid;

yet i ween when you left him he charged you straitly saying,

though much at parting that great chief might say,
and much enjoin thee, this important day.

‘come not back to the ships, knight patroclus, till you have rent

‘return not, my brave friend (perhaps he said),

the blood-stained shirt of murderous hector about his body.

without the bloody arms of hector dead.

’ thus

’

i ween did he charge you, and your fool’s heart answered him

he spoke, patroclus march’d, and thus he sped.

‘yea’ within you.
”

”

then, as the life ebbed out of you, you answered, o knight

supine, and wildly gazing on the skies,
with faint, expiring breath, the chief replies:

patroclus: “hector, vaunt as you will, for jove the son of saturn

“vain boaster!

and apollo have vouchsafed you victory; it is they who have

cease, and know the powers divine!
jove’s and apollo’s is this deed, not thine;
to heaven is owed whate’er your own you call,

vanquished me so easily, and they who have stripped the armour

and heaven itself disarm’d me ere my fall.

from my shoulders; had twenty such men as you attacked me, all of

had twenty mortals, each thy match in might,

them would have fallen before my spear.

opposed me fairly, they had sunk in fight:

fate and the son of leto
have overpowered me, and among mortal men euphorbus; you are

by fate and phœbus was i first o’erthrown,

yourself third only in the killing of me.

euphorbus next; the third mean part thy own.
but thou, imperious!

i say further, and lay

hear my latest breath;

my saying to your heart, you too shall live but for a little

the gods inspire it, and it sounds thy death:
insulting man, thou shalt be soon as i;

season; death and the day of your doom are close upon you, and

black fate o’erhangs thee, and thy hour draws nigh;
even now on life’s last verge i see thee stand,

they will lay you low by the hand of achilles son of aeacus.

i see thee fall, and by achilles’ hand.

”

”

when he had thus spoken his eyes were closed in death, his soul

he faints: the soul unwilling wings her way,

left his body and flitted down to the house of hades, mourning

(the beauteous body left a load of clay)

its sad fate and bidding farewell to the youth and vigor of its

flits to the lone, uncomfortable coast;

manhood.

a naked, wandering, melancholy ghost!

dead though he was, hector still spoke to him saying,

then hector pausing, as his eyes he fed
on the pale carcase, thus address’d the dead:
“from whence this boding speech, the stern decree

“patroclus, why should you thus foretell my doom?

of death denounced, or why denounced to me?

who knows but

why not as well achilles’ fate be given

achilles, son of lovely thetis, may be smitten by my spear and

to hector’s lance?

die before me?

who knows the will of heaven?

”

”

as he spoke he drew the bronze spear from the wound, planting his

pensive he said; then pressing as he lay

foot upon the body, which he thrust off and let lie on its back.

his breathless bosom, tore the lance away;

he then went spear in hand after automedon, squire of the fleet

and upwards cast the corse: the reeking spear
he shakes, and charges the bold charioteer.
but swift automedon with loosen’d reins

descendant of aeacus, for he longed to lay him low, but the

rapt in the chariot o’er the distant plains,

immortal steeds which the gods had given as a rich gift to peleus

far from his rage the immortal coursers drove;
the immortal coursers were the gift of jove.

bore him swiftly from the field.

argument.

the fight around the body of patroclus.

this, glaucus

objects to hector as a flight, who thereupon puts on the armour he had

the greeks give way, till
ajax rallies them: æneas sustains the trojans.
æneas and hector attempt

thick darkness: the noble prayer of ajax on that occasion.

he

menelaus

held his round shield and his spear in front of him, resolute to

returns to the fight, where, though attacked with the utmost fury, he
and meriones, assisted by the ajaces, bear off the body to the ships.

kill any who should dare face him.

the time is the evening of the eight-and-twentieth day.
the scene
lies in the fields before troy.

but the son of panthous had

on the cold earth divine patroclus spread,

also noted the body, and came up to menelaus saying, “menelaus,

lies pierced with wounds among the vulgar dead.

son of atreus, draw back, leave the body, and let the

great menelaus, touch’d with generous woe,
springs to the front, and guards him from the foe.
thus round her new-fallen young the heifer moves,
fruit of her throes, and first-born of her loves;
and anxious (helpless as he lies, and bare)
turns, and re-turns her, with a mother’s care,
opposed to each that near the carcase came,
his broad shield glimmers, and his lances flame.
the son of panthus, skill’d the dart to send,
eyes the dead hero, and insults the friend.
“this hand, atrides, laid patroclus low;

blood-stained spoils be.

warrior!

i was first of the trojans and their

desist, nor tempt an equal blow:

brave allies to drive my spear into patroclus, let me, therefore,

to me the spoils my prowess won, resign:

have my full glory among the trojans, or i will take aim and kill

depart with life, and leave the glory mine.

you.
”

”

to this menelaus answered in great anger “by father jove,

the trojan thus: the spartan monarch burn’d
with generous anguish, and in scorn return’d:
“laugh’st thou not, jove!
from thy superior throne,

boasting is an ill thing.

when mortals boast of prowess not their own?

the pard is not more bold, nor the lion

not thus the lion glories in his might,

nor savage wild boar, which is fiercest and most dauntless of all

nor panther braves his spotted foe in fight,
nor thus the boar (those terrors of the plain;)
man only vaunts his force, and vaunts in vain.
but far the vainest of the boastful kind,

creatures, than are the proud sons of panthous.

these sons of panthus vent their haughty mind.

yet hyperenor did

yet ’twas but late, beneath my conquering steel
this boaster’s brother, hyperenor, fell;

not see out the days of his youth when he made light of me and

against our arm which rashly he defied,

withstood me, deeming me the meanest soldier among the danaans.

vain was his vigour, and as vain his pride.
these eyes beheld him on the dust expire,

his own feet never bore him back to gladden his wife and parents.

no more to cheer his spouse, or glad his sire.

even so shall i make an end of you too, if you withstand me; get

presumptuous youth!

you back into the crowd and do not face me, or it shall be worse

like his shall be thy doom,

for you.

go, wait thy brother to the stygian gloom;

even a fool may be wise after the event.

or, while thou may’st, avoid the threaten’d fate;
fools stay to feel it, and are wise too late.

”

”

euphorbus would not listen, and said, “now indeed, menelaus,

unmoved, euphorbus thus: “that action known,

shall you pay for the death of my brother over whom you vaunted,

come, for my brother’s blood repay thy own.
his weeping father claims thy destined head,

and whose wife you widowed in her bridal chamber, while you

and spouse, a widow in her bridal bed.

brought grief unspeakable on his parents.
i shall comfort these
poor people if i bring your head and armour and place them in the

on these thy conquer’d spoils i shall bestow,

hands of panthous and noble phrontis.

to soothe a consort’s and a parent’s woe.

the time is come when this

no longer then defer the glorious strife,

matter shall be fought out and settled, for me or against me.

let heaven decide our fortune, fame, and life.

”

”

as he spoke he struck menelaus full on the shield, but the spear

swift as the word the missile lance he flings;

did not go through, for the shield turned its point.

the well-aim’d weapon on the buckler rings,

menelaus

but blunted by the brass, innoxious falls.

then took aim, praying to father jove as he did so; euphorbus was

on jove the father great atrides calls,

drawing back, and menelaus struck him about the roots of his

nor flies the javelin from his arm in vain,

throat, leaning his whole weight on the spear, so as to drive it
home.

it pierced his throat, and bent him to the plain;

the point went clean through his neck, and his armour rang

wide through the neck appears the grisly wound,

rattling round him as he fell heavily to the ground.

prone sinks the warrior, and his arms resound.

his hair

the shining circlets of his golden hair,

which was like that of the graces, and his locks so deftly bound

which even the graces might be proud to wear,

in bands of silver and gold, were all bedrabbled with blood.

instarr’d with gems and gold, bestrow the shore,

as

with dust dishonour’d, and deform’d with gore.

one who has grown a fine young olive tree in a clear space where

as the young olive, in some sylvan scene,

there is abundance of water—the plant is full of promise, and

crown’d by fresh fountains with eternal green,

though the winds beat upon it from every quarter it puts forth

lifts the gay head, in snowy flowerets fair,
and plays and dances to the gentle air;
when lo!

its white blossoms till the blasts of some fierce hurricane sweep

a whirlwind from high heaven invades

down upon it and level it with the ground—even so did menelaus

the tender plant, and withers all its shades;
it lies uprooted from its genial bed,
a lovely ruin now defaced and dead:

strip the fair youth euphorbus of his armour after he had slain

thus young, thus beautiful, euphorbus lay,
while the fierce spartan tore his arms away.

him.

proud of his deed, and glorious in the prize,

or as some fierce lion upon the mountains in the pride of

affrighted troy the towering victor flies:
flies, as before some mountain lion’s ire

his strength fastens on the finest heifer in a herd as it is

the village curs and trembling swains retire,
when o’er the slaughter’d bull they hear him roar,

feeding—first he breaks her neck with his strong jaws, and then

and see his jaws distil with smoking gore:

gorges on her blood and entrails; dogs and shepherds raise a hue

all pale with fear, at distance scatter’d round,

and cry against him, but they stand aloof and will not come close

they shout incessant, and the vales resound.

to him, for they are pale with fear—even so no one had the

meanwhile apollo view’d with envious eyes,

courage to face valiant menelaus.

and urged great hector to dispute the prize;

“hector,” said he,

but you will not take them; they cannot be kept in hand and

immortal mother.

by sparta slain!

euphorbus son of panthous, so that he can fight no more.

for ever now suppress’d
the fire which burn’d in that undaunted breast!

”

”

the god then went back into the toil and turmoil, but the soul of

thus having spoke, apollo wing’d his flight,
and mix’d with mortals in the toils of fight:
his words infix’d unutterable care
deep in great hector’s soul: through all the war

hector was darkened with a cloud of grief; he looked along the

he darts his anxious eye; and, instant, view’d

ranks and saw euphorbus lying on the ground with the blood still

the breathless hero in his blood imbued,

flowing from his wound, and menelaus stripping him of his armour.

(forth welling from the wound, as prone he lay)
and in the victor’s hands the shining prey.
sheath’d in bright arms, through cleaving ranks he flies,

on this he made his way to the front like a flame of fire, clad

and sends his voice in thunder to the skies:
fierce as a flood of flame by vulcan sent,
it flew, and fired the nations as it went.

in his gleaming armour, and crying with a loud voice.
when the

atrides from the voice the storm divined,

son of atreus heard him, he said to himself in his dismay, “alas!

and thus explored his own unconquer’d mind:

what shall i do?
i may not let the trojans take the armour of
patroclus who has fallen fighting on my behalf, lest some danaan
who sees me should cry shame upon me.
still if for my honour’s
sake i fight hector and the trojans single-handed, they will

“then shall i quit patroclus on the plain,

prove too many for me, for hector is bringing them up in force.

slain in my cause, and for my honour slain!

why, however, should i thus hesitate?

desert the arms, the relics, of my friend?

when a man fights in

or singly, hector and his troops attend?

despite of heaven with one whom a god befriends, he will soon rue

sure where such partial favour heaven bestow’d,

it.

to brave the hero were to brave the god:

let no danaan think ill of me if i give place to hector, for

forgive me, greece, if once i quit the field;

the hand of heaven is with him.

’tis not to hector, but to heaven i yield.
yet, nor the god, nor heaven, should give me fear,

yet, if i could find ajax, the

did but the voice of ajax reach my ear:

two of us would fight hector and heaven too, if we might only

still would we turn, still battle on the plains,

save the body of patroclus for achilles son of peleus.

and give achilles all that yet remains

this, of

of his and our patroclus—” this, no more

many evils would be the least.

the time allow’d: troy thicken’d on the shore.

”

a sable scene!

while he was thus in two minds, the trojans came up to him with

the terrors hector led.

hector at their head; he therefore drew back and left the body,

slow he recedes, and sighing quits the dead.

turning about like some bearded lion who is being chased by dogs

forced by loud clamours, and a storm of darts;

all grim in arms, and cover’d o’er with blood;

had sunk each heart with terror and dismay.

he ran up to him and

his armour, hector already has it.

and hector glories in the dazzling prize.

”

and now before, and now behind he stood:

stands over his whelps if hunters have come upon him in a forest

with many a step, the lioness surrounds

“hector,” said he, “you make a brave show,

“where now in hector shall we hector find?

but in fight you are sadly wanting.

a manly form, without a manly mind.

a runaway like yourself has

is this, o chief!

no claim to so great a reputation.

a hero’s boasted fame?
how vain, without the merit, is the name!

think how you may now save

ilius; for you will get no lycians to fight for you, seeing what

mean, empty boast!

thanks they have had for their incessant hardships.

those lycians you forsake?

likely, sir, to do anything to help a man of less note, after

thy friend sarpedon proves thy base neglect;
say, shall our slaughter’d bodies guard your walls,

to be the spoil and prey of the danaans?

while unreveng’d the great sarpedon falls?

so long as he lived he

if

hector scowled at him and answered, “glaucus, you should know

the lycian leader, and sedate replied:
“say, is it just, my friend, that hector’s ear

better.

from such a warrior such a speech should hear?

i have held you so far as a man of more understanding

i deem’d thee once the wisest of thy kind,

than any in all lycia, but now i despise you for saying that i am

but ill this insult suits a prudent mind.

afraid of ajax.

i shun great ajax?

i fear neither battle nor the din of chariots,

i desert my train?
’tis mine to prove the rash assertion vain;
i joy to mingle where the battle bleeds,
and hear the thunder of the sounding steeds.

but jove’s will is stronger than ours; jove at one time makes

but jove’s high will is ever uncontroll’d,

even a strong man draw back and snatches victory from his grasp,

the strong he withers, and confounds the bold;
now crowns with fame the mighty man, and now

while at another he will set him on to fight.

strikes the fresh garland from the victor’s brow!

come hither then,

come, through yon squadrons let us hew the way,

my friend, stand by me and see indeed whether i shall play the
coward the whole day through as you say, or whether i shall not

and thou be witness, if i fear to-day;

stay some even of the boldest danaans from fighting round the

if yet a greek the sight of hector dread,

body of patroclus.

or yet their hero dare defend the dead.

”

“ye trojans, dardans, lycians, and allies!

friends, and fight might and main, while i put on the goodly

be men, my friends, in action as in name,

armour of achilles, which i took when i killed patroclus.

and yet be mindful of your ancient fame.
hector in proud achilles’ arms shall shine,
torn from his friend, by right of conquest mine.

”

”

with this hector left the fight, and ran full speed after his men

he strode along the field, as thus he said:

who were taking the armour of achilles to troy, but had not yet

(the sable plumage nodded o’er his head:)

got far.

swift through the spacious plain he sent a look;

standing for a while apart from the woeful fight, he

one instant saw, one instant overtook
the distant band, that on the sandy shore

the radiant spoils to sacred ilion bore.

and to the trojans, while he put on the immortal armour of the

armour.

he shook the sacred honours of his head;

“ah, wretched man!
unmindful of thy end!
a moment’s glory; and what fates attend!

poor wretch, you arm in

in heavenly panoply divinely bright
thou stand’st, and armies tremble at thy sight,
as at achilles’ self!
beneath thy dart

the armour of a hero, before whom many another trembles, and you

lies slain the great achilles’ dearer part.
thou from the mighty dead those arms hast torn,

reck nothing of the doom that is already close upon you.

which once the greatest of mankind had worn.

you have

yet live!

i do

the son of saturn bowed his portentous brows, and hector fitted

the armour to his body, while terrible mars entered into him, and

the stubborn arms (by jove’s command disposed)

filled his whole body with might and valour.

conform’d spontaneous, and around him closed:

with a shout he

fill’d with the god, enlarged his members grew,

strode in among the allies, and his armour flashed about him so

through all his veins a sudden vigour flew,

that he seemed to all of them like the great son of peleus

the blood in brisker tides began to roll,

himself.

and mars himself came rushing on his soul.

he went about among them and cheered them on—mesthles,

exhorting loud through all the field he strode,

glaucus, medon, thersilochus, asteropaeus, deisenor and

and look’d, and moved, achilles, or a god.
now mesthles, glaucus, medon, he inspires,
now phorcys, chromius, and hippothous fires;
the great thersilochus like fury found,
asteropaeus kindled at the sound,

hippothous, phorcys, chromius and ennomus the augur.

and ennomus, in augury renown’d.

all these

“hear, all ye hosts, and hear, unnumber’d bands

did he exhort saying, “hear me, allies from other cities who are

of neighbouring nations, or of distant lands!

here in your thousands, it was not in order to have a crowd about
me that i called you hither each from his several city, but that

’twas not for state we summon’d you so far,

with heart and soul you might defend the wives and little ones of

to boast our numbers, and the pomp of war:

the trojans from the fierce achaeans.

ye came to fight; a valiant foe to chase,

for this do i oppress my

to save our present, and our future race.

people with your food and the presents that make you rich.

for this, our wealth, our products, you enjoy,

therefore turn, and charge at the foe, to stand or fall as is the

and glean the relics of exhausted troy.

game of war; whoever shall bring patroclus, dead though he be,

now then, to conquer or to die prepare;
to die or conquer are the terms of war.

into the hands of the trojans, and shall make ajax give way

whatever hand shall win patroclus slain,

before him, i will give him one half of the spoils while i keep

whoe’er shall drag him to the trojan train,

the other.

with hector’s self shall equal honours claim;

he will thus share like honour with myself.

with hector part the spoil, and share the fame.

”

”

when he had thus spoken they charged full weight upon the danaans

fired by his words, the troops dismiss their fears,
they join, they thicken, they protend their spears;
full on the greeks they drive in firm array,

with their spears held out before them, and the hopes of each ran

and each from ajax hopes the glorious prey:
vain hope!

“our fatal day, alas!

then ajax said to menelaus, “my good friend menelaus, you

is come, my friend;

and i shall hardly come out of this fight alive.

and all our wars and glories at an end!

i am less

’tis not this corse alone we guard in vain,

concerned for the body of patroclus, who will shortly become meat

condemn’d to vultures on the trojan plain;
we too must yield: the same sad fate must fall

for the dogs and vultures of troy, than for the safety of my own

on thee, on me, perhaps, my friend, on all.
see what a tempest direful hector spreads,

head and yours.

and lo!

hector has wrapped us round in a storm of battle
from every quarter, and our destruction seems now certain.

it bursts, it thunders on our heads!

call

call on our greeks, if any hear the call,

then upon the princes of the danaans if there is any who can hear

the bravest greeks: this hour demands them all.

us.
”

”

the top of his voice.

“o chiefs!

“my friends,” he cried, “princes and

o princes, to whose hand is given

the rule of men; whose glory is from heaven!
whom with due honours both atrides grace:

menelaus drink at the public cost, and give orders each to his

ye guides and guardians of our argive race!

own people as jove vouchsafes him power and glory, the fight is

all, whom this well-known voice shall reach from far,

so thick about me that i cannot distinguish you severally; come

all, whom i see not through this cloud of war;

on, therefore, every man unbidden, and think it shame that

come all!
let generous rage your arms employ,

patroclus should become meat and morsel for trojan hounds.

and save patroclus from the dogs of troy.

remain,

i have known men, whose

there have been heroes, who, by virtuous care,

numbers, courage, and self-reliance have saved their people in

by valour, numbers, and by arts of war,
have forced the powers to spare a sinking state,
and gain’d at length the glorious odds of fate:

but you, when fortune smiles, when jove declares

ran red with blood as the corpses fell thick on one another alike

fierce as conflicting fires the combat burns,

and stand by one another.

and now it rises, now it sinks by turns.

thus did they fight as it were a flaming fire; it seemed as

in one thick darkness all the fight was lost;

though it had gone hard even with the sun and moon, for they were

the sun, the moon, and all the ethereal host
seem’d as extinct: day ravish’d from their eyes,

hidden over all that part where the bravest heroes were fighting

and all heaven’s splendours blotted from the skies.

about the dead son of menoetius, whereas the other danaans and

such o’er patroclus’ body hung the night,

neither on plain nor mountain.

no vapour rested on the mountain’s head,

these last moreover would rest for

and thick and heavy grows the work of death:

sweat of their toil rained ever on their legs under them, and on

their knees, their legs, their feet, are covered o’er;
drops follow drops, the clouds on clouds arise,

their hands and eyes, as they fought over the squire of the fleet

and carnage clogs their hands, and darkness fills their eyes.

son of peleus.
it was as when a man gives a great ox-hide all

as when a slaughter’d bull’s yet reeking hide,

drenched in fat to his men, and bids them stretch it; whereon

strain’d with full force, and tugg’d from side to side,

they stand round it in a ring and tug till the moisture leaves

the brawny curriers stretch; and labour o’er

it, and the fat soaks in for the many that pull at it, and it is

the extended surface, drunk with fat and gore:

well stretched—even so did the two sides tug the dead body hither

so tugging round the corse both armies stood;

and thither within the compass of but a little space—the trojans

the mangled body bathed in sweat and blood;

steadfastly set on dragging it into ilius, while the achaeans

while greeks and ilians equal strength employ,

were no less so on taking it to their ships; and fierce was the
fight between them.

now to the ships to force it, now to troy.

as he had gone close up to the gates.

had informed him of the counsels of great jove.

perhaps to him: this thetis had reveal’d;

now, however, she

and heaps on heaps by mutual wounds they bled.

then would one say,

“my friends, we can never again show our faces at the

who dares desert this well-disputed day!

ships—better, and greatly better, that earth should open and

first may the cleaving earth before our eyes

gape wide, and drink our blood for sacrifice;

trojans have the triumph of bearing off patroclus to their city.

first perish all, ere haughty troy shall boast
we lost patroclus, and our glory lost!

automedon, valiant son of diores, lashed them

in vain automedon now shakes the rein,

again and again; many a time did he speak kindly to them, and

now plies the lash, and soothes and threats in vain;

many a time did he upbraid them, but they would neither go back
to the ships by the waters of the broad hellespont, nor yet into

nor to the fight nor hellespont they go,

battle among the achaeans; they stood with their chariot stock

restive they stood, and obstinate in woe:

still, as a pillar set over the tomb of some dead man or woman,

still as a tombstone, never to be moved,
on some good man or woman unreproved
lays its eternal weight; or fix’d, as stands
a marble courser by the sculptor’s hands,
placed on the hero’s grave.

and bowed their heads to the ground.

along their face

the big round drops coursed down with silent pace,

their manes, that late

side the yoke.

and prone to earth was hung their languid head:

the son of saturn saw them and took pity upon their sorrow.

nor jove disdain’d to cast a pitying look,

he

while thus relenting to the steeds he spoke:

wagged his head, and muttered to himself, saying, “poor things,

“unhappy coursers of immortal strain,

why did we give you to king peleus who is a mortal, while you are

exempt from age, and deathless, now in vain;
did we your race on mortal man bestow,

yourselves ageless and immortal?

only, alas!

was it that you might share the
sorrows that befall mankind?

to share in mortal woe?

for of all creatures that live and

for ah!

move upon the earth there is none so pitiable as he is—still,

what is there of inferior birth,
that breathes or creeps upon the dust of earth;
what wretched creature of what wretched kind,

hector son of priam shall drive neither you nor your chariot.

than man more weak, calamitous, and blind?

i

a miserable race!

will not have it.

but cease to mourn:
for not by you shall priam’s son be borne

it is enough that he should have the armour

high on the splendid car: one glorious prize

over which he vaunts so vainly.

he rashly boasts: the rest our will denies.

furthermore i will give you

ourself will swiftness to your nerves impart,

strength of heart and limb to bear automedon safely to the ships

ourself with rising spirits swell your heart.
automedon your rapid flight shall bear
safe to the navy through the storm of war.

from battle, for i shall let the trojans triumph still further,

for yet ’tis given to troy to ravage o’er

and go on killing till they reach the ships; whereon night shall

the field, and spread her slaughters to the shore;
the sun shall see her conquer, till his fall

fall and darkness overshadow the land.

with sacred darkness shades the face of all.

”

”

as he spoke he breathed heart and strength into the horses so

he said; and breathing in the immortal horse

that they shook the dust from out of their manes, and bore their

excessive spirit, urged them to the course;
from their high manes they shake the dust, and bear

chariot swiftly into the fight that raged between trojans and

the kindling chariot through the parted war:

achaeans.

no greek like him the heavenly steeds restrains,
or holds their fury in suspended reins:

can, save only patroclus—while he was alive—peer of gods in

patroclus, while he lived, their rage could tame,

counsel.

but now patroclus is an empty name!

take then the whip and reins, while i go down from the

the ruling charge: the task of fight be mine.

he said.

i am sure,
if you think well, that we might take them; they will not dare

face us if we both attack them.

unite thy force, my friend, and we prevail.

”

the valiant son of anchises was of the same mind, and the pair

the son of venus to the counsel yields;

went right on, with their shoulders covered under shields of

tough dry ox-hide, overlaid with much bronze.

with brass refulgent the broad surface shined,

then in the lower belly struck the dart.

as when some sturdy youth, axe in hand,

as when a ponderous axe, descending full,

deals his blow behind the horns of an ox and severs the tendons

cleaves the broad forehead of some brawny bull:[249]
struck ’twixt the horns, he springs with many a bound,

at the back of its neck so that it springs forward and then

then tumbling rolls enormous on the ground:

drops, even so did aretus give one bound and then fall on his

thus fell the youth; the air his soul received,

back the spear quivering in his body till it made an end of him.

and the spear trembled as his entrails heaved.

hector then aimed a spear at automedon but he saw it coming and

now at automedon the trojan foe

stooping, he shunn’d; the javelin idly fled,
and hiss’d innoxious o’er the hero’s head;

point stuck in the ground, while the butt-end went on quivering

deep rooted in the ground, the forceful spear

till mars robbed it of its force.

in long vibrations spent its fury there.

they would then have fought

high on the chariot at one bound he sprung,

steeped in gore as a lion that has been gorging upon a bull.

and o’er his seat the bloody trophies hung.

and now the fierce groanful fight again raged about patroclus,
for minerva came down from heaven and roused its fury by the

and now minerva from the realms of air

command of far-seeing jove, who had changed his mind and sent her

to encourage the danaans.

for, pleased at length the grecian arms to aid,
the lord of thunders sent the blue-eyed maid.

as when jove bends his bright bow in

as when high jove denouncing future woe,
o’er the dark clouds extends his purple bow,

heaven in token to mankind either of war or of the chill storms

(in sign of tempests from the troubled air,
or from the rage of man, destructive war,)

that stay men from their labour and plague the flocks—even so,

the drooping cattle dread the impending skies,
and from his half-till’d field the labourer flies:

wrapped in such radiant raiment, did minerva go in among the host

in such a form the goddess round her drew

and speak man by man to each.

a livid cloud, and to the battle flew.

first she took the form and voice

menelaus answered, “phoenix, my good old friend, may minerva

by long experience wise!

vouchsafe me strength and keep the darts from off me, for so

what more desires my soul, than here unmoved
to guard the body of the man i loved?
ah, would minerva send me strength to rear

shall i stand by patroclus and defend him; his death has gone to

this wearied arm, and ward the storm of war!

my heart, but hector is as a raging fire and deals his blows

but hector, like the rage of fire, we dread,

without ceasing, for jove is now granting him a time of triumph.

and jove’s own glories blaze around his head!

”

”

minerva was pleased at his having named herself before any of the

“alas,” said he,

then thus begun,

“even a fool may see that father jove is helping the trojans.

to atreus’s seed, the godlike telamon:

all

“alas!

their weapons strike home; no matter whether it be a brave man or

who sees not jove’s almighty hand
transfers the glory to the trojan band?
whether the weak or strong discharge the dart,

a coward that hurls them, jove speeds all alike, whereas ours

he guides each arrow to a grecian heart:
not so our spears; incessant though they rain,

fall each one of them without effect.

he suffers every lance to fall in vain.

what, then, will be best

deserted of the god, yet let us try

both as regards rescuing the body, and our return to the joy of

what human strength and prudence can supply;
if yet this honour’d corse, in triumph borne,
may glad the fleets that hope not our return,

our friends who will be grieving as they look hitherwards; for
they will make sure that nothing can now check the terrible hands

who tremble yet, scarce rescued from their fates,

of hector, and that he will fling himself upon our ships.

and still hear hector thundering at their gates.

i wish

some hero too must be despatch’d to bear

the mournful message to pelides’ ear;

do not think he can have yet heard the sad news that the dearest

for sure he knows not, distant on the shore,

his friend, his loved patroclus, is no more.

but i can see not a man among the

achaeans to send, for they and their chariots are alike hidden in

the men, the steeds, the armies, all are lost

darkness.

in general darkness—lord of earth and air!
oh king!

o father jove, lift this cloud from over the sons of

oh father!

the achaeans; make heaven serene, and let us see; if you will

hear my humble prayer:
dispel this cloud, the light of heaven restore;
give me to see, and ajax asks no more:
if greece must perish, we thy will obey,

that we perish, let us fall at any rate by daylight.

but let us perish in the face of day!

”

”

father jove heard him and had compassion upon his tears.

with tears the hero spoke, and at his prayer

forthwith he chased away the cloud of darkness, so that the sun

the god relenting clear’d the clouded air;
forth burst the sun with all-enlightening ray;

shone out and all the fighting was revealed.

the blaze of armour flash’d against the day.

ajax then said to

“now, now, atrides!

cast around thy sight;

still living, send him at once to tell achilles that by far the

let him to great achilles’ ear convey

dearest to him of all his comrades has fallen.
”

the fatal news”—atrides hastes away.

menelaus heeded his words and went his way as a lion from a
stockyard—the lion is tired of attacking the men and hounds, who
keep watch the whole night through and will not let him feast on

so turns the lion from the nightly fold,

the fat of their herd.

though high in courage, and with hunger bold,

in his lust of meat he makes straight at

long gall’d by herdsmen, and long vex’d by hounds,

them but in vain, for darts from strong hands assail him, and

stiff with fatigue, and fretted sore with wounds;
the darts fly round him from a hundred hands,

burning brands which daunt him for all his hunger, so in the

and the red terrors of the blazing brands:

morning he slinks sulkily away—even so did menelaus sorely

till late, reluctant, at the dawn of day
sour he departs, and quits the untasted prey,

against his will leave patroclus, in great fear lest the achaeans

so moved atrides from his dangerous place

should be driven back in rout and let him fall into the hands of

with weary limbs, but with unwilling pace;

the foe.

the foe, he fear’d, might yet patroclus gain,

he charged meriones and the two ajaxes straitly saying,

and much admonish’d, much adjured his train:

“ajaxes and meriones, leaders of the argives, now indeed remember

“o guard these relics to your charge consign’d,

how good patroclus was; he was ever courteous while alive, bear

and bear the merits of the dead in mind;
how skill’d he was in each obliging art;
the mildest manners, and the gentlest heart:
he was, alas!
but fate decreed his end,

it in mind now that he is dead.

in death a hero, as in life a friend!

”

”

with this menelaus left them, looking round him as keenly as an

so parts the chief; from rank to rank he flew,
and round on all sides sent his piercing view.

eagle, whose sight they say is keener than that of any other

as the bold bird, endued with sharpest eye

bird—however high he may be in the heavens, not a hare that runs

of all that wings the mid aërial sky,
the sacred eagle, from his walks above

can escape him by crouching under bush or thicket, for he will

looks down, and sees the distant thicket move;

swoop down upon it and make an end of it—even so, o menelaus, did
your keen eyes range round the mighty host of your followers to

snatches his life amid the clouds of air.

presently

which i would indeed were untrue.

for sadder tidings never touch’d thy ear;

you must see with your own eyes

that heaven is heaping calamity upon the danaans, and giving
victory to the trojans.

how ilion triumphs, and the achaians mourn.

patroclus has fallen, who was the bravest

of the achaeans, and sorely will the danaans miss him.

now pale and dead, shall succour greece no more.

as for the armour,

the sad achilles, how his loved-one fell:
he too may haste the naked corse to gain:

hector already has it.

the arms are hector’s, who despoil’d the slain.

”

”

antilochus was struck with horror.

the youthful warrior heard with silent woe,

for a long time he was

what sorrow dictates, but no word found way.

who, near him wheeling, drove his steeds along;

“gone is antilochus (the hero said);

ships to tell achilles, but rage against hector as he may, he

but hope not, warriors, for achilles’ aid:
though fierce his rage, unbounded be his woe,

cannot come, for he cannot fight without armour.

unarm’d, he fights not with the trojan foe.

what then will

’tis in our hands alone our hopes remain,

be our best plan both as regards rescuing the dead, and our own

’tis our own vigour must the dead regain,
and save ourselves, while with impetuous hate

escape from death amid the battle-cries of the trojans?

troy pours along, and this way rolls our fate.

”

”

ajax answered, “menelaus, you have said well: do you, then, and

“’tis well (said ajax), be it then thy care,

meriones stoop down, raise the body, and bear it out of the fray,

with merion’s aid, the weighty corse to rear;

while we two behind you keep off hector and the trojans, one in

myself, and my bold brother will sustain
the shock of hector and his charging train:
nor fear we armies, fighting side by side;

heart as in name, and long used to fighting side by side with one

what troy can dare, we have already tried,

another.

have tried it, and have stood.

”

” the hero said.

on this menelaus and meriones took the dead man in their arms and
lifted him high aloft with a great effort.

high from the ground the warriors heave the dead.

the trojan host raised

a general clamour rises at the sight:

a hue and cry behind them when they saw the achaeans bearing the

loud shout the trojans, and renew the fight.
not fiercer rush along the gloomy wood,

body away, and flew after them like hounds attacking a wounded

with rage insatiate, and with thirst of blood,
voracious hounds, that many a length before

boar at the loo of a band of young huntsmen.

their furious hunters, drive the wounded boar;

for a while the
hounds fly at him as though they would tear him in pieces, but

but if the savage turns his glaring eye,

now and again he turns on them in a fury, scaring and scattering

they howl aloof, and round the forest fly.

them in all directions—even so did the trojans for a while charge

thus on retreating greece the trojans pour,

in a body, striking with sword and with spears pointed at both

wave their thick falchions, and their javelins shower:

the ends, but when the two ajaxes faced them and stood at bay,

but ajax turning, to their fears they yield,

they would turn pale and no man dared press on to fight further

all pale they tremble and forsake the field.

about the dead.
in this wise did the two heroes strain every nerve to bear the

while thus aloft the hero’s corse they bear,

body to the ships out of the fight.
the battle raged round them

behind them rages all the storm of war:

like fierce flames that when once kindled spread like wildfire

confusion, tumult, horror, o’er the throng
of men, steeds, chariots, urged the rout along:
less fierce the winds with rising flames conspire

over a city, and the houses fall in the glare of its burning—even

to whelm some city under waves of fire;
now sink in gloomy clouds the proud abodes,
now crack the blazing temples of the gods;

such was the roar and tramp of men and horses that pursued them

the rumbling torrent through the ruin rolls,

as they bore patroclus from the field.

and sheets of smoke mount heavy to the poles.
the heroes sweat beneath their honour’d load:

or as mules that put forth

as when two mules, along the rugged road,

all their strength to draw some beam or great piece of ship’s

from the steep mountain with exerted strength
drag some vast beam, or mast’s unwieldy length;

timber down a rough mountain-track, and they pant and sweat as

inly they groan, big drops of sweat distil,
the enormous timber lumbering down the hill:

they go—even so did menelaus and meriones pant and sweat as they bore the

so these—behind, the bulk of ajax stands,

body of patroclus.
behind them the two ajaxes held stoutly out.

and breaks the torrent of the rushing bands.

as some wooded mountain-spur that stretches across a plain will

thus when a river swell’d with sudden rains

turn water and check the flow even of a great river, nor is there

spreads his broad waters o’er the level plains,

any stream strong enough to break through it—even so did the two

some interposing hill the stream divides,

ajaxes face the trojans and stem the tide of their fighting

and breaks its force, and turns the winding tides.

though they kept pouring on towards them and foremost among them

still close they follow, close the rear engage;

all was aeneas son of anchises with valiant hector.

æneas storms, and hector foams with rage:

as a flock of

while greece a heavy, thick retreat maintains,
wedged in one body, like a flight of cranes,

daws or starlings fall to screaming and chattering when they see
a falcon, foe to all small birds, come soaring near them, even so

that shriek incessant, while the falcon, hung

did the achaean youth raise a babel of cries as they fled before

high on poised pinions, threats their callow young.

aeneas and hector, unmindful of their former prowess.

so from the trojan chiefs the grecians fly,
such the wild terror, and the mingled cry:

in the rout

within, without the trench, and all the way,

of the danaans much goodly armour fell round about the trench,

strow’d in bright heaps, their arms and armour lay;
such horror jove impress’d!

and of fighting there was no end.

yet still proceeds
the work of death, and still the battle bleeds.

book xviii.

[illustration: ] vulcan from an antique gem
book xviii.
argument.

the grief of achilles over patroclus—the visit of thetis to

the grief of achilles, and new armour made him by vulcan.
the news of the death of patroclus is brought to achilles by
antilochus.
thetis, hearing his lamentations, comes with all her sea-
nymphs to comfort him.
the speeches of the mother and son on this
occasion.
iris appears to achilles by the command of juno, and orders
him to show himself at the head of the intrenchments.
the sight of him
turns the fortunes of the day, and the body of patroclus is carried off
by the greeks.
the trojans call a council, where hector and polydamas
disagree in their opinions: but the advice of the former prevails, to
remain encamped in the field.
the grief of achilles over the body of

vulcan and the armour that he made for achilles.

patroclus.
thetis goes to the palace of vulcan to obtain new arms for her son.
the description of the wonderful works of vulcan: and, lastly, that
noble one of the shield of achilles.
the latter part of the nine-and-twentieth day, and the night
ensuing, take up this book: the scene is at achilles’ tent on the
sea-shore, from whence it changes to the palace of vulcan.

thus then did they fight as it were a flaming fire.

thus like the rage of fire the combat burns,[250]
and now it rises, now it sinks by turns.

meanwhile the

meanwhile, where hellespont’s broad waters flow,

fleet runner antilochus, who had been sent as messenger, reached

stood nestor’s son, the messenger of woe:

achilles, and found him sitting by his tall ships and boding that

there sat achilles, shaded by his sails,
on hoisted yards extended to the gales;
pensive he sat; for all that fate design’d

which was indeed too surely true.

rose in sad prospect to his boding mind.

“alas,” said he to himself in

thus to his soul he said: “ah!

the heaviness of his heart, “why are the achaeans again scouring

what constrains

the plain and flocking towards the ships?

the greeks, late victors, now to quit the plains?

heaven grant the gods

is this the day, which heaven so long ago

be not now bringing that sorrow upon me of which my mother thetis

ordain’d, to sink me with the weight of woe?

spoke, saying that while i was yet alive the bravest of the

(so thetis warn’d;) when by a trojan hand

the bravest of the myrmidonian band
should lose the light!

the sun no longer.

fulfilled is that decree;

i fear the brave son of menoetius has fallen

fallen is the warrior, and patroclus he!

through his own daring and yet i bade him return to the ships as
soon as he had driven back those that were bringing fire against

in vain i charged him soon to quit the plain,

them, and not join battle with hector.

and warn’d to shun hectorean force in vain!

”

”

as he was thus pondering, the son of nestor came up to him and

thus while he thinks, antilochus appears,

told his sad tale, weeping bitterly the while.

and tells the melancholy tale with tears.

“alas,” he cried,
“son of noble peleus, i bring you bad tidings, would indeed that

“sad tidings, son of peleus!

they were untrue.

thou must hear;

patroclus has fallen, and a fight is raging

and wretched i, the unwilling messenger!
dead is patroclus!

about his naked body—for hector holds his armour.

for his corse they fight;
his naked corse: his arms are hector’s right.

”

”

a dark cloud of grief fell upon achilles as he listened.

a sudden horror shot through all the chief,
and wrapp’d his senses in the cloud of grief;

he
filled both hands with dust from off the ground, and poured it

cast on the ground, with furious hands he spread

over his head, disfiguring his comely face, and letting the

the scorching ashes o’er his graceful head;

refuse settle over his shirt so fair and new.

his purple garments, and his golden hairs,

he flung himself

those he deforms with dust, and these he tears;

down all huge and hugely at full length, and tore his hair with

on the hard soil his groaning breast he threw,

his hands.

and roll’d and grovell’d, as to earth he grew.

the bondswomen whom achilles and patroclus had taken

the virgin captives, with disorder’d charms,
(won by his own, or by patroclus’ arms,)

captive screamed aloud for grief, beating their breasts, and with

rush’d from their tents with cries; and gathering round,

their limbs failing them for sorrow.

beat their white breasts, and fainted on the ground:

antilochus bent over him the

while nestor’s son sustains a manlier part,

while, weeping and holding both his hands as he lay groaning for

and mourns the warrior with a warrior’s heart;

he feared that he might plunge a knife into his own throat.

hangs on his arms, amidst his frantic woe,

then

and oft prevents the meditated blow.

achilles gave a loud cry and his mother heard him as she was

far in the deep abysses of the main,[251]

sitting in the depths of the sea by the old man her father,

with hoary nereus, and the watery train,

whereon she screamed, and all the goddesses daughters of nereus

the mother-goddess from her crystal throne
heard his loud cries, and answer’d groan for groan.
the circling nereids with their mistress weep,

that dwelt at the bottom of the sea, came gathering round her.

and all the sea-green sisters of the deep.

there were glauce, thalia and cymodoce, nesaia, speo, thoe and

the depths of the sea.

in their lament.

till thetis’ sorrows thus began to flow:

“listen,” she cried, “sisters, daughters of nereus, that you may

“hear me, and judge, ye sisters of the main!

hear the burden of my sorrows.

how just a cause has thetis to complain!
how wretched, were i mortal, were my fate!
how more than wretched in the immortal state!

alas, woe is me, woe in that i

sprung from my bed a godlike hero came,

have borne the most glorious of offspring.

the bravest far that ever bore the name;

i bore him fair and

like some fair olive, by my careful hand

strong, hero among heroes, and he shot up as a sapling; i tended
him as a plant in a goodly garden, and sent him with his ships to

he grew, he flourish’d and adorn’d the land!

ilius to fight the trojans, but never shall i welcome him back to

to troy i sent him: but the fates ordain

the house of peleus.

he never, never must return again.

so long as he lives to look upon the light

so short a space the light of heaven to view,
so short, alas!

of the sun he is in heaviness, and though i go to him i cannot

and fill’d with anguish too!

help him.

hear how his sorrows echo through the shore!

nevertheless i will go, that i may see my dear son and

i cannot ease them, but i must deplore;

learn what sorrow has befallen him though he is still holding

i go at least to bear a tender part,

aloof from battle.

and mourn my loved-one with a mother’s heart.

”

”

“why mourns my son?

are you thus weeping?

thy late preferr’d request

the god has granted, and the greeks distress’d:
why mourns my son?

tell me;

thy anguish let me share,

surely jove has granted you the prayer you

”

patroclus—ah!

—say, goddess, can i boast

a pleasure now?

me, seeing that my dear comrade patroclus has fallen—he whom i

revenge itself is lost;

valued more than all others, and loved as dearly as my own life?

patroclus, loved of all my martial train,
beyond mankind, beyond myself is slain!

i have lost him; aye, and hector when he had killed him stripped
the wondrous armour, so glorious to behold, which the gods gave

to peleus when they laid you in the couch of a mortal man.

on peleus; hector bears the glorious load.

would

cursed be that day, when all the powers above

that you were still dwelling among the immortal sea-nymphs, and

thy charms submitted to a mortal love:
o hadst thou still, a sister of the main,
pursued the pleasures of the watery reign:
and happier peleus, less ambitious, led

that peleus had taken to himself some mortal bride.

a mortal beauty to his equal bed!
ere the sad fruit of thy unhappy womb
had caused such sorrows past, and woes to come.

for now you

for soon, alas!

shall have grief infinite by reason of the death of that son whom

that wretched offspring slain,
new woes, new sorrows, shall create again.

you can never welcome home—nay, i will not live nor go about

’tis not in fate the alternate now to give;
patroclus dead, achilles hates to live.

among mankind unless hector fall by my spear, and thus pay me for

let me revenge it on proud hector’s heart,
let his last spirit smoke upon my dart;
on these conditions will i breathe: till then,

having slain patroclus son of menoetius.

i blush to walk among the race of men.

”

”

thetis wept and answered, “then, my son, is your end near at

a flood of tears, at this, the goddess shed:

hand—for your own death awaits you full soon after that of

“ah then, i see thee dying, see thee dead!

hector.

when hector falls, thou diest.

”
then said achilles in his great grief, “i would die here and now,

”—“let hector die,

in that i could not save my comrade.

and let me fall!

he has fallen far from home,

(achilles made reply)
far lies patroclus from his native plain!

and in his hour of need my hand was not there to help him.

he fell, and falling, wish’d my aid in vain.

what

ah then, since from this miserable day

is there for me?
return to my own land i shall not, and i have

i cast all hope of my return away;

brought no saving neither to patroclus nor to my other comrades

since, unrevenged, a hundred ghosts demand

of whom so many have been slain by mighty hector; i stay here by

the fate of hector from achilles’ hand;
since here, for brutal courage far renown’d,

my ships a bootless burden upon the earth, i, who in fight have

i live an idle burden to the ground,

no peer among the achaeans, though in council there are better

(others in council famed for nobler skill,
more useful to preserve, than i to kill,)

than i.

let me—but oh!
ye gracious powers above!

therefore, perish strife both from among gods and men,
and anger, wherein even a righteous man will harden his

wrath and revenge from men and gods remove:

heart—which rises up in the soul of a man like smoke, and the

far, far too dear to every mortal breast,

taste thereof is sweeter than drops of honey.

sweet to the soul, as honey to the taste:

even so has

gathering like vapours of a noxious kind

agamemnon angered me.

from fiery blood, and darkening all the mind.
me agamemnon urged to deadly hate;

and yet—so be it, for it is over; i will
force my soul into subjection as i needs must; i will go; i will

’tis past—i quell it; i resign to fate.

pursue hector who has slain him whom i loved so dearly, and will

yes—i will meet the murderer of my friend;

then abide my doom when it may please jove and the other gods to

or (if the gods ordain it) meet my end.

send it.

the stroke of fate the strongest cannot shun:

even hercules, the best beloved of jove—even he could

the great alcides, jove’s unequall’d son,

not escape the hand of death, but fate and juno’s fierce anger

to juno’s hate, at length resign’d his breath,
and sunk the victim of all-conquering death.

laid him low, as i too shall lie when i am dead if a like doom

so shall achilles fall!
stretch’d pale and dead,

awaits me.

no more the grecian hope, or trojan dread!

till then i will win fame, and will bid trojan and

let me, this instant, rush into the fields,
and reap what glory life’s short harvest yields.

dardanian women wring tears from their tender cheeks with both

shall i not force some widow’d dame to tear
with frantic hands her long dishevell’d hair?
shall i not force her breast to heave with sighs,
and the soft tears to trickle from her eyes?

their hands in the grievousness of their great sorrow; thus shall

yes, i shall give the fair those mournful charms—

they know that he who has held aloof so long will hold aloof no

in vain you hold me—hence!

longer.

my arms!
my arms!
—

hold me not back, therefore, in the love you bear me, for

soon shall the sanguine torrent spread so wide,

you shall not move me.

that all shall know achilles swells the tide.

then silver-footed thetis answered, “my son, what you have said

is true.

to fate submitting with a secret sigh,)

the host to succour, and thy friends to save,

is worthy thee; the duty of the brave.
but canst thou, naked, issue to the plains?

triumph upon his own shoulders.

thy radiant arms the trojan foe detains.

full well i know that his vaunt

insulting hector bears the spoils on high,

shall not be lasting, for his end is close at hand; go not,

but vainly glories, for his fate is nigh.

however, into the press of battle till you see me return hither;

yet, yet awhile thy generous ardour stay;

to-morrow at break of day i shall be here, and will bring you

assured, i meet thee at the dawn of day,

goodly armour from king vulcan.

charged with refulgent arms (a glorious load),
vulcanian arms, the labour of a god.

as oft the ajaces his assault sustain;

the fight, and now again he would stand still and cry aloud, but

but check’d, he turns; repuls’d, attacks again.
with fiercer shouts his lingering troops he fires,

he would give no ground.

nor yields a step, nor from his post retires:

as upland shepherds that cannot chase

so watchful shepherds strive to force, in vain,

some famished lion from a carcase, even so could not the two
ajaxes scare hector son of priam from the body of patroclus.

the hungry lion from a carcase slain.

they have my armour.

arms i have none, and can i fight unarm’d?

my mother forbade me to arm till

i should see her come, for she promised to bring me goodly armour

till thetis bring me at the dawn of day

from vulcan; i know no man whose arms i can put on, save only the

vulcanian arms: what other can i wield,

shield of ajax son of telamon, and he surely must be fighting in

except the mighty telamonian shield?
that, in my friend’s defence, has ajax spread,
while his strong lance around him heaps the dead:

and does what his achilles should have done.

patroclus.

you are; go to the deep trench and show yourself before the

but though unarm’d, yet clad in terrors, go!
let but achilles o’er yon trench appear,

trojans, that they may fear you and cease fighting.

proud troy shall tremble, and consent to fear;

thus will the

greece from one glance of that tremendous eye

fainting sons of the achaeans gain some brief breathing time,
which in battle may hardly be.

shall take new courage, and disdain to fly.

she spoke, and pass’d in air.

a stream of glory flamed above his head.

as the smoke that goes

as when from some beleaguer’d town arise
the smokes, high curling to the shaded skies;

up into heaven from some city that is being beleaguered on an

(seen from some island, o’er the main afar,

island far out at sea—all day long do men sally from the city and

when men distress’d hang out the sign of war;)

fight their hardest, and at the going down of the sun the line of

soon as the sun in ocean hides his rays,

beacon-fires blazes forth, flaring high for those that dwell near

them to behold, if so be that they may come with their ships and

with long-projected beams the seas are bright,

succour them—even so did the light flare from the head of

and heaven’s high arch reflects the ruddy light:
so from achilles’ head the splendours rise,
reflecting blaze on blaze against the skies.

achilles, as he stood by the trench, going beyond the wall—but he
did not join the achaeans for he heeded the charge which his

forth march’d the chief, and distant from the crowd,

mother laid upon him.
there did he stand and shout aloud.

high on the rampart raised his voice aloud;

minerva also raised her voice

with her own shout minerva swells the sound;

from afar, and spread terror unspeakable among the trojans.

troy starts astonish’d, and the shores rebound.

ringing as the note of a trumpet that sounds alarm then the foe

as the loud trumpet’s brazen mouth from far
with shrilling clangour sounds the alarm of war,

is at the gates of a city, even so brazen was the voice of the

struck from the walls, the echoes float on high,
and the round bulwarks and thick towers reply;
so high his brazen voice the hero rear’d:

son of aeacus, and when the trojans heard its clarion tones they

hosts dropp’d their arms, and trembled as they heard:

were dismayed; the horses turned back with their chariots for

and back the chariots roll, and coursers bound,

they boded mischief, and their drivers were awe-struck by the

and steeds and men lie mingled on the ground.

steady flame which the grey-eyed goddess had kindled above the

aghast they see the living lightnings play,

head of the great son of peleus.

and turn their eyeballs from the flashing ray.

thrice did achilles raise his loud cry as he stood by the trench,

thrice from the trench his dreadful voice he raised,

and thrice were the trojans and their brave allies thrown into

and thrice they fled, confounded and amazed.

confusion; whereon twelve of their noblest champions fell beneath

twelve in the tumult wedged, untimely rush’d

the wheels of their chariots and perished by their own spears.

on their own spears, by their own chariots crush’d:

the achaeans to their great joy then drew patroclus out of reach

while, shielded from the darts, the greeks obtain
the long-contended carcase of the slain.

of the weapons, and laid him on a litter: his comrades stood

pours unavailing sorrows o’er the dead,

had sent him out with horses and chariots into battle, but his

whom late triumphant, with his steeds and car,
he sent refulgent to the field of war;

return he was not to welcome.

(unhappy change!

then juno sent the busy sun, loth though he was, into the waters

) now senseless, pale, he found,

of oceanus; so he set, and the achaeans had rest from the tug and

stretch’d forth, and gash’d with many a gaping wound.
meantime, unwearied with his heavenly way,
in ocean’s waves the unwilling light of day
quench’d his red orb, at juno’s high command,
and from their labours eased the achaian band.

turmoil of war.
now the trojans when they had come out of the fight, unyoked

the frighted trojans (panting from the war,

supper.

a sudden council call’d: each chief appear’d

they kept their feet, nor would any dare to sit down, for
fear had fallen upon them all because achilles had shown himself

in haste, and standing; for to sit they fear’d.

after having held aloof so long from battle.

’twas now no season for prolong’d debate;

polydamas son of

they saw achilles, and in him their fate.

panthous was first to speak, a man of judgement, who alone among

silent they stood: polydamas at last,

them could look both before and after.

skill’d to discern the future by the past,

he was comrade to hector,

(the friend of hector, and of equal years;

and they had been born upon the same night; with all sincerity

the self-same night to both a being gave,

[illustration: ] juno commanding the sun to set

“look to it well, my friends; i would urge you to go back now to

“in free debate, my friends, your sentence speak;

your city and not wait here by the ships till morning, for we are

for me, i move, before the morning break,
to raise our camp: too dangerous here our post,

far from our walls.

far from troy walls, and on a naked coast.

so long as this man was at enmity with

i deem’d not greece so dreadful, while engaged

agamemnon the achaeans were easier to deal with, and i would have

in mutual feuds her king and hero raged;

gladly camped by the ships in the hope of taking them; but now i

then, while we hoped our armies might prevail
we boldly camp’d beside a thousand sail.

go in great fear of the fleet son of peleus; he is so daring that

i dread pelides now: his rage of mind

he will never bide here on the plain whereon the trojans and

not long continues to the shores confined,

retreat.

and the hard contest not for fame, but life.

for this is what will happen.

haste then to ilion, while the favouring night

detains these terrors, keeps that arm from fight.

for a time stay the son of peleus, but if he find us here in the
morning when he sallies forth in full armour, we shall have

if but the morrow’s sun behold us here,

knowledge of him in good earnest.

that arm, those terrors, we shall feel, not fear;

glad indeed will he be who can

and hearts that now disdain, shall leap with joy,

escape and get back to ilius, and many a trojan will become meat

if heaven permit them then to enter troy.

for dogs and vultures may i never live to hear it.

let not my fatal prophecy be true,

if we do as i

nor what i tremble but to think, ensue.

say, little though we may like it, we shall have strength in

whatever be our fate, yet let us try

close them will protect the city.

ships to fight us.

array’d in arms, shall line the lofty towers.

he will go back when he has given his horses

let the fierce hero, then, when fury calls,

their fill of being driven all whithers under our walls, and will

vent his mad vengeance on our rocky walls,

be in no mind to try and force his way into the city.

or fetch a thousand circles round the plain,

neither

till his spent coursers seek the fleet again:

will he ever sack it, dogs shall devour him ere he do so.

so may his rage be tired, and labour’d down!
and dogs shall tear him ere he sack the town.

”

”
“return!

hector looked fiercely at him and answered, “polydamas, your

words are not to my liking in that you bid us go back and be pent

within the city.

coop whole armies in our walls again?

have you not had enough of being cooped up

behind walls?

nine years imprison’d in those towers ye lay?

in the old-days the city of priam was famous the

wide o’er the world was ilion famed of old

whole world over for its wealth of gold and bronze, but our

for brass exhaustless, and for mines of gold:
but while inglorious in her walls we stay’d,

treasures are wasted out of our houses, and much goods have been

sunk were her treasures, and her stores decay’d;

sold away to phrygia and fair meonia, for the hand of jove has
been laid heavily upon us.
now, therefore, that the son of

the phrygians now her scatter’d spoils enjoy,

scheming saturn has vouchsafed me to win glory here and to hem

and proud mæonia wastes the fruits of troy.
great jove at length my arms to conquest calls,

the achaeans in at their ships, prate no more in this fool’s wise

and shuts the grecians in their wooden walls,
darest thou dispirit whom the gods incite?

among the people.

flies any trojan?

you will have no man with you; it shall not be;

i shall stop his flight.

do all of you as i now say;—take your suppers in your companies

to better counsel then attention lend;

throughout the host, and keep your watches and be wakeful every

take due refreshment, and the watch attend.

man of you.
if any trojan is uneasy about his possessions, let

if there be one whose riches cost him care,

him gather them and give them out among the people.

forth let him bring them for the troops to share;

better let

’tis better generously bestow’d on those,

these, rather than the achaeans, have them.

than left the plunder of our country’s foes.

at daybreak we will

soon as the morn the purple orient warms,

arm and fight about the ships; granted that achilles has again

fierce on yon navy will we pour our arms.

come forward to defend them, let it be as he will, but it shall

if great achilles rise in all his might,

go hard with him.
i shall not shun him, but will fight him, to

his be the danger: i shall stand the fight.

fall or conquer.

honour, ye gods!
or let me gain or give;

the god of war deals out like measure to all,

and live he glorious, whosoe’er shall live!
mars is our common lord, alike to all;

and the slayer may yet be slain.

and oft the victor triumphs, but to fall.

”

”

thus spoke hector; and the trojans, fools that they were, shouted

understanding.

their lament.

his clamorous grief the bellowing wood resounds.
so grieves achilles; and, impetuous, vents

the myrmidons saying, “alas!

“in what vain promise, gods!

vain were the words with which i

did i engage,

cheered the hero menoetius in his own house; i said that i would

when to console menoetius’ feeble age,

ilius and taken his share of the spoils—but jove does not give

charged with rich spoils, to fair opuntia’s shore?
[252]
but mighty jove cuts short, with just disdain,

all men their heart’s desire.

the long, long views of poor designing man!

the same soil shall be reddened

one fate the warrior and the friend shall strike,

here at troy by the blood of us both, for i too shall never be

and troy’s black sands must drink our blood alike:

welcomed home by the old knight peleus, nor by my mother thetis,

me too a wretched mother shall deplore,
an aged father never see me more!

but even in this place shall the earth cover me.

yet, my patroclus!

nevertheless, o

yet a space i stay,

patroclus, now that i am left behind you, i will not bury you,

then swift pursue thee on the darksome way.
ere thy dear relics in the grave are laid,

till i have brought hither the head and armour of mighty hector

shall hector’s head be offer’d to thy shade;

who has slain you.

that, with his arms, shall hang before thy shrine;

twelve noble sons of trojans will i behead

and twelve, the noblest of the trojan line,

before your bier to avenge you; till i have done so you shall lie

sacred to vengeance, by this hand expire;
their lives effused around thy flaming pyre.
thus let me lie till then!

as you are by the ships, and fair women of troy and dardanus,

thus, closely press’d,
bathe thy cold face, and sob upon thy breast!
while trojan captives here thy mourners stay,
weep all the night and murmur all the day:

whom we have taken with spear and strength of arm when we sacked

spoils of my arms, and thine; when, wasting wide,

men’s goodly cities, shall weep over you both night and day.

our swords kept time, and conquer’d side by side.

”

”

reach’d the vulcanian dome, eternal frame!
high-eminent amid the works divine,

heaven, a house of bronze wrought by the lame god’s own hands.

where heaven’s far-beaming brazen mansions shine.

she found him busy with his bellows, sweating and hard at work,

there the lame architect the goddess found,
obscure in smoke, his forges flaming round,
while bathed in sweat from fire to fire he flew;
and puffing loud, the roaring billows blew.
that day no common task his labour claim’d:

for he was making twenty tripods that were to stand by the wall

full twenty tripods for his hall he framed,

of his house, and he set wheels of gold under them all that they

that placed on living wheels of massy gold,

might go of their own selves to the assemblies of the gods, and
come back again—marvels indeed to see.

(wondrous to tell,) instinct with spirit roll’d

they were finished all but

answered, “then it is indeed an august and honoured goddess who

an ever-dear, an ever-honour’d name!

has come here; she it was that took care of me when i was
suffering from the heavy fall which i had through my cruel
mother’s anger—for she would have got rid of me because i was

when my proud mother hurl’d me from the sky,

lame.

(my awkward form, it seems, displeased her eye,)

it would have gone hardly with me had not eurynome,
daughter of the ever-encircling waters of oceanus, and thetis,

she, and eurynome, my griefs redress’d,

taken me to their bosom.

and soft received me on their silver breast.

nine years did i stay with them, and

even then these arts employ’d my infant thought:

many beautiful works in bronze, brooches, spiral armlets, cups,
and chains, did i make for them in their cave, with the roaring

chains, bracelets, pendants, all their toys, i wrought.

waters of oceanus foaming as they rushed ever past it; and no one

nine years kept secret in the dark abode,

knew, neither of gods nor men, save only thetis and eurynome who

secure i lay, conceal’d from man and god:

took care of me.

deep in a cavern’d rock my days were led;
the rushing ocean murmur’d o’er my head.

if, then, thetis has come to my house i must

now, since her presence glads our mansion, say,
for such desert what service can i pay?

make her due requital for having saved me; entertain her,

vouchsafe, o thetis!

therefore, with all hospitality, while i put by my bellows and

at our board to share
the genial rites, and hospitable fare;
while i the labours of the forge forego,

all my tools.

and bid the roaring bellows cease to blow.

who was but mortal, and who now stays at home worn out with age.

who, sinking now with age and sorrow, pays

but his native shore

(even while he lives, he wastes with secret woe;)

is in heaviness, and though i go to him i cannot help him; king

nor i, a goddess, can retard the blow!

agamemnon has made him give up the maiden whom the sons of the

robb’d of the prize the grecian suffrage gave,
the king of nations forced his royal slave:

achaeans had awarded him, and he wastes with sorrow for her sake.

for this he grieved; and, till the greeks oppress’d

then the trojans hemmed the achaeans in at their ships’ sterns

required his arm, he sorrow’d unredress’d.

and would not let them come forth; the elders, therefore, of the
argives besought achilles and offered him great treasure, whereon

large gifts they promise, and their elders send;

he refused to bring deliverance to them himself, but put his own

in vain—he arms not, but permits his friend

armour on patroclus and sent him into the fight with much people
after him.

his arms, his steeds, his forces to employ:

all day long they fought by the scaean gates and would

grace with immortal arms this short-lived son,

near at hand, with helmet and shield, with goodly greaves fitted

and to the field in martial pomp restore,

when his true comrade fell at the hands of the trojans, and he
now lies stretched on earth in the bitterness of his soul.

to shine with glory, till he shines no more!

when he had so said he left her and went to his bellows, turning
