to the black labours of his forge retires.

twenty

soon as he bade them blow, the bellows turn’d

bellows blew upon the melting-pots, and they blew blasts of every

their iron mouths; and where the furnace burn’d,
resounding breathed: at once the blast expires,
and twenty forges catch at once the fires;

kind, some fierce to help him when he had need of them, and

just as the god directs, now loud, now low,

others less strong as vulcan willed it in the course of his work.

they raise a tempest, or they gently blow;

he threw tough copper into the fire, and tin, with silver and

in hissing flames huge silver bars are roll’d,
and stubborn brass, and tin, and solid gold;

gold; he set his great anvil on its block, and with one hand

before, deep fix’d, the eternal anvils stand;
the ponderous hammer loads his better hand,
his left with tongs turns the vex’d metal round,

grasped his mighty hammer while he took the tongs in the other.

and thick, strong strokes, the doubling vaults rebound.

first he shaped the shield so great and strong, adorning it all

then first he form’d the immense and solid shield;
rich various artifice emblazed the field;

over and binding it round with a gleaming circuit in three

its utmost verge a threefold circle bound;[253]

layers; and the baldric was made of silver.

a silver chain suspends the massy round;

he made the shield in

five ample plates the broad expanse compose,

five thicknesses, and with many a wonder did his cunning hand

and godlike labours on the surface rose.

enrich it.

there shone the image of the master-mind:

he wrought the earth, the heavens, and the sea; the moon also at

there earth, there heaven, there ocean he design’d;

her full and the untiring sun, with all the signs that glorify

the unwearied sun, the moon completely round;

the face of heaven—the pleiads, the hyads, huge orion, and the

the starry lights that heaven’s high convex crown’d;
the pleiads, hyads, with the northern team;
and great orion’s more refulgent beam;
to which, around the axle of the sky,

bear, which men also call the wain and which turns round ever in

the bear, revolving, points his golden eye,

one place, facing orion, and alone never dips into the stream of

still shines exalted on the ethereal plain,

oceanus.

nor bathes his blazing forehead in the main.

he wrought also two cities, fair to see and busy with the hum of

two cities radiant on the shield appear,

men.

the image one of peace, and one of war.

in the one were weddings and wedding-feasts, and they were

here sacred pomp and genial feast delight,
and solemn dance, and hymeneal rite;

going about the city with brides whom they were escorting by

along the street the new-made brides are led,

torchlight from their chambers.
loud rose the cry of hymen, and

with torches flaming, to the nuptial bed:

the youths danced to the music of flute and lyre, while the women

the youthful dancers in a circle bound
to the soft flute, and cithern’s silver sound:

stood each at her house door to see them.

through the fair streets the matrons in a row
stand in their porches, and enjoy the show.

meanwhile the people were gathered in assembly, for there was a

there in the forum swarm a numerous train;

quarrel, and two men were wrangling about the blood-money for a

the subject of debate, a townsman slain:

man who had been killed, the one saying before the people that he
had paid damages in full, and the other that he had not been

one pleads the fine discharged, which one denied,

paid.

and bade the public and the laws decide:

each was trying to make his own case good, and the people

the witness is produced on either hand:

took sides, each man backing the side that he had taken; but the

for this, or that, the partial people stand:

heralds kept them back, and the elders sate on their seats of

the appointed heralds still the noisy bands,

stone in a solemn circle, holding the staves which the heralds

and form a ring, with sceptres in their hands:
on seats of stone, within the sacred place,[254]

had put into their hands.

the reverend elders nodded o’er the case;

then they rose and each in his turn

alternate, each the attesting sceptre took,
and rising solemn, each his sentence spoke.

gave judgement, and there were two talents laid down, to be given

two golden talents lay amidst, in sight,

to him whose judgement should be deemed the fairest.

the prize of him who best adjudged the right.

about the other city there lay encamped two hosts in gleaming

another part (a prospect differing far)[255]

armour, and they were divided whether to sack it, or to spare it

glow’d with refulgent arms, and horrid war.
two mighty hosts a leaguer’d town embrace,

and accept the half of what it contained.

and one would pillage, one would burn the place.

but the men of the city

meantime the townsmen, arm’d with silent care,

would not yet consent, and armed themselves for a surprise; their

a secret ambush on the foe prepare:

wives and little children kept guard upon the walls, and with

their wives, their children, and the watchful band

of trembling parents, on the turrets stand.

that followed were smaller.

august, divine, superior by the head!

when they reached the place where
they would lay their ambush, it was on a riverbed to which live
stock of all kinds would come from far and near to water; here,

a place for ambush fit they found, and stood,

then, they lay concealed, clad in full armour.

cover’d with shields, beside a silver flood.

some way off them
there were two scouts who were on the look-out for the coming of

two spies at distance lurk, and watchful seem

sheep or cattle, which presently came, followed by two shepherds

if sheep or oxen seek the winding stream.
soon the white flocks proceeded o’er the plains,
and steers slow-moving, and two shepherd swains;

who were playing on their pipes, and had not so much as a thought

behind them piping on their reeds they go,

of danger.

nor fear an ambush, nor suspect a foe.

when those who were in ambush saw this, they cut off

in arms the glittering squadron rising round

the flocks and herds and killed the shepherds.

rush sudden; hills of slaughter heap the ground;
whole flocks and herds lie bleeding on the plains,
and, all amidst them, dead, the shepherd swains!

meanwhile the
besiegers, when they heard much noise among the cattle as they

the bellowing oxen the besiegers hear;

sat in council, sprang to their horses, and made with all speed

they rise, take horse, approach, and meet the war,

the banks of the river, and the hosts aimed their bronze-shod

they fight, they fall, beside the silver flood;

spears at one another.

the waving silver seem’d to blush with blood.

there tumult, there contention stood confess’d;

fate who was dragging three men after her, one with a fresh

was dragging him along by his heel: and her robe was bedrabbled

now here, now there, the carcases they tore:

in men’s blood.

fate stalk’d amidst them, grim with human gore.

they went in and out with one another and fought

and the whole war came out, and met the eye;

as though they were living people haling away one another’s dead.

and each bold figure seem’d to live or die.

he wrought also a fair fallow field, large and thrice ploughed

already.

headland.

then back the turning ploughshares cleave the soil:

behind, the rising earth in ridges roll’d;

so that the field, though it was of gold, still looked as if it

and sable look’d, though form’d of molten gold.

were being ploughed—very curious to behold.

the gatherers follow, and collect in bands;

they tore his flesh, and drank his sable blood.

dread the grim terrors, and at distance bay.

that glittering gay, from silver belts depend.
now all at once they rise, at once descend,
with well-taught feet: now shape in oblique ways,
confusedly regular, the moving maze:
now forth at once, too swift for sight, they spring,

in a ring with merry twinkling feet, as it were a potter sitting

and undistinguish’d blend the flying ring:

argument.

achilles is reconciled with agamemnon, puts on the armour which

the reconciliation of achilles and agamemnon.
thetis brings to her son the armour made by vulcan.
she preserves the
body of his friend from corruption, and commands him to assemble the
army, to declare his resentment at an end.
agamemnon and achilles are
solemnly reconciled: the speeches, presents, and ceremonies on that
occasion.
achilles is with great difficulty persuaded to refrain from
the battle till the troops have refreshed themselves by the advice of
ulysses.
the presents are conveyed to the tent of achilles, where
briseïs laments over the body of patroclus.
the hero obstinately

vulcan had made him, and goes out to fight.

refuses all repast, and gives himself up to lamentations for his
friend.
minerva descends to strengthen him, by the order of jupiter.
he
arms for the fight: his appearance described.
he addresses himself to
his horses, and reproaches them with the death of patroclus.
one of
them is miraculously endued with voice, and inspired to prophesy his
fate: but the hero, not astonished by that prodigy, rushes with fury to
the combat.

now when dawn in robe of saffron was hasting from the streams of

the thirtieth day.
the scene is on the sea-shore.
soon as aurora heaved her orient head
above the waves, that blush’d with early red,

oceanus, to bring light to mortals and immortals, thetis reached

(with new-born day to gladden mortal sight,
and gild the courts of heaven with sacred light,)

the ships with the armour that the god had given her.

their sovereign’s sorrows in their own express’d.
a ray divine her heavenly presence shed,
and thus, his hand soft touching, thetis said:

“my son, grieve as we may we must let this man lie, for it is by

“suppress, my son, this rage of grief, and know

it was not man, but heaven, that gave the blow;

vulcan this rich and goodly armour, which no man has ever yet

borne upon his shoulders.

arms worthy thee, or fit to grace a god.

”

”

as she spoke she set the armour before achilles, and it rang out

then drops the radiant burden on the ground;

bravely as she did so.

the myrmidons were struck with awe, and

menoetius and breed worms about his wounds, so that his body, now

in those wide wounds through which his spirit fled,

he is dead, will be disfigured and the flesh will rot.

shall flies, and worms obscene, pollute the dead?

”

”

silver-footed thetis answered, “my son, be not disquieted about

i will find means to protect him from the swarms of

in battle.

(the azure goddess to her son replied,)

he may lie for a whole year, and his flesh shall still

whole years untouch’d, uninjured shall remain,

be as sound as ever, or even sounder.

fresh as in life, the carcase of the slain.

call, therefore, the

but go, achilles, as affairs require,

achaean heroes in assembly; unsay your anger against agamemnon;

before the grecian peers renounce thine ire:

arm at once, and fight with might and main.

then uncontroll’d in boundless war engage,
and heaven with strength supply the mighty rage!

”

”

as she spoke she put strength and courage into his heart, and she

the flies forbid their prey,

patroclus, that his body might suffer no change.

untouch’d it rests, and sacred from decay.

then achilles went out upon the sea-shore, and with a loud cry

achilles to the strand obedient went:
the shores resounded with the voice he sent.

called on the achaean heroes.

the heroes heard, and all the naval train

on this even those who as yet had
stayed always at the ships, the pilots and helmsmen, and even the

that tend the ships, or guide them o’er the main,

came to the place of assembly because achilles had shown himself

frequent and full, the great assembly crown’d;
studious to see the terror of the plain,

after having held aloof so long from fighting.

long lost to battle, shine in arms again.

two sons of mars,

tydides and ulysses first appear,

ulysses and the son of tydeus, came limping, for their wounds
still pained them; nevertheless they came, and took their seats

lame with their wounds, and leaning on the spear;

in the front row of the assembly.

these on the sacred seats of council placed,

last of all came agamemnon,

king of men, he too wounded, for coon son of antenor had struck

him with a spear in battle.

achilles (rising in the midst) begun:

when the achaeans were got together achilles rose and said, “son

“o monarch!

of atreus, surely it would have been better alike for both you

of thee, of me, of all the grecian state,

and me, when we two were in such high anger about briseis, surely

if (ere the day when by mad passion sway’d,
rash we contended for the black-eyed maid)

it would have been better, had diana’s arrow slain her at the

preventing dian had despatch’d her dart,

ships on the day when i took her after having sacked lyrnessus.

and shot the shining mischief to the heart!

for so, many an achaean the less would have bitten dust before

then many a hero had not press’d the shore,

the foe in the days of my anger.
it has been well for hector and

nor troy’s glad fields been fatten’d with our gore.

the trojans, but the achaeans will long indeed remember our

long, long shall greece the woes we caused bewail,

quarrel.

and sad posterity repeat the tale.

now, however, let it be, for it is over.

but this, no more the subject of debate,
is past, forgotten, and resign’d to fate.

if we have been

why should, alas, a mortal man, as i,

angry, necessity has schooled our anger.

burn with a fury that can never die?

i put it from me: i dare

here then my anger ends: let war succeed,

not nurse it for ever; therefore, bid the achaeans arm forthwith

and even as greece has bled, let ilion bleed.

that i may go out against the trojans, and learn whether they

now call the hosts, and try if in our sight

will be in a mind to sleep by the ships or no.

troy yet shall dare to camp a second night!

glad, i ween, will

i deem, their mightiest, when this arm he knows,

he be to rest his knees who may fly my spear when i wield it.

shall ’scape with transport, and with joy repose.

”

”

thus did he speak, and the achaeans rejoiced in that he had put

he said: his finish’d wrath with loud acclaim

away his anger.

the greeks accept, and shout pelides’ name.

then agamemnon spoke, rising in his place, and not going into the

when thus, not rising from his lofty throne,

middle of the assembly.

in state unmoved, the king of men begun:

“danaan heroes,” said he, “servants of

“hear me, ye sons of greece!

mars, it is well to listen when a man stands up to speak, and it
is not seemly to interrupt him, or it will go hard even with a
practised speaker.
who can either hear or speak in an uproar?

with silence hear!

even the finest orator will be disconcerted by it.

and grant your monarch an impartial ear:
awhile your loud, untimely joy suspend,

i will expound

and let your rash, injurious clamours end:

to the son of peleus, and do you other achaeans heed me and mark

unruly murmurs, or ill-timed applause,

me well.

wrong the best speaker, and the justest cause.

often have the achaeans spoken to me of this matter and

nor charge on me, ye greeks, the dire debate:

upbraided me, but it was not i that did it: jove, and fate, and

know, angry jove, and all-compelling fate,

erinys that walks in darkness struck me mad when we were
assembled on the day that i took from achilles the meed that had

with fell erinnys, urged my wrath that day

been awarded to him.

when from achilles’ arms i forced the prey.

what could i do?

what then could i against the will of heaven?

all things are in the hand

not by myself, but vengeful ate driven;

of heaven, and folly, eldest of jove’s daughters, shuts men’s

she, jove’s dread daughter, fated to infest

eyes to their destruction.

the race of mortals, enter’d in my breast.

she walks delicately, not on the solid

not on the ground that haughty fury treads,
but prints her lofty footsteps on the heads

earth, but hovers over the heads of men to make them stumble or

of mighty men; inflicting as she goes

to ensnare them.

long-festering wounds, inextricable woes!

“time was when she fooled jove himself, who they say is greatest

of old, she stalk’d amid the bright abodes;

whether of gods or men; for juno, woman though she was, beguiled

and jove himself, the sire of men and gods,
the world’s great ruler, felt her venom’d dart;
deceived by juno’s wiles, and female art:

him on the day when alcmena was to bring forth mighty hercules in

for when alcmena’s nine long months were run,

the fair city of thebes.

and jove expected his immortal son,

he told it out among the gods saying,

to gods and goddesses the unruly joy

he show’d, and vaunted of his matchless boy:

minded; this day shall an ilithuia, helper of women who are in

‘from us, (he said) this day an infant springs,

labour, bring a man child into the world who shall be lord over
all that dwell about him who are of my blood and lineage.

fated to rule, and born a king of kings.

’ then

’

said juno all crafty and full of guile, ‘you will play false, and
will not hold to your word.
swear me, o olympian, swear me a
great oath, that he who shall this day fall between the feet of a
woman, shall be lord over all that dwell about him who are of

saturnia ask’d an oath, to vouch the truth,

your blood and lineage.
’

and fix dominion on the favour’d youth.

“thus she spoke, and jove suspected her not, but swore the great

the thunderer, unsuspicious of the fraud,

oath, to his much ruing thereafter.

pronounced those solemn words that bind a god.

for juno darted down from the
high summit of olympus, and went in haste to achaean argos where

the joyful goddess, from olympus’ height,

she knew that the noble wife of sthenelus son of perseus then

swift to achaian argos bent her flight:

was.
she being with child and in her seventh month, juno brought

scarce seven moons gone, lay sthenelus’s wife;

the child to birth though there was a month still wanting, but

she push’d her lingering infant into life:

she stayed the offspring of alcmena, and kept back the ilithuiae.

her charms alcmena’s coming labours stay,

then she went to tell jove the son of saturn, and said, ‘father

and stop the babe, just issuing to the day.

jove, lord of the lightning—i have a word for your ear.

then bids saturnius bear his oath in mind;

there is

‘a youth (said she) of jove’s immortal kind

a fine child born this day, eurystheus, son to sthenelus the son
of perseus; he is of your lineage; it is well, therefore, that he

is this day born: from sthenelus he springs,

should reign over the argives.

and claims thy promise to be king of kings.

’

’

“on this jove was stung to the very quick, and in his rage he

grief seized the thunderer, by his oath engaged;
stung to the soul, he sorrow’d, and he raged.

caught folly by the hair, and swore a great oath that never

from his ambrosial head, where perch’d she sate,
he snatch’d the fury-goddess of debate,
the dread, the irrevocable oath he swore,

should she again invade starry heaven and olympus, for she was

the immortal seats should ne’er behold her more;
and whirl’d her headlong down, for ever driven
from bright olympus and the starry heaven:

the bane of all.
then he whirled her round with a twist of his
hand, and flung her down from heaven so that she fell on to the

thence on the nether world the fury fell;

fields of mortal men; and he was ever angry with her when he saw

ordain’d with man’s contentious race to dwell.

his son groaning under the cruel labours that eurystheus laid

full oft the god his son’s hard toils bemoan’d,
cursed the dire fury, and in secret groan’d.

upon him.

[258]

even so did i grieve when mighty hector was killing the

even thus, like jove himself, was i misled,

argives at their ships, and all the time i kept thinking of folly

while raging hector heap’d our camps with dead.

who had so baned me.

what can the errors of my rage atone?

i was blind, and jove robbed me of my
reason; i will now make atonement, and will add much treasure by

my martial troops, my treasures are thy own:

way of amends.

this instant from the navy shall be sent

go, therefore, into battle, you and your people

whate’er ulysses promised at thy tent:

with you.

but thou!

i will give you all that ulysses offered you yesterday
in your tents: or if it so please you, wait, though you would

appeased, propitious to our prayer,

fain fight at once, and my squires shall bring the gifts from my
ship, that you may see whether what i give you is enough.

resume thy arms, and shine again in war.

”

”

and achilles answered, “son of atreus, king of men agamemnon, you

“o king of nations!
whose superior sway
(returns achilles) all our hosts obey!

can give such gifts as you think proper, or you can withhold

to keep or send the presents, be thy care;

them: it is in your own hands.
let us now set battle in array; it

to us, ’tis equal: all we ask is war.

is not well to tarry talking about trifles, for there is a deed

while yet we talk, or but an instant shun

which is as yet to do.

the fight, our glorious work remains undone.

achilles shall again be seen fighting

let every greek, who sees my spear confound

among the foremost, and laying low the ranks of the trojans: bear

the trojan ranks, and deal destruction round,
with emulation, what i act survey,

this in mind each one of you when he is fighting.

and learn from thence the business of the day.

”

”

then ulysses said, “achilles, godlike and brave, send not the

the son of peleus thus; and thus replies
the great in councils, ithacus the wise:
“though, godlike, thou art by no toils oppress’d,

achaeans thus against ilius to fight the trojans fasting, for the

at least our armies claim repast and rest:

battle will be no brief one, when it is once begun, and heaven

long and laborious must the combat be,

has filled both sides with fury; bid them first take food both

when by the gods inspired, and led by thee.

bread and wine by the ships, for in this there is strength and

strength is derived from spirits and from blood,
and those augment by generous wine and food:

stay.

what boastful son of war, without that stay,

no man can do battle the livelong day to the going down of

can last a hero through a single day?

the sun if he is without food; however much he may want to fight

courage may prompt; but, ebbing out his strength,
mere unsupported man must yield at length;

his strength will fail him before he knows it; hunger and thirst

shrunk with dry famine, and with toils declined,

will find him out, and his limbs will grow weary under him.

the drooping body will desert the mind:

but a

but built anew with strength-conferring fare,

man can fight all day if he is full fed with meat and wine; his
heart beats high, and his strength will stay till he has routed

with limbs and soul untamed, he tires a war.

all his foes; therefore, send the people away and bid them

with strong repast to hearten every band;

and king agamemnon answered, “son of laertes, your words please

to him the monarch: “just is thy decree,

me well, for throughout you have spoken wisely.

thy words give joy, and wisdom breathes in thee.
each due atonement gladly i prepare;

i will swear as
you would have me do; i do so of my own free will, neither shall
i take the name of heaven in vain.

and heaven regard me as i justly swear!

ulysses answered, “achilles, son of peleus, mightiest of all the

“o first of greeks, (ulysses thus rejoin’d,)

achaeans, in battle you are better than i, and that more than a

the best and bravest of the warrior kind!
thy praise it is in dreadful camps to shine,

little, but in counsel i am much before you, for i am older and
of greater knowledge.

but old experience and calm wisdom mine.

therefore be patient under my words.

then hear my counsel, and to reason yield,

fighting is a thing of which men soon surfeit, and when jove, who

the bravest soon are satiate of the field;

is war’s steward, weighs the upshot, it may well prove that the
straw which our sickles have reaped is far heavier than the

though vast the heaps that strow the crimson plain,

grain.

the bloody harvest brings but little gain:

it may not be that the achaeans should mourn the dead with

the scale of conquest ever wavering lies,

their bellies; day by day men fall thick and threefold

great jove but turns it, and the victor dies!
the great, the bold, by thousands daily fall,

continually; when should we have respite from our sorrow?

and endless were the grief, to weep for all.
eternal sorrows what avails to shed?
greece honours not with solemn fasts the dead:
enough, when death demands the brave, to pay

let us

the tribute of a melancholy day.

mourn our dead for a day and bury them out of sight and mind, but

one chief with patience to the grave resign’d,

let those of us who are left eat and drink that we may arm and

our care devolves on others left behind.
let generous food supplies of strength produce,
let rising spirits flow from sprightly juice,

fight our foes more fiercely.

let their warm heads with scenes of battle glow,
and pour new furies on the feebler foe.

in that hour let no man hold back,

yet a short interval, and none shall dare

waiting for a second summons; such summons shall bode ill for him

expect a second summons to the war;
who waits for that, the dire effects shall find,

who is found lagging behind at our ships; let us rather sally as

if trembling in the ships he lags behind.
embodied, to the battle let us bend,

one man and loose the fury of war upon the trojans.

and all at once on haughty troy descend.

”

who rule the dead, and horrid woes prepare
for perjured kings, and all who falsely swear!

swear falsely, that i have laid no hand upon the girl briseis,

the black-eyed maid inviolate removes,

neither to take her to my bed nor otherwise, but that she has
remained in my tents inviolate.

pure and unconscious of my manly loves.

and levell’d thunder strike my guilty head!

the son of

nor from my arms, unwilling, force the dame.

surely jove

must have counselled the destruction of many an argive.

that doom’d our strife, and doom’d the greeks to fall.

go, now,

go then, ye chiefs!

briseis, fair as venus, when she saw the mangled body of

briseïs, radiant as the queen of love,
slow as she pass’d, beheld with sad survey
where, gash’d with cruel wounds, patroclus lay.
prone on the body fell the heavenly fair,

patroclus, flung herself upon it and cried aloud, tearing her
breast, her neck, and her lovely face with both her hands.

beat her sad breast, and tore her golden hair;

beautiful as a goddess she wept and said, “patroclus, dearest

all beautiful in grief, her humid eyes
shining with tears she lifts, and thus she cries:
“ah, youth for ever dear, for ever kind,

friend, when i went hence i left you living; i return, o prince,

once tender friend of my distracted mind!

to find you dead; thus do fresh sorrows multiply upon me one

i left thee fresh in life, in beauty gay;
now find thee cold, inanimated clay!
what woes my wretched race of life attend!

after the other.

sorrows on sorrows, never doom’d to end!

i saw him to whom my father and mother married

the first loved consort of my virgin bed

me, cut down before our city, and my three own dear brothers

before these eyes in fatal battle bled:
my three brave brothers in one mournful day

perished with him on the self-same day; but you, patroclus, even

all trod the dark, irremeable way:
thy friendly hand uprear’d me from the plain,

when achilles slew my husband and sacked the city of noble mynes,

and dried my sorrows for a husband slain;

told me that i was not to weep, for you said you would make

achilles’ care you promised i should prove,

achilles marry me, and take me back with him to phthia, we should

the first, the dearest partner of his love;
that rites divine should ratify the band,
and make me empress in his native land.

have a wedding feast among the myrmidons.

accept these grateful tears!

you were always kind to

for thee they flow,

me and i shall never cease to grieve for you.

for thee, that ever felt another’s woe!

”

”

she wept as she spoke, and the women joined in her lament-making

her sister captives echoed groan for groan,

as though their tears were for patroclus, but in truth each was
weeping for her own sorrows.

nor mourn’d patroclus’ fortunes, but their own.

the elders of the achaeans gathered

round achilles and prayed him to take food, but he groaned and
would not do so.

“i pray you,” said he, “if any comrade will hear

“if yet achilles have a friend, whose care

me, bid me neither eat nor drink, for i am in great heaviness,

is bent to please him, this request forbear;

and will stay fasting even to the going down of the sun.

till yonder sun descend, ah, let me pay
to grief and anguish one abstemious day.

and, like the moon, the broad refulgent shield

as the light seen by sailors from out

blazed with long rays, and gleam’d athwart the field.
so to night-wandering sailors, pale with fears,
wide o’er the watery waste, a light appears,

at sea, when men have lit a fire in their homestead high up among
the mountains, but the sailors are carried out to sea by wind and
storm far from the haven where they would be—even so did the

which on the far-seen mountain blazing high,

gleam of achilles’ wondrous shield strike up into the heavens.

streams from some lonely watch-tower to the sky:

he

with mournful eyes they gaze, and gaze again;

lifted the redoubtable helmet, and set it upon his head, from

loud howls the storm, and drives them o’er the main.
next, his high head the helmet graced; behind

whence it shone like a star, and the golden plumes which vulcan

the sweepy crest hung floating in the wind:
like the red star, that from his flaming hair
shakes down diseases, pestilence, and war;
so stream’d the golden honours from his head,

had set thick about the ridge of the helmet, waved all around it.

trembled the sparkling plumes, and the loose glories shed.

then achilles made trial of himself in his armour to see whether

the chief beholds himself with wondering eyes;

it fitted him, so that his limbs could play freely under it, and

his arms he poises, and his motions tries;

it seemed to buoy him up as though it had been wings.

buoy’d by some inward force, he seems to swim,
and feels a pinion lifting every limb.

he also drew his father’s spear out of the spear-stand, a spear

and now he shakes his great paternal spear,

ponderous and huge, which not a greek could rear,

then fleet xanthus answered under the yoke—for white-armed juno

when, strange to tell!

“achilles!

“dread achilles,” said he, “we will indeed save you now, but the

yes!

day of your death is near, and the blame will not be ours, for it

this day at least we bear
thy rage in safety through the files of war:
but come it will, the fatal time must come,

will be heaven and stern fate that will destroy you.

not ours the fault, but god decrees thy doom.

neither was
it through any sloth or slackness on our part that the trojans

not through our crime, or slowness in the course,

stripped patroclus of his armour; it was the mighty god whom

fell thy patroclus, but by heavenly force;

lovely leto bore that slew him as he fought among the foremost,

the bright far-shooting god who gilds the day

and vouchsafed a triumph to hector.

(confess’d we saw him) tore his arms away.

we two can fly as swiftly as

no—could our swiftness o’er the winds prevail,

zephyrus who they say is fleetest of all winds; nevertheless it

or beat the pinions of the western gale,
all were in vain—the fates thy death demand,

is your doom to fall by the hand of a man and of a god.

due to a mortal and immortal hand.

”

”

when he had thus said the erinyes stayed his speech, and achilles

then ceased for ever, by the furies tied,
his fateful voice.

answered him in great sadness, saying, “why, o xanthus, do you

the intrepid chief replied
with unabated rage—“so let it be!

thus foretell my death?

portents and prodigies are lost on me.

you need not do so, for i well know that

i know my fate: to die, to see no more

i am to fall here, far from my dear father and mother; none the

my much-loved parents, and my native shore—

more, however, shall i stay my hand till i have given the trojans

enough—when heaven ordains, i sink in night:

their fill of fighting.

now perish troy!
” he said, and rush’d to fight.

”
so saying, with a loud cry he drove his horses to the front.

their several sides and went into battle.

on adverse parts the warring gods engage:

juno, pallas minerva,

heaven’s awful queen; and he whose azure round

girds the vast globe; the maid in arms renown’d;

excellent in all cunning—all these joined the host that came from

hermes, of profitable arts the sire;

the ships; with them also came vulcan in all his glory, limping,

and vulcan, the black sovereign of the fire:
these to the fleet repair with instant flight;

but yet with his thin legs plying lustily under him.

the vessels tremble as the gods alight.

long lost to battle, shone in arms again.

there was not a trojan but his limbs

pale troy beheld, and seem’d already lost;

failed him for fear as he beheld the fleet son of peleus all

her bravest heroes pant with inward fear,

glorious in his armour, and looking like mars himself.

and trembling see another god of war.

when,

earth echoes, and the nations rush to arms.

hades, king of the realms below,

deep in the dismal regions of the dead,[260]

was struck with fear; he sprang panic-stricken from his throne
and cried aloud in terror lest neptune, lord of the earthquake,

the infernal monarch rear’d his horrid head,

should crack the ground over his head, and lay bare his mouldy

leap’d from his throne, lest neptune’s arm should lay

mansions to the sight of mortals and immortals—mansions so

his dark dominions open to the day,
and pour in light on pluto’s drear abodes,

ghastly grim that even the gods shudder to think of them.

abhorr’d by men, and dreadful even to gods.

such

was the uproar as the gods came together in battle.

and bathed his brazen lance in hostile gore.

no man may fight achilles, for

what mortal man achilles can sustain?

one of the gods is always with him as his guardian angel, and

the immortals guard him through the dreadful plain,

even were it not so, his weapon flies ever straight, and fails
not to pierce the flesh of him who is against him; if heaven

and suffer not his dart to fall in vain.

would let me fight him on even terms he should not soon overcome

were god my aid, this arm should check his power,

me, though he boasts that he is made of bronze.

though strong in battle as a brazen tower.

the gleaming champaign glows with brazen light.

the foremost of them all, met between the hosts to fight—to wit,

amid both hosts (a dreadful space) appear,

aeneas son of anchises, and noble achilles.

there great achilles; bold æneas, here.

aeneas was first to stride forward in attack, his doughty helmet

with towering strides æneas first advanced;
the nodding plumage on his helmet danced:
spread o’er his breast the fencing shield he bore,

tossing defiance as he came on.

and, so he moved, his javelin flamed before.

he held his strong shield before

not so pelides; furious to engage,

his breast, and brandished his bronze spear.

he rush’d impetuous.

the son of peleus

such the lion’s rage,

from the other side sprang forth to meet him, like some fierce

who viewing first his foes with scornful eyes,

lion that the whole country-side has met to hunt and kill—at

though all in arms the peopled city rise,

first he bodes no ill, but when some daring youth has struck him

stalks careless on, with unregarding pride;
till at the length, by some brave youth defied,

with a spear, he crouches openmouthed, his jaws foam, he roars

to his bold spear the savage turns alone,
he murmurs fury with a hollow groan;
he grins, he foams, he rolls his eyes around,

with fury, he lashes his tail from side to side about his ribs

lash’d by his tail his heaving sides resound;

and loins, and glares as he springs straight before him, to find

he calls up all his rage; he grinds his teeth,

out whether he is to slay, or be slain among the foremost of his

resolved on vengeance, or resolved on death.

foes—even with such fury did achilles burn to spring upon aeneas.

so fierce achilles on æneas flies;
so stands æneas, and his force defies.

when they were now close up with one another achilles was first

ere yet the stern encounter join’d, begun

to speak.

the seed of thetis thus to venus’ son:

“aeneas,” said he, “why do you stand thus out before

“why comes æneas through the ranks so far?

the host to fight me?

seeks he to meet achilles’ arm in war,

is it that you hope to reign over the

in hope the realms of priam to enjoy,

trojans in the seat of priam?

and prove his merits to the throne of troy?

nay, though you kill me priam will

grant that beneath thy lance achilles dies,

not hand his kingdom over to you.

the partial monarch may refuse the prize;

he is a man of sound judgement,

sons he has many; those thy pride may quell:

and he has sons of his own.

and ’tis his fault to love those sons too well,

or have the trojans been allotting

or, in reward of thy victorious hand,
has troy proposed some spacious tract of land,

you a demesne of passing richness, fair with orchard lawns and

an ample forest, or a fair domain,

corn lands, if you should slay me?

of hills for vines, and arable for grain?

this you shall hardly do.

even this, perhaps, will hardly prove thy lot.

i

but can achilles be so soon forgot?

have discomfited you once already.
have you forgotten how when

once (as i think) you saw this brandish’d spear,

you were alone i chased you from your herds helter-skelter down

and then the great æneas seem’d to fear:

the slopes of ida?

with hearty haste from ida’s mount he fled,

you did not turn round to look behind you; you

nor, till he reach’d lyrnessus, turn’d his head.
her lofty walls not long our progress stay’d;

took refuge in lyrnessus, but i attacked the city, and with the
help of minerva and father jove i sacked it and carried its women

those, pallas, jove, and we, in ruins laid:

into captivity, though jove and the other gods rescued you.

in grecian chains her captive race were cast;

you

’tis true, the great æneas fled too fast.

think they will protect you now, but they will not do so;

defrauded of my conquest once before,

therefore i say go back into the host, and do not face me, or you

what then i lost, the gods this day restore.

will rue it.

go; while thou may’st, avoid the threaten’d fate;

even a fool may be wise after the event.

fools stay to feel it, and are wise too late.

”

”

then aeneas answered, “son of peleus, think not that your words

to this anchises’ son: “such words employ

can scare me as though i were a child.

to one that fears thee, some unwarlike boy;

i too, if i will, can brag

such we disdain; the best may be defied

and talk unseemly.

with mean reproaches, and unmanly pride;

we know one another’s race and parentage as

unworthy the high race from which we came

matters of common fame, though neither have you ever seen my

proclaim’d so loudly by the voice of fame:

parents nor i yours.
men say that you are son to noble peleus,
and that your mother is thetis, fair-haired daughter of the sea.

each from illustrious fathers draws his line;

i have noble anchises for my father, and venus for my mother; the

each goddess-born; half human, half divine.

parents of one or other of us shall this day mourn a son, for it

thetis’ this day, or venus’ offspring dies,

will be more than silly talk that shall part us when the fight is

and tears shall trickle from celestial eyes:
for when two heroes, thus derived, contend,

over.

’tis not in words the glorious strife can end.

learn, then, my lineage if you will—and it is known to

if yet thou further seek to learn my birth

many.

(a tale resounded through the spacious earth)

“in the beginning dardanus was the son of jove, and founded

hear how the glorious origin we prove
from ancient dardanus, the first from jove:

dardania, for ilius was not yet stablished on the plain for men

dardania’s walls he raised; for ilion, then,
(the city since of many-languaged men,)
was not.

to dwell in, and her people still abode on the spurs of

the natives were content to till

many-fountained ida.

the shady foot of ida’s fountful hill.
[264]

dardanus had a son, king erichthonius, who

from dardanus great erichthonius springs,

was wealthiest of all men living; he had three thousand mares

the richest, once, of asia’s wealthy kings;
three thousand mares his spacious pastures bred,

that fed by the water-meadows, they and their foals with them.

three thousand foals beside their mothers fed.

boreas was enamoured of them as they were feeding, and covered

boreas, enamour’d of the sprightly train,
conceal’d his godhead in a flowing mane,
with voice dissembled to his loves he neigh’d,

them in the semblance of a dark-maned stallion.

and coursed the dappled beauties o’er the mead:

twelve filly

hence sprung twelve others of unrivall’d kind,

foals did they conceive and bear him, and these, as they sped

swift as their mother mares, and father wind.

over the rich plain, would go bounding on over the ripe ears of

these lightly skimming, when they swept the plain,

corn and not break them; or again when they would disport

nor plied the grass, nor bent the tender grain;

themselves on the broad back of ocean they could gallop on the

and when along the level seas they flew,[265]

crest of a breaker.

scarce on the surface curl’d the briny dew.

erichthonius begat tros, king of the trojans,

such erichthonius was: from him there came
the sacred tros, of whom the trojan name.

and tros had three noble sons, ilus, assaracus, and ganymede who

three sons renown’d adorn’d his nuptial bed,
ilus, assaracus, and ganymed:

was comeliest of mortal men; wherefore the gods carried him off

the matchless ganymed, divinely fair,
whom heaven, enamour’d, snatch’d to upper air,

to be jove’s cup-bearer, for his beauty’s sake, that he might

to bear the cup of jove (ethereal guest,

dwell among the immortals.

the grace and glory of the ambrosial feast).
the two remaining sons the line divide:

ilus begat laomedon, and laomedon

first rose laomedon from ilus’ side;

begat tithonus, priam, lampus, clytius, and hiketaon of the stock

from him tithonus, now in cares grown old,
and priam, bless’d with hector, brave and bold;
clytius and lampus, ever-honour’d pair;

of mars.

and hicetaon, thunderbolt of war.

but assaracus was father to capys, and capys to

from great assaracus sprang capys, he

anchises, who was my father, while hector is son to priam.

begat anchises, and anchises me.

“such do i declare my blood and lineage, but as for valour, jove

such is our race: ’tis fortune gives us birth,
but jove alone endues the soul with worth:

gives it or takes it as he will, for he is lord of all.
and now

he, source of power and might!

let there be no more of this prating in mid-battle as though we

with boundless sway,

were children.

all human courage gives, or takes away.

we could fling taunts without end at one another;

long in the field of words we may contend,
reproach is infinite, and knows no end,

a hundred-oared galley would not hold them.

arm’d or with truth or falsehood, right or wrong;

the tongue can run

so voluble a weapon is the tongue;

all whithers and talk all wise; it can go here and there, and as

wounded, we wound; and neither side can fail,

a man says, so shall he be gainsaid.
what is the use of our

for every man has equal strength to rail:

bandying hard like women who when they fall foul of one another

women alone, when in the streets they jar,

go out and wrangle in the streets, one half true and the other

perhaps excel us in this wordy war;

lies, as rage inspires them?

like us they stand, encompass’d with the crowd,
and vent their anger impotent and loud.

no words of yours shall turn me now

cease then—our business in the field of fight

that i am fain to fight—therefore let us make trial of one

is not to question, but to prove our might.
to all those insults thou hast offer’d here,

another with our spears.

receive this answer: ’tis my flying spear.

”

”
he spoke.

as he spoke he drove his spear at the great and terrible shield

with all his force the javelin flung,

of achilles, which rang out as the point struck it.

fix’d deep, and loudly in the buckler rung.

the son of

there stuck the lance.

vanquished by the son of peleus.

by phœbus urged; but phœbus has bestow’d

the counsel of apollo.

and can ye see this righteous chief atone

apollo will never save him from
destruction.
why should this man suffer when he is guiltless, to
no purpose, and in another’s quarrel?
has he not at all times

with guiltless blood for vices not his own?

offered acceptable sacrifice to the gods that dwell in heaven?

to all the gods his constant vows were paid;

let us then snatch him from death’s jaws, lest the son of saturn

sure, though he wars for troy, he claims our aid.

be angry should achilles slay him.

fate wills not this; nor thus can jove resign

it is fated, moreover, that he

the future father of the dardan line:[266]

should escape, and that the race of dardanus, whom jove loved

the first great ancestor obtain’d his grace,

above all the sons born to him of mortal women, shall not perish

and still his love descends on all the race:

utterly without seed or sign.

for priam now, and priam’s faithless kind,

for now indeed has jove hated the

at length are odious to the all-seeing mind;

blood of priam, while aeneas shall reign over the trojans, he and

on great æneas shall devolve the reign,

his children’s children that shall be born hereafter.

and sons succeeding sons the lasting line sustain.

”

”

then answered juno, “earth-shaker, look to this matter yourself,

the great earth-shaker thus: to whom replies

and consider concerning aeneas, whether you will save him, or

the imperial goddess with the radiant eyes:

suffer him, brave though he be, to fall by the hand of achilles

“good as he is, to immolate or spare

son of peleus.

the dardan prince, o neptune!
be thy care;

for of a truth we two, i and pallas minerva, have
sworn full many a time before all the immortals, that never would

pallas and i, by all that gods can bind,

we shield trojans from destruction, not even when all troy is

have sworn destruction to the trojan kind;
not even an instant to protract their fate,

burning in the flames that the achaeans shall kindle.

or save one member of the sinking state;
till her last flame be quench’d with her last gore,
and even her crumbling ruins are no more.

”

”

when earth-encircling neptune heard this he went into the battle

the king of ocean to the fight descends,
through all the whistling darts his course he bends,

amid the clash of spears, and came to the place where achilles

swift interposed between the warrior flies,

and aeneas were.

then he

the dardan prince, and bore him through the sky,

smooth-gliding without step, above the heads

fighting the son of peleus, who is both a mightier man of valour

“what power, o prince!
with force inferior far,

and more beloved of heaven than you are?

urged thee to meet achilles’ arm in war?

give way before him

henceforth beware, nor antedate thy doom,

whensoever you meet him, lest you go down to the house of hades

defrauding fate of all thy fame to come.

even though fate would have it otherwise.

but when the day decreed (for come it must)

when achilles is dead

shall lay this dreadful hero in the dust,

you may then fight among the foremost undaunted, for none other

let then the furies of that arm be known,

of the achaeans shall slay you.

secure no grecian force transcends thy own.

”

the god left him when he had given him these instructions, and at

then from achilles chased the mist away:

opened them wide indeed and said in great anger, “alas!

sudden, returning with a stream of light,

what

the scene of war came rushing on his sight.

marvel am i now beholding?

then thus, amazed; “what wonders strike my mind!

here is my spear upon the ground, but

my spear, that parted on the wings of wind,
laid here before me!
and the dardan lord,
that fell this instant, vanish’d from my sword!

i see not him whom i meant to kill when i hurled it.
of a truth

i thought alone with mortals to contend,

aeneas also must be under heaven’s protection, although i had

but powers celestial sure this foe defend.

thought his boasting was idle.
let him go hang; he will be in no
mood to fight me further, seeing how narrowly he has missed being

great as he is, our arms he scarce will try,

killed.

content for once, with all his gods, to fly.

i will now give my orders to the danaans and attack some
other of the trojans.

now then let others bleed.

”

” this said, aloud

he sprang forward along the line and cheered his men on as he did

he vents his fury and inflames the crowd:

so.

“o greeks!

“let not the trojans,” he cried, “keep you at arm’s length,

(he cries, and every rank alarms)

achaeans, but go for them and fight them man for man.

join battle, man to man, and arms to arms!

however

’tis not in me, though favour’d by the sky,

valiant i may be, i cannot give chase to so many and fight all of

to mow whole troops, and make whole armies fly:

them.

no god can singly such a host engage,

even mars, who is an immortal, or minerva, would shrink
from flinging himself into the jaws of such a fight and laying

not mars himself, nor great minerva’s rage.

about him; nevertheless, so far as in me lies i will show no

but whatsoe’er achilles can inspire,

slackness of hand or foot nor want of endurance, not even for a

whate’er of active force, or acting fire;
whate’er this heart can prompt, or hand obey;

moment; i will utterly break their ranks, and woe to the trojan

all, all achilles, greeks!

who shall venture within reach of my spear.

is yours to-day.
through yon wide host this arm shall scatter fear,
and thin the squadrons with my single spear.

”

”

thus did he exhort them.

he said: nor less elate with martial joy,

meanwhile hector called upon the trojans

the godlike hector warm’d the troops of troy:

and declared that he would fight achilles.

“trojans, to war!

“be not afraid, proud

think, hector leads you on;

trojans,” said he, “to face the son of peleus; i could fight gods

nor dread the vaunts of peleus’ haughty son.

myself if the battle were one of words only, but they would be
more than a match for me, if we had to use our spears.

deeds must decide our fate.

even so

e’en these with words

the deed of achilles will fall somewhat short of his word; he

insult the brave, who tremble at their swords:
the weakest atheist-wretch all heaven defies,

will do in part, and the other part he will clip short.

but shrinks and shudders when the thunder flies.

i will go

nor from yon boaster shall your chief retire,

up against him though his hands be as fire—though his hands be

not though his heart were steel, his hands were fire;

fire and his strength iron.

that fire, that steel, your hector should withstand,
and brave that vengeful heart, that dreadful hand.

”

”

thus urged the trojans lifted up their spears against the

he hears, obedient to the god of light,

on towards him, and split it clean in two; whereon he fell

the parted visage falls on equal sides:

the trojan earth

demoleon, a valiant man of war and son to antenor.

breathless in dust, the price of rashness paid.

he struck him

the impatient steel with full-descending sway

on the temple through his bronze-cheeked helmet.

forced through his brazen helm its furious way,

the helmet did
not stay the spear, but it went right on, crushing the bone so

resistless drove the batter’d skull before,

that the brain inside was shed in all directions, and his lust of
fighting was ended.

and dash’d and mingled all the brains with gore.

then he struck hippodamas in the midriff as

this sees hippodamas, and seized with fright,

he was springing down from his chariot in front of him, and

deserts his chariot for a swifter flight:
the lance arrests him: an ignoble wound

trying to escape.

the panting trojan rivets to the ground.

he breathed his last, bellowing like a bull

he groans away his soul: not louder roars,

bellows when young men are dragging him to offer him in sacrifice

at neptune’s shrine on helicè’s high shores,

to the king of helice, and the heart of the earth-shaker is glad;

the victim bull; the rocks re-bellow round,

even so did he bellow as he lay dying.

and ocean listens to the grateful sound.

achilles then went in
pursuit of polydorus son of priam, whom his father had always

then fell on polydore his vengeful rage,[268]

forbidden to fight because he was the youngest of his sons, the

the youngest hope of priam’s stooping age:

one he loved best, and the fastest runner.

(whose feet for swiftness in the race surpass’d:)
of all his sons, the dearest, and the last.

he, in his folly and

to the forbidden field he takes his flight,
in the first folly of a youthful knight,

“son of peleus, think not that your words can scare me as though

hector, undaunted, thus: “such words employ

i were a child; i too if i will can brag and talk unseemly; i

to one that dreads thee, some unwarlike boy:
such we could give, defying and defied,
mean intercourse of obloquy and pride!

know that you are a mighty warrior, mightier by far than i,

i know thy force to mine superior far;

nevertheless the issue lies in the lap of heaven whether i, worse

but heaven alone confers success in war:

man though i be, may not slay you with my spear, for this too has

mean as i am, the gods may guide my dart,

been found keen ere now.

and give it entrance in a braver heart.

that one the spear destroy’d, and one the sword.

there was also tros the son of

nor less unpitied, young alastor bleeds;

that he would spare him and not kill him but let him go, because

they were both of the same age.

to spare a form, an age so like thy own!

fool, he might have known that he

unhappy boy!

should not prevail with him, for the man was in no mood for pity

or forbearance but was in grim earnest.

e’er bent that fierce, inexorable heart!

therefore when tros laid

while yet he trembled at his knees, and cried,

drove his sword into his liver, and the liver came rolling out,

the ruthless falchion oped his tender side;

while his bosom was all covered with the black blood that welled
from the wound.

the panting liver pours a flood of gore

thus did death close his eyes as he lay lifeless.

that drowns his bosom till he pants no more.

achilles then went up to mulius and struck him on the ear with a

spear, and the bronze spear-head came right out at the other ear.

the warrior falls, transfix’d from ear to ear.

he also struck echeclus son of agenor on the head with his sword,

thy life, echeclus!
next the sword bereaves,
deep though the front the ponderous falchion cleaves;

which became warm with the blood, while death and stern fate

the purple death comes floating o’er his eyes.

then brave deucalion died: the dart was flung

he dropp’d his arm, an unassisting weight,

the elbow are united, whereon he waited achilles’ onset with his

and stood all impotent, expecting fate:

arm hanging down and death staring him in the face.
achilles cut

full on his neck the falling falchion sped,

his head off with a blow from his sword and flung it helmet and

from his broad shoulders hew’d his crested head:

all away from him, and the marrow came oozing out of his backbone

forth from the bone the spinal marrow flies,

as he lay.

and, sunk in dust, the corpse extended lies.

he then went in pursuit of rhigmus, noble son of

rhigmas, whose race from fruitful thracia came,
(the son of pierus, an illustrious name,)

peires, who had come from fertile thrace, and struck him through
the middle with a spear which fixed itself in his belly, so that

succeeds to fate: the spear his belly rends;

he fell headlong from his chariot.

prone from his car the thundering chief descends.

he also speared areithous

the squire, who saw expiring on the ground

squire to rhigmus in the back as he was turning his horses in

his prostrate master, rein’d the steeds around;

flight, and thrust him from his chariot, while the horses were

his back, scarce turn’d, the pelian javelin gored,

struck with panic.

and stretch’d the servant o’er his dying lord.

as a fire raging in some mountain glen after long drought—and the

as when a flame the winding valley fills,
and runs on crackling shrubs between the hills;
then o’er the stubble up the mountain flies,

dense forest is in a blaze, while the wind carries great tongues

fires the high woods, and blazes to the skies,

of fire in every direction—even so furiously did achilles rage,

this way and that, the spreading torrent roars:

wielding his spear as though he were a god, and giving chase to

so sweeps the hero through the wasted shores;
around him wide, immense destruction pours

those whom he would slay, till the dark earth ran with blood.

and earth is deluged with the sanguine showers,

or
as one who yokes broad-browed oxen that they may tread barley in

as with autumnal harvests cover’d o’er,

a threshing-floor—and it is soon bruised small under the feet of

and thick bestrewn, lies ceres’ sacred floor;
when round and round, with never-wearied pain,

the lowing cattle—even so did the horses of achilles trample on

the trampling steers beat out the unnumber’d grain:
so the fierce coursers, as the chariot rolls,

the shields and bodies of the slain.

tread down whole ranks, and crush out heroes’ souls,

the axle underneath and the

dash’d from their hoofs while o’er the dead they fly,

railing that ran round the car were bespattered with clots of

black, bloody drops the smoking chariot dye:
the spiky wheels through heaps of carnage tore;
and thick the groaning axles dropp’d with gore.
high o’er the scene of death achilles stood,

blood thrown up by the horses’ hoofs, and from the tyres of the

all grim with dust, all horrible in blood:

wheels; but the son of peleus pressed on to win still further

yet still insatiate, still with rage on flame;

glory, and his hands were bedrabbled with gore.

such is the lust of never-dying fame!

[illustration: ] centaur

argument.

the fight between achilles and the river scamander—the gods fight

the battle in the river scamander.

among themselves—achilles drives the trojans within their gates.

[269]
the trojans fly before achilles, some towards the town, others to the

now when they came to the ford of the full-flowing river xanthus,

river scamander: he falls upon the latter with great slaughter: takes

begotten of immortal jove, achilles cut their forces in two: one

twelve captives alive, to sacrifice to the shade of patroclus; and
kills lycaon and asteropeus.
scamander attacks him with all his waves:
neptune and pallas assist the hero: simois joins scamander: at length

half he chased over the plain towards the city by the same way

city.

the same day continues.

silver-eddying stream, and fell into it with a great uproar.

the scene is on the banks and in the stream

the

of scamander.

waters resounded, and the banks rang again, as they swam hither

and now to xanthus’ gliding stream they drove,
xanthus, immortal progeny of jove.
the river here divides the flying train,
part to the town fly diverse o’er the plain,
where late their troops triumphant bore the fight,
now chased, and trembling in ignoble flight:
(these with a gathered mist saturnia shrouds,
and rolls behind the rout a heap of clouds:)
part plunge into the stream: old xanthus roars,
the flashing billows beat the whiten’d shores:
with cries promiscuous all the banks resound,

and thither with loud cries amid the whirling eddies.

and here, and there, in eddies whirling round,
the flouncing steeds and shrieking warriors drown’d.

as locusts

as the scorch’d locusts from their fields retire,

flying to a river before the blast of a grass fire—the flame

while fast behind them runs the blaze of fire;

comes on and on till at last it overtakes them and they huddle

driven from the land before the smoky cloud,

into the water—even so was the eddying stream of xanthus filled

the clustering legions rush into the flood:
so, plunged in xanthus by achilles’ force,

with the uproar of men and horses, all struggling in confusion

roars the resounding surge with men and horse.

before achilles.
forthwith the hero left his spear upon the bank, leaning it

his bloody lance the hero casts aside,

against a tamarisk bush, and plunged into the river like a god,

(which spreading tamarisks on the margin hide,)
then, like a god, the rapid billows braves,

armed with his sword only.

arm’d with his sword, high brandish’d o’er the waves:

fell was his purpose as he hewed the

now down he plunges, now he whirls it round,

trojans down on every side.

deep groan’d the waters with the dying sound;

their dying groans rose hideous as

repeated wounds the reddening river dyed,

the sword smote them, and the river ran red with blood.

and the warm purple circled on the tide.
swift through the foamy flood the trojans fly,

as when

and close in rocks or winding caverns lie:

fish fly scared before a huge dolphin, and fill every nook and

so the huge dolphin tempesting the main,

corner of some fair haven—for he is sure to eat all he can

in shoals before him fly the scaly train,

catch—even so did the trojans cower under the banks of the mighty

confusedly heap’d they seek their inmost caves,
or pant and heave beneath the floating waves.

river, and when achilles’ arms grew weary with killing them, he

now, tired with slaughter, from the trojan band

the young lycaon in his passage stood;

the ransom’d prince to fair arisbe bore.

escaped and returned to his father’s house.
he had spent eleven
days happily with his friends after he had come from lemnos, but

on the twelfth heaven again delivered him into the hands of

he felt the sweets of liberty again;
the next, that god whom men in vain withstand
gives the same youth to the same conquering hand
now never to return!

a sadder journey to the shades below.

he was unarmed when achilles caught sight of

his well-known face when great achilles eyed,

with wild affright, and dropp’d upon the field

for he had thrown all his armour from him on to the bank, and was

“ye mighty gods!

see here?

is it in vain our conquering arms subdue?

if this man can come back alive after having been sold

sure i shall see yon heaps of trojans kill’d

over into lemnos, i shall have the trojans also whom i have slain

rise from the shades, and brave me on the field;
as now the captive, whom so late i bound

rising from the world below.

and sold to lemnos, stalks on trojan ground!

could not even the waters of the

grey sea imprison him, as they do many another whether he will or

that bar such numbers from their native plain;

lo!
he returns.

this time let him taste my spear, that i may know for certain

whether mother earth who can keep even a strong man down, will be

try, if the grave can hold the wanderer;
if earth, at length this active prince can seize,

earth, whose strong grasp has held down hercules.

”

”

thus did he pause and ponder.

thus while he spoke, the trojan pale with fears

but lycaon came up to him dazed and

approach’d, and sought his knees with suppliant tears

trying hard to embrace his knees, for he would fain live, not

loth as he was to yield his youthful breath,

die.

and his soul shivering at the approach of death.

achilles thrust at him with his spear, meaning to kill him,

achilles raised the spear, prepared to wound;

but lycaon ran crouching up to him and caught his knees, whereby

he kiss’d his feet, extended on the ground:

the spear passed over his back, and stuck in the ground,

and while, above, the spear suspended stood,

hungering though it was for blood.

longing to dip its thirsty point in blood,

with one hand he caught
achilles’ knees as he besought him, and with the other he
clutched the spear and would not let it go.

one hand embraced them close, one stopp’d the dart,

then he said,

while thus these melting words attempt his heart:

“achilles, have mercy upon me and spare me, for i am your

“thy well-known captive, great achilles!

suppliant.

see,

it was in your tents that i first broke bread on the

day when you took me prisoner in the vineyard; after which you

who shared the gifts of ceres at thy board;
whom late thy conquering arm to lemnos bore,

sold me away to lemnos far from my father and my friends, and i

far from his father, friends, and native shore;

brought you the price of a hundred oxen.

a hundred oxen were his price that day,
now sums immense thy mercy shall repay.

i have paid three times

scarce respited from woes i yet appear,

as much to gain my freedom; it is but twelve days that i have

and scarce twelve morning suns have seen me here;

come to ilius after much suffering, and now cruel fate has again

lo!

thrown me into your hands.
surely father jove must hate me, that

jove again submits me to thy hands,

he has given me over to you a second time.

again, her victim cruel fate demands!

short of life indeed

”

but achilles answered him sternly.

the youth address’d to unrelenting ears:

“idiot,” said he, “talk not to

“talk not of life, or ransom (he replies):

me of ransom.
until patroclus fell i preferred to give the
trojans quarter, and sold beyond the sea many of those whom i had
taken alive; but now not a man shall live of those whom heaven

patroclus dead, whoever meets me, dies:

delivers into my hands before the city of ilius—and of all

in vain a single trojan sues for grace;

trojans it shall fare hardest with the sons of priam.

but least, the sons of priam’s hateful race.

therefore,
my friend, you too shall die.

die then, my friend!

why should you whine in this way?

what boots it to deplore?

patroclus fell, and he was a better man than you are.

the great, the good patroclus is no more!
he, far thy better, was foredoom’d to die,

i too—see

and thou, dost thou bewail mortality?

you not how i am great and goodly?
i am son to a noble father,

seest thou not me, whom nature’s gifts adorn,

and have a goddess for my mother, but the hands of doom and death

sprung from a hero, from a goddess born?

overshadow me all as surely.
the day will come, either at dawn or

the day shall come (which nothing can avert)

dark, or at the noontide, when one shall take my life also in

bow.

impending death and certain fate are mine!

to draw it out, and thrice he had to leave off trying; the fourth

the fourth, he tries to break the spear in vain;

he struck him

there—begotten of a river though you be, it is hard for you to

strive with the offspring of saturn’s son.

you declare yourself

sprung from a river, didst thou boast thy line?

mighty jove.

my father is peleus, son of aeacus ruler over the
many myrmidons, and aeacus was the son of jove.
therefore as jove

of peleus, æacus, and jove, am i.

is mightier than any river that flows into the sea, so are his

the race of these superior far to those,
as he that thunders to the stream that flows.

children stronger than those of any river whatsoever.

what rivers can, scamander might have shown;

whom not even king achelous can compare, nor the mighty stream of

“o first of mortals!

you: if, then, the son of saturn has vouchsafed it to you to

destroy all the trojans, at any rate drive them out of my stream,

’tis not on me thy rage should heap the dead.

and do your grim work on land.

see!

my fair waters are now filled with

my choked streams no more their course can keep,

into the sea for i am choked with dead, and yet you go on

nor roll their wonted tribute to the deep.

mercilessly slaying.

turn then, impetuous!

i am in despair, therefore, o captain of

from our injured flood;

your host, trouble me no further.

content, thy slaughters could amaze a god.

”

all across; whereby achilles struggled out of the stream, and

bridged the rough flood across: the hero stay’d
on this his weight, and raised upon his hand,

fled full speed over the plain, for he was afraid.

leap’d from the channel, and regain’d the land.
then blacken’d the wild waves: the murmur rose:

but the mighty god ceased not in his pursuit, and sprang upon him

the god pursues, a huger billow throws,

with a dark-crested wave, to stay his hands and save the trojans
from destruction.

and bursts the bank, ambitious to destroy

the son of peleus darted away a spear’s throw

the man whose fury is the fate of troy.

from him; swift as the swoop of a black hunter-eagle which is the

he like the warlike eagle speeds his pace

strongest and fleetest of all birds, even so did he spring

(swiftest and strongest of the aerial race);
far as a spear can fly, achilles springs;

forward, and the armour rang loudly about his breast.

at every bound his clanging armour rings:

he fled on

now here, now there, he turns on every side,

in front, but the river with a loud roar came tearing after.

and winds his course before the following tide;
the waves flow after, wheresoe’er he wheels,

as

and gather fast, and murmur at his heels.

one who would water his garden leads a stream from some fountain

so when a peasant to his garden brings
soft rills of water from the bubbling springs,
and calls the floods from high, to bless his bowers,

over his plants, and all his ground—spade in hand he clears away

and feed with pregnant streams the plants and flowers:
soon as he clears whate’er their passage stay’d,
and marks the future current with his spade,

the dams to free the channels, and the little stones run rolling

swift o’er the rolling pebbles, down the hills,

round and round with the water as it goes merrily down the bank

louder and louder purl the falling rills;

faster than the man can follow—even so did the river keep

before him scattering, they prevent his pains,

catching up with achilles albeit he was a fleet runner, for the

and shine in mazy wanderings o’er the plains.
still flies achilles, but before his eyes
still swift scamander rolls where’er he flies:
not all his speed escapes the rapid floods;

gods are stronger than men.

the first of men, but not a match for gods.

as often as he would strive to stand

oft as he turn’d the torrent to oppose,

his ground, and see whether or no all the gods in heaven were in

and bravely try if all the powers were foes;

league against him, so often would the mighty wave come beating

so oft the surge, in watery mountains spread,

down upon his shoulders, and he would have to keep flying on and

beats on his back, or bursts upon his head.

on in great dismay; for the angry flood was tiring him out as it

yet dauntless still the adverse flood he braves,
and still indignant bounds above the waves.
tired by the tides, his knees relax with toil;

flowed past him and ate the ground from under his feet.

wash’d from beneath him slides the slimy soil;

then the son of peleus lifted up his voice to heaven saying,

when thus (his eyes on heaven’s expansion thrown)
forth bursts the hero with an angry groan:

“father jove, is there none of the gods who will take pity upon

“is there no god achilles to befriend,

me, and save me from the river?

no power to avert his miserable end?

i do not care what may happen to

prevent, o jove!
this ignominious date,[271]

me afterwards.

and make my future life the sport of fate.

i blame none of the other dwellers on olympus so

of all heaven’s oracles believed in vain,

severely as i do my dear mother, who has beguiled and tricked me.

but most of thetis must her son complain;

she told me i was to fall under the walls of troy by the flying

and my swift soul o’ertake my slaughter’d friend.
ah no!

” thus spake the gods:

when they had so said they went back to the other immortals, but

then swift ascended to the bright abodes.

achilles strove onward over the plain, encouraged by the charge

stung with new ardour, thus by heaven impell’d,

the gods had laid upon him.

he springs impetuous, and invades the field:

all was now covered with the flood of

heaved on the bounding billows danced the dead,

waters, and much goodly armour of the youths that had been slain

floating ’midst scatter’d arms; while casques of gold

was rifting about, as also many corpses, but he forced his way

and turn’d-up bucklers glitter’d as they roll’d.

against the stream, speeding right onwards, nor could the broad

high o’er the surging tide, by leaps and bounds,

waters stay him, for minerva had endowed him with great strength.

he wades, and mounts; the parted wave resounds.

nevertheless scamander did not slacken in his pursuit, but was

while pallas fills him with immortal force.

out against him.

and ilion tumble from her towery height.

help me at once; fill your streams with water

from their sources, rouse all your torrents to a fury; raise your

from all thy fountains swell thy watery store,

with broken rocks, and with a load of dead,

that we may make an end of this savage creature who is now

mark how resistless through the floods he goes,

lording it as though he were a god.

and boldly bids the warring gods be foes!

nothing shall serve him

but nor that force, nor form divine to sight,

longer, not strength nor comeliness, nor his fine armour, which

shall aught avail him, if our rage unite:

forsooth shall soon be lying low in the deep waters covered over

whelm’d under our dark gulfs those arms shall lie,

with mud.

that blaze so dreadful in each trojan eye;

i will wrap him in sand, and pour tons of shingle round

and deep beneath a sandy mountain hurl’d,

him, so that the achaeans shall not know how to gather his bones

immersed remain this terror of the world.

for the silt in which i shall have hidden him, and when they

such ponderous ruin shall confound the place,

celebrate his funeral they need build no barrow.

no greeks shall e’er his perish’d relics grace,
no hand his bones shall gather, or inhume;
these his cold rites, and this his watery tomb.

”

”

on this he upraised his tumultuous flood high against achilles,

“my child, be up and doing, for i deem it is with you that

assemble all thy fires!

xanthus is fain to fight; help us at once, kindle a fierce fire;

while to their aid, by our command enjoin’d,

i will then bring up the west and the white south wind in a

mighty hurricane from the sea, that shall bear the flames against

these from old ocean at my word shall blow,

corses and arms to one bright ruin turn,

go along the banks of xanthus burning his trees and wrapping him

and hissing rivers to their bottoms burn.

round with fire.

go, mighty in thy rage!

let him not turn you back neither by fair words

nor foul, and slacken not till i shout and tell you.

scorch all the banks!

then you may

and (till our voice reclaim)

stay your flames.

exert the unwearied furies of the flame!

”

”

on this vulcan kindled a fierce fire, which broke out first upon

the power ignipotent her word obeys:

the plain and burned the many dead whom achilles had killed and
whose bodies were lying about in great numbers; by this means the

wide o’er the plain he pours the boundless blaze;

plain was dried and the flood stayed.

at once consumes the dead, and dries the soil
and the shrunk waters in their channel boil.

as the north wind, blowing

as when autumnal boreas sweeps the sky,

on an orchard that has been sodden with autumn rain, soon dries

and instant blows the water’d gardens dry:

it, and the heart of the owner is glad—even so the whole plain
was dried and the dead bodies were consumed.
then he turned

so look’d the field, so whiten’d was the ground,

tongues of fire on to the river.

while vulcan breathed the fiery blast around.

he burned the elms the willows

swift on the sedgy reeds the ruin preys;
along the margin winds the running blaze:
the trees in flaming rows to ashes turn,

and the tamarisks, the lotus also, with the rushes and marshy

the flowering lotos and the tamarisk burn,

herbage that grew abundantly by the banks of the river.

broad elm, and cypress rising in a spire;

the eels

the watery willows hiss before the fire.

and fishes that go darting about everywhere in the water, these,

now glow the waves, the fishes pant for breath,
the eels lie twisting in the pangs of death:
now flounce aloft, now dive the scaly fry,

too, were sorely harassed by the flames that cunning vulcan had

or, gasping, turn their bellies to the sky.

kindled, and the river himself was scalded, so that he spoke

“oh vulcan!

i

oh!

cannot fight you when you flare out your flames in this way;

what power resists thy might?

i faint, i sink, unequal to the fight—

let achilles drive the trojans out of
their city immediately.

i yield—let ilion fall; if fate decree—

what have i to do with quarrelling and

ah—bend no more thy fiery arms on me!

helping people?
”

”

he was boiling as he spoke, and all his waters were seething.

he ceased; wide conflagration blazing round;
the bubbling waters yield a hissing sound.
