”
when she had thus spoken vulcan quenched his flames, and the

infest a god: the obedient flame withdraws:

river went back once more into his own fair bed.

again the branching streams begin to spread,
and soft remurmur in their wonted bed.

xanthus was now beaten, so these two left off fighting, for juno
stayed them though she was still angry; but a furious quarrel

while these by juno’s will the strife resign,

broke out among the other gods, for they were of divided
counsels.

the warring gods in fierce contention join:

they fell on one another with a mighty uproar—earth

rekindling rage each heavenly breast alarms:

groaned, and the spacious firmament rang out as with a blare of

with horrid clangour shock the ethereal arms:

trumpets.

heaven in loud thunder bids the trumpet sound;
and wide beneath them groans the rending ground.

jove heard as he was sitting on olympus, and laughed

jove, as his sport, the dreadful scene descries,

for joy when he saw the gods coming to blows among themselves.

and views contending gods with careless eyes.

they were not long about beginning, and mars piercer of shields
opened the battle.
sword in hand he sprang at once upon minerva

the power of battles lifts his brazen spear,

and reviled her.

and first assaults the radiant queen of war:

“why, vixen,” said he, “have you again set the

“what moved thy madness, thus to disunite

gods by the ears in the pride and haughtiness of your heart?

ethereal minds, and mix all heaven in fight?

have

what wonder this, when in thy frantic mood

you forgotten how you set diomed son of tydeus on to wound me,

thou drovest a mortal to insult a god?

and yourself took visible spear and drove it into me to the hurt

thy impious hand tydides’ javelin bore,

of my fair body?
you shall now suffer for what you then did to

and madly bathed it in celestial gore.

me.
”

”

as he spoke he struck her on the terrible tasselled aegis—so

he spoke, and smote the long-resounding shield,

terrible that not even can jove’s lightning pierce it.

which bears jove’s thunder on its dreadful field:

here did

the adamantine ægis of her sire,

murderous mars strike her with his great spear.

that turns the glancing bolt and forked fire.

she drew back and

then heaved the goddess in her mighty hand

with this she struck mars on the neck, and

this at the heavenly homicide she cast.

brought him down.

thundering he falls, a mass of monstrous size:

nine roods did he cover in his fall, and his

and seven broad acres covers as he lies.

hair was all soiled in the dust, while his armour rang rattling

the stunning stroke his stubborn nerves unbound:

round him.

loud o’er the fields his ringing arms resound:

but minerva laughed and vaunted over him saying,

the scornful dame her conquest views with smiles,
and, glorying, thus the prostrate god reviles:

“idiot, have you not learned how far stronger i am than you, but
you must still match yourself against me?

“hast thou not yet, insatiate fury!

thus do your mother’s

known

lent to the wounded god her tender hand:
slowly he rises, scarcely breathes with pain,

all the time, for it was only with great difficulty that he had

this the bright empress of the heavens survey’d,

experience.

and guard the race of proud laomedon!
hast thou forgot, how, at the monarch’s prayer,

jove’s house and worked for laomedon a whole year at a stated
wage and he gave us his orders.

we shared the lengthen’d labours of a year?

i built the trojans the wall

troy walls i raised (for such were jove’s commands),

about their city, so wide and fair that it might be impregnable,

and yon proud bulwarks grew beneath my hands:

while you, phoebus, herded cattle for him in the dales of many

thy task it was to feed the bellowing droves

valleyed ida.

along fair ida’s vales and pendant groves.

when, however, the glad hours brought round the

but when the circling seasons in their train

time of payment, mighty laomedon robbed us of all our hire and

brought back the grateful day that crown’d our pain,
with menace stern the fraudful king defied

sent us off with nothing but abuse.

our latent godhead, and the prize denied:

he threatened to bind us hand

mad as he was, he threaten’d servile bands,

and foot and sell us over into some distant island.

and doom’d us exiles far in barbarous lands.

he tried,

[273]

moreover, to cut off the ears of both of us, so we went away in a

incensed, we heavenward fled with swiftest wing,

rage, furious about the payment he had promised us, and yet

and destined vengeance on the perjured king.

and king apollo answered, “lord of the earthquake, you would have

apollo thus: “to combat for mankind

no respect for me if i were to fight you about a pack of

ill suits the wisdom of celestial mind;
for what is man?

miserable mortals, who come out like leaves in summer and eat the

calamitous by birth,
they owe their life and nourishment to earth;
like yearly leaves, that now, with beauty crown’d,

fruit of the field, and presently fall lifeless to the ground.

smile on the sun; now, wither on the ground.

let us stay this fighting at once and let them settle it among

to their own hands commit the frantic scene,

themselves.

nor mix immortals in a cause so mean.

”

”

he turned away as he spoke, for he would lay no hand on the

then turns his face, far-beaming heavenly fires,

brother of his own father.

and from the senior power submiss retires:

but his sister the huntress diana,

him thus retreating, artemis upbraids,

patroness of wild beasts, was very angry with him and said, “so

the quiver’d huntress of the sylvan shades:

you would fly, far-darter, and hand victory over to neptune with

“and is it thus the youthful phœbus flies,

a cheap vaunt to boot.

and yields to ocean’s hoary sire the prize?

baby, why keep your bow thus idle?

how vain that martial pomp, and dreadful show

never

of pointed arrows and the silver bow!

let me again hear you bragging in my father’s house, as you have
often done in the presence of the immortals, that you would stand

now boast no more in yon celestial bower,

up and fight with neptune.

thy force can match the great earth-shaking power.

”

”

apollo made her no answer, but jove’s august queen was angry and

silent he heard the queen of woods upbraid:

upbraided her bitterly.

not so saturnia bore the vaunting maid:

“bold vixen,” she cried, “how dare you

but furious thus: “what insolence has driven

cross me thus?
for all your bow you will find it hard to hold
your own against me.

thy pride to face the majesty of heaven?

jove made you as a lion among women, and

what though by jove the female plague design’d,
fierce to the feeble race of womankind,

lets you kill them whenever you choose.

the wretched matron feels thy piercing dart;

you will find it better

thy sex’s tyrant, with a tiger’s heart?

to chase wild beasts and deer upon the mountains than to fight

what though tremendous in the woodland chase

those who are stronger than you are.

thy certain arrows pierce the savage race?

if you would try war, do so,

how dares thy rashness on the powers divine

and find out by pitting yourself against me, how far stronger i
am than you are.

employ those arms, or match thy force with mine?

”

learn hence, no more unequal war to wage—”

she caught both diana’s wrists with her left hand as she spoke,

she said, and seized her wrists with eager rage;
these in her left hand lock’d, her right untied

and with her right she took the bow from her shoulders, and

the bow, the quiver, and its plumy pride.

laughed as she beat her with it about the ears while diana

about her temples flies the busy bow;

wriggled and writhed under her blows.

now here, now there, she winds her from the blow;

her swift arrows were shed

the scattering arrows, rattling from the case,

upon the ground, and she fled weeping from under juno’s hand as a

drop round, and idly mark the dusty place.
swift from the field the baffled huntress flies,
and scarce restrains the torrent in her eyes:

dove that flies before a falcon to the cleft of some hollow rock,

so, when the falcon wings her way above,
to the cleft cavern speeds the gentle dove;

when it is her good fortune to escape.

(not fated yet to die;) there safe retreats,

even so did she fly

yet still her heart against the marble beats.

weeping away, leaving her bow and arrows behind her.

to her latona hastes with tender care;

then the slayer of argus, guide and guardian, said to leto,

whom hermes viewing, thus declines the war:

“leto, i shall not fight you; it is ill to come to blows with any

“how shall i face the dame, who gives delight
to him whose thunders blacken heaven with night?

of jove’s wives.

go, matchless goddess!

therefore boast as you will among the immortals

triumph in the skies,

that you worsted me in fair fight.

and boast my conquest, while i yield the prize.

”

”

leto then gathered up diana’s bow and arrows that had fallen

he spoke; and pass’d: latona, stooping low,
collects the scatter’d shafts and fallen bow,

about amid the whirling dust, and when she had got them she made

that, glittering on the dust, lay here and there

all haste after her daughter.

dishonour’d relics of diana’s war:

diana had now reached jove’s

then swift pursued her to her blest abode,

bronze-floored mansion on olympus, and sat herself down with many

where, all confused, she sought the sovereign god;

tears on the knees of her father, while her ambrosial raiment was

weeping, she grasp’d his knees: the ambrosial vest

quivering all about her.

shook with her sighs, and panted on her breast.

the son of saturn drew her towards him,
and laughing pleasantly the while began to question her saying,

the sire superior smiled, and bade her show

“which of the heavenly beings, my dear child, has been treating
you in this cruel manner, as though you had been misconducting

what heavenly hand had caused his daughter’s woe?

yourself in the face of everybody?
” and the fair-crowned goddess
of the chase answered, “it was your wife juno, father, who has
been beating me; it is always her doing when there is any

abash’d, she names his own imperial spouse;

quarrelling among the immortals.

and the pale crescent fades upon her brows.

”
thus did they converse, and meanwhile phoebus apollo entered the

strong city of ilius, for he was uneasy lest the wall should not

apollo enters ilion’s sacred town;

hold out and the danaans should take the city then and there,

the guardian-god now trembled for her wall,

before its hour had come; but the rest of the ever-living gods

and fear’d the greeks, though fate forbade her fall.

went back, some angry and some triumphant to olympus, where they

back to olympus, from the war’s alarms,
return the shining bands of gods in arms;
some proud in triumph, some with rage on fire;

took their seats beside jove lord of the storm-cloud, while

and take their thrones around the ethereal sire.

achilles still kept on dealing out death alike on the trojans and

through blood, through death, achilles still proceeds,

on their horses.

o’er slaughter’d heroes, and o’er rolling steeds.

as when the smoke from some burning city ascends

as when avenging flames with fury driven

to heaven when the anger of the gods has kindled it—there is then

on guilty towns exert the wrath of heaven;

toil for all, and sorrow for not a few—even so did achilles bring

the pale inhabitants, some fall, some fly;
and the red vapours purple all the sky:
so raged achilles: death and dire dismay,

toil and sorrow on the trojans.

and toils, and terrors, fill’d the dreadful day.

old king priam stood on a high tower of the wall looking down on

high on a turret hoary priam stands,

huge achilles as the trojans fled panic-stricken before him, and

and marks the waste of his destructive hands;
views, from his arm, the trojans’ scatter’d flight,
and the near hero rising on his sight!

there was none to help them.

no stop, no check, no aid!

presently he came down from off the

with feeble pace,
and settled sorrow on his aged face,

tower and with many a groan went along the wall to give orders to

fast as he could, he sighing quits the walls;

the brave warders of the gate.

and thus descending, on the guards he calls:

“keep the gates,” said he, “wide

“you to whose care our city-gates belong,
set wide your portals to the flying throng:

open till the people come flying into the city, for achilles is

for lo!

hard by and is driving them in rout before him.

he comes, with unresisted sway;
he comes, and desolation marks his way!

i see we are in
great peril.
as soon as our people are inside and in safety,

but when within the walls our troops take breath,

close the strong gates for i fear lest that terrible man should
come bounding inside along with the others.

lock fast the brazen bars, and shut out death.

”

”

as he spoke they drew back the bolts and opened the gates, and

thus charged the reverend monarch: wide were flung
the opening folds; the sounding hinges rung.

when these were opened there was a haven of refuge for the

phœbus rush’d forth, the flying bands to meet;

trojans.

struck slaughter back, and cover’d the retreat,

apollo then came full speed out of the city to meet them

on heaps the trojans crowd to gain the gate,

and protect them.

and gladsome see their last escape from fate.

right for the city and the high wall, parched

thither, all parch’d with thirst, a heartless train,

with thirst and grimy with dust, still they fled on, with

hoary with dust, they beat the hollow plain:
and gasping, panting, fainting, labour on

achilles wielding his spear furiously behind them.

with heavier strides, that lengthen toward the town.
enraged achilles follows with his spear;

for he was as

wild with revenge, insatiable of war.

one possessed, and was thirsting after glory.

then had the greeks eternal praise acquired,
and troy inglorious to her walls retired;
but he, the god who darts ethereal flame,
shot down to save her, and redeem her fame:

then had the sons of the achaeans taken the lofty gates of troy

to young agenor force divine he gave;

if apollo had not spurred on agenor, valiant and noble son to
antenor.

(antenor’s offspring, haughty, bold, and brave;)

he put courage into his heart, and stood by his side to
guard him, leaning against a beech tree and shrouded in thick

in aid of him, beside the beech he sate,

darkness.

and wrapt in clouds, restrain’d the hand of fate.

when agenor saw achilles he stood still and his heart

when now the generous youth achilles spies,
thick beats his heart, the troubled motions rise.

was clouded with care.

(so, ere a storm, the waters heave and roll.
)

“alas,” said he to himself in his dismay,

he stops, and questions thus his mighty soul;

“if i fly before mighty achilles, and go where all the others are

“what, shall i fly this terror of the plain!
like others fly, and be like others slain?

being driven in rout, he will none the less catch me and kill me

vain hope!
to shun him by the self-same road

for a coward.

yon line of slaughter’d trojans lately trod.

how would it be were i to let achilles drive the

no: with the common heap i scorn to fall—

others before him, and then fly from the wall to the plain that

is behind ilius till i reach the spurs of ida and can hide in the

while i decline to yonder path, that leads

underwood that is thereon?

to ida’s forests and surrounding shades?

i could then wash the sweat from off

so may i reach, conceal’d, the cooling flood,
from my tired body wash the dirt and blood,

me in the river and in the evening return to ilius.

as soon as night her dusky veil extends,
return in safety to my trojan friends.

but why

what if?
—but wherefore all this vain debate?

commune with myself in this way?

stand i to doubt, within the reach of fate?

like enough he would see me as i

even now perhaps, ere yet i turn the wall,
the fierce achilles sees me, and i fall:

am hurrying from the city over the plain, and would speed after

such is his swiftness, ’tis in vain to fly,

me till he had caught me—i should stand no chance against him,
for he is mightiest of all mankind.

and such his valour, that who stands must die.

what, then, if i go out and

howe’er ’tis better, fighting for the state,

meet him in front of the city?

here, and in public view, to meet my fate.

his flesh too, i take it, can be

yet sure he too is mortal; he may feel

pierced by pointed bronze.

(like all the sons of earth) the force of steel.

life is the same in one and all, and
men say that he is but mortal despite the triumph that jove son

one only soul informs that dreadful frame:

of saturn vouchsafes him.

and jove’s sole favour gives him all his fame.

”

”

so saying he stood on his guard and awaited achilles, for he was

he said, and stood, collected, in his might;

now fain to fight him.

and all his beating bosom claim’d the fight.

as a leopardess that bounds from out a

so from some deep-grown wood a panther starts,

thick covert to attack a hunter—she knows no fear and is not

roused from his thicket by a storm of darts:
untaught to fear or fly, he hears the sounds

dismayed by the baying of the hounds; even though the man be too

of shouting hunters, and of clamorous hounds;

quick for her and wound her either with thrust or spear, still,

though struck, though wounded, scarce perceives the pain;

though the spear has pierced her she will not give in till she

and the barb’d javelin stings his breast in vain:
on their whole war, untamed, the savage flies;

has either caught him in her grip or been killed outright—even so

and tears his hunter, or beneath him dies.

did noble agenor son of antenor refuse to fly till he had made

disdainful of retreat: high held before,

day sack the city of the proud trojans.

“how proud achilles glories in his fame!
and hopes this day to sink the trojan name

fool, there will be

beneath her ruins!
know, that hope is vain;

trouble enough yet before it, for there is many a brave man of us

a thousand woes, a thousand toils remain.

still inside who will stand in front of our dear parents with our

parents and children our just arms employ,

wives and children, to defend ilius.

and strong and many are the sons of troy.

here therefore, huge and

mighty warrior though you be, here shall you die.

these phrygian fields, and press a foreign shore.

”

he stands impassive in the ethereal arms.

achilles in his turn attacked noble agenor,

then fiercely rushing on the daring foe,
his lifted arm prepares the fatal blow:

but apollo would not vouchsafe him glory, for he snatched agenor

but, jealous of his fame, apollo shrouds
the god-like trojan in a veil of clouds.

away and hid him in a thick mist, sending him out of the battle

safe from pursuit, and shut from mortal view,

unmolested.

dismiss’d with fame, the favoured youth withdrew.

then he craftily drew the son of peleus away from

the furious chief still follows where he flies.

and pursued him over the corn lands of the plain, turning him

towards the deep waters of the river scamander.

now urge the course where swift scamander glides:

apollo ran but a

the god, now distant scarce a stride before,

all the time that he was on the point of overtaking him.

while all the flying troops their speed employ,

meanwhile the rabble of routed trojans was thankful to crowd

and pour on heaps into the walls of troy:

within the city till their numbers thronged it; no longer did
they dare wait for one another outside the city walls, to learn

no stop, no stay; no thought to ask, or tell,

who had escaped and who were fallen in fight, but all whose feet

who ’scaped by flight, or who by battle fell.
’twas tumult all, and violence of flight;
and sudden joy confused, and mix’d affright.
pale troy against achilles shuts her gate:

and knees could still carry them poured pell-mell into the town.

and nations breathe, deliver’d from their fate.

book xxii.

book xxii.

the death of hector.

argument.
the death of hector.

thus the trojans in the city, scared like fawns, wiped the sweat

the trojans being safe within the walls, hector only stays to oppose

from off them and drank to quench their thirst, leaning against

achilles.
priam is struck at his approach, and tries to persuade his
son to re-enter the town.
hecuba joins her entreaties, but in vain.
hector consults within himself what measures to take; but at the
advance of achilles, his resolution fails him, and he flies.
achilles
pursues him thrice round the walls of troy.
the gods debate concerning
the fate of hector; at length minerva descends to the aid of achilles.
she deludes hector in the shape of deiphobus; he stands the combat, and
is slain.
achilles drags the dead body at his chariot in the sight of
priam and hecuba.
their lamentations, tears, and despair.
their cries
reach the ears of andromache, who, ignorant of this, was retired into
the inner part of the palace: she mounts up to the walls, and beholds
her dead husband.
she swoons at the spectacle.
her excess of grief and
lamentation.

the goodly battlements, while the achaeans with their shields

the thirtieth day still continues.
the scene lies under the walls,
and on the battlements of troy.
thus to their bulwarks, smit with panic fear,
the herded ilians rush like driven deer:
there safe they wipe the briny drops away,
and drown in bowls the labours of the day.

laid upon their shoulders drew close up to the walls.

close to the walls, advancing o’er the fields

but stern

beneath one roof of well-compacted shields,

fate bade hector stay where he was before ilius and the scaean

march, bending on, the greeks’ embodied powers,
far stretching in the shade of trojan towers.
great hector singly stay’d: chain’d down by fate
there fix’d he stood before the scæan gate;
still his bold arms determined to employ,

gates.

the guardian still of long-defended troy.

then phoebus apollo spoke to the son of peleus saying,

apollo now to tired achilles turns:
(the power confess’d in all his glory burns:)

“why, son of peleus, do you, who are but man, give chase to me

“and what (he cries) has peleus’ son in view,

who am immortal?

with mortal speed a godhead to pursue?

have you not yet found out that it is a god whom

for not to thee to know the gods is given,
unskill’d to trace the latent marks of heaven.

you pursue so furiously?

what boots thee now, that troy forsook the plain?

you did not harass the trojans whom you

vain thy past labour, and thy present vain:

had routed, and now they are within their walls, while you have
been decoyed hither away from them.

safe in their walls are now her troops bestow’d,

me you cannot kill, for death

while here thy frantic rage attacks a god.

can take no hold upon me.
”

”

achilles was greatly angered and said, “you have baulked me,

the chief incensed—“too partial god of day!

far-darter, most malicious of all gods, and have drawn me away

to check my conquests in the middle way:

from the wall, where many another man would have bitten the dust

how few in ilion else had refuge found!
what gasping numbers now had bit the ground!

ere he got within ilius; you have robbed me of great glory and

thou robb’st me of a glory justly mine,
powerful of godhead, and of fraud divine:
mean fame, alas!

have saved the trojans at no risk to yourself, for you have

for one of heavenly strain,

nothing to fear, but i would indeed have my revenge if it were in

to cheat a mortal who repines in vain.

my power to do so.
”

”

on this, with fell intent he made towards the city, and as the

then to the city, terrible and strong,
with high and haughty steps he tower’d along,

winning horse in a chariot race strains every nerve when he is

so the proud courser, victor of the prize,

flying over the plain, even so fast and furiously did the limbs

to the near goal with double ardour flies.

of achilles bear him onwards.

him, as he blazing shot across the field,

king priam was first to note him as

the careful eyes of priam first beheld.
not half so dreadful rises to the sight,[274]

he scoured the plain, all radiant as the star which men call

through the thick gloom of some tempestuous night,

orion’s hound, and whose beams blaze forth in time of harvest

orion’s dog (the year when autumn weighs),

more brilliantly than those of any other that shines by night;

and o’er the feebler stars exerts his rays;

brightest of them all though he be, he yet bodes ill for mortals,

terrific glory!

for he brings fire and fever in his train—even so did achilles’

for his burning breath
taints the red air with fevers, plagues, and death.

armour gleam on his breast as he sped onwards.

so flamed his fiery mail.

priam raised a cry

then wept the sage:

and beat his head with his hands as he lifted them up and shouted

he strikes his reverend head, now white with age;
he lifts his wither’d arms; obtests the skies;

out to his dear son, imploring him to return; but hector still

he calls his much-loved son with feeble cries:
the son, resolved achilles’ force to dare,

stayed before the gates, for his heart was set upon doing battle

full at the scæan gates expects the war;

with achilles.

while the sad father on the rampart stands,

the old man reached out his arms towards him and

and thus adjures him with extended hands:

bade him for pity’s sake come within the walls.

“ah stay not, stay not!

“hector,” he

guardless and alone;
hector!

cried, “my son, stay not to face this man alone and unsupported,

my loved, my dearest, bravest son!

or you will meet death at the hands of the son of peleus, for he

methinks already i behold thee slain,
and stretch’d beneath that fury of the plain.

is mightier than you.

implacable achilles!

monster that he is; would indeed that the

might’st thou be

gods loved him no better than i do, for so, dogs and vultures

to all the gods no dearer than to me!

would soon devour him as he lay stretched on earth, and a load of

thee, vultures wild should scatter round the shore,
and bloody dogs grow fiercer from thy gore.

grief would be lifted from my heart, for many a brave son has he

how many valiant sons i late enjoy’d,

reft from me, either by killing them or selling them away in the

valiant in vain!
by thy cursed arm destroy’d:
or, worse than slaughtered, sold in distant isles

islands that are beyond the sea: even now i miss two sons from

to shameful bondage, and unworthy toils.

among the trojans who have thronged within the city, lycaon and

two, while i speak, my eyes in vain explore,

polydorus, whom laothoe peeress among women bore me.

two from one mother sprung, my polydore,
and loved lycaon; now perhaps no more!

should they

oh!

be still alive and in the hands of the achaeans, we will ransom

if in yonder hostile camp they live,

them with gold and bronze, of which we have store, for the old

what heaps of gold, what treasures would i give!

man altes endowed his daughter richly; but if they are already

(their grandsire’s wealth, by right of birth their own,
consign’d his daughter with lelegia’s throne:)
but if (which heaven forbid) already lost,

dead and in the house of hades, sorrow will it be to us two who

all pale they wander on the stygian coast;

were their parents; albeit the grief of others will be more

what sorrows then must their sad mother know,
what anguish i?
unutterable woe!
yet less that anguish, less to her, to me,

short-lived unless you too perish at the hands of achilles.

less to all troy, if not deprived of thee.
yet shun achilles!

come,

enter yet the wall;

then, my son, within the city, to be the guardian of trojan men

and spare thyself, thy father, spare us all!

and trojan women, or you will both lose your own life and afford

save thy dear life; or, if a soul so brave

a mighty triumph to the son of peleus.

neglect that thought, thy dearer glory save.

have pity also on your

pity, while yet i live, these silver hairs;
while yet thy father feels the woes he bears,
yet cursed with sense!

unhappy father while life yet remains to him—on me, whom the son

a wretch, whom in his rage

of saturn will destroy by a terrible doom on the threshold of old

(all trembling on the verge of helpless age)
great jove has placed, sad spectacle of pain!
the bitter dregs of fortune’s cup to drain:
to fill with scenes of death his closing eyes,

age, after i have seen my sons slain and my daughters haled away

and number all his days by miseries!

as captives, my bridal chambers pillaged, little children dashed

my heroes slain, my bridal bed o’erturn’d,

to earth amid the rage of battle, and my sons’ wives dragged away

my daughters ravish’d, and my city burn’d,
my bleeding infants dash’d against the floor;
these i have yet to see, perhaps yet more!

by the cruel hands of the achaeans; in the end fierce hounds will

perhaps even i, reserved by angry fate,
the last sad relic of my ruin’d state,
(dire pomp of sovereign wretchedness!
) must fall,

tear me in pieces at my own gates after some one has beaten the

and stain the pavement of my regal hall;

life out of my body with sword or spear-hounds that i myself

where famish’d dogs, late guardians of my door,

reared and fed at my own table to guard my gates, but who will

shall lick their mangled master’s spatter’d gore.

yet lap my blood and then lie all distraught at my doors.

yet for my sons i thank ye, gods!

when a

’tis well;

young man falls by the sword in battle, he may lie where he is

well have they perish’d, for in fight they fell.
who dies in youth and vigour, dies the best,

and there is nothing unseemly; let what will be seen, all is

struck through with wounds, all honest on the breast.

honourable in death, but when an old man is slain there is

but when the fates, in fulness of their rage,
spurn the hoar head of unresisting age,
in dust the reverend lineaments deform,

nothing in this world more pitiable than that dogs should defile

and pour to dogs the life-blood scarcely warm:
this, this is misery!
the last, the worse,

his grey hair and beard and all that men hide for shame.

that man can feel!
man, fated to be cursed!

”

”

the old man tore his grey hair as he spoke, but he moved not the

he said, and acting what no words could say,

heart of hector.

rent from his head the silver locks away.

his mother hard by wept and moaned aloud as she

with him the mournful mother bears a part;
yet all her sorrows turn not hector’s heart.

bared her bosom and pointed to the breast which had suckled him.

the zone unbraced, her bosom she display’d;

“hector,” she cried, weeping bitterly the while, “hector, my son,

and thus, fast-falling the salt tears, she said:
“have mercy on me, o my son!
revere
the words of age; attend a parent’s prayer!

spurn not this breast, but have pity upon me too: if i have ever

if ever thee in these fond arms i press’d,
or still’d thy infant clamours at this breast;

given you comfort from my own bosom, think on it now, dear son,

ah do not thus our helpless years forego,

and come within the wall to protect us from this man; stand not

but, by our walls secured, repel the foe.

without to meet him.

against his rage if singly thou proceed,

should the wretch kill you, neither i nor

should’st thou, (but heaven avert it!
) should’st thou bleed,
nor must thy corse lie honour’d on the bier,

your richly dowered wife shall ever weep, dear offshoot of

nor spouse, nor mother, grace thee with a tear!

myself, over the bed on which you lie, for dogs will devour you

far from our pious rites those dear remains

at the ships of the achaeans.

must feast the vultures on the naked plains.

”

”

thus did the two with many tears implore their son, but they

so they, while down their cheeks the torrents roll;

moved not the heart of hector, and he stood his ground awaiting

but fix’d remains the purpose of his soul;
resolved he stands, and with a fiery glance

huge achilles as he drew nearer towards him.

expects the hero’s terrible advance.

as a serpent in its

so, roll’d up in his den, the swelling snake
beholds the traveller approach the brake;

den upon the mountains, full fed with deadly poisons, waits for

when fed with noxious herbs his turgid veins
have gather’d half the poisons of the plains;
he burns, he stiffens with collected ire,

the approach of man—he is filled with fury and his eyes glare

and his red eyeballs glare with living fire.

terribly as he goes writhing round his den—even so hector leaned
his shield against a tower that jutted out from the wall and

beneath a turret, on his shield reclined,

stood where he was, undaunted.

he stood, and question’d thus his mighty mind:[275]
“where lies my way?

“alas,” said he to himself in the heaviness of his heart, “if i

to enter in the wall?

go within the gates, polydamas will be the first to heap reproach

honour and shame the ungenerous thought recall:
shall proud polydamas before the gate

upon me, for it was he that urged me to lead the trojans back to

proclaim, his counsels are obey’d too late,

the city on that awful night when achilles again came forth

which timely follow’d but the former night,

against us.

what numbers had been saved by hector’s flight?

i would not listen, but it would have been indeed

that wise advice rejected with disdain,

better if i had done so.

i feel my folly in my people slain.

now that my folly has destroyed the

methinks my suffering country’s voice i hear,

host, i dare not look trojan men and trojan women in the face,

but most her worthless sons insult my ear,

lest a worse man should say, ‘hector has ruined us by his

on my rash courage charge the chance of war,

self-confidence.

and blame those virtues which they cannot share.

’ surely it would be better for me to return

no—if i e’er return, return i must

after having fought achilles and slain him, or to die gloriously

glorious, my country’s terror laid in dust:
or if i perish, let her see me fall

here before the city.

in field at least, and fighting for her wall.

what, again, if i were to lay down my

and yet suppose these measures i forego,

shield and helmet, lean my spear against the wall and go straight

approach unarm’d, and parley with the foe,
the warrior-shield, the helm, and lance, lay down,

up to noble achilles?

and treat on terms of peace to save the town:

what if i were to promise to give up helen,

the wife withheld, the treasure ill-detain’d

who was the fountainhead of all this war, and all the treasure

(cause of the war, and grievance of the land)

that alexandrus brought with him in his ships to troy, aye, and

with honourable justice to restore:

to let the achaeans divide the half of everything that the city
contains among themselves?

and add half ilion’s yet remaining store,

i might make the trojans, by the
mouths of their princes, take a solemn oath that they would hide

which troy shall, sworn, produce; that injured greece

nothing, but would divide into two shares all that is within the

may share our wealth, and leave our walls in peace.

city—but why argue with myself in this way?

but why this thought?

were i to go up to

unarm’d if i should go,

him he would show me no kind of mercy; he would kill me then and

what hope of mercy from this vengeful foe,

there as easily as though i were a woman, when i had off my

but woman-like to fall, and fall without a blow?

armour.

we greet not here, as man conversing man,

there is no parleying with him from some rock or oak tree

met at an oak, or journeying o’er a plain;
no season now for calm familiar talk,

as young men and maidens prattle with one another.

like youths and maidens in an evening walk:

better fight

war is our business, but to whom is given

him at once, and learn to which of us jove will vouchsafe

to die, or triumph, that, determine heaven!

victory.
”

”

thus did he stand and ponder, but achilles came up to him as it

thus pondering, like a god the greek drew nigh;

were mars himself, plumed lord of battle.

his dreadful plumage nodded from on high;

from his right shoulder
he brandished his terrible spear of pelian ash, and the bronze

the pelian javelin, in his better hand,

gleamed around him like flashing fire or the rays of the rising

shot trembling rays that glitter’d o’er the land;
and on his breast the beamy splendour shone,

sun.

like jove’s own lightning, or the rising sun.

fear fell upon hector as he beheld him, and he dared not

as hector sees, unusual terrors rise,
struck by some god, he fears, recedes, and flies.

stay longer where he was but fled in dismay from before the

he leaves the gates, he leaves the wall behind:

gates, while achilles darted after him at his utmost speed.

achilles follows like the winged wind.

as a

thus at the panting dove a falcon flies

mountain falcon, swiftest of all birds, swoops down upon some

(the swiftest racer of the liquid skies),

cowering dove—the dove flies before him but the falcon with a

just when he holds, or thinks he holds his prey,
obliquely wheeling through the aerial way,

shrill scream follows close after, resolved to have her—even so

with open beak and shrilling cries he springs,

did achilles make straight for hector with all his might, while

and aims his claws, and shoots upon his wings:

hector fled under the trojan wall as fast as his limbs could take

no less fore-right the rapid chase they held,

him.

one urged by fury, one by fear impell’d:

on they flew along the waggon-road that ran hard by under the

now circling round the walls their course maintain,

wall, past the look-out station, and past the weather-beaten wild

where the high watch-tower overlooks the plain;

fig-tree, till they came to two fair springs which feed the river

now where the fig-trees spread their umbrage broad,

scamander.

(a wider compass,) smoke along the road.

one of these two springs is warm, and steam rises from

next by scamander’s double source they bound,
where two famed fountains burst the parted ground;
this hot through scorching clefts is seen to rise,

it as smoke from a burning fire, but the other even in summer is

with exhalations steaming to the skies;
that the green banks in summer’s heat o’erflows,

as cold as hail or snow, or the ice that forms on water.

like crystal clear, and cold as winter snows:

here,

each gushing fount a marble cistern fills,

hard by the springs, are the goodly washing-troughs of stone,

whose polish’d bed receives the falling rills;

where in the time of peace before the coming of the achaeans the

where trojan dames (ere yet alarm’d by greece)

wives and fair daughters of the trojans used to wash their

wash’d their fair garments in the days of peace.

clothes.

[276]

past these did they fly, the one in front and the other

by these they pass’d, one chasing, one in flight:

giving chase behind him: good was the man that fled, but better

(the mighty fled, pursued by stronger might:)

far was he that followed after, and swiftly indeed did they run,

swift was the course; no vulgar prize they play,

for the prize was no mere beast for sacrifice or bullock’s hide,

no vulgar victim must reward the day:

as it might be for a common foot-race, but they ran for the life
of hector.
as horses in a chariot race speed round the

(such as in races crown the speedy strife:)

turning-posts when they are running for some great prize—a tripod

the prize contended was great hector’s life.
as when some hero’s funerals are decreed
in grateful honour of the mighty dead;
where high rewards the vigorous youth inflame
(some golden tripod, or some lovely dame)
the panting coursers swiftly turn the goal,

or woman—at the games in honour of some dead hero, so did these

and with them turns the raised spectator’s soul:

two run full speed three times round the city of priam.

thus three times round the trojan wall they fly.

all the

the gazing gods lean forward from the sky;

gods watched them, and the sire of gods and men was the first to

to whom, while eager on the chase they look,
the sire of mortals and immortals spoke:

speak.

“unworthy sight!

“alas,” said he, “my eyes behold a man who is dear to me being

the man beloved of heaven,

pursued round the walls of troy; my heart is full of pity for

behold, inglorious round yon city driven!
my heart partakes the generous hector’s pain;

hector, who has burned the thigh-bones of many a heifer in my

hector, whose zeal whole hecatombs has slain,

honour, one while on the crests of many-valleyed ida, and again

whose grateful fumes the gods received with joy,

on the citadel of troy; and now i see noble achilles in full

from ida’s summits, and the towers of troy:
now see him flying; to his fears resign’d,

pursuit of him round the city of priam.

and fate, and fierce achilles, close behind.

what say you?

consult, ye powers!

consider

(’tis worthy your debate)

among yourselves and decide whether we shall now save him or let

whether to snatch him from impending fate,

him fall, valiant though he be, before achilles, son of peleus.

or let him bear, by stern pelides slain,
(good as he is) the lot imposed on man.

”

”

then minerva said, “father, wielder of the lightning, lord of

then pallas thus: “shall he whose vengeance forms

cloud and storm, what mean you?

the forky bolt, and blackens heaven with storms,

would you pluck this mortal whose

shall he prolong one trojan’s forfeit breath?
a man, a mortal, pre-ordain’d to death!

doom has long been decreed out of the jaws of death?

and will no murmurs fill the courts above?
no gods indignant blame their partial jove?

do as you
will, but we others shall not be of a mind with you.
”

”

and jove answered, “my child, trito-born, take heart.
i did not

“go then (return’d the sire) without delay,

exert thy will: i give the fates their way.

do
without let or hindrance as you are minded.

”

darted from the topmost summits of olympus.

and stoops impetuous from the cleaving skies.

achilles was still in full pursuit of hector, as a hound chasing

as through the forest, o’er the vale and lawn,
the well-breath’d beagle drives the flying fawn,

a fawn which he has started from its covert on the mountains, and

in vain he tries the covert of the brakes,

hunts through glade and thicket.

or deep beneath the trembling thicket shakes;

the fawn may try to elude him by

sure of the vapour in the tainted dews,

crouching under cover of a bush, but he will scent her out and

the certain hound his various maze pursues.

follow her up until he gets her—even so there was no escape for

thus step by step, where’er the trojan wheel’d,

hector from the fleet son of peleus.

there swift achilles compass’d round the field.

whenever he made a set to

from the high turrets might oppress the foe,)

would gain on him and head him back towards the plain, keeping

so oft achilles turns him to the plain:

himself always on the city side.

he eyes the city, but he eyes in vain.

as a man in a dream who fails to

lay hands upon another whom he is pursuing—the one cannot escape

one to pursue, and one to lead the chase,
their sinking limbs the fancied course forsake,

nor the other overtake—even so neither could achilles come up

nor this can fly, nor that can overtake:

with hector, nor hector break away from achilles; nevertheless he

no less the labouring heroes pant and strain:
while that but flies, and this pursues in vain.
what god, o muse, assisted hector’s force

with fate itself so long to hold the course?

and leave untouch’d the honours of the day.

make a stand and fight you.

and urge to meet the fate he cannot shun.

thus spoke minerva.

deiphobus.

me of all my brothers, children of hecuba and priam, but

of all that hecuba to priam bore,

henceforth i shall rate you yet more highly, inasmuch as you have

long tried, long loved: much loved, but honoured more!

ventured outside the wall for my sake when all the others remain

since you, of all our numerous race alone

inside.

sternly they met.

his dreadful plumage nodded as he spoke:
“enough, o son of peleus!

doing hitherto.

troy has view’d

three times have i fled round the mighty city of

her walls thrice circled, and her chief pursued.

priam, without daring to withstand you, but now, let me either

but now some god within me bids me try

slay or be slain, for i am in the mind to face you.

thine, or my fate: i kill thee, or i die.

let us, then,

yet on the verge of battle let us stay,

give pledges to one another by our gods, who are the fittest

and for a moment’s space suspend the day;
let heaven’s high powers be call’d to arbitrate

witnesses and guardians of all covenants; let it be agreed

the just conditions of this stern debate,
(eternal witnesses of all below,
and faithful guardians of the treasured vow!
)

between us that if jove vouchsafes me the longer stay and i take

to them i swear; if, victor in the strife,

your life, i am not to treat your dead body in any unseemly

jove by these hands shall shed thy noble life,
no vile dishonour shall thy corse pursue;

fashion, but when i have stripped you of your armour, i am to

stripp’d of its arms alone (the conqueror’s due)

give up your body to the achaeans.

the rest to greece uninjured i’ll restore:

and do you likewise.

now plight thy mutual oath, i ask no more.

”

”

achilles glared at him and answered, “fool, prate not to me about

“talk not of oaths (the dreadful chief replies,
while anger flash’d from his disdainful eyes),

covenants.

detested as thou art, and ought to be,

there can be no covenants between men and lions,

nor oath nor pact achilles plights with thee:

wolves and lambs can never be of one mind, but hate each other

such pacts as lambs and rabid wolves combine,
such leagues as men and furious lions join,

out and out all through.

to such i call the gods!

therefore there can be no understanding

one constant state

between you and me, nor may there be any covenants between us,

of lasting rancour and eternal hate:

till one or other shall fall and glut grim mars with his life’s

no thought but rage, and never-ceasing strife,

blood.

till death extinguish rage, and thought, and life.

put forth all your strength; you have need now to prove

rouse then thy forces this important hour,

yourself indeed a bold soldier and man of war.

collect thy soul, and call forth all thy power.

you have no more

no further subterfuge, no further chance;

chance, and pallas minerva will forthwith vanquish you by my

’tis pallas, pallas gives thee to my lance.

spear: you shall now pay me in full for the grief you have caused

each grecian ghost, by thee deprived of breath,

me on account of my comrades whom you have killed in battle.

now hovers round, and calls thee to thy death.

”

”

he poised his spear as he spoke and hurled it.

he spoke, and launch’d his javelin at the foe;

hector saw it

but hector shunn’d the meditated blow:

coming and avoided it; he watched it and crouched down so that it

he stoop’d, while o’er his head the flying spear

flew over his head and stuck in the ground beyond; minerva then

sang innocent, and spent its force in air.
minerva watch’d it falling on the land,

to thee, presumptuous as thou art, unknown,

or what must prove my fortune, or thy own.

boasting is but an art, our fears to blind,

your spear into the back of a runaway—drive it, should heaven so

and with false terrors sink another’s mind.

grant you power, drive it into me as i make straight towards you;

but know, whatever fate i am to try,

and now for your own part avoid my spear if you can—would that

by no dishonest wound shall hector die.
i shall not fall a fugitive at least,

you might receive the whole of it into your body; if you were

my soul shall bravely issue from my breast.

once dead the trojans would find the war an easier matter, for it

but first, try thou my arm; and may this dart

is you who have harmed them most.

end all my country’s woes, deep buried in thy heart.

”

”

he poised his spear as he spoke and hurled it.
his aim was true

the weapon flew, its course unerring held,

for he hit the middle of achilles’ shield, but the spear

unerring, but the heavenly shield repell’d
the mortal dart; resulting with a bound

rebounded from it, and did not pierce it.

from off the ringing orb, it struck the ground.

hector was angry when
he saw that the weapon had sped from his hand in vain, and stood

hector beheld his javelin fall in vain,

there in dismay for he had no second spear.

nor other lance, nor other hope remain;

with a loud cry he

he calls deiphobus, demands a spear—

called deiphobus and asked him for one, but there was no man;

in vain, for no deiphobus was there.

then he saw the truth and said to himself, “alas!

all comfortless he stands: then, with a sigh;

the gods have

“’tis so—heaven wills it, and my hour is nigh!

lured me on to my destruction.
i deemed that the hero deiphobus

inveigled me; death is now indeed exceedingly near at hand and

a god deceived me; pallas, ’twas thy deed,
death and black fate approach!
’tis i must bleed.

there is no way out of it—for so jove and his son apollo the

no refuge now, no succour from above,

far-darter have willed it, though heretofore they have been ever

propitious once, and kind!

ready to protect me.

then welcome fate!

my doom has come upon me; let me not then

’tis true i perish, yet i perish great:

die ingloriously and without a struggle, but let me first do some

yet in a mighty deed i shall expire,

great thing that shall be told among men hereafter.

let future ages hear it, and admire!

”

”

as he spoke he drew the keen blade that hung so great and strong

by his side, and gathering himself together be sprang on achilles

and, all collected, on achilles flew.

like a soaring eagle which swoops down from the clouds on to some
lamb or timid hare—even so did hector brandish his sword and

so jove’s bold bird, high balanced in the air,

spring upon achilles.

stoops from the clouds to truss the quivering hare.

achilles mad with rage darted towards him,

nor less achilles his fierce soul prepares:

with his wondrous shield before his breast, and his gleaming

before his breast the flaming shield he bears,

refulgent orb!
above his fourfold cone

the thick tresses of gold with which vulcan had crested the

nodding at every step: (vulcanian frame!

and as he moved, his figure seem’d on flame.

when all the starry train emblaze the sphere:

right hand, fraught with the death of noble hector.

but the rich mail patroclus lately wore

all was protected by the goodly armour of which hector had

spoiled patroclus after he had slain him, save only the throat

where the collar-bones divide the neck from the shoulders, and

where ’twixt the neck and throat the jointed plate

this is a most deadly place: here then did achilles strike him as

gave entrance: through that penetrable part

he was coming on towards him, and the point of his spear went

furious he drove the well-directed dart:

right through the fleshy part of the neck, but it did not sever

nor pierced the windpipe yet, nor took the power

his windpipe so that he could still speak.

of speech, unhappy!

hector fell headlong,

from thy dying hour.

and achilles vaunted over him saying, “hector, you deemed that

prone on the field the bleeding warrior lies,

you should come off scatheless when you were spoiling patroclus,

while, thus triumphing, stern achilles cries:
“at last is hector stretch’d upon the plain,

and recked not of myself who was not with him.

who fear’d no vengeance for patroclus slain:

fool that you

then, prince!
you should have fear’d, what now you feel;

were: for i, his comrade, mightier far than he, was still left

achilles absent was achilles still:
yet a short space the great avenger stayed,

behind him at the ships, and now i have laid you low.

then low in dust thy strength and glory laid.

the

peaceful he sleeps, with all our rites adorn’d,

achaeans shall give him all due funeral rites, while dogs and

for ever honour’d, and for ever mourn’d:
while cast to all the rage of hostile power,

vultures shall work their will upon yourself.

thee birds shall mangle, and the gods devour.

”

”

then hector said, as the life ebbed out of him, “i pray you by

then hector, fainting at the approach of death:
“by thy own soul!
by those who gave thee breath!
by all the sacred prevalence of prayer;

your life and knees, and by your parents, let not dogs devour me

ah, leave me not for grecian dogs to tear!

at the ships of the achaeans, but accept the rich treasure of

the common rites of sepulture bestow,

gold and bronze which my father and mother will offer you, and

to soothe a father’s and a mother’s woe:

send my body home, that the trojans and their wives may give me

let their large gifts procure an urn at least,

my dues of fire when i am dead.

and hector’s ashes in his country rest.

”

”
“no, wretch accursed!

achilles glared at him and answered, “dog, talk not to me neither

relentless he replies;
(flames, as he spoke, shot flashing from his eyes;)

of knees nor parents; would that i could be as sure of being able

not those who gave me breath should bid me spare,

to cut your flesh into pieces and eat it raw, for the ill you

nor all the sacred prevalence of prayer.

have done me, as i am that nothing shall save you from the

could i myself the bloody banquet join!

dogs—it shall not be, though they bring ten or twenty-fold ransom

no—to the dogs that carcase i resign.

and weigh it out for me on the spot, with promise of yet more

should troy, to bribe me, bring forth all her store,

hereafter.

and giving thousands, offer thousands more;

though priam son of dardanus should bid them offer me

should dardan priam, and his weeping dame,

your weight in gold, even so your mother shall never lay you out

drain their whole realm to buy one funeral flame:

and make lament over the son she bore, but dogs and vultures

their hector on the pile they should not see,

shall eat you utterly up.

nor rob the vultures of one limb of thee.

”

”

hector with his dying breath then said, “i know you what you are,

then thus the chief his dying accents drew:
“thy rage, implacable!
too well i knew:

and was sure that i should not move you, for your heart is hard

the furies that relentless breast have steel’d,
and cursed thee with a heart that cannot yield.

as iron; look to it that i bring not heaven’s anger upon you on

yet think, a day will come, when fate’s decree
and angry gods shall wreak this wrong on thee;

the day when paris and phoebus apollo, valiant though you be,

phœbus and paris shall avenge my fate,

shall slay you at the scaean gates.

and stretch thee here before the scæan gate.

”

”[278]
he ceased.

when he had thus said the shrouds of death enfolded him, whereon

the fates suppress’d his labouring breath,
and his eyes stiffen’d at the hand of death;

his soul went out of him and flew down to the house of hades,

to the dark realm the spirit wings its way,
(the manly body left a load of clay,)

lamenting its sad fate that it should enjoy youth and strength no

and plaintive glides along the dreary coast,

longer.

a naked, wandering, melancholy ghost!

but achilles said, speaking to the dead body, “die; for

achilles, musing as he roll’d his eyes
o’er the dead hero, thus unheard, replies:
“die thou the first!

my part i will accept my fate whensoever jove and the other gods

when jove and heaven ordain,

see fit to send it.
”
as he spoke he drew his spear from the body and set it on one

i follow thee”—he said, and stripp’d the slain.

side; then he stripped the blood-stained armour from hector’s

then forcing backward from the gaping wound
the reeking javelin, cast it on the ground.

shoulders while the other achaeans came running up to view his

the thronging greeks behold with wondering eyes

wondrous strength and beauty; and no one came near him without

his manly beauty and superior size;
while some, ignobler, the great dead deface

giving him a fresh wound.

with wounds ungenerous, or with taunts disgrace:

then would one turn to his neighbour
and say, “it is easier to handle hector now than when he was

“how changed that hector, who like jove of late

flinging fire on to our ships”—and as he spoke he would thrust

sent lightning on our fleets, and scatter’d fate!

his spear into him anew.

”

when achilles had done spoiling hector of his armour, he stood

high o’er the slain the great achilles stands,

among the argives and said, “my friends, princes and counsellors

begirt with heroes and surrounding bands;
and thus aloud, while all the host attends:
“princes and leaders!
countrymen and friends!

of the argives, now that heaven has vouchsafed us to overcome

since now at length the powerful will of heaven

this man, who has done us more hurt than all the others together,
consider whether we should not attack the city in force, and

the dire destroyer to our arm has given,

discover in what mind the trojans may be.

is not troy fallen already?

we should thus learn

haste, ye powers!

whether they will desert their city now that hector has fallen,

see, if already their deserted towers

or will still hold out even though he is no longer living.

are left unmann’d; or if they yet retain
the souls of heroes, their great hector slain.

but

but what is troy, or glory what to me?

why argue with myself in this way, while patroclus is still lying

or why reflects my mind on aught but thee,
divine patroclus!

at the ships unburied, and unmourned—he whom i can never forget

death hath seal’d his eyes;
unwept, unhonour’d, uninterr’d he lies!
can his dear image from my soul depart,

so long as i am alive and my strength fails not?

long as the vital spirit moves my heart?

though men

if in the melancholy shades below,

forget their dead when once they are within the house of hades,

the flames of friends and lovers cease to glow,

yet not even there will i forget the comrade whom i have lost.

yet mine shall sacred last; mine, undecay’d,
burn on through death, and animate my shade.

now, therefore, achaean youths, let us raise the song of victory

meanwhile, ye sons of greece, in triumph bring

and go back to the ships taking this man along with us; for we

the corpse of hector, and your pæans sing.

have achieved a mighty triumph and have slain noble hector to

be this the song, slow-moving toward the shore,

whom the trojans prayed throughout their city as though he were a

“hector is dead, and ilion is no more.

god.
”

””

on this he treated the body of hector with contumely: he pierced

then his fell soul a thought of vengeance bred;
(unworthy of himself, and of the dead;)

the sinews at the back of both his feet from heel to ancle and

the nervous ancles bored, his feet he bound

passed thongs of ox-hide through the slits he had made: thus he

with thongs inserted through the double wound;
these fix’d up high behind the rolling wain,

made the body fast to his chariot, letting the head trail upon
the ground.

his graceful head was trail’d along the plain.

then when he had put the goodly armour on the chariot

proud on his car the insulting victor stood,

and had himself mounted, he lashed his horses on and they flew

and bore aloft his arms, distilling blood.

forward nothing loth.

he smites the steeds; the rapid chariot flies;

the dust rose from hector as he was being

the sudden clouds of circling dust arise.

dragged along, his dark hair flew all abroad, and his head once

now lost is all that formidable air;
the face divine, and long-descending hair,

so comely was laid low on earth, for jove had now delivered him

purple the ground, and streak the sable sand;

into the hands of his foes to do him outrage in his own land.

deform’d, dishonour’d, in his native land,

thus was the head of hector being dishonoured in the dust.

given to the rage of an insulting throng,

his

and, in his parents’ sight, now dragg’d along!

mother tore her hair, and flung her veil from her with a loud cry

the mother first beheld with sad survey;

as she looked upon her son.

she rent her tresses, venerable grey,

his father made piteous moan, and

and cast, far off, the regal veils away.
with piercing shrieks his bitter fate she moans,
while the sad father answers groans with groans,

throughout the city the people fell to weeping and wailing.

tears after tears his mournful cheeks o’erflow,
and the whole city wears one face of woe:

it

no less than if the rage of hostile fires,

was as though the whole of frowning ilius was being smirched with

from her foundations curling to her spires,
o’er the proud citadel at length should rise,

fire.

and the last blaze send ilion to the skies.

hardly could the people hold priam back in his hot haste to

the wretched monarch of the falling state,

rush without the gates of the city.

distracted, presses to the dardan gate.

he grovelled in the mire and

scarce the whole people stop his desperate course,
while strong affliction gives the feeble force:
grief tears his heart, and drives him to and fro,
in all the raging impotence of woe.
at length he roll’d in dust, and thus begun,

besought them, calling each one of them by his name.

imploring all, and naming one by one:

“let be, my

“ah!
let me, let me go where sorrow calls;

friends,” he cried, “and for all your sorrow, suffer me to go

i, only i, will issue from your walls

single-handed to the ships of the achaeans.

(guide or companion, friends!

let me beseech this

i ask ye none),

cruel and terrible man, if maybe he will respect the feeling of

and bow before the murderer of my son.
my grief perhaps his pity may engage;

his fellow-men, and have compassion on my old age.

perhaps at least he may respect my age.

his own father
is even such another as myself—peleus, who bred him and reared

he has a father too; a man like me;

him to be the bane of us trojans, and of myself more than of all

one, not exempt from age and misery
(vigorous no more, as when his young embrace

others.

begot this pest of me, and all my race).

many a son of mine has he slain in the flower of his

how many valiant sons, in early bloom,
has that cursed hand sent headlong to the tomb!

youth, and yet, grieve for these as i may, i do so for

thee, hector!

one—hector—more than for them all, and the bitterness of my

last: thy loss (divinely brave)

sorrow will bring me down to the house of hades.

sinks my sad soul with sorrow to the grave.

would that he

o had thy gentle spirit pass’d in peace,

had died in my arms, for so both his ill-starred mother who bore

the son expiring in the sire’s embrace,
while both thy parents wept the fatal hour,

him, and myself, should have had the comfort of weeping and

and, bending o’er thee, mix’d the tender shower!
some comfort that had been, some sad relief,

mourning over him.

to melt in full satiety of grief!

”

”

thus did he speak with many tears, and all the people of the city

thus wail’d the father, grovelling on the ground,
and all the eyes of ilion stream’d around.

joined in his lament.

amidst her matrons hecuba appears:

(a mourning princess, and a train in tears;)
“ah why has heaven prolong’d this hated breath,
patient of horrors, to behold thy death?

the trojans.

o hector!

“alas, my son,” she cried, “what have i left to live

late thy parents’ pride and joy,

for now that you are no more?

the boast of nations!

night and day did i glory in you

the defence of troy!

throughout the city, for you were a tower of strength to all in

to whom her safety and her fame she owed;

troy, and both men and women alike hailed you as a god.

her chief, her hero, and almost her god!

so long

o fatal change!

as you lived you were their pride, but now death and destruction

become in one sad day

have fallen upon you.

a senseless corse!
inanimated clay!

”

hector’s wife had as yet heard nothing, for no one had come to

but not as yet the fatal news had spread
to fair andromache, of hector dead;

tell her that her husband had remained without the gates.

not e’en his stay without the scæan gate.

she was

far in the close recesses of the dome,

pensive she plied the melancholy loom;
a growing work employ’d her secret hours,

purple web, and embroidering it with many flowers.

confusedly gay with intermingled flowers.

she told her
maids to set a large tripod on the fire, so as to have a warm

bath ready for hector when he came out of battle; poor woman, she

the bath preparing for her lord’s return

in vain; alas!

she heard the

her lord returns no more;

cry coming as from the wall, and trembled in every limb; the

unbathed he lies, and bleeds along the shore!
now from the walls the clamours reach her ear,
and all her members shake with sudden fear:

shuttle fell from her hands, and again she spoke to her

waiting-women.

safe in the crowd he ever scorn’d to wait,

and sought for glory in the jaws of fate:

perhaps that noble heat has cost his breath,

foremost of them all in valour.

now quench’d for ever in the arms of death.

”

”

“o wretched husband of a wretched wife!

born with one fate, to one unhappy life!
for sure one star its baneful beam display’d

from different parents, different climes we came.
at different periods, yet our fate the same!

the

for him nor he for you.

no more to smile upon his sire; no friend

no father to defend!

even though he escape the horrors of this

for should he ’scape the sword, the common doom,
what wrongs attend him, and what griefs to come!
even from his own paternal roof expell’d,
some stranger ploughs his patrimonial field.

woeful war with the achaeans, yet shall his life henceforth be

the day, that to the shades the father sends,

one of labour and sorrow, for others will seize his lands.

robs the sad orphan of his father’s friends:
he, wretched outcast of mankind!

the

achilles and the myrmidons do honours to the body of patroclus.
after
the funeral feast he retires to the sea-shore, where, falling asleep,
the ghost of his friend appears to him, and demands the rites of
burial; the next morning the soldiers are sent with mules and waggons
to fetch wood for the pyre.
the funeral procession, and the offering

when the pile has burned all night, they gather the bones,

achilles institutes

spoke to his brave comrades saying, “myrmidons, famed horsemen

the funeral games: the chariot-race, the fight of the caestus, the

and my own trusted friends, not yet, forsooth, let us unyoke, but

wrestling, the foot-race, the single combat, the discus, the shooting

with arrows, the darting the javelin: the various descriptions of
which, and the various success of the several antagonists, make the

in due honour to the dead.

greatest part of the book.

is generally on the sea-shore.

on this they all joined in a cry of wailing and achilles led them

through the sad city mourn’d her hero slain.
the body soil’d with dust, and black with gore,
lies on broad hellespont’s resounding shore.
the grecians seek their ships, and clear the strand,
all, but the martial myrmidonian band:

in their lament.

and the stern purpose of his mind unfolds:

lo!

their lives effused around thy funeral pyre.

presently the

when lo!

sad spirit of patroclus drew near him, like what he had been in

the shade, before his closing eyes,
of sad patroclus rose, or seem’d to rise:
in the same robe he living wore, he came:

stature, voice, and the light of his beaming eyes, clad, too, as

in stature, voice, and pleasing look, the same.

he had been clad in life.
the spirit hovered over his head and

the form familiar hover’d o’er his head,

said—

“and sleeps achilles?
(thus the phantom said:)

“you sleep, achilles, and have forgotten me; you loved me living,

sleeps my achilles, his patroclus dead?
living, i seem’d his dearest, tenderest care,

but now that i am dead you think for me no further.

but now forgot, i wander in the air.

bury me with

let my pale corse the rites of burial know,

all speed that i may pass the gates of hades; the ghosts, vain

and give me entrance in the realms below:

shadows of men that can labour no more, drive me away from them;

till then the spirit finds no resting-place,

they will not yet suffer me to join those that are beyond the

but here and there the unbodied spectres chase

river, and i wander all desolate by the wide gates of the house

the vagrant dead around the dark abode,

of hades.

forbid to cross the irremeable flood.

give me now your hand i pray you, for when you have

now give thy hand; for to the farther shore

once given me my dues of fire, never shall i again come forth out

when once we pass, the soul returns no more:

of the house of hades.

when once the last funereal flames ascend,

nevermore shall we sit apart and take

no more our thoughts to those we loved make known;
or quit the dearest, to converse alone.

sweet counsel among the living; the cruel fate which was my

noble trojans.

even great and godlike thou art doom’d to fall.

“one prayer more will i make you, if you will grant it; let not

hear then; and as in fate and love we join,

my bones be laid apart from yours, achilles, but with them; even

ah suffer that my bones may rest with thine!

as we were brought up together in your own home, what time
menoetius brought me to you as a child from opoeis because by a
sad spite i had killed the son of amphidamas—not of set purpose,
but in childish quarrel over the dice.
the knight peleus took me

together have we lived; together bred,

one house received us, and one table fed;

said, “spercheius, in vain did my father peleus vow to you that

delightful roll along my native coast!

when i returned home to my loved native land i should cut off

to whom we vainly vow’d, at our return,

this lock and offer you a holy hecatomb; fifty she-goats was i to

these locks to fall, and hecatombs to burn:
full fifty rams to bleed in sacrifice,

sacrifice to you there at your springs, where is your grove and

where to the day thy silver fountains rise,
and where in shade of consecrated bowers

your altar fragrant with burnt-offerings.

thy altars stand, perfumed with native flowers!

thus did my father vow,

so vow’d my father, but he vow’d in vain;

but you have not fulfilled his prayer; now, therefore, that i

no more achilles sees his native plain;

shall see my home no more, i give this lock as a keepsake to the

in that vain hope these hairs no longer grow,

hero patroclus.

patroclus bears them to the shades below.

with this she left them, and the two winds rose with a cry that

swift as the word she vanish’d from their view;
swift as the word the winds tumultuous flew;
forth burst the stormy band with thundering roar,

rent the air and swept the clouds before them.

and heaps on heaps the clouds are toss’d before.

they blew on and

to the wide main then stooping from the skies,

as a father mourns when he is burning the bones of his

as a poor father, helpless and undone,

bridegroom son whose death has wrung the hearts of his parents,

mourns o’er the ashes of an only son,

even so did achilles mourn while burning the body of his comrade,

takes a sad pleasure the last bones to burn,
and pours in tears, ere yet they close the urn:

pacing round the bier with piteous groaning and lamentation.

so stay’d achilles, circling round the shore,

at length as the morning star was beginning to herald the light

so watch’d the flames, till now they flame no more.
’twas when, emerging through the shades of night,
the morning planet told the approach of light;

which saffron-mantled dawn was soon to suffuse over the sea, the

and, fast behind, aurora’s warmer ray
o’er the broad ocean pour’d the golden day:

flames fell and the fire began to die.

then sank the blaze, the pile no longer burn’d,

the winds then went home

and to their caves the whistling winds return’d:

beyond the thracian sea, which roared and boiled as they swept

till i shall follow to the infernal shade.

the hero, rising, thus address’d the train:

“son of atreus, and all other achaeans, these are the prizes that
lie waiting the winners of the chariot races.

“behold the prizes, valiant greeks!

at any other time i

decreed

to the brave rulers of the racing steed;
prizes which none beside ourself could gain,

know how far my steeds excel all others—for they are immortal;

should our immortal coursers take the plain;

with beating heart, and cheers his pylian horse.

stood in but little need.

the prudent son with unattending ears.

“antilochus,” said nestor, “you are

“my son!

young, but jove and neptune have loved you well, and have made

though youthful ardour fire thy breast,
the gods have loved thee, and with arts have bless’d;
neptune and jove on thee conferr’d the skill

you an excellent horseman.

swift round the goal to turn the flying wheel.

i need not therefore say much by way
of instruction.
you are skilful at wheeling your horses round the

to guide thy conduct little precept needs;

post, but the horses themselves are very slow, and it is this

but slow, and past their vigour, are my steeds.

that will, i fear, mar your chances.
the other drivers know less

fear not thy rivals, though for swiftness known;

than you do, but their horses are fleeter; therefore, my dear

compare those rivals’ judgment and thy own:

son, see if you cannot hit upon some artifice whereby you may
insure that the prize shall not slip through your fingers.

it is not strength, but art, obtains the prize,

the

and to be swift is less than to be wise.

woodman does more by skill than by brute force; by skill the

’tis more by art than force of numerous strokes
the dexterous woodman shapes the stubborn oaks;

pilot guides his storm-tossed barque over the sea, and so by

by art the pilot, through the boiling deep
and howling tempest, steers the fearless ship;

skill one driver can beat another.

and ’tis the artist wins the glorious course;
not those who trust in chariots and in horse.

if a man go wide in rounding

in vain, unskilful to the goal they strive,
and short, or wide, the ungovern’d courser drive:

this way and that, whereas a man who knows what he is doing may
have worse horses, but he will keep them well in hand when he

while with sure skill, though with inferior steeds,

sees the doubling-post; he knows the precise moment at which to

the knowing racer to his end proceeds;

pull the rein, and keeps his eye well on the man in front of him.

fix’d on the goal his eye foreruns the course,

i will give you this certain token which cannot escape your

his hand unerring steers the steady horse,
and now contracts, or now extends the rein,

notice.

observing still the foremost on the plain.

there is a stump of a dead tree—oak or pine as it may

mark then the goal, ’tis easy to be found;

be—some six feet above the ground, and not yet rotted away by

yon aged trunk, a cubit from the ground;
of some once stately oak the last remains,

rain; it stands at the fork of the road; it has two white stones

or hardy fir, unperish’d with the rains:
inclosed with stones, conspicuous from afar;

set one on each side, and there is a clear course all round it.

and round, a circle for the wheeling car.

it may have been a monument to some one long since dead, or it

(some tomb perhaps of old, the dead to grace;

may have been used as a doubling-post in days gone by; now,

or then, as now, the limit of a race.

however, it has been fixed on by achilles as the mark round which

)

the chariots shall turn; hug it as close as you can, but as you

bear close to this, and warily proceed,

stand in your chariot lean over a little to the left; urge on

a little bending to the left-hand steed;

your right-hand horse with voice and lash, and give him a loose

but urge the right, and give him all the reins;
while thy strict hand his fellow’s head restrains,

rein, but let the left-hand horse keep so close in, that the nave

and turns him short; till, doubling as they roll,

of your wheel shall almost graze the post; but mind the stone, or

the wheel’s round naves appear to brush the goal.
yet (not to break the car, or lame the horse)
clear of the stony heap direct the course;

you will wound your horses and break your chariot in pieces,

lest through incaution failing, thou mayst be

which would be sport for others but confusion for yourself.

a joy to others, a reproach to me.

therefore, my dear son, mind well what you are about, for if you

so shalt thou pass the goal, secure of mind,

can be first to round the post there is no chance of any one

and leave unskilful swiftness far behind:

giving you the go-by later, not even though you had adrestus’s

though thy fierce rival drove the matchless steed

horse arion behind you—a horse which is of divine race—or those

which bore adrastus, of celestial breed;
or the famed race, through all the regions known,

of laomedon, which are the noblest in this country.

that whirl’d the car of proud laomedon.

”

”

when nestor had made an end of counselling his son he sat down in

thus (nought unsaid) the much-advising sage
concludes; then sat, stiff with unwieldy age.

his place, and fifth in order meriones got ready his horses.

next bold meriones was seen to rise,

they

the last, but not least ardent for the prize.

then all mounted their chariots and cast lots.

they mount their seats; the lots their place dispose

the last place fell to the lot of
diomed son of tydeus, who was the best man of them all.

and, far the bravest, diomed, was last.

they took

they stand in order, an impatient train:

their places in line; achilles showed them the doubling-post
round which they were to turn, some way off upon the plain; here

pelides points the barrier on the plain,

he stationed his father’s follower phoenix as umpire, to note the

and sends before old phœnix to the place,

running, and report truly.

to mark the racers, and to judge the race.

at the same instant they all of them lashed their horses, struck

at once the coursers from the barrier bound;
the lifted scourges all at once resound;

them with the reins, and shouted at them with all their might.

their heart, their eyes, their voice, they send before;

they flew full speed over the plain away from the ships, the dust

and up the champaign thunder from the shore:

rose from under them as it were a cloud or whirlwind, and their

thick, where they drive, the dusty clouds arise,

manes were all flying in the wind.

and the lost courser in the whirlwind flies;
loose on their shoulders the long manes reclined,
float in their speed, and dance upon the wind:

at one moment the chariots

the smoking chariots, rapid as they bound,

seemed to touch the ground, and then again they bounded into the

now seem to touch the sky, and now the ground.

air; the drivers stood erect, and their hearts beat fast and
furious in their lust of victory.

while hot for fame, and conquest all their care,

each kept calling on his

(each o’er his flying courser hung in air,)

horses, and the horses scoured the plain amid the clouds of dust

erect with ardour, poised upon the rein,

that they raised.

they pant, they stretch, they shout along the plain.

it was when they were doing the last part of the course on their
way back towards the sea that their pace was strained to the

now (the last compass fetch’d around the goal)

utmost and it was seen what each could do.

at the near prize each gathers all his soul,

the horses of the

each burns with double hope, with double pain,

descendant of pheres now took the lead, and close behind them

tears up the shore, and thunders toward the main.
