was thrown from his chariot close to the wheel; his elbows,

she breaks his rival’s chariot from the yoke:
no more their way the startled horses held;
the car reversed came rattling on the field;
shot headlong from his seat, beside the wheel,
prone on the dust the unhappy master fell;
his batter’d face and elbows strike the ground;

mouth, and nostrils were all torn, and his forehead was bruised

nose, mouth, and front, one undistinguish’d wound:

above his eyebrows; his eyes filled with tears and he could find
no utterance.

grief stops his voice, a torrent drowns his eyes:

but the son of tydeus turned his horses aside and

before him far the glad tydides flies;

shot far ahead, for minerva put fresh strength into them and

minerva’s spirit drives his matchless pace,

covered diomed himself with glory.

and crowns him victor of the labour’d race.

menelaus son of atreus came next behind him, but antilochus

called to his father’s horses.

”

add perjury to fraud, and make it thine—”

then he called on his horses and said to them, “keep your pace,

then to his steeds with all his force he cries,
“be swift, be vigorous, and regain the prize!

and slacken not; the limbs of the other horses will weary sooner

your rivals, destitute of youthful force,
with fainting knees shall labour in the course,

than yours, for they are neither of them young.

and yield the glory yours.

”

”—the steeds obey;

the horses feared the rebuke of their master, and went faster, so

already at their heels they wing their way,

that they were soon nearly up with the others.

and seem already to retrieve the day.

meanwhile the achaeans from their seats were watching how the

meantime the grecians in a ring beheld

ajax the son of oileus took him up rudely and said, “idomeneus,

“old man!

why should you be in such a hurry to tell us all about it, when

(oïleus rashly thus replies)

the mares are still so far out upon the plain?

thy tongue too hastily confers the prize;

you are none of

of those who view the course, nor sharpest eyed,

the youngest, nor your eyes none of the sharpest, but you are

nor youngest, yet the readiest to decide.

always laying down the law.

eumelus’ steeds, high bounding in the chase,

you have no right to do so, for there

still, as at first, unrivall’d lead the race:

are better men here than you are.
eumelus’s horses are in front

i well discern him, as he shakes the rein,

“barbarous of words!

and arrogant of mind!

an excellent railer, but you have no judgement, and are wanting

the last in merit, as the first in pride!

i will wager

and be the king the judge.

decide whose horses are first.

the most unwise

but menelaus got up in a rage, furiously angry with antilochus.

with generous joy: then menelaus rose;

keep silence: the hero then addressed them.

and still’d the clamour of the shouting bands.
not without cause incensed at nestor’s son,
and inly grieving, thus the king begun:

“antilochus,” said

“the praise of wisdom, in thy youth obtain’d,

he, “what is this from you who have been so far blameless?

an act so rash, antilochus!

you

has stain’d.

have made me cut a poor figure and baulked my horses by flinging

robb’d of my glory and my just reward,

your own in front of them, though yours are much worse than mine

to you, o grecians!

are; therefore, o princes and counsellors of the argives, judge

be my wrong declared:

between us and show no favour, lest one of the achaeans say,

so not a leader shall our conduct blame,

‘menelaus has got the mare through lying and corruption; his

or judge me envious of a rival’s fame.

horses were far inferior to antilochus’s, but he has greater

but shall not we, ourselves, the truth maintain?

weight and influence.

what needs appealing in a fact so plain?

’ nay, i will determine the matter myself,
and no man will blame me, for i shall do what is just.

what greek shall blame me, if i bid thee rise,

come here,

and vindicate by oath th’ ill-gotten prize?

antilochus, and stand, as our custom is, whip in hand before your

rise if thou darest, before thy chariot stand,

chariot and horses; lay your hand on your steeds, and swear by

the driving scourge high-lifted in thy hand;
and touch thy steeds, and swear thy whole intent

earth-encircling neptune that you did not purposely and

was but to conquer, not to circumvent.
swear by that god whose liquid arms surround

guilefully get in the way of my horses.

the globe, and whose dread earthquakes heave the ground!

”

”

and antilochus answered, “forgive me; i am much younger, king

the prudent chief with calm attention heard;
then mildly thus: “excuse, if youth have err’d;

menelaus, than you are; you stand higher than i do and are the

superior as thou art, forgive the offence,
nor i thy equal, or in years, or sense.

better man of the two; you know how easily young men are betrayed

thou know’st the errors of unripen’d age,

into indiscretion; their tempers are more hasty and they have

weak are its counsels, headlong is its rage.

less judgement; make due allowances therefore, and bear with me;
i will of my own accord give up the mare that i have won, and if

the prize i quit, if thou thy wrath resign;

you claim any further chattel from my own possessions, i would

the mare, or aught thou ask’st, be freely thine

rather yield it to you, at once, than fall from your good graces

ere i become (from thy dear friendship torn)

henceforth, and do wrong in the sight of heaven.

hateful to thee, and to the gods forsworn.

”

”

the son of nestor then took the mare and gave her over to

so spoke antilochus; and at the word
the mare contested to the king restored.

menelaus, whose anger was thus appeased; as when dew falls upon a

joy swells his soul: as when the vernal grain

field of ripening corn, and the lands are bristling with the

lifts the green ear above the springing plain,
the fields their vegetable life renew,
and laugh and glitter with the morning dew;

harvest—even so, o menelaus, was your heart made glad within you.

such joy the spartan’s shining face o’erspread,
and lifted his gay heart, while thus he said:
“still may our souls, o generous youth!

he turned to antilochus and said, “now, antilochus, angry though

agree
’tis now atrides’ turn to yield to thee.

i have been, i can give way to you of my own free will; you have

rash heat perhaps a moment might control,

never been headstrong nor ill-disposed hitherto, but this time

not break, the settled temper of thy soul.
not but (my friend) ’tis still the wiser way

your youth has got the better of your judgement; be careful how

to waive contention with superior sway;

you outwit your betters in future; no one else could have brought

for ah!
how few, who should like thee offend,
like thee, have talents to regain the friend!

me round so easily, but your good father, your brother, and

to plead indulgence, and thy fault atone,
suffice thy father’s merit and thy own:
generous alike, for me, the sire and son

yourself have all of you had infinite trouble on my behalf; i

have greatly suffer’d, and have greatly done.

therefore yield to your entreaty, and will give up the mare to
you, mine though it indeed be; the people will thus see that i am

i yield; that all may know, my soul can bend,

neither harsh nor vindictive.

nor is my pride preferr’d before my friend.

”

”

with this he gave the mare over to antilochus’s comrade noemon,

he said; and pleased his passion to command,
resign’d the courser to noemon’s hand,
friend of the youthful chief: himself content,

and then took the cauldron.

the shining charger to his vessel sent.

meriones, who had come in fourth,

the golden talents merion next obtain’d;

carried off the two talents of gold, and the fifth prize, the

the fifth reward, the double bowl, remain’d.

two-handled urn, being unawarded, achilles gave it to nestor,

achilles this to reverend nestor bears.

going up to him among the assembled argives and saying, “take

and thus the purpose of his gift declares:
“accept thou this, o sacred sire!
(he said)

this, my good old friend, as an heirloom and memorial of the

in dear memorial of patroclus dead;

funeral of patroclus—for you shall see him no more among the

dead and for ever lost patroclus lies,

argives.

for ever snatch’d from our desiring eyes!

i give you this prize though you cannot win one; you can

take thou this token of a grateful heart,

now neither wrestle nor fight, and cannot enter for the

though ’tis not thine to hurl the distant dart,

javelin-match nor foot-races, for the hand of age has been laid

the quoit to toss, the ponderous mace to wield,
or urge the race, or wrestle on the field:
thy pristine vigour age has overthrown,

heavily upon you.

but left the glory of the past thy own.

”

”

so saying he gave the urn over to nestor, who received it gladly

he said, and placed the goblet at his side;
with joy the venerable king replied:

and answered, “my son, all that you have said is true; there is

“wisely and well, my son, thy words have proved
a senior honour’d, and a friend beloved!

no strength now in my legs and feet, nor can i hit out with my

too true it is, deserted of my strength,

hands from either shoulder.

these wither’d arms and limbs have fail’d at length.

would that i were still young and

oh!
had i now that force i felt of yore,

strong as when the epeans were burying king amarynceus in

known through buprasium and the pylian shore!

buprasium, and his sons offered prizes in his honour.

victorious then in every solemn game,

there was

ordain’d to amarynces’ mighty name;

then none that could vie with me neither of the epeans nor the

the brave epeians gave my glory way,

pylians themselves nor the aetolians.

ætolians, pylians, all resign’d the day.

in boxing i overcame
clytomedes son of enops, and in wrestling, ancaeus of pleuron who

i quell’d clytomedes in fights of hand,

had come forward against me.

and backward hurl’d ancæus on the sand,

iphiclus was a good runner, but i

surpass’d iphyclus in the swift career,

beat him, and threw farther with my spear than either phyleus or
polydorus.

phyleus and polydorus with the spear.

in chariot-racing alone did the two sons of actor

the sons of actor won the prize of horse,

angry at the way victory had gone, and at the greater part of the

but won by numbers, not by art or force:
for the famed twins, impatient to survey

they were twins, and the one kept on holding the reins, and

sprung to their car; and with united pains

holding the reins, while the other plied the whip.

one lash’d the coursers, while one ruled the reins.

such was i

such once i was!

then, but now i must leave these matters to younger men; i must

now to these tasks succeeds
a younger race, that emulate our deeds:
i yield, alas!
(to age who must not yield?

bow before the weight of years, but in those days i was eminent

)

among heroes.

though once the foremost hero of the field.

those due distinctions thou so well canst pay,
may the just gods return another day!

in great abundance.

as a large fish, when winds and waters roar,

by some huge billow dash’d against the shore,

lies panting; not less batter’d with his wound,

water.

the bleeding hero pants upon the ground.

clots of gore.

fetch the double cup.

”
forthwith uprose great ajax the son of telamon, and crafty
ulysses, full of wiles, rose also.

when tower-like ajax and ulysses rose.

the two girded themselves and
went into the middle of the ring.
they gripped each other in

amid the ring each nervous rival stands,

their strong hands like the rafters which some master-builder

embracing rigid with implicit hands.
close lock’d above, their heads and arms are mix’d:
below, their planted feet at distance fix’d;
like two strong rafters which the builder forms,

frames for the roof of a high house to keep the wind out.

proof to the wintry winds and howling storms,

their

their tops connected, but at wider space

backbones cracked as they tugged at one another with their mighty

fix’d on the centre stands their solid base.
now to the grasp each manly body bends;

arms—and sweat rained from them in torrents.

the humid sweat from every pore descends;

many a bloody weal
sprang up on their sides and shoulders, but they kept on striving

their bones resound with blows: sides, shoulders, thighs

with might and main for victory and to win the tripod.

swell to each gripe, and bloody tumours rise.

ulysses

nor could ulysses, for his art renown’d,

elaborate, with artifice divine;

own mother.

for each brave champion, when the combat ends,

achilles next offered the massive iron quoit which mighty eetion

then hurl’d the hero, thundering on the ground,
a mass of iron (an enormous round),
whose weight and size the circling greeks admire,
rude from the furnace, and but shaped by fire.
this mighty quoit aëtion wont to rear,

had erewhile been used to hurl, until achilles had slain him and

and from his whirling arm dismiss in air;
the giant by achilles slain, he stow’d

among his spoils this memorable load.

he stood up

for this, he bids those nervous artists vie,

and said among the argives, “stand forward, you who would essay

that teach the disk to sound along the sky.
“let him, whose might can hurl this bowl, arise;

this contest.

who farthest hurls it, take it as his prize;

he who wins it will have a store of iron that will

if he be one enrich’d with large domain
of downs for flocks, and arable for grain,
small stock of iron needs that man provide;

last him five years as they go rolling round, and if his fair

his hinds and swains whole years shall be supplied

fields lie far from a town his shepherd or ploughman will not

from hence; nor ask the neighbouring city’s aid

have to make a journey to buy iron, for he will have a stock of

for ploughshares, wheels, and all the rural trade.

it on his own premises.

”

then uprose the two mighty men polypoetes and leonteus, with ajax

and great leonteus, more than mortal strong;
whose force with rival forces to oppose,

son of telamon and noble epeus.

uprose great ajax; up epeus rose.

they stood up one after the other
and epeus took the quoit, whirled it, and flung it from him,

each stood in order: first epeus threw;

which set all the achaeans laughing.

high o’er the wondering crowds the whirling circle flew.

after him threw leonteus of
the race of mars.

leonteus next a little space surpass’d;

ajax son of telamon threw third, and sent the

and third, the strength of godlike ajax cast.

quoit beyond any mark that had been made yet, but when mighty

o’er both their marks it flew; till fiercely flung

from polypœtes’ arm the discus sung:

stockman’s stick which he sends flying about among his cattle

far as a swain his whirling sheephook throws,
that distant falls among the grazing cows,

when he is driving them, so far did his throw out-distance those
of the others.

so past them all the rapid circle flies:

all who saw it roared applause, and his comrades

his friends, while loud applauses shake the skies,

carried the prize for him and set it on board his ship.

with force conjoin’d heave off the weighty prize.

achilles next offered a prize of iron for archery—ten

those, who in skilful archery contend,
he next invites the twanging bow to bend;

double-edged axes and ten with single edges: he set up a ship’s

and twice ten axes casts amidst the round,
ten double-edged, and ten that singly wound

mast, some way off upon the sands, and with a fine string tied a

the mast, which late a first-rate galley bore,
the hero fixes in the sandy shore;
to the tall top a milk-white dove they tie,

pigeon to it by the foot; this was what they were to aim at.

the trembling mark at which their arrows fly.

“whoever,” he said, “can hit the pigeon shall have all the axes
and take them away with him; he who hits the string without

“whose weapon strikes yon fluttering bird, shall bear

hitting the bird will have taken a worse aim and shall have the

these two-edged axes, terrible in war;

single-edged axes.

the single, he whose shaft divides the cord.

”

no grateful sacrifice,

apollo, and missed his bird, for apollo foiled his aim; but he

to phœbus, patron of the shaft and bow.

arrow cut the string clean through so that it hung down towards

and the free bird to heaven displays her wing:

shouted applause.

sea, shores, and skies, with loud applause resound,

meriones, who had his arrow ready while teucer

and merion eager meditates the wound:

was aiming, snatched the bow out of his hand, and at once

he takes the bow, directs the shaft above,
and following with his eye the soaring dove,

apollo lord of the bow; then espying the pigeon high up under the

amid the clouds the piercing arrow feels;

upwards; the arrow went clean through the wing and fixed itself

quite through and through the point its passage found,

in the ground at meriones’ feet, but the bird perched on the

and at his feet fell bloody to the ground.
the wounded bird, ere yet she breathed her last,
with flagging wings alighted on the mast,

ship’s mast hanging her head and with all her feathers drooping;

a moment hung, and spread her pinions there,

the life went out of her, and she fell heavily from the mast.

then sudden dropp’d, and left her life in air.

meriones, therefore, took all ten double-edged axes, while teucer

from the pleased crowd new peals of thunder rise,

bore off the single-edged ones to his ships.

and to the ships brave merion bears the prize.

then the son of peleus brought in a spear and a cauldron that had

to close the funeral games, achilles last
a massy spear amid the circle placed,
and ample charger of unsullied frame,

never been on the fire; it was worth an ox, and was chased with a

whose dexterous skill directs the flying dart.

nor here disdain’d the king of men to rise.
with joy pelides saw the honour paid,

“thee first in virtue, as in power supreme,

stalwart squire of idomeneus.

o king of nations!

this beamy javelin in thy brother’s war.

”

”

king agamemnon assented.

the king to merion gives the brazen spear:

so he gave the bronze spear to meriones,

but, set apart for sacred use, commands

and handed the goodly cauldron to talthybius his esquire.

the glittering charger to talthybius’ hands.

through both on the field of battle and on the waves of the weary

the scene is partly in
achilles’ camp, and partly in troy.
now from the finish’d games the grecian band
seek their black ships, and clear the crowded strand,
all stretch’d at ease the genial banquet share,

sea.

and pleasing slumbers quiet all their care.

as he dwelt on these things he wept bitterly and lay now on

not so achilles: he, to grief resign’d,
his friend’s dear image present to his mind,
takes his sad couch, more unobserved to weep;
nor tastes the gifts of all-composing sleep.
restless he roll’d around his weary bed,
and all his soul on his patroclus fed:
the form so pleasing, and the heart so kind,
that youthful vigour, and that manly mind,
what toils they shared, what martial works they wrought,
what seas they measured, and what fields they fought;
all pass’d before him in remembrance dear,
thought follows thought, and tear succeeds to tear.
and now supine, now prone, the hero lay,

his side, now on his back, and now face downwards, till at last

now shifts his side, impatient for the day:

he rose and went out as one distraught to wander upon the

then starting up, disconsolate he goes

sea-shore.

wide on the lonely beach to vent his woes.

then, when he saw dawn breaking over beach and sea, he

there as the solitary mourner raves,
the ruddy morning rises o’er the waves:
soon as it rose, his furious steeds he join’d!

yoked his horses to his chariot, and bound the body of hector
behind it that he might drag it about.

the chariot flies, and hector trails behind.

thrice did he drag it

and thrice, patroclus!

round the tomb of the son of menoetius, and then went back into

round thy monument

his tent, leaving the body on the ground full length and with its

was hector dragg’d, then hurried to the tent.

face downwards.

there sleep at last o’ercomes the hero’s eyes;

but apollo would not suffer it to be disfigured,

while foul in dust the unhonour’d carcase lies,
but not deserted by the pitying skies:

for he pitied the man, dead though he now was; therefore he

for phœbus watch’d it with superior care,

shielded him with his golden aegis continually, that he might
take no hurt while achilles was dragging him.

preserved from gaping wounds and tainting air;

thus shamefully did achilles in his fury dishonour hector; but

and, ignominious as it swept the field,
spread o’er the sacred corse his golden shield.

the blessed gods looked down in pity from heaven, and urged

all heaven was moved, and hermes will’d to go

mercury, slayer of argus, to steal the body.

by stealth to snatch him from the insulting foe:

all were of this

but neptune this, and pallas this denies,

mind save only juno, neptune, and jove’s grey-eyed daughter, who

and th’ unrelenting empress of the skies,

persisted in the hate which they had ever borne towards ilius

with priam and his people; for they forgave not the wrong done

what time young paris, simple shepherd boy,

won by destructive lust (reward obscene),

when he was in his sheepyards, and preferring her who had offered
him a wanton to his ruin.

their charms rejected for the cyprian queen.

when, therefore, the morning of the twelfth day had now come,

but when the tenth celestial morning broke,

phoebus apollo spoke among the immortals saying, “you gods ought

to heaven assembled, thus apollo spoke:

to be ashamed of yourselves; you are cruel and hard-hearted.

“unpitying powers!

goats?

and now dare you not rescue even his dead body, for his

and can ye still his cold remains pursue?
still grudge his body to the trojans’ view?

wife to look upon, with his mother and child, his father priam,

deny to consort, mother, son, and sire,

and his people, who would forthwith commit him to the flames, and
give him his due funeral rites?

the last sad honours of a funeral fire?

so, then, you would all be on the

is then the dire achilles all your care?

side of mad achilles, who knows neither right nor ruth?

that iron heart, inflexibly severe;

he is

a lion, not a man, who slaughters wide,

like some savage lion that in the pride of his great strength and

in strength of rage, and impotence of pride;
who hastes to murder with a savage joy,

daring springs upon men’s flocks and gorges on them.

invades around, and breathes but to destroy!

even so has

shame is not of his soul; nor understood,

achilles flung aside all pity, and all that conscience which at

the greatest evil and the greatest good.

once so greatly banes yet greatly boons him that will heed it.

still for one loss he rages unresign’d,

a

repugnant to the lot of all mankind;

man may lose one far dearer than achilles has lost—a son, it may
be, or a brother born from his own mother’s womb; yet when he has

to lose a friend, a brother, or a son,

mourned him and wept over him he will let him bide, for it takes

heaven dooms each mortal, and its will is done:
awhile they sorrow, then dismiss their care;
fate gives the wound, and man is born to bear.

much sorrow to kill a man; whereas achilles, now that he has

but this insatiate, the commission given

slain noble hector, drags him behind his chariot round the tomb

by fate exceeds, and tempts the wrath of heaven:

of his comrade.

lo, how his rage dishonest drags along

it were better of him, and for him, that he

hector’s dead earth, insensible of wrong!

should not do so, for brave though he be we gods may take it ill

brave though he be, yet by no reason awed,

that he should vent his fury upon dead clay.

he violates the laws of man and god.

”

”

juno spoke up in a rage.

achilles; but hector was mortal and suckled at a woman’s breast,

then said jove, “juno, be not so bitter.

the gods, as also to myself, for his offerings never failed me.

(the only honours men to gods can pay,)

never was my altar stinted of its dues, nor of the

nor ever from our smoking altar ceased

drink-offerings and savour of sacrifice which we claim of right.

the pure libation, and the holy feast:

i shall therefore permit the body of mighty hector to be stolen;
and yet this may hardly be without achilles coming to know it,

howe’er by stealth to snatch the corse away,

for his mother keeps night and day beside him.

we will not: thetis guards it night and day.

let some one of
you, therefore, send thetis to me, and i will impart my counsel

achilles.

the hoary monarch thus.
her piercing cries
sad hecuba renews, and then replies:
“ah!

what think you of this matter?

whither wanders thy distemper’d mind?
and where the prudence now that awed mankind?

for my own part i am

through phrygia once and foreign regions known;

greatly moved to pass through the camps of the achaeans and go to

now all confused, distracted, overthrown!
singly to pass through hosts of foes!

their ships.

(o heart of steel!

) the murderer of thy race!

become of that judgement for which you have been ever famous both

to view that deathful eye, and wander o’er
those hands yet red with hector’s noble gore!

among strangers and your own people?

alas!
my lord!

how can you venture alone to

he knows not how to spare,

the ships of the achaeans, and look into the face of him who has

and what his mercy, thy slain sons declare;

slain so many of your brave sons?

so brave!
so many fallen!

you must have iron courage, for

to claim his rage

if the cruel savage sees you and lays hold on you, he will know
neither respect nor pity.

vain were thy dignity, and vain thy age.

let us then weep hector from afar here

no—pent in this sad palace, let us give
to grief the wretched days we have to live.
still, still for hector let our sorrows flow,

in our own house, for when i gave him birth the threads of

born to his own, and to his parents’ woe!

overruling fate were spun for him that dogs should eat his flesh

doom’d from the hour his luckless life begun,
to dogs, to vultures, and to peleus’ son!

far from his parents, in the house of that terrible man on whose

oh!

liver i would fain fasten and devour it.

in his dearest blood might i allay
my rage, and these barbarities repay!

thus would i avenge my

for ah!
could hector merit thus, whose breath

son, who showed no cowardice when achilles slew him, and thought

expired not meanly, in unactive death?

neither of flight nor of avoiding battle as he stood in defence

he poured his latest blood in manly fight,

of trojan men and trojan women.

and fell a hero in his country’s right.

”

”

then priam said, “i would go, do not therefore stay me nor be as
a bird of ill omen in my house, for you will not move me.

“seek not to stay me, nor my soul affright

had it

with words of omen, like a bird of night,

been some mortal man who had sent me some prophet or priest who

(replied unmoved the venerable man;)

divines from sacrifice—i should have deemed him false and have

’tis heaven commands me, and you urge in vain.
had any mortal voice the injunction laid,

given him no heed; but now i have heard the goddess and seen her

nor augur, priest, nor seer, had been obey’d.
a present goddess brought the high command,

face to face, therefore i will go and her saying shall not be in

i saw, i heard her, and the word shall stand.

vain.

i go, ye gods!
obedient to your call:

if it be my fate to die at the ships of the achaeans even

if in yon camp your powers have doom’d my fall,

so would i have it; let achilles slay me, if i may but first have

content—by the same hand let me expire!

taken my son in my arms and mourned him to my heart’s

add to the slaughter’d son the wretched sire!
one cold embrace at least may be allow’d,
and my last tears flow mingled with his blood!

comforting.
”

”

so saying he lifted the lids of his chests, and took out twelve

from forth his open’d stores, this said, he drew
twelve costly carpets of refulgent hue,

goodly vestments.

as many vests, as many mantles told,

he took also twelve cloaks of single fold,
twelve rugs, twelve fair mantles, and an equal number of shirts.

and twelve fair veils, and garments stiff with gold,

he weighed out ten talents of gold, and brought moreover two

two tripods next, and twice two chargers shine,

and last a large well-labour’d bowl had place,

lo!

around him furious drives his menial train:

the trojans from the court and rebuked them with words of anger.

in vain each slave with duteous care attends,
each office hurts him, and each face offends.

“out,” he cried, “shame and disgrace to me that you are.

“what make ye here, officious crowds!

have you

hence!

no grief in your own homes that you are come to plague me here?

nor obtrude your anguish on my eyes.
have ye no griefs at home, to fix ye there:

is it a small thing, think you, that the son of saturn has sent

am i the only object of despair?

this sorrow upon me, to lose the bravest of my sons?

am i become my people’s common show,

nay, you

set up by jove your spectacle of woe?

shall prove it in person, for now he is gone the achaeans will

no, you must feel him too; yourselves must fall;

have easier work in killing you.

the same stern god to ruin gives you all:

as for me, let me go down within

nor is great hector lost by me alone;

the house of hades, ere mine eyes behold the sacking and wasting

your sole defence, your guardian power is gone!
i see your blood the fields of phrygia drown,
i see the ruins of your smoking town!
o send me, gods!
ere that sad day shall come,
a willing ghost to pluto’s dreary dome!

of the city.

“inglorious sons of an unhappy sire!

killed at the ships rather than hector.

why did not all in hector’s cause expire?

miserable man that i am,

wretch that i am!

i have had the bravest sons in all troy—noble nestor, troilus the

you, the disgrace of priam’s house, remain!
mestor the brave, renown’d in ranks of war,

and last great hector, more than man divine,

one would have thought he was son to an immortal—yet there is not

one of them left.

whose days the feast and wanton dance employ,
gluttons and flatterers, the contempt of troy!

why teach ye not my rapid wheels to run,

things upon it that i may set out on my way?

and speed my journey to redeem my son?

”

”

so did he pray, and jove the lord of counsel heard his prayer.

jove heard his prayer, and from the throne on high,

forthwith he sent an eagle, the most unerring portent of all
birds that fly, the dusky hunter that men also call the black
eagle.

despatch’d his bird, celestial augury!

his wings were spread abroad on either side as wide as the

the swift-wing’d chaser of the feather’d game,

well-made and well-bolted door of a rich man’s chamber.

and known to gods by percnos’ lofty name.
wide as appears some palace-gate display’d,

he came

so broad, his pinions stretch’d their ample shade,

to them flying over the city upon their right hands, and when

as stooping dexter with resounding wings
the imperial bird descends in airy rings.

they saw him they were glad and their hearts took comfort within

them.

the mourning matron dries her timorous tears:

and through surrounding friends the chariot rolls.

mourn at each step, and give him up to fate;

for him as though he were on his road to death.

thus he spoke and mercury, guide and guardian, slayer of argus,
did as he was told.
forthwith he bound on his glittering golden

the god obeys, his golden pinions binds,[294]

sandals with which he could fly like the wind over land and sea;

and mounts incumbent on the wings of winds,
that high, through fields of air, his flight sustain,
o’er the wide earth, and o’er the boundless main;

he took the wand with which he seals men’s eyes in sleep, or

then grasps the wand that causes sleep to fly,
or in soft slumbers seals the wakeful eye:

wakes them just as he pleases, and flew holding it in his hand

thus arm’d, swift hermes steers his airy way,

till he came to troy and to the hellespont.

and stoops on hellespont’s resounding sea.

to look at, he was

a beauteous youth, majestic and divine,

like a young man of noble birth in the hey-day of his youth and

he seem’d; fair offspring of some princely line!

beauty with the down just coming upon his face.

now twilight veil’d the glaring face of day,

now when priam and idaeus had driven past the great tomb of

and clad the dusky fields in sober grey;
what time the herald and the hoary king

ilius, they stayed their mules and horses that they might drink

(their chariots stopping at the silver spring,
that circling ilus’ ancient marble flows)
allow’d their mules and steeds a short repose,

in the river, for the shades of night were falling, when,

through the dim shade the herald first espies

therefore, idaeus saw mercury standing near them he said to

a man’s approach, and thus to priam cries:

priam, “take heed, descendant of dardanus; here is matter which

“i mark some foe’s advance: o king!

demands consideration.

beware;
this hard adventure claims thy utmost care!

i see a man who i think will presently

for much i fear destruction hovers nigh:

fall upon us; let us fly with our horses, or at least embrace his

our state asks counsel; is it best to fly?
or old and helpless, at his feet to fall,

knees and implore him to take compassion upon us?

two wretched suppliants, and for mercy call?

”

”

when he heard this the old man’s heart failed him, and he was in

the afflicted monarch shiver’d with despair;

great fear; he stayed where he was as one dazed, and the hair

pale grew his face, and upright stood his hair;
sunk was his heart; his colour went and came;

stood on end over his whole body; but the bringer of good luck

a sudden trembling shook his aged frame:

came up to him and took him by the hand, saying, “whither,

when hermes, greeting, touch’d his royal hand,
and, gentle, thus accosts with kind demand:

father, are you thus driving your mules and horses in the dead of

“say whither, father!

night when other men are asleep?

when each mortal sight
is seal’d in sleep, thou wanderest through the night?

are you not afraid of the fierce

why roam thy mules and steeds the plains along,

achaeans who are hard by you, so cruel and relentless?

through grecian foes, so numerous and so strong?

should
some one of them see you bearing so much treasure through the

what couldst thou hope, should these thy treasures view;

darkness of the flying night, what would not your state then be?
you are no longer young, and he who is with you is too old to

these, who with endless hate thy race pursue?

protect you from those who would attack you.

for what defence, alas!

for myself, i will

could’st thou provide;

do you no harm, and i will defend you from any one else, for you

thyself not young, a weak old man thy guide?
yet suffer not thy soul to sink with dread;
from me no harm shall touch thy reverend head;
from greece i’ll guard thee too; for in those lines

remind me of my own father.

the living image of my father shines.

”

”

and priam answered, “it is indeed as you say, my dear son;

“thy words, that speak benevolence of mind,
are true, my son!

nevertheless some god has held his hand over me, in that he has

(the godlike sire rejoin’d:)
great are my hazards; but the gods survey

sent such a wayfarer as yourself to meet me so opportunely; you

my steps, and send thee, guardian of my way.

are so comely in mien and figure, and your judgement is so

hail, and be bless’d!

excellent that you must come of blessed parents.

for scarce of mortal kind
appear thy form, thy feature, and thy mind.

”

”

then said the slayer of argus, guide and guardian, “sir, all that

“nor true are all thy words, nor erring wide;
(the sacred messenger of heaven replied;)

you have said is right; but tell me and tell me true, are you

but say, convey’st thou through the lonely plains

taking this rich treasure to send it to a foreign people where it

what yet most precious of thy store remains,

may be safe, or are you all leaving strong ilius in dismay now

to lodge in safety with some friendly hand:
prepared, perchance, to leave thy native land?
or fliest thou now?
—what hopes can troy retain,

that your son has fallen who was the bravest man among you and
was never lacking in battle with the achaeans?

thy matchless son, her guard and glory, slain?

”

”

and priam said, “who are you, my friend, and who are your

who search the sorrows of a parent’s heart,
and know so well how godlike hector died?

son?

the slayer of argus, guide and guardian, answered him, “sir, you

thus priam spoke, and hermes thus replied:
“you tempt me, father, and with pity touch:

would prove me, that you question me about noble hector.

on this sad subject you inquire too much.

many a

oft have these eyes that godlike hector view’d

time have i set eyes upon him in battle when he was driving the

in glorious fight, with grecian blood embrued:
i saw him when, like jove, his flames he toss’d

argives to their ships and putting them to the sword.

on thousand ships, and wither’d half a host:

we stood

i saw, but help’d not: stern achilles’ ire

still and marvelled, for achilles in his anger with the son of

forbade assistance, and enjoy’d the fire.

atreus suffered us not to fight.
i am his squire, and came with

for him i serve, of myrmidonian race;

him in the same ship.

one ship convey’d us from our native place;

i am a myrmidon, and my father’s name is

polyctor is my sire, an honour’d name,

polyctor: he is a rich man and about as old as you are; he has

old like thyself, and not unknown to fame;

six sons besides myself, and i am the seventh.
we cast lots, and

of seven his sons, by whom the lot was cast

it fell upon me to sail hither with achilles.

to serve our prince, it fell on me, the last.

i am now come from

to watch this quarter, my adventure falls:

the ships on to the plain, for with daybreak the achaeans will
set battle in array about the city.

for with the morn the greeks attack your walls;

they chafe at doing nothing,

sleepless they sit, impatient to engage,

and are so eager that their princes cannot hold them back.

and scarce their rulers check their martial rage.

”

”

then answered priam, “if you are indeed the squire of achilles

“if then thou art of stern pelides’ train,
(the mournful monarch thus rejoin’d again,)

son of peleus, tell me now the whole truth.

ah tell me truly, where, oh!

is my son still at

where are laid
my son’s dear relics?

the ships, or has achilles hewn him limb from limb, and given him

what befalls him dead?

to his hounds?

have dogs dismember’d (on the naked plains),
or yet unmangled rest, his cold remains?

”

”

“sir,” replied the slayer of argus, guide and guardian, “neither

“o favour’d of the skies!
(thus answered then
the power that mediates between god and men)

hounds nor vultures have yet devoured him; he is still just lying

nor dogs nor vultures have thy hector rent,
but whole he lies, neglected in the tent:

at the tents by the ship of achilles, and though it is now twelve
days that he has lain there, his flesh is not wasted nor have the

this the twelfth evening since he rested there,

worms eaten him although they feed on warriors.

untouch’d by worms, untainted by the air.
still as aurora’s ruddy beam is spread,
round his friend’s tomb achilles drags the dead:

at daybreak

yet undisfigured, or in limb or face,

achilles drags him cruelly round the sepulchre of his dear

all fresh he lies, with every living grace,

comrade, but it does him no hurt.

majestical in death!

you should come yourself and

no stains are found

see how he lies fresh as dew, with the blood all washed away, and

o’er all the corse, and closed is every wound,

his wounds every one of them closed though many pierced him with
their spears.

though many a wound they gave.

such care have the blessed gods taken of your brave

some heavenly care,
some hand divine, preserves him ever fair:

son, for he was dear to them beyond all measure.

or all the host of heaven, to whom he led
a life so grateful, still regard him dead.

”

”

the old man was comforted as he heard him and said, “my son, see

thus spoke to priam the celestial guide,
and joyful thus the royal sire replied:

what a good thing it is to have made due offerings to the

“blest is the man who pays the gods above

immortals; for as sure as that he was born my son never forgot

the constant tribute of respect and love!
those who inhabit the olympian bower
my son forgot not, in exalted power;

the gods that hold olympus, and now they requite it to him even

and heaven, that every virtue bears in mind,

in death.

even to the ashes of the just is kind.

accept therefore at my hands this goodly chalice; guard

but thou, o generous youth!
this goblet take,
a pledge of gratitude for hector’s sake;

me and with heaven’s help guide me till i come to the tent of the

and while the favouring gods our steps survey,
safe to pelides’ tent conduct my way.

son of peleus.
”

”

then answered the slayer of argus, guide and guardian, “sir, you

to whom the latent god: “o king, forbear

are tempting me and playing upon my youth, but you shall not move

to tempt my youth, for apt is youth to err.

me, for you are offering me presents without the knowledge of

but can i, absent from my prince’s sight,
take gifts in secret, that must shun the light?
what from our master’s interest thus we draw,

achilles whom i fear and hold it great guilt to defraud, lest

is but a licensed theft that ’scapes the law.
respecting him, my soul abjures the offence;
and as the crime, i dread the consequence.

some evil presently befall me; but as your guide i would go with

thee, far as argos, pleased i could convey;

you even to argos itself, and would guard you so carefully

guard of thy life, and partner of thy way:
on thee attend, thy safety to maintain,

whether by sea or land, that no one should attack you through
making light of him who was with you.

o’er pathless forests, or the roaring main.

”

”

the bringer of good luck then sprang on to the chariot, and

he said, then took the chariot at a bound,

seizing the whip and reins he breathed fresh spirit into the

and snatch’d the reins, and whirl’d the lash around:
before the inspiring god that urged them on,

mules and horses.

the coursers fly with spirit not their own.

when they reached the trench and the wall that

and now they reach’d the naval walls, and found

was before the ships, those who were on guard had just been

the guards repasting, while the bowls go round;

getting their suppers, and the slayer of argus threw them all

on these the virtue of his wand he tries,

into a deep sleep.

and pours deep slumber on their watchful eyes:

then he drew back the bolts to open the gates,

then heaved the massy gates, removed the bars,

and took priam inside with the treasure he had upon his waggon.

and o’er the trenches led the rolling cars.

ere long they came to the lofty dwelling of the son of peleus for

unseen, through all the hostile camp they went,
and now approach’d pelides’ lofty tent.

which the myrmidons had cut pine and which they had built for
their king; when they had built it they thatched it with coarse
tussock-grass which they had mown out on the plain, and all round

on firs the roof was raised, and cover’d o’er

it they made a large courtyard, which was fenced with stakes set

with reeds collected from the marshy shore;
and, fenced with palisades, a hall of state,

close together.

(the work of soldiers,) where the hero sat:

the gate was barred with a single bolt of pine

large was the door, whose well-compacted strength
a solid pine-tree barr’d of wondrous length:

which it took three men to force into its place, and three to

scarce three strong greeks could lift its mighty weight,

draw back so as to open the gate, but achilles could draw it by

but great achilles singly closed the gate.

himself.

this hermes (such the power of gods) set wide;

mercury opened the gate for the old man, and brought in

then swift alighted the celestial guide,

the treasure that he was taking with him for the son of peleus.

and thus reveal’d—”hear, prince!

then he sprang from the chariot on to the ground and said, “sir,

and understand

it is i, immortal mercury, that am come with you, for my father

thou ow’st thy guidance to no mortal hand:

sent me to escort you.

hermes i am, descended from above,

i will now leave you, and will not enter

the king of arts, the messenger of jove,

into the presence of achilles, for it might anger him that a god

farewell: to shun achilles’ sight i fly;
uncommon are such favours of the sky,

should befriend mortal men thus openly.

nor stand confess’d to frail mortality.

go you within, and

now fearless enter, and prefer thy prayers;

embrace the knees of the son of peleus: beseech him by his

adjure him by his father’s silver hairs,
his son, his mother!
urge him to bestow

father, his lovely mother, and his son; thus you may move him.

whatever pity that stern heart can know.

”

”

with these words mercury went back to high olympus.

thus having said, he vanish’d from his eyes,

priam sprang

and in a moment shot into the skies:

from his chariot to the ground, leaving idaeus where he was, in

the king, confirm’d from heaven, alighted there,

charge of the mules and horses.
the old man went straight into

the house where achilles, loved of the gods, was sitting.

with solemn pace through various rooms he went,

there

and found achilles in his inner tent:

he found him with his men seated at a distance from him: only

there sat the hero: alcimus the brave,

busy in attendance about his person, for he had but just done

these served his person at the royal feast;

eating and drinking, and the table was still there.

around, at awful distance, stood the rest.

king priam

unseen by these, the king his entry made:

entered without their seeing him, and going right up to achilles

and, prostrate now before achilles laid,
sudden (a venerable sight!
) appears;

he clasped his knees and kissed the dread murderous hands that

embraced his knees, and bathed his hands in tears;
those direful hands his kisses press’d, embrued

had slain so many of his sons.

even with the best, the dearest of his blood!

as when some cruel spite has befallen a man that he should have

as when a wretch (who, conscious of his crime,

killed some one in his own country, and must fly to a great man’s

pursued for murder, flies his native clime)

protection in a land of strangers, and all marvel who see him,

just gains some frontier, breathless, pale, amazed,
all gaze, all wonder: thus achilles gazed:

even so did achilles marvel as he beheld priam.

thus stood the attendants stupid with surprise:

the others looked

all mute, yet seem’d to question with their eyes:
each look’d on other, none the silence broke,

one to another and marvelled also, but priam besought achilles

till thus at last the kingly suppliant spoke:

saying, “think of your father, o achilles like unto the gods, who

“ah think, thou favour’d of the powers divine!
[295]
think of thy father’s age, and pity mine!
in me that father’s reverend image trace,
those silver hairs, that venerable face;
his trembling limbs, his helpless person, see!

is such even as i am, on the sad threshold of old age.

in all my equal, but in misery!

it may be

yet now, perhaps, some turn of human fate

that those who dwell near him harass him, and there is none to

expels him helpless from his peaceful state;
think, from some powerful foe thou seest him fly,

keep war and ruin from him.

and beg protection with a feeble cry.

yet when he hears of you being still

yet still one comfort in his soul may rise;
he hears his son still lives to glad his eyes,

alive, he is glad, and his days are full of hope that he shall

and, hearing, still may hope a better day

see his dear son come home to him from troy; but i, wretched man

may send him thee, to chase that foe away.

that i am, had the bravest in all troy for my sons, and there is

no comfort to my griefs, no hopes remain,
the best, the bravest, of my sons are slain!

not one of them left.

yet what a race!

i had fifty sons when the achaeans came

ere greece to ilion came,

here; nineteen of them were from a single womb, and the others

the pledge of many a loved and loving dame:
nineteen one mother bore—dead, all are dead!

were borne to me by the women of my household.

how oft, alas!

the greater part

has wretched priam bled!

of them has fierce mars laid low, and hector, him who was alone

still one was left their loss to recompense;

left, him who was the guardian of the city and ourselves, him

his father’s hope, his country’s last defence.

have you lately slain; therefore i am now come to the ships of

him too thy rage has slain!

the achaeans to ransom his body from you with a great ransom.

beneath thy steel,
unhappy in his country’s cause he fell!
“for him through hostile camps i bent my way,
for him thus prostrate at thy feet i lay;
large gifts proportion’d to thy wrath i bear;

fear, o achilles, the wrath of heaven; think on your own father

o hear the wretched, and the gods revere!
“think of thy father, and this face behold!

and have compassion upon me, who am the more pitiable, for i have

see him in me, as helpless and as old!
though not so wretched: there he yields to me,
the first of men in sovereign misery!
thus forced to kneel, thus grovelling to embrace

steeled myself as no man yet has ever steeled himself before me,

the scourge and ruin of my realm and race;

and have raised to my lips the hand of him who slew my son.

suppliant my children’s murderer to implore,
and kiss those hands yet reeking with their gore!

”

”

thus spoke priam, and the heart of achilles yearned as he

these words soft pity in the chief inspire,

bethought him of his father.

touch’d with the dear remembrance of his sire.

he took the old man’s hand and moved

then with his hand (as prostrate still he lay)

the old man’s cheek he gently turn’d away.

the man whose fury has destroy’d thy race!

you must have iron courage: sit now upon

a strength proportion’d to the woes you feel.

rise, then: let reason mitigate your care:

hearts, for weeping will not avail us.

lord of thunder mixes the gifts he sends, will meet now with good

and now with evil fortune; but he to whom jove sends none but

to most he mingles both: the wretch decreed

pursued by wrongs, by meagre famine driven,

famine will pursue him to the ends of the world, and he will go
up and down the face of the earth, respected neither by gods nor

he wanders, outcast both of earth and heaven.

men.

the happiest taste not happiness sincere;

good things from his birth upwards, for he reigned over the

who more than peleus shone in wealth and power

though he was they gave him a goddess for his bride.

what stars concurring bless’d his natal hour!
a realm, a goddess, to his wishes given;
graced by the gods with all the gifts of heaven.

but even on

him too did heaven send misfortune, for there is no race of royal

an only son; and he, alas!

and to look upon the light of the sun.

a weak old man to see the light and live!

”

”

achilles looked at him sternly and said, “vex me, sir, no longer;

“move me no more, (achilles thus replies,
while kindling anger sparkled in his eyes,)

i am of myself minded to give up the body of hector.

nor seek by tears my steady soul to bend:
to yield thy hector i myself intend:

my mother,

for know, from jove my goddess-mother came,

daughter of the old man of the sea, came to me from jove to bid

(old ocean’s daughter, silver-footed dame,)

me deliver it to you.
moreover i know well, o priam, and you

nor comest thou but by heaven; nor comest alone,

cannot hide it, that some god has brought you to the ships of the

some god impels with courage not thy own:

achaeans, for else, no man however strong and in his prime would

no human hand the weighty gates unbarr’d,

dare to come to our host; he could neither pass our guard unseen,

nor could the boldest of our youth have dared

nor draw the bolt of my gates thus easily; therefore, provoke me

to pass our outworks, or elude the guard.

no further, lest i sin against the word of jove, and suffer you

cease; lest, neglectful of high jove’s command,

not, suppliant though you are, within my tents.

i show thee, king!
thou tread’st on hostile land;
release my knees, thy suppliant arts give o’er,
and shake the purpose of my soul no more.

”

”

the old man feared him and obeyed.

“lo!

extended on the funeral couch he lies;
and soon as morning paints the eastern skies,
the sight is granted to thy longing eyes:

take him away at daybreak; for the present let us prepare our

but now the peaceful hours of sacred night
demand reflection, and to rest invite:

supper.

nor thou, o father!

even lovely niobe had to think about eating, though her

thus consumed with woe,
the common cares that nourish life forego.
not thus did niobe, of form divine,

twelve children—six daughters and six lusty sons—had been all

a parent once, whose sorrows equall’d thine:
six youthful sons, as many blooming maids,

slain in her house.

in one sad day beheld the stygian shades;

apollo killed the sons with arrows from his

those by apollo’s silver bow were slain,

silver bow, to punish niobe, and diana slew the daughters,

these, cynthia’s arrows stretch’d upon the plain:

because niobe had vaunted herself against leto; she said leto had

so was her pride chastised by wrath divine,
who match’d her own with bright latona’s line;

borne two children only, whereas she had herself borne

but two the goddess, twelve the queen enjoy’d;

many—whereon the two killed the many.

those boasted twelve, the avenging two destroy’d.
steep’d in their blood, and in the dust outspread,

nine days did they lie

nine days, neglected, lay exposed the dead;

weltering, and there was none to bury them, for the son of saturn

none by to weep them, to inhume them none;

turned the people into stone; but on the tenth day the gods in

(for jove had turn’d the nation all to stone.
)

heaven themselves buried them, and niobe then took food, being

the gods themselves, at length relenting gave

worn out with weeping.

the unhappy race the honours of a grave.

they say that somewhere among the rocks on

herself a rock (for such was heaven’s high will)

the mountain pastures of sipylus, where the nymphs live that

through deserts wild now pours a weeping rill;
where round the bed whence achelous springs,
the watery fairies dance in mazy rings;
there high on sipylus’s shaggy brow,

haunt the river achelous, there, they say, she lives in stone and

she stands, her own sad monument of woe;

still nurses the sorrows sent upon her by the hand of heaven.

the rock for ever lasts, the tears for ever flow.

therefore, noble sir, let us two now take food; you can weep for

“such griefs, o king!

your dear son hereafter as you are bearing him back to ilius—and

have other parents known;
remember theirs, and mitigate thy own.
the care of heaven thy hector has appear’d,
nor shall he lie unwept, and uninterr’d;

many a tear will he cost you.

soon may thy aged cheeks in tears be drown’d,
and all the eyes of ilion stream around.

”

”

“permit me now, beloved of jove!

boon of sleep.

to steep
my careful temples in the dew of sleep:

never once have my eyes been closed from the day

for, since the day that number’d with the dead

your hands took the life of my son; i have grovelled without

my hapless son, the dust has been my bed;

ceasing in the mire of my stable-yard, making moan and brooding

soft sleep a stranger to my weeping eyes;

over my countless sorrows.

my only food, my sorrows and my sighs!

now, moreover, i have eaten bread and

till now, encouraged by the grace you give,

drunk wine; hitherto i have tasted nothing.

i share thy banquet, and consent to live.

”

”

as he spoke achilles told his men and the women servants to set

the hills of ide, and forests for the fire.

nine days, therefore, will we mourn hector in my house; on

the tenth day we will bury him and there shall be a public feast

in his honour; on the eleventh we will build a mound over his

the next, to raise his monument be given;

ashes, and on the twelfth, if there be need, we will fight.

have paid a great ransom, and have received the body of your son;

at home would have to give three times as much to free you; and

may offer all thy treasures yet contain,

so it would be if agamemnon and the other achaeans were to know

to spare thy age; and offer all in vain.

of your being here.

the winged deity forsook their view,

went back to high olympus, and dawn in robe of saffron began to

and in a moment to olympus flew.
now shed aurora round her saffron ray,
sprang through the gates of light, and gave the day:

break over all the land.
priam and idaeus then drove on toward
the city lamenting and making moan, and the mules drew the body

charged with the mournful load, to ilion go

of hector.

the sage and king, majestically slow.

no one neither man nor woman saw them, till cassandra,
fair as golden venus standing on pergamus, caught sight of her
dear father in his chariot, and his servant that was the city’s

cassandra first beholds, from ilion’s spire,

herald with him.

the sad procession of her hoary sire;

then she saw him that was lying upon the bier,

then, as the pensive pomp advanced more near,
(her breathless brother stretched upon the bier,)

drawn by the mules, and with a loud cry she went about the city

a shower of tears o’erflows her beauteous eyes,
alarming thus all ilion with her cries:

saying, “come hither trojans, men and women, and look on hector;

“turn here your steps, and here your eyes employ,
ye wretched daughters, and ye sons of troy!

if ever you rejoiced to see him coming from battle when he was

if e’er ye rush’d in crowds, with vast delight,
to hail your hero glorious from the fight,

alive, look now on him that was the glory of our city and all our

now meet him dead, and let your sorrows flow;
your common triumph, and your common woe.

people.
”

”

at this there was not man nor woman left in the city, so great a

in thronging crowds they issue to the plains;
nor man nor woman in the walls remains;

sorrow had possessed them.

in every face the self-same grief is shown;

hard by the gates they met priam as he

and troy sends forth one universal groan.
at scæa’s gates they meet the mourning wain,

was bringing in the body.

hang on the wheels, and grovel round the slain.

hector’s wife and his mother were the

the wife and mother, frantic with despair,

first to mourn him: they flew towards the waggon and laid their
hands upon his head, while the crowd stood weeping round them.

kiss his pale cheek, and rend their scatter’d hair:

they would have stayed before the gates, weeping and lamenting

thus wildly wailing, at the gates they lay;

the livelong day to the going down of the sun, had not priam

and there had sigh’d and sorrow’d out the day;

spoken to them from the chariot and said, “make way for the mules

but godlike priam from the chariot rose:

to pass you.

“forbear (he cried) this violence of woes;

afterwards when i have taken the body home you shall

first to the palace let the car proceed,

have your fill of weeping.

then pour your boundless sorrows o’er the dead.

”

”

on this the people stood asunder, and made a way for the waggon.

the waves of people at his word divide,
slow rolls the chariot through the following tide;

when they had borne the body within the house they laid it upon a

even to the palace the sad pomp they wait:

bed and seated minstrels round it to lead the dirge, whereon the

they weep, and place him on the bed of state.

women joined in the sad music of their lament.

a melancholy choir attend around,
with plaintive sighs, and music’s solemn sound:
alternately they sing, alternate flow
the obedient tears, melodious in their woe.

foremost among

while deeper sorrows groan from each full heart,

them all andromache led their wailing as she clasped the head of

and nature speaks at every pause of art.
first to the corse the weeping consort flew;

mighty hector in her embrace.

around his neck her milk-white arms she threw,

“husband,” she cried, “you have

“and oh, my hector!
oh, my lord!
(she cries)
snatch’d in thy bloom from these desiring eyes!

died young, and leave me in your house a widow; he of whom we are

thou to the dismal realms for ever gone!
and i abandon’d, desolate, alone!

the ill-starred parents is still a mere child, and i fear he may

an only son, once comfort of our pains,
sad product now of hapless love, remains!

not reach manhood.

never to manly age that son shall rise,

ere he can do so our city will be razed and

or with increasing graces glad my eyes:

overthrown, for you who watched over it are no more—you who were

for ilion now (her great defender slain)
shall sink a smoking ruin on the plain.

its saviour, the guardian of our wives and children.

who now protects her wives with guardian care?

our women

who saves her infants from the rage of war?

will be carried away captives to the ships, and i among them;

now hostile fleets must waft those infants o’er
(those wives must wait them) to a foreign shore:

while you, my child, who will be with me will be put to some

thou too, my son, to barbarous climes shall go,
the sad companion of thy mother’s woe;

unseemly tasks, working for a cruel master.

driven hence a slave before the victor’s sword

or, may be, some
achaean will hurl you (o miserable death) from our walls, to

condemn’d to toil for some inhuman lord:

avenge some brother, son, or father whom hector slew; many of

or else some greek whose father press’d the plain,
or son, or brother, by great hector slain,

them have indeed bitten the dust at his hands, for your father’s
hand in battle was no light one.

in hector’s blood his vengeance shall enjoy,

therefore do the people mourn

and hurl thee headlong from the towers of troy.

him.

[297]

you have left, o hector, sorrow unutterable to your parents,

for thy stern father never spared a foe:
thence all these tears, and all this scene of woe!
thence many evils his sad parents bore,
his parents many, but his consort more.

and my own grief is greatest of all, for you did not stretch

why gav’st thou not to me thy dying hand?

forth your arms and embrace me as you lay dying, nor say to me

and why received not i thy last command?

any words that might have lived with me in my tears night and day

some word thou would’st have spoke, which, sadly dear,
my soul might keep, or utter with a tear;
which never, never could be lost in air,
fix’d in my heart, and oft repeated there!

for evermore.
”

”

bitterly did she weep the while, and the women joined in her

thus to her weeping maids she makes her moan,

lament.
hecuba in her turn took up the strains of woe.

her weeping handmaids echo groan for groan.

“hector,”

the mournful mother next sustains her part:

she cried, “dearest to me of all my children.

“o thou, the best, the dearest to my heart!

so long as you were

of all my race thou most by heaven approved,

alive the gods loved you well, and even in death they have not

and by the immortals even in death beloved!

been utterly unmindful of you; for when achilles took any other

while all my other sons in barbarous bands

of my sons, he would sell him beyond the seas, to samos imbrus or

achilles bound, and sold to foreign lands,
this felt no chains, but went a glorious ghost,
free, and a hero, to the stygian coast.

rugged lemnos; and when he had slain you too with his sword, many

sentenced, ’tis true, by his inhuman doom,

a time did he drag you round the sepulchre of his comrade—though

thy noble corse was dragg’d around the tomb;
(the tomb of him thy warlike arm had slain;)

this could not give him life—yet here you lie all fresh as dew,

ungenerous insult, impotent and vain!
yet glow’st thou fresh with every living grace;

and comely as one whom apollo has slain with his painless

no mark of pain, or violence of face:

shafts.

rosy and fair!
as phœbus’ silver bow
dismiss’d thee gently to the shades below.

”

”

thus did she too speak through her tears with bitter moan, and

thus spoke the dame, and melted into tears.

then helen for a third time took up the strain of lamentation.

sad helen next in pomp of grief appears;
fast from the shining sluices of her eyes
fall the round crystal drops, while thus she cries.

“hector,” said she, “dearest of all my brothers-in-law—for i am

“ah, dearest friend!

wife to alexandrus who brought me hither to troy—would that i had

in whom the gods had join’d[298]
the mildest manners with the bravest mind,

died ere he did so—twenty years are come and gone since i left my

now twice ten years (unhappy years) are o’er
since paris brought me to the trojan shore,
(o had i perish’d, ere that form divine
seduced this soft, this easy heart of mine!

home and came from over the sea, but i have never heard one word

)
yet was it ne’er my fate, from thee to find

of insult or unkindness from you.

a deed ungentle, or a word unkind.

when another would chide with

when others cursed the authoress of their woe,

me, as it might be one of your brothers or sisters or of your

thy pity check’d my sorrows in their flow.

brothers’ wives, or my mother-in-law—for priam was as kind to me

if some proud brother eyed me with disdain,

as though he were my own father—you would rebuke and check them

or scornful sister with her sweeping train,

with words of gentleness and goodwill.

thy gentle accents soften’d all my pain.

therefore my tears flow

for thee i mourn, and mourn myself in thee,
the wretched source of all this misery.
the fate i caused, for ever i bemoan;

both for you and for my unhappy self, for there is no one else in

sad helen has no friend, now thou art gone!

troy who is kind to me, but all shrink and shudder as they go by

through troy’s wide streets abandon’d shall i roam!
in troy deserted, as abhorr’d at home!

me.
”

”

she wept as she spoke and the vast crowd that was gathered round

so spoke the fair, with sorrow-streaming eye.

her joined in her lament.

distressful beauty melts each stander-by.
on all around the infectious sorrow grows;

then king priam spoke to them saying,

but priam check’d the torrent as it rose:

“bring wood, o trojans, to the city, and fear no cunning ambush

of the argives, for achilles when he dismissed me from the ships

what the rites require,

gave me his word that they should not attack us until the morning

and fell the forests for a funeral pyre;

of the twelfth day.

twelve days, nor foes nor secret ambush dread;
achilles grants these honours to the dead.

with rosy lustre streak’d the dewy lawn,

people again assembled, round the pyre of mighty hector.
when

again the mournful crowds surround the pyre,

they were got together, they first quenched the fire with wine

and quench with wine the yet remaining fire.

wherever it was burning, and then his brothers and comrades with

the snowy bones his friends and brothers place

many a bitter tear gathered his white bones, wrapped them in soft

(with tears collected) in a golden vase;

robes of purple, and laid them in a golden urn, which they placed

the golden vase in purple palls they roll’d,

in a grave and covered over with large stones set close together.

of softest texture, and inwrought with gold.

then they built a barrow hurriedly over it keeping guard on every
side lest the achaeans should attack them before they had
finished.
when they had heaped up the barrow they went back again
into the city, and being well assembled they held high feast in
the house of priam their king.

last o’er the urn the sacred earth they spread,

thus, then, did they celebrate the funeral of hector tamer of

and raised the tomb, memorial of the dead.
